column1:
{"Apple's CEO Discusses F4Q10 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Apple Inc. (NASDAQ:AAPL)

"
column6:
"

Nancy Paxton - Senior Director of IR

"
column10:
"

Analysts

"
column13:
"

Mike Abramsky - RBC Capital Markets

"
column20:
"

Good day everyone and welcome to this Apple Incorporated fourth quarter fiscal year 2010 earnings release. (Operator Instructions) At this time for opening remarks and introductions
column21: I would like to turn the call over to Nancy Paxton
column23:
"

Nancy Paxton

"
column24:
"

Thank you. Good afternoon and thanks to everyone for joining us. Please note that some of the information you'll hear during our discussion today will consist of forward-looking statements including
column28: operating expenses
column30: stock-based compensation expense
column31: taxes
column33:
and future products. Actual results or trends could differ materially from our forecast.

"
column35: please refer to the Risk Factors discussed in Apple's Form 10-K for 2009
column37:
the Form 10-Q for the first three quarters of fiscal 2010 and the Form 8-K filed with the SEC today along with the attached press release. Apple assumes no obligation to update any forward-looking statements or information which speaks as of their respective dates.

"
column38:
"

And with that
column39: I'd like to turn the call over to Apple's CFO
column40: Peter Oppenheimer
column41:
for introductory remarks.

"
column44: Nancy. Thank you for joining us. We're extremely pleased to report the conclusion of a great fiscal year for Apple with outstanding results for the September quarter. Our innovative product lineup is the best ever and customer response has been tremendous. As a result
column45: we set new all-time records for Mac
column46: iPhone and iPad sales in the September quarter
column47:
and we are thrilled to report the highest quarterly revenue and earnings in Apple's history.

"
column48:
"

Revenue for the quarter was $20.34 billion
column49: an increase of more than $8.1 billion over the prior September quarter's result
column50: representing growth of 67%. The very strong growth was fueled primarily by record iPhone sales
column51:
the tremendous popularity of iPad and our best Mac quarter ever.

"
column52:
"

Operating margin was $5.45 billion
column53: representing 26.8% of revenue. Net income was $4.31 billion
column54:
which exceeded our previous quarterly earnings record by $930 million and represented 70% growth over the year-ago quarter's earnings. These results translated to earnings per share of $4.64.

"
column55:
"

Turning to the details of the quarter
column56: I'd like to begin with our Mac products and services. We set a new quarterly record with sales of almost 3.9 million Macs
column57: exceeding the previous record established in the June quarter by over 400
column58: 000. This represents 27% year-over-year growth
column59:
more than double IDC's latest published estimate of 11% growth for the market overall in the September quarter.

"
column60:
"

We experienced strong double-digit growth in both Mac desktop and portable categories led by very strong sales of iMac which was updated in July and the continued popularity of the MacBook Pro and MacBook. Mac growth was strong in each of our geographic segments
column61:
led by Asia-Pacific at 56% year-over-year and Japan at 49%. We began and ended the quarter with between three and four weeks of Mac channel inventory.

"
column62:
"

Moving to our music products
column63: we sold nearly 9.1 million iPods compared to 10.2 million in the year-ago quarter. In September
column64: we announced a great new lineup of iPods for the holiday season
column65: including our redesigned iPod Shuffle featuring clickable buttons
column66:
the reinvented iPod Nano with multi-touch and the new iPod touch with Retina display and FaceTime video calling.

"
column67:
"

iPod's share of the U.S. market for MP3 players remains at over 70% based on the latest monthly data published by NPD. iPod also continues to be the top selling MP3 player and gained share internationally year-over-year in most of the countries we track based on the latest data published by GfK. We remain within our target range of four to six weeks of iPod channel inventory on a look-back basis.

"
column68:
"

The iTunes Store also had another strong quarter with revenue over $1 billion. In September
column69: we launched iTunes 10
column70: including a number of new features such as $0.99 TV rentals
column71: AirPlay wireless music playback and Ping
column72:
which offers social music discovery to millions of iTunes users in 23 countries. We also introduced new Apple TV which provides a simple way to watch movies and TV shows on your HDTV for the breakthrough price of just $99.

"
column73:
"

I'd now like to turn to iPhone. We were extremely pleased to have sold 14.1 million iPhones compared to just under 7.4 million in the previous September quarter. This represents 91% year-over-year growth and is well ahead of IDC's latest published estimate of 64% growth for the global smart phone market overall in the September quarter.

"
column74:
"

Recognized revenue from iPhone handset and accessories sales was $8.82 billion during the quarter compared with $4.61 billion in the year-ago quarter
column75:
an increase of 92%. The sales value of iPhones alone was about $8.6 billion which yields an ASP of about $610.

"
column76:
"

At the end of the September quarter
column77: we had iPhone distribution through 166 carriers in 89 countries. We continue to experience very strong year-over-year growth
column78: particularly in Asia
column79: Europe and Japan where iPhone sales more than doubled year-over-year. We were very happy to be shipping iPhone 4 in China as of the last day of the September quarter
column80:
and we've been very pleased with the customer response to date.

"
column81:
"

Last month
column82: J.D. Power and Associates announced that for the fourth consecutive time
column83: Apple ranks highest in its survey of customer satisfaction among manufacturers of smart phones
column84: citing particularly strong performance and ease of operation
column85: operating system
column86:
features and physical design.

"
column87:
"

Adoption of iPhone within the enterprise continues to accelerate. In fact
column88: since we've shipped iPhone 4
column89:
we've seen extraordinary growth from 60% to more than 80% of Fortune 500 companies deploying or piloting iPhone. Enterprise CIOs continue to add iPhone to their approved device list worldwide.

"
column90:
"

Most recently
column91: Fortune 500 companies like Procter & Gamble
column92: General Electric
column93: Pfizer
column94: Allstate
column95: and Cardinal Health and Global 500 accounts such as Aviva Group
column96: Total
column97: Novartis
column98:
Roche and Sanofi-Aventis have made iPhone available to their employees.

"
column99:
"

We ended the quarter with about 3.3 million iPhones in channel inventory
column100: a sequential increase of about 825
column101:
000 to support the launch of iPhone 4. We continue to have a sizeable backlog and believe we could have sold even more iPhones if we had been able to supply them.

"
column102:
"

Turning to iPad
column103: we're thrilled with its momentum. In just the second quarter of availability
column104: we sold almost 4.2 million iPads with distribution in 26 countries by the end of the September quarter. We're seeing great enthusiasm for iPad from consumers
column105:
educators and businesses.

"
column106:
"

Enterprise CIOs are adding iPad to their approved device list at an impressive rate. Since the launch of iPad
column107: over 65% of the Fortune 100 is already deploying or piloting iPad. Some recent examples of companies approving iPad include
column108: Procter & Gamble
column109: Lowes
column110: Hyatt
column111:
NBC Universal and Novartis.

"
column112:
"

Recognized revenue from sales of iPad and iPad accessories during the quarter was $2.8 billion. The sales value of iPads alone was about $2.7 billion
column113: which yields an ASP of about $645. We were able to increase the supply of iPads over the course of the quarter
column114: building channel inventory by about 500
column115:
000 units to end the quarter with between three and four weeks of channel inventory below our target range of four to six weeks.

"
column116:
"

We are expanding U.S. iPad distribution to include Wal-Mart
column117: Target
column118:
Verizon and AT&T stores. We are also expanding distribution internationally.

"
column119:
"

Combining iPhone
column120: iPad and iPod Touch
column121: we surpassed cumulative iOS device sales by 125 million last month. During the September quarter
column122: we released iOS 4.1
column123: which builds on the innovations of iOS 4 bringing FaceTime video calling
column124: multi-tasking
column125:
folders and Game Center to iPod Touch in addition to iPhone customers.

"
column126:
"

And in November
column127: we plan to release iOS 4.2 which will bring many of the great new features of iOS 4 to iPad. iOS 4.2 will also include AirPrint
column128:
Apple's new printing architecture that automatically finds printers on local networks and enables printing from iOS devices over Wi-Fi without the need to install drivers or download software.

"
column129:
"

The App Store continues to be an unparalleled success. There are now over 200
column130: 000 registered iOS developers who continue to bring outstanding and creative new apps to the iOS platform
column131: including over 65
column132: 000 game and entertainment titles and over 30
column133:
000 apps designed specifically for iPad.

"
column134:
"

And we launched iAd in July
column135: which provides marketers with the ability to place interactive ads in popular apps for iPhone
column136:
iPod Touch and iPad. We were very happy with results so far. Customers are loving the media-rich ads and marketers are very pleased with viewer engagement.

"
column137:
"

I'd now like to turn to the Apple retail stores
column138: which had a record-breaking quarter. Retail revenue was $3.57 billion compared to $2.04 billion in the year-ago quarter
column139: an increase of 75%. Our stores sold a record 874
column140: 000 Macs compared to 670
column141: 000 Macs in the year-ago quarter
column142:
an increase of 30%. About half the Macs sold in our stores during the September quarter were to customers who had never owned a Mac before.

"
column143:
"

We opened 24 stores during the September quarter
column144: 16 of which were outside the United States
column145: including spectacular stores in Beijing
column146: Shanghai
column147: London and Paris. Our new Beijing and Shanghai stores opened on the last day of the quarter
column148:
and first-day sales from both stores exceeded all previous store openings. Our four China stores are our highest traffic stores in the world and are among our highest performing.

"
column149:
"

We also entered our eleventh country
column150: with the opening of stores in Barcelona and Madrid. That brings us to a total of 317 stores worldwide as at the end of the quarter
column151: with 84 of them outside the United States. With an average of 301 stores opened during the September quarter
column152: average revenue per store was $11.8 million compared to $7.8 million in the year-ago quarter
column153:
an increase of 52%.

"
column154:
"

Retail segment margin was $917 million compared to $564 million in the year-ago quarter. We hosted a record 74.5 million visitors in our stores during the quarter compared to 45.9 million visitors in the year-ago quarter
column155:
an increase of 62%.

"
column156:
"

As we look ahead to fiscal 2011
column157: we see great opportunity to continue our retail growth with our focus on international expansion. In total
column158:
we expect to open 40 to 50 stores in our fiscal 2011 with over 50% of them outside the United States. We will also begin replacing several stores in the United States to get them right-sized for Apple's current product line and to meet our service goals.

"
column159:
"

Total company gross margin was 36.9%
column160: which was 190 basis points above our guidance. About two-thirds of this favorability was driven by lower commodity and other costs
column161:
and the remainder was mostly attributable to a better-than-planned mix of iPhone sales.

"
column162:
"

Operating expenses were $2.07 billion and included $185 million in stock-based compensation expense. OI&E was $14 million and the tax rate for the quarter was 21%
column163: about five points below our guidance
column164: largely a result of two factors. First
column165: we had a higher mix of foreign earnings than we planned. Second
column166:
we had some discrete one-time tax benefits in the quarter as well. Our tax rate for fiscal 2010 was about 24.5%.

"
column167:
"

Turning to cash
column168: our cash flow short term and long term marketable securities totaled $51 billion at the end of the September quarter compared to $45.8 billion at the end of the June quarter
column169: an increase of $5.2 billion. Cash flow from operations was $5.7 billion. The September quarter was the culmination of a monumental year for Apple. In fiscal 2010
column170: we launched several new Macs; establishing record sales of over $13.6 million and achieving 31% year-over-year sales growth
column171:
significantly outpacing the growth of the overall pc market.

"
column172:
"

We introduced the tremendously popular iPhone 4 with breakthrough features including FaceTime and Retina display fueling full-year sales of 40 million iPhones
column173: an increase of 93% over fiscal 2009. We launched the groundbreaking iPad
column174: selling nearly 7.5 million to delighted customers in two quarters alone. We also brought great new features to iOS and iTunes
column175:
and continue to innovate with completely new designs for iPod.

"
column176:
"

And as a result
column177: we generated record revenue of over $65 billion
column178: an increase of over $22 billion year-over-year or 52%. Earnings of $14 billion grew even faster at 70% year-over-year. To put this growth in a perspective
column179: in fiscal 2010
column180:
Apple generated almost five times the revenue and more than 10 times the earnings it did just five years earlier in fiscal 2005.

"
column181:
"

As we move ahead into the December quarter
column182:
I'd like to review our outlook which includes the types of forward-looking information that Nancy referred to at the beginning of the call. We expect revenue to be about $23 billion compared to $15.7 billion in the December quarter last year. We expect gross margins to be about 36% reflecting approximately $52 million related to stock-based compensation expense. We expect OpEx to be about $2.325 billion including about $250 million related to stock-based compensation.

"
column183:
"

We expect OI&E to be about $65 million. And we expect the tax rate to be about 25.5%. We're targeting EPS of about $4.80. In closing
column184:
we're thrilled with our record September quarter and fiscal year 2010 results. We're very enthusiastic about our innovative product line-up and our significant opportunities for growth as we head into fiscal 2011.

"
column185:
"

And we remain extremely confident in our new product pipeline. Before taking your questions
column186: I would like to turn the call over to our CEO
column187:
Steve Jobs.

"
column188:
"

Steve Jobs

"
column189:
"

As most of you know
column190:
I don't usually participate in Apple's earnings calls since you are all in such capable hands with Peter and Tim. But I just couldn't help dropping by for our first $20 billion quarter. I would like to chat about a few things and then stay for the rest of the Q&A if that's alright.

"
column192: let me discuss iPhone. We sold 14.1 million iPhones in the quarter which represents a 91% unit growth over the year-ago quarter and was well ahead of IDC's latest published estimate of 64% growth for the global smartphone market in the September quarter. And it handily beat RIM's 12.1 million Blackberry's sold in their most recent quarter ending in August. We've now passed RIM
column193:
and I don't seem them catching up with us in the foreseeable future. They must move beyond their area of strength and comfort into the unfamiliar territory of trying to become a software platform company.

"
column194:
"

I think it's going to be a challenge for them to create a competitive platform and to convince developers to create apps for yet a third software platform after iOS and Android. With 300
column195: 000 apps on Apple's App Store
column196:
RIM has a high mountain ahead of them to climb.

"
column197:
"

Well
column198: what about Google? Last week
column199: Eric Schmidt reiterated that they are activating 200
column200: 000 Android devices per day. And have around 90
column201: 000 apps in their App Store. For comparison
column202: Apple has activated around 275
column203: 000 iOS devices per day on average for the past 30 days with a peak of almost 300
column204: 000 iOS devices per day on a few of those days. And Apple has 300
column205:
000 apps on its App Store.

"
column206:
"

Unfortunately
column207:
there is no solid data on how many Android phones are shipped each quarter. We hope that manufacturers will soon start reporting the number of Android handsets they ship each quarter. But today that just isn't the case. Gartner reported that around 10 million Android phones were shipped in the June quarter and we await to see if iPhone or Android was the winner in this most recent quarter.

"
column208:
"

Google loves to characterize Android as open
column209: and iOS and iPhone as closed. We find this a bit disingenuous and clouding the real difference between our two approaches. The first thing most of us think about when we hear the work open is Windows which is available on a variety of devices. Unlike Windows
column210: however
column211: where most pc's have the same user interface and run the same app
column212: Android is very fragmented. Many Android OEMs
column213: including the two largest
column214: HTC and Motorola install proprietary user interfaces to differentiate themselves from the commodity Android experience. The users will have to figure it all out. Compare this with iPhone
column215:
where every handset works the same.

"
column216:
"

Twitter client
column217: Twitter Deck
column218: recently launched their app for Android. They reported that they had to contend with more than 100 different versions of Android software on 244 different handsets. The multiple hardware and software iterations present developers with a daunting challenge. Many Android apps work only on selected Android handsets running selected Android versions. And this is for handsets that have been shipped less than 12 months ago. Compare this with iPhone
column219: where there are two versions of the software
column220:
the current and the most recent predecessor to test against.

"
column221:
"

In addition to Google's own app marketplace
column222: Amazon
column223: Verizon and Vodafone have all announced that they are creating their own app stores for Android. So there will be at least four app stores on Android
column224: which customers must search among to find the app they want and developers will need to work with to distribute their apps and get paid. This is going to be a mess for both users and developers. Contrast this with Apple's integrated App Store
column225: which offers users the easiest-to-use largest app store in the world
column226:
preloaded on every iPhone. Apple's App Store has over three times as many apps as Google's marketplace and offers developers' one-stop shopping to get their apps to market easily and to get paid swiftly.

"
column227:
"

Even if Google were right
column228: and the real issue is closed versus open
column229: it is worthwhile to remember that open systems don't always win. Take Microsoft's PlaysForSure music strategy
column230: which use the PC model
column231: which Android uses as well
column232: of separating the software components from the hardware components. Even Microsoft finally abandoned this open strategy in favor of copying Apple's integrated approach with their Zoom Player
column233:
unfortunately leaving their OEMs empty-handed in the process. Google flirted with this integrated approach with their Nexus One phone.

"
column234:
"

In reality
column235: we think the open versus closed argument is just a smokescreen to try and hide the real issue
column236: which is
column237: what's best for the customer
column238: fragmented versus integrated. We think Android is very
column239: very fragmented and becoming more fragmented by the day. And as you know
column240:
Apple's strives for the integrated model so that the user isn't forced to be the systems integrator.

"
column241:
"

We see tremendous value in having Apple rather than our users' be the systems integrator. We think this is a huge strength of our approach compared to Google's. When selling to users who want their devices to just work
column242:
we believe integrated will trump fragmented every time. And we also think our developers can be more innovative if they can target a singular platform rather than a hundred variants. They can put their time into innovative new features rather than testing on hundreds of different handsets.

"
column243:
"

So we are very committed to the integrated approach
column244: no matter how many times Google tries to characterize it as closed. And we are confident that it will triumph over Google's fragmented approach
column245:
no matter how many times Google tries to characterize it as open.

"
column246:
"

Second
column247: I'd like to comment on the avalanche of tablets poised to enter the market in the coming months. First
column248: it appears to be just a handful of credible entrants
column249: not exactly an avalanche. Second
column250: almost all of them use seven-inch screens as compared to iPad's near 10-inch screen. Let's start there. One naturally thinks that a seven-inch screen would offer 70% of the benefits of a 10-inch screen. Unfortunately
column251: this is far from the truth. The screen measurements are diagonal
column252:
so that a seven-inch screen is only 45% as large as iPad's 10-inch screen. You heard me right; just 45% as large

"
column253:
"

If you take an iPad and hold it upright in portrait view and draw an imaginary horizontal line halfway down the screen
column254:
the screens on the seven-inch tablets are a bit smaller than the bottom half of the iPad display. This size isn't sufficient to create great tablet apps in our opinion.

"
column255:
"

Well
column256: one could increase the resolution of the display to make up for some of the difference. It is meaningless
column257: unless your tablet also includes sandpaper
column258: so that the user can sand down their fingers to around one quarter of the present size. Apple's done extensive user-testing on touch interfaces over many years
column259: and we really understand this stuff. There are clear limits of how close you can physically place elements on a touch screen before users cannot reliably tap
column260:
flick or pinch them. This is one of the key reasons we think the 10-inch screen size is the minimum size required to create great tablet apps.

"
column261:
"

Third
column262: every tablet user is also a smartphone user. No tablet can compete with the mobility of a smartphone
column263: its ease of fitting into your pocket or purse
column264: its unobtrusiveness when used in a crowd. Given that all tablet users will already have a smartphone in their pockets
column265: giving up precious display area to fit a tablet in our pockets is clearly the wrong tradeoff. The seven-inch tablets are tweeners
column266:
too big to compete with a smartphone and too small to compete with an iPad.

"
column267:
"

Fourth
column268: almost all of these new tablets use Android software
column269: but even Google is telling the tablet manufacturers not to use their current release
column270: Froyo
column271: for tablets
column272:
and to wait for a special tablet release next year. What does it mean when your software suppliers does not (inaudible) to use their software in your tablet? And what does it mean when you ignore them and use it anyway?

"
column273:
"

Fifth
column274: iPad now has over 35
column275:
000 apps on the App Store. This new crop of tablets will have near zero.

"
column276:
"

And sixth and last
column277: our potential competitors are having a tough time coming close to iPad's pricing
column278: even with their far smaller
column279: far less expensive screens. The iPad incorporates everything we have learnt about building high value products from iPhones
column280: iPods and Macs. We create our own A4 chip
column281: our own software
column282: our own battery chemistry
column284:
our own everything. And this results in an incredible product at a great price. The proof of this will be in the pricing of our competitor's products which will likely offer less for more.

"
column285:
"

These are among the reasons we think the current crop of seven-inch tablets are going to be DOA
column286: Dead on Arrival. Their manufacturers will learn the painful lesson that their tablets are too small and increase the size next year
column287:
thereby abandoning both customers and developers who jumped on the seven-inch bandwagon with an orphan product. Sounds like lots of fun ahead.

"
column288:
"

So thank you
column289:
and let me turn it back to Peter for the Q&A session.

"
column290:
"

Question-and-Answer Session

"
column291:
"

Operator

"
column292:
"

(Operator Instructions) And your first question will come from Richard Gardner with Citi.

"
column293:
"

Richard Gardner - Citi

"
column294:
"

I had two quick ones
column295:
if I could. One is the supply constraints on iPad. Could you talk about how severe the supply constraints are on that product and how quickly you expect it to improve? And then a follow-up for Peter on gross margin please.

"
column296:
"

Tim Cook

"
column297:
"

Relative to iPad supply/demand
column298: we\u2019ve got into a balanced situation in September with the limited number of distribution points in the 26 countries where we sold the iPad. And so we exited the quarter in a supply position that allows us to expand distribution prior to the holidays as we've planned for sometime. And hopefully you've seen some of the recent announcements of added partners in the United States. We're also expanding internationally
column299:
and will be launching additional countries as the quarter goes on.

"
column300:
"

Richard Gardner - Citi

"
column301:
"

And then Peter
column302: you mentioned several sequential tailwinds for gross margin during the September quarter. Could you talk about the headwinds in the quarter and what impact they had on gross margin sequentially
column303:
please?

"
column304:
"

Peter Oppenheimer

"
column305:
"

I'm sorry
column307:
for the September quarter?

"
column308:
"

Richard Gardner - Citi

"
column309:
"

For the September quarter
column310:
yes.

"
column311:
"

Peter Oppenheimer

"
column312:
"

In our last conference call
column313: we talked about several things that we thought would cause margins to come down some. And all those things did play out
column314: but margins came down actually about half of what we thought that they would. And we did a bit better in the quarter because commodity and other costs were better than we thought
column315:
and we sold more iPhones than we had planned to.

"
column316:
"

Operator

"
column317:
"

From Piper Jaffray
column318:
we have Gene Munster.

"
column319:
"

Gene Munster - Piper Jaffray

"
column320:
"

If you can talk a little bit about the iPad opportunity you went through
column321: and gave us some good insight in terms of the competitive landscape. But as analysts
column322:
we're here kind of trying to put some estimates out there and we're not doing a great job of trying to figure out this trajectory in the iPad.

"
column323:
"

Can you help us understand how you think about the business a year or two years down the road in terms of size of your overall business
column324: impact on enterprise
column325: education
column326:
anything you can give to help us on that front? And then a follow-up question.

"
column327:
"

Steve Jobs

"
column328:
"

Well
column329: the iPad is clearly going to affect notebook computers. And I think the iPad proves
column330: it's not a question of if
column331: it's a question of when. And I think a lot of development and progress that will occur over the next few years. But we're already seeing tremendous interest in iPad from education
column332: and much to my surprise
column333:
from business.

"
column334:
"

We haven't pushed it real hard in business
column335: and it's being grabbed out of our hands. And I talk to people everyday in all kinds of businesses that are using iPads
column336: all the way from Boards of Directors that are shipping iPads around instead of board books
column337:
down to nurses and doctors in hospitals and other large and small businesses.

"
column338:
"

So the more time that passes
column339: the more I am convinced that we've got a tiger by the tail here. And this is a new model of computing which we've already got tens of millions of people trained on with the iPhone. And that lends itself to lots of different aspects of life both personal
column340:
educational and business.

"
column341:
"

So
column342: I see it as very general purpose
column343: and I see it as really big. And the timing
column344: one could argue about the timing endlessly
column345:
but I don't think one could argue that it's going to happen anymore.

"
column346:
"

Gene Munster - Piper Jaffray

"
column347:
"

Do you think this could be your second-biggest business in iPhone?

"
column348:
"

Steve Jobs

"
column349:
"

I try to not predict
column350: I try to just report. So
column351: we'll keep you posted. As you know
column352:
we're already shipping more of them than Macs after just a few quarters.

"
column353:
"

Gene Munster - Piper Jaffray

"
column354:
"

On the Flash side
column355:
any updates on your stance on Flash?

"
column356:
"

Steve Jobs

"
column357:
"

Flash memory; we love Flash memory.

"
column358:
"

Gene Munster - Piper Jaffray

"
column359:
"

Peter
column360:
just one quick question. Our tracks were that you had about three weeks lead-time in most of your countries on the iPhone throughout the quarter. You mentioned you could have sold more iPhones. How do you think about what the true demand could have been in the quarter?

"
column361:
"

Tim Cook

"
column362:
"

I think that which you're referring to is the quote that's on the Apple Online Store. What I would say is that the demand in all countries is absolutely staggering. And at this point I can't predict when supply will meet demand. I feel great about our ability to move the supply and the sales up from an 8 million kind of number to over 14 million. But it's clear
column363: last quarter that wasn't enough. And we are obviously working on that
column364:
but it will take some time to increase further.

"
column365:
"

Gene Munster - Piper Jaffray

"
column366:
"

Were you more supply-constrained in the September quarter versus the June quarter? Totally different dynamics in the quarter
column367:
but any perspective on the two quarters?

"
column368:
"

Tim Cook

"
column369:
"

It's clear that the iPhone 4 and the announcement of iPhone 4 and the demand for it took the demand to an entirely different level. And we had anticipated a very different level
column370:
but it's even higher than that.

"
column371:
"

Operator

"
column373:
we'll go to Mike Abramsky.

"
column374:
"

Mike Abramsky - RBC Capital Markets

"
column375:
"

Steve
column376: appreciate your commentary. You know
column377: you are the tablet market right now. And this is I think the second time now you've come on to talk about or certainly at one time during your presentation to talk about competition. And I am just wondering
column378: if much like Apple encroaching on whims
column379: monopoly and enterprise
column380:
if you think that Apple's going to able to sustain share growth for tablets amid some of those new competitive headwinds?

"
column381:
"

Some of those players may try different things and strategies like tethering and Flash
column383: less content and app restrictions and subsidized pricing. And just wondered if you think that
column384:
that may create itself a more fragmented market and how you see that rolling out with regard to Apple?

"
column385:
"

Steve Jobs

"
column386:
"

I have a hard time envisioning what those strategies you mentioned are. I mean
column387: in terms of pricing
column388: so far
column390: the tablets with far less functionality are having a hard time matching us in price. Flash hasn't presented any problem at all. As you know
column391: most of the video on the web is now available in HTML 5. And having the iTunes media store and over 35
column392: 000 apps on the App Store for iPad dwarfs anything else. And we think we have a very good product here that's going to be hard to match
column393:
and we're not done. We're working on a lot of things for the future.

"
column394:
"

So I don't know exactly what these strategies are. And we've priced iPad pretty aggressively. So we're out to win this one.

"
column395:
"

Mike Abramsky - RBC Capital Markets

"
column396:
"

And just lastly
column397: the smartphones
column398:
do you see that as a zero sum game?

"
column399:
"

Steve Jobs

"
column400:
"

Well
column401: as you know the largest market of phones today around the world are non smartphones. And so over the next several years
column402: many of those non-smartphones are going to convert to smartphones. And the pie is going to continue to grow
column403: and I think there will be room for some number of companies to be successful. But eventually
column404: as most of those phones do convert to smartphones
column405:
it will turn into a zero sum game or at least a lot closer to that.

"
column406:
"

But I think right now it's a battle for developers and a battle for the mindshare of developers and a battle for the mindshare of customers. And right now iPhone and Android are winning that battle.

"
column407:
"

Operator

"
column408:
"

It's Benjamin Reitzes with Barclays Capital.

"
column409:
"

Benjamin Reitzes - Barclays Capital

"
column410:
"

First
column411: for Peter
column412: can you just talk a little bit about gross margins? You have gross margin guidance of 36. With component prices still favorable and probably more iPhone's being sold sequentially
column413: can you just talk about why margins would go down sequentially
column414: which seems also that you released the revenue on the bumper program? And then I have a follow-up for Steve
column415:
if you don't mind.

"
column416:
"

Peter Oppenheimer

"
column418: in providing our guidance we thought about each of those factors that you cited
column419: and we do see a small sequential decline. This has been primarily driven by a higher than expected mix of new iPod's that we just recently announced
column420: and more iPad sales
column421: and which as Steve said
column422:
we've been very aggressive with our pricing and are delivering great value to customers. So it's the higher mix of those on a sequential basis that I see impacting the gross margin slightly.

"
column423:
"

Benjamin Reitzes - Barclays Capital

"
column425: can you just comment on how your hobby is doing
column426: Apple TV? You took the hard drive out of there
column427: and it seems like Apple is moving more to a streaming model work
column428: you know
column429: potentially a lot of other things
column430: and I was just wondering what your thoughts were for the Apple TV
column431:
maybe that kind of business model proliferating into more products. But I was wondering how Apple TV is doing and what's your thoughts going forward?

"
column432:
"

Steve Jobs

"
column433:
"

Well
column434: we don't talk about unannounced products
column435: but I'm happy to tell you what I know about Apple TV. We have gone to streaming model on Apple TV; it's complete streaming. So all the content is rented from the iTunes store or is streamed from your computer
column436: or soon to be streamed from your iPhone or iPad with AirPlay. And so how is our new model of Apple TV doing? Well
column437: I can report that in just a very short amount of time we've already sold a quarter million of them
column441:
"

I think that it's a great product and I think its $99 price point is very enticing. And I think when we get the AirPlay stuff in place before the end of this year
column442:
it's going to give another big reason for people to buy it. So we're really happy with how it's turned out.

"
column444:
"

The next question will come from Katy Huberty with Morgan Stanley

"
column445:
"

Katy Huberty - Morgan Stanley

"
column446:
"

First
column447: for Peter
column448:
how much of the sequential decline in gross margin related to the iPhone in the September quarter and particularly the bumper program?

"
column449:
"

Peter Oppenheimer

"
column450:
"

Katy
column451: we've recorded a revenue deferral of just over $100 million in the September quarter for the bumper program. We would expect to record that in revenue in the December quarter. We did ship a number of bumpers in the September quarter
column452: and that is reflected in our gross margin
column453:
as is the number that we expect to ship in the December quarter. That's reflected in our guidance as well.

"
column454:
"

Katy Huberty - Morgan Stanley

"
column455:
"

And just to be clear
column456:
is the iPhone the product segment that dropped the most sequentially as it relates to gross margins? I guess people are just asking what drove the sequential down tick which we haven't seen for some time.

"
column457:
"

Peter Oppenheimer

"
column458:
"

You mean in the September quarter?

"
column459:
"

Katy Huberty - Morgan Stanley

"
column460:
"

Yes
column462:
"

Peter Oppenheimer

"
column463:
"

Well again
column464: this was not a surprise to us. And we
column465: on our last conference call highlighted that we would have a higher mix of iPhone 4 sales
column466: and we were very aggressive with feature function there. So it had a different gross margin than its predecessor product. We also sold more iPads. Again
column467:
we were very aggressive there with our pricing. And we had the bumper program and some one-time items that occurred in June that we said wouldn't occur in September.

"
column468:
"

So these were sort of the factors we saw bringing down gross margin. To some extent
column469: each of them did occur in the September quarter
column470:
but we ended up doing about 50% better than we thought as a result of the commodity market and selling more iPhones.

"
column471:
"

Katy Huberty - Morgan Stanley

"
column472:
"

And then Steve
column473: just as a follow-up. It seems like you fundamentally believe that Apple should be able to out-ship Android if you add up all the mobile devices over time. What are the key risks you're managing the company to make sure you don't lose that lead
column474: whether it's distribution
column475: or pricing
column476:
or features? What do you think the biggest risks are that you need to watch carefully?

"
column477:
"

Steve Jobs

"
column478:
"

Well
column479: our goal is to make the best devices in the world. It's not to be the biggest; as you know
column480: Nokia is the biggest. And we admire them for being able to ship the number of handsets that they do. But we don't aspire to be like them. They are good at being like them. We want to be like us
column481:
and we want to make the best ones.

"
column482:
"

So in our part of the market
column483: Android is our biggest competitor. They out-shipped us in the June quarter as we were transitioning to iPhone 4. They out-shipped us for the first time according to Gartner's numbers
column484: which we think are pretty accurate. And so we're waiting to find out what happened in this quarter. We'll find out. I don't know how we'll find out
column485: but Gartner will put out some new numbers
column486: and maybe others will
column487:
so one of these days we'll eventually learn.

"
column488:
"

And I imagine we'll be competing with them for quite some time. But we have very different approaches. And we believe in our approach very strongly is providing users products that just work. And we think there is lots of users that want that in the world
column489:
and their approach is very different than that. And there maybe lots of users that want that their approach as well. But we're going to pursue ours and we think that's the winning approach in the end.

"
column490:
"

Operator

"
column491:
"

And that will come from Toni Sacconaghi with Sanford Bernstein.

"
column492:
"

Toni Sacconaghi - Sanford Bernstein

"
column493:
"

I guess this is for both Steve and Tim. I wanted to just better understand your aspirations for iPhone and iPad. Tim
column494: I think I've heard you say
column495: \"Look
column496: we think about the Mac business as being one where we make the best products
column497:
but we're competing against kind of strong income and power in Microsoft. And we don't aspire to have high market share.\"

"
column498:
"

In your iPod business it was kind of the opposite. You had very high volume
column499: you drove price points down to entry points in the marketplace. And you have more than 50% market share globally. I think when we've talked about it in the past
column500:
you've actually said that you view the iPhone business as being more akin to the iPod business in terms of your aspiration.

"
column501:
"

Steve
column502: it sounded like that wasn't really consistent with what you said. You said very clearly
column503: we don't want to be Nokia
column504: we just to want to make good phone. So perhaps
column505: you can help me better understand how we should think about your aspiration for both the iPhone and the iPad. Steve
column506: you also made a comment about seven inch screens aren't going to cut it
column507:
and implying that you're not going to go down to those lower price points.

"
column508:
"

Is your aspiration for iPhone and iPad to be volume players and market leaders? Or is it simply to make good products? And if you have smaller share like you do in Mac
column509: that's fine. Can you help me with that
column510:
please?

"
column511:
"

Steve Jobs

"
column512:
"

Sure
column513: and I'll let Tim say what he's going to say too. First of all
column514: Nokia makes $50 handsets
column515: and we don't know how to make a great smartphone for $50. We're not smart enough to figure that one out yet
column516: but believe me I'll let you know
column517: when we do. So our goal is to make a really breakthrough great product. Make the best products in every industry that we compete in and to drive the cost down
column518:
while constantly making the products better at the same time. That's what we did with iPod.

"
column519:
"

We updated our products many times every year
column520: with better functionality oftentimes at the same price
column521: and sometimes at a lower price. And it was this relentless improvement
column522: and in some cases a lower price that was able to beat our competition and yield the market share that it did. And as you know
column523: we have a very low market share in the phone market in the single digits
column524: in terms of all the handsets. And we have a very high market share now in tablets
column525:
because we're the first mover.

"
column526:
"

But we don't think about it that way. The reason we wouldn't make a seven inch tablet isn't because we don't want to hit a price point
column527: it's because we don't think you can make a great tablet with a seven inch screen. We think it's too small to express the software that people want to put on these things. And we think as a software driven company
column528:
we think about the software strategies first.

"
column529:
"

And we know that software developers they're not going to deal real well with all these different size products
column530: when they have to redo their software
column531:
every time a screen size changes. And they're not going to deal well with products where they can't put enough elements on the screen to build the kind of apps they want to build.

"
column532:
"

So when we make decisions on seven inch tablets
column533: it's not about cost
column534: it's about the value of the product when you factor in the software. You see what I'm getting at? So we're all about making the best products at aggressive prices. And that's what we will do and that's what we've done with the iPod
column535:
and that's what we will do with the iPad as well.

"
column536:
"

Toni Sacconaghi - Sanford Bernstein

"
column538: maybe you want to comment
column539: if I could push you on that Steve. So if the market starts to move towards somewhat lower functionality smartphones in that migration of non-smartphones to smartphones that you talked about. If the market starts to move to dramatically lower price points
column540: you feel you can't make an appropriate product that is good at those price points
column541:
you will cede share under those circumstances. Do I hear you correctly?

"
column543:
"

You're looking at it wrong. You're looking at it as a hardware person in a fragmented world. You're looking at it as a hardware manufacturer that doesn't really know much about software
column544: who doesn't think about an integrated product
column545: but assumes the software will somehow take care of itself. And you're sitting around saying
column546: \"Well
column547: how can we make this cheaper? Well
column548: we can put on a smaller screen on it and a slower processor
column549: and less memory.\" And you assume that the software will somehow just come alive on this product that you're dreaming of
column550: but it won't. Because these app developers have taken advantage of the products that came before with faster processors
column551: with larger screens
column552:
with more capabilities that they can take advantage of to make better apps for customers.

"
column553:
"

And it's a hard one because it throws you right back into the beginning of that chicken and egg problem again to change all the assumptions on those developers. Most of them will not follow you
column554: most of them will say
column555: \"I'm sorry
column556:
but I'm not going to go back and write a watered down version of my app just because you've got this phone that you can sell for $50 less and you're begging me to write software for it.\"

"
column558:
"

One more if I may
column559: please
column560: Steve? You now have more than $50 billion in cash. You're generating more than $20 billion a year in cash; it rests very comfortably on your balance sheet
column561:
earning less than 1% interest. What is your aspiration for that cash? And why are you not more open to returning some of that cash to shareholders in the form of buybacks or dividend?

"
column562:
"

Steve Jobs

"
column563:
"

Of course that's been suggested to us. We strongly believe that one or more very strategic opportunities may come along that we're in a unique position to take advantage of because of our strong cash position. And I think we've demonstrated a really strong track record of being very disciplined with the use of our cash. We don't let it burn a hole in our pocket
column564:
we don't allow it to motivate us to do stupid acquisitions.

"
column565:
"

And so I think that we'd like to continue to keep our powder dry because we do feel that there are one or more strategic opportunities in the future. That's the biggest reason. And there are other reasons as well that we could go into. But that's the biggest one.

"
column566:
"

Operator

"
column567:
"

From Cross Research
column568:
we'll hear from Shannon Cross.

"
column570:
"

Steve and Tim
column571: could you talk a little bit about the corporate opportunity? And what I'm looking for is sort how you're thinking about Apple as it's been positioned over the last several years
column572: sort of more of a consumer focused
column573: SMB focused company
column574:
but clearly there is a huge opportunity here with the iPad and the iPhone and probably at some point the Macs into the corporate world.

"
column575:
"

So how do you think about your position from a marketing standpoint
column576: a sales standpoint? Any changes you need to make
column577:
or how are you sort of addressing that?

"
column578:
"

Tim Cook

"
column579:
"

On the iPad
column580: there have been some comments about this earlier
column581: but just to give you some stats here
column582: about two-thirds of the Fortune 100 are deploying or piloting iPad. And I don't know about you
column583: but I've never seen an adoption like this in my life in enterprise. Enterprise is historically much slower moving on adoption. We're also seeing the iPad begin to pick up interest in K12 which is another market that historically adopts very
column584: very slowly. And so the early data points look great. And as a matter of fact
column585: we have built and are building additional capacity internally in the sales organizations
column586:
to call on businesses and obviously we have a huge amount of sales people already there calling on education institutions.

"
column587:
"

We're also enabling in training our carrier partners to do the same. You probably saw a announcement last week with AT&T
column588: and that's a direct result of customers wanting to buy the iPad on a postpaid type plan. And so we're putting a lot of energy in those. iPhone has followed a trajectory that gets into same kinds of numbers as I pointed on iPad where
column589: or a little bit higher by now
column590:
is 85% of the Fortune 100 are deploying are deploying or piloting iPhone.

"
column591:
"

And so this isn't a hobby or something we're doing lightly. We put enormous energy in the company
column592: in engineering
column593: in software to build a number of enterprise features in the OS. You've seen that
column594:
it gets better and better as we step through the different OS releases. And we're building the sales capability for those groups as well. It's clear that both the phone and the iPad have an enormous opportunity.

"
column595:
"

The Mac is also increasingly getting pulled into an enterprise where the employees are able to select. And of course
column596: this is a trend that we like to see
column597: and that we think will continue in larger ways. But when people are given the choice
column598: they would prefer a Mac
column599:
so Macs are being pulled in as well.

"
column600:
"

We don't have as much distribution effort on that
column601: but as we see if it gets any larger
column602: we will move accordingly. The great thing is that we're maintaining our focus on the consumer
column603:
and the consumer is a forefront on thinking of all our products. And it's these consumers in the enterprise so to speak that are pulling these products in.

"
column604:
"

And so we're not developing two different lines like many companies do and have enterprise versions and consumer versions. This is another part of our simplistic approach to things that I think will pay us great dividend and is already starting to do so.

"
column605:
"

Shannon Cross - Cross Research

"
column606:
"

And I had a follow-up for Peter
column607: I am getting substantial questions
column608: as I am sure everybody on the call is
column609: just about gross margin. So one of the questions I have is
column610: as you're seeing the increase in volume
column611: is there any kind of a change in terms of sort of the scale leverage you have from a manufacturing standpoint? I know you guided to lower gross margins
column612:
but the Street of course was higher?

"
column613:
"

So
column614: just anything you can give us in terms of color on the gross margins with the iPhone 4 in terms of how that's panning out and how we should think about start up costs that were associated with
column615: both that as well as the iPad
column616:
just any color would be great?

"
column617:
"

Peter Oppenheimer

"
column618:
"

We don't provide product specific gross margins but we are always working aggressively to lower our costs whether it's the iPhone or any of our other products. I think we have a very good track record in this regard. And we were happy with our gross margins in the September quarter
column619:
they were ahead of what we thought. And we see them being just down slightly in the December quarter as we ship more iPods where we've been quite aggressive and continue to ship more iPads as well.

"
column621:
"

And our next question will come from Chris Whitmore with Deutsche Bank.

"
column623:
"

I am interested in understanding demand from new carriers to take up iPhone 4 and whether or not you're seeing any pressure on subsidies as you look to expand your distribution networks on the phone business?

"
column626:
the pressure that I am getting is on supply. Virtually everyone we're doing business with wants more supply. So that's the pressure that I feel.

"
column628:
"

Can you give us some color
column631: but some color in terms of where you are from a number of carriers with iPhone 4
column632:
how did you end the quarter? Do you have targets for the December quarter in terms of carrier penetration with existing relationships?

"
column635: if you count at the country level
column636:
we have about 166 relationships that we ended the quarter with in about 89 countries. And so that's a significant expansion across from last year as we in many countries went from a single carrier relationship to more than one carrier.

"
column637:
"

The latest country that we have done that in or that we've announced that in is Germany and we will be launching both with Vodafone and O2 together with our existing partner T-Mobile in Germany later this month.

"
column639:
"

And all 166 of the carriers have the phone 4 by year end
column643:
we're in 85 of those 89 countries. And I believe that we will be in all 89 by the end of the year.

"
column645:
"

And what is your experience then when you've gone non-exclusive from a subsidy and margin standpoint on the phone
column646:
have you had to give anything up in the past?

"
column648:
"

We don't give specific information out on the margins. But I think you can look at our ASPs and see that they've generally stayed above $600
column649:
and that's despite opening up several markets from an exclusive market to a non-exclusive market.

"
column652:
you discussed competitors not matching Apple's price point so far on the tablet space. Why do you think you have an advantage on the price point for iPad versus the PC manufacturers?

"
column655: I think part of it is because we engineer so much of it ourselves. The A4 chip inside it is an Apple creation; everything
column657:
as I mentioned from the battery chemistry to the enclosures. And we've learned a lot. We've learned a lot from the miniaturization we've done on iPods and iPhones. And we're a very high volume consumer electronics manufacturer.

"
column658:
"

So I think we've learned a lot. We've developed a lot of our own components where other have to buy them on the market with middlemen
column659: getting their cut of things. I think we're systems architects and know how to build systems in a very efficient way. So I think this is a product we've been training for
column662:
"

Thanks to everyone for joining us today. A replay of today's call will be available for two weeks as a podcast on the iTunes Store
column663:
as a webcast on apple.com/investor and via telephone. And the numbers for the telephone replay are 888-203-1112 or 719-457-0820. And the confirmation code is 1034928. These replays will be available beginning at approximately 5 p.m. pacific time today.

"
column664:
"

Members of the press with additional questions can contact Steve Dowling at 408-974-1896. And financial analysts can contact Joan Hoover or me with additional questions. Joan is at 408-974-4570. And I am at 408-974-5420. And thanks again for joining us.

"
column667:
that does conclude today's presentation. We do thank everyone for your participation.

"

column1:
{"Apple Management Discusses Q1 2011 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL)

"
column6:
"

Peter Oppenheimer - Chief Financial Officer and Senior Vice President

"
column7:
"

Timothy Cook - Chief Operating Officer

"
column10:
"

Benjamin Reitzes - Barclays Capital

"
column11:
"

Keith Bachman - BMO Capital Markets U.S.

"
column13:
"

Charles Munster - Piper Jaffray Companies

"
column18:
"

Mark Moskowitz - JP Morgan Chase & Co

"
column20:
"

Jason Maynard - Wells Fargo Securities
column23:
"

Good day
column24: everyone
column25: and welcome to this Apple Incorporated First Quarter Fiscal Year 2011 Earnings Release Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] At this time for opening remarks and introductions
column26: I would like to turn the call over to Nancy Paxton
column27: Senior Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead
column28:
ma'am.

"
column30:
"

Thank you. Good afternoon
column31: and thanks for joining us. Please note that some of the information you'll hear during our discussion today will consist of forward-looking statements including
column33: those regarding revenue
column38: taxes
column39: earnings per share and future products. Actual results or trends could differ materially from our forecast. For more information
column40: please refer to the risk factors discussed in Apple's Form 10-K for 2010
column41: and the Form 8-K filed with the SEC this afternoon along with the attached press release. Apple assumes no obligation to update any forward-looking statements or information or speak as of their respective date. And with that
column42: I'd like to turn the call over to Apple's CFO
column46:
"

Thank you
column47: Nancy. Thank you for joining us. We are very pleased to report the outstanding results of our December quarter. The performance of our business was extremely strong
column48: as we sold more Macs
column49: iPhones and iPads than in any previous quarter in Apple's history. And as a result
column50:
we're thrilled to announce all-time record quarterly revenue and earnings.

"
column51:
"

Revenue for the quarter was $26.7 billion
column52: an increase of more than $11 billion over the prior December quarter's result
column53: representing growth of 71%. The robust revenue growth was fueled by record iPhone
column54: iPad and Mac sales. Operating margin was over $7.8 billion
column55: representing 29.3% of revenue. Net income was $6 billion
column56: which exceeded our previous quarterly earnings record set in the September quarter by $1.7 billion
column57:
and represented 78% growth over the year-ago quarter's earnings. These results translated to earnings per share of $6.43.

"
column58:
"

Turning to the details of the quarter
column59: I'd like to begin with our Mac products and services. We established a new quarterly record with sales of 4.13 million Macs
column60: representing 23% growth over the year-ago quarter. That's almost 8x IDC's most recently published estimate of 3% growth for the PC market. We experienced strong sales growth in each of our geographic segments
column61: with over 50% growth in both the Asia-Pacific region and Japan. The growth was fueled primarily by strong demand for the new MacBook Air
column62: which was launched in October
column63: as well as continued strong sales of MacBook Pro. Customers love the new thin and light unibody design of the MacBook Air
column64: and the impressive responsiveness and reliability of its solid-state storage
column65:
while MacBook Pro continues to provide customers tremendous speed and high-performance graphics at an excellent value.

"
column66:
"

We ended the quarter with between three and four weeks of Mac channel inventory. We opened the Mac App Store in January 6
column67: bringing what we've learned from iOS Apps to Mac users to make discovering
column68: installing and updating apps easier than ever. The Mac App Store is available in 90 countries
column69: and features more than 1
column70: 000 free and paid apps in categories like education
column71: games
column72: graphics and design
column73: lifestyle
column74: productivity and utility. We've been very pleased with customer response
column75:
with over 1 million downloads on the first day alone.

"
column76:
"

Moving to our music products. We sold 19.4 million iPods compared to 21 million in the year-ago quarter. We experienced continued strong sales of iPod touch
column77: which grew 27% year-over-year and accounted for over 50% of all iPods sold during the quarter. iPod's share of the U.S. market for MP3 players remains at over 70% based on the latest monthly data published by NPD
column78:
and iPod continues to be the top-selling MP3 player in most countries we track based on the latest data published by GfK. We ended the quarter within our target range of four to six weeks of iPod channel inventory.

"
column79:
"

The iTunes Store generated another strong quarter with revenue exceeding $1.1 billion
column80: thanks to strong sales of music
column81: video and apps. We were extremely pleased to bring the legendary music of the Beatles to iTunes during the quarter and to introduce movies to the iTunes Store in Japan. And as we announced a few weeks ago
column82: iTunes users are now renting and purchasing over 400
column83: 000 TV episodes and over 150
column84:
000 movies per day.

"
column85:
"

I'd now like to turn to iPhone. We were thrilled to have sold 16.2 million iPhones compared to 8.7 million in the previous December quarter. This represents 86% year-over-year growth compared to IDC's latest published estimate of 70% growth for the global smartphone market overall in the December quarter. Recognized revenue from iPhone handset and accessory sales was $10.47 billion during the quarter
column86: compared to $5.58 billion in the year-ago quarter
column87:
an increase of 88%.

"
column88:
"

The sales value of iPhones alone was over $10.1 billion
column89: which yields an ASP of about $625. At the end of the December quarter
column90: we had iPhone distributions through 185 carriers in 90 countries. We continue to experience very strong year-over-year growth in all of our segments
column91:
with sales in the Asia-Pacific region and Japan both more than doubling year-over-year.

"
column92:
"

Enterprise customers continue to embrace iPhone
column93:
with 88 of the Fortune 100 companies and almost 60% of the Financial Times Europe 100 companies now testing or deploying iPhones. Strong employee demand in custom app development are fueling deployment within the corporate sector.

"
column94:
"

Enterprise CIOs continue to add iPhone to their approved device list worldwide. Most recently
column95: Fortune 500
column96: like Wells Fargo
column97: Archer Daniels Midland
column98: DuPont
column99: Staples
column100: Starbucks and Genworth Financial
column101: and Global 500 accounts such as Nissan Motor
column102: BBVA [Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria]
column103: Standard Chartered Group and Danone
column104:
have made iPhone available to their employees.

"
column105:
"

We ended the quarter with about 3.5 million iPhones in channel inventory
column106: a sequential increase of about 250k. We continue to have a sizable backlog
column107: and believe we could have sold even more iPhones if we had been able to supply them. And we're thrilled to begin working with Verizon next month to offer iPhone 4 to its more than 93 million customers
column108:
as well as to new customers who want iPhone 4 on Verizon.

"
column109:
"

Turning to iPad. We continue to be thrilled with its momentum and customer interest. We sold 7.3 million iPads
column110: a sequential increase of over 3 million
column111: with distribution in 46 countries by the end of the December quarter. We continue to see great enthusiasm for iPads from consumer
column112: business and education customers. Employee demand for iPad in the corporate environment remains strong
column113:
and the response to the product continues to be significant.

"
column114:
"

Enterprise CIOs are adding iPad to their approved device list at an amazing rate. Today

column117: Cardinal Health
column118: Wells Fargo
column119: Archer Daniels Midland
column120:
Sears Holdings and DuPont.

"
column121:

Recognized revenue from sales of iPad and iPad accessories during the quarter was $4.61 billion. The sales value by iPads alone was over $4.4 billion
column122:
which yields an ASP of about $600. We increased the supply of iPads during the quarter and expanded both the number of countries and the number of channel partners carrying iPad.

"
column123:
"

Channel inventory increased by about 525
column124: 000 units from the beginning to the end of the quarter to support increased sales and channel expansion
column125: and we ended the quarter within our target range of four to six weeks. Combining iPhone
column126: iPad and iPod touch
column127:
we reached over 160 million cumulative iOS device sales through the end of the December quarter.

"
column128:
"

In November
column129: we launched iOS 4.2
column130: which brings over 100 new features to iPad users including multitasking
column131: folders
column132: unified inbox
column133: Game Center
column134:
AirPlay and AirPrint.

"
column135:
"

The App Store continues to be incredibly successful
column136: with over 300
column137: 000 apps available and well over 9 billion downloads to date. We continue to be very pleased with iAd
column138: which combines the narrative quality of TV ads with the interactivity of digital to provide a new kind of advertising experience.  During the quarter
column139:
we expanded iAds beyond the U.S. to Europe and Japan and provided iAd Producer to marketers.

"
column140:

I'd now like to turn to the Apple Retail Stores
column141: which had a record-breaking quarter. Retail revenue almost doubled year-over-year to $3.85 billion compared to $1.97 billion in the year-ago quarter
column142: an increase of 95%. iPad sales in our stores were very strong in the first holiday quarter. The stores also delivered a record Mac quarter
column143: selling 851
column144: 000 Macs compared to 689
column145: 000 Macs in the year-ago quarter
column146:
an increase of 24%. And about half the Macs sold in our stores during the December quarter were to customers who had never owned a Mac before. International Retail Store sales were particularly strong with our average international store volume exceeding our very productive average U.S. store volume.

"
column147:
"

Additionally
column148: our four stores in China were
column149: on average
column150: our highest traffic and our highest revenue stores in the world. We opened six stores during the December quarter
column151: bringing us to a total of 323 stores worldwide at the quarter end
column152:
with 87 of them outside the United States.

"
column153:
"

With an average of 321 stores opened during the December quarter
column154: average revenue per store was $12 million compared to $7.1 million in the year-ago quarter
column155:
an increase of 69%.

"
column156:
"

Retail segment margin exceeded $1 billion for the first time and more than doubled from $481 million in the year-ago quarter. We hosted a record 75.7 million visitors in our stores during the quarter
column157: compared to 50.9 million visitors in the year-ago quarter
column158:
an increase of 49%.

"
column159:
"

Total company gross margin was 38.5%
column160: which was about 250 basis points higher than our guidance. About half this difference was due to better commodity cost than we had planned. The remainder of the difference was due to the leverage on the higher revenue and lower other product costs
column161: including freight
column162:
warranty and phone support.

"
column163:
"

Operating expenses were $2.47 billion and included $247 million in stock-based compensation expense. OI&E was $136 million
column164: ahead of our guidance primarily due to the positive impact of fluctuating foreign exchange rates from net asset. The tax rate for the quarter was 24.6%
column165: below our guidance of 25.5% due to the one-time benefit of the retroactive extension of the R&D tax credit from January 1
column166:
2010. We expect our tax rate for the remaining quarters of fiscal '11 to be about 25.5%.

"
column167:
"

Turning to cash. Our cash
column168: plus short-term and long-term marketable securities
column169: totaled $59.7 billion at the end of the December quarter
column170: compared to $51 billion at the end of the September quarter
column171: an increase of $8.7 billion. Cash flow from operations was $9.8 billion
column172:
an increase of 69% year-over-year.

"
column173:
"

During the September and December quarters
column174: we executed long-term supply agreements with three vendors through which we expect to spend a total of approximately $3.9 billion in inventory component prepayments and capital expenditures over a two-year period. We made approximately $650 million in payments under these agreements in the December quarter
column175:
and anticipate making $1.05 billion in payments in the March quarter.

"
column176:
"

As we move ahead into the March quarter
column177: I'd like to review our outlook
column178: which includes the types of forward-looking information that Nancy referred to at the beginning of the call. We expect revenue to be about $22 billion
column179: compared to $13.5 billion in the March quarter last year. We expect gross margins to be about 38.5%
column180: reflecting approximately $50 million related to stock-based compensation expense. We expect OpEx to be about $2.35 billion
column181: including about $250 million related to stock-based compensation. We expect OI&E to be about $50 million
column182:
and we expect the tax rate to be about 25.5%. We are targeting EPS of about $4.90.

"

column185: and we remain very confident in our strategy and our new product pipeline. And with that

I'd like to open the call to questions.

column338: we design components where we believe we can innovate beyond what's available in the market. And the most recent example of this is the A4 chip. But with the A4 chip

And so we wanted to secure supply for the company

column371: if that's changed
column373:

column374:

Timothy Cook

column375:

Well
column376: and if you're look at what's shipping today
column377: there's not much out there as you know. And generally speaking
column378: there's two kinds of groups today
column379: that are at least on the market today. The ones that are using a Windows-based operating system are generally fairly big and heavy and expensive. They have very weak battery life
column380: they require a keyboard or a stylus as an input device. And from our point of view and what we've seen
column381: customers
column383: just are not interested in them. Then you have the Android tablet
column384: and the variety that are out shipping today
column385: the operating system wasn't really designed for a tablet. And Google has said this
column386: and so this is not just an Apple view by any means. And so you wind up having a size of a tablet that is less than what we believe is reasonable or even one that would provide what we feel is a real tablet experience. And so basically
column387: you wind up with kind of a scaled-up smartphone
column388: which is a bizarre product in our view. Then you've got kind of a third group -- and so those are the two that are shipping today. And frankly speaking
column389: it's hard for me to understand if somebody does a side-by-side with an iPad
column390: I think some enormous percentage of people are going to select an iPad there. Those are not tablets that we have any concern on. The next-generation Android tablets
column391: which are primarily what you mentioned in terms of the CES
column392: there's nothing shipping yet
column393: and so I don't know. Generally
column394: they lack performance specs
column395: they lack prices
column396: they lack timing. And so today

column414: as our long-standing practice has been

column416: after that period of time. Relative to other carriers

column419: et cetera. And so we'll continue to do that. What I've said before and we have seen this in every case

column423: our growth has changed significantly and our market share has increased. We look at each one individual because each market has its own individual characteristics and parameters and technology. On the CDMA phone
column425: I don't have any specific thing to announce today other than we're truly thrilled to be working with the Verizon team. They have built quite a company and earned a great deal of respect from the customers
column426: and some of them have waited a long time to get iPhone. And we're very
column427: very happy to give them iPhone
column428:
and any other customers that are non-Verizon customers who wish to buy an iPhone. We're also very happy that we've signed a multi-year non-inclusive deal with AT&T. And so we're very happy that we'll have shortly a dual-carrier setup in the United States.

Tim

that may be limiting your ability to sign important carrier agreements in potentially very important and strategic areas for the company?

column439: I generally found people really want to do business with us

and we're working around the clock to get as many of these out to our existing partners as we can.

Can you maybe give us your updated thoughts on the Mac side and maybe specifically address the impact of iPads? With the tremendous iPad unit this quarter
column450: the cannibalization question is going to come up. And I just want to get your latest thoughts on that
column451:
if we could?

column452:

Timothy Cook

column453:
"

That's a good question. What we saw in the Mac this quarter was we grew 23% at the worldwide level
column454: and that is compared to a market growth of only 3%. And so we grew almost 8x the market rate of growth
column455: which is
column456: I think
column457: stunning. And every region outgrew the market
column458: so it wasn't just one region. Asia-Pacific led the growth with a whopping 67% year-over-year increase
column459: and that's almost 10x what market did there
column460: to put it in context. Japan grew at 56%
column462: and Europe and the United States both grew in double-digits despite both markets contracting overall. And so we did significantly better than the market in every major region
column463: and we're very proud of that. Now was there any cannibalization by iPad? Honestly
column464: I don't know for sure. But yes
column465: I think there is some cannibalization. But I also think there's a halo effect. As we've seen on the Mac by the iPod some years ago
column466: I think there is a halo effect from Apple product to Apple product. And of course
column467: we have introduced millions of people in Asia to Apple through the iPhone. And we're now introducing many more through the iPad
column468: and I think some of those decide to buy a Mac. And so when you look at the Mac growth in Asia at 67%
column469: and you look at the Japan growth at 56%
column470: and you look at the U.S. and Europe growing in double-digits against shrinking markets
column471: if this is cannibalization
column472: it feels pretty good. The other point I would make is that if the iPad or tablets do cannibalize the PC market
column473: keep in mind that we have low share of the PC market. And so the other guys lose a lot more
column474: and we have a lot more to win because of that. And so honestly
column475: cannibalization is not something that we are spending one minute on here. The iPad team are building the best iPad for the future
column476: and the Mac teams are building the best Mac
column477: and I can tell you that both groups believe that they can continue to grow and do great stuff
column478:
and I believe that.

"
column479:
"

Brian Blair - Wedge Partners

"
column480:
"

And that's a great way to look at it. One of the things that's interesting to me is I see this trend of your bringing a lot more of the functionality from the tablet side
column481: you're bringing it on to the Mac side. It was talked about earlier
column482: the Mac App Store that's now on Mac OS X. And then as we're getting kind of teaser shots of Lion
column483: it looks like the next OS is also taking even more kind of design and UI elements from the iPad side. So maybe if you could just talk about that a little bit
column484:
are these two platforms really merging into one? And is this the future of computing as you see it? Or is it just -- are you just kind of grabbing one or two aspects of tablets and bringing it into the OS X?

"
column485:
"

Timothy Cook

"
column486:
"

I think one of the -- part of the magic of Apple is that there's not high walls between these product groups. They like each other
column487: talk to each other
column488: they're of the same DNA
column489: they want to build the best products in the world. And so if one has a great idea
column490: there's not a \"not invented here\" in the other group. And so one of the key learnings from the iPad was that people love instant on
column491: they really love that. And so the MacBook Air incorporated that
column492: and that's just one simple example. But there are tons of examples throughout all of our products
column493: where something started on one and went to a different one. And it's not always in the same direction either. It could start on the phone
column495: it could start on the iPad and flow
column496: and so on and so forth. And so just the part of the way we run the company. And I think Steve said it great when he said
column497: \"If the Mac company were a separate company
column498: and the iPad company were a separate company
column499: what would the Mac company build to compete with the iPad? And I think the answer is the MacBook Air.\" And I think that's a phenomenal insight
column500: and I think a great way to look at it. And it's not that the groups are competing
column501:
they are sharing and coming up with these incredible products that people really want.

"

"

Operator

From Bank of Montreal

we'll hear from Keith Bachman.

Tim

column509: but I want to hear a little bit about that. And depending on that outcome

column512:
the Pad in emerging markets may help to continue drive share opportunities for you?

column518: and moved to mainstream and enterprise and all the rest in record time. But nevertheless

column524: where just two years ago

column527: or actually for the year before. And so I think we are -- it's clear that we're introducing a lot of people to Apple who previously had not been introduced to the company
column528:
and I think that helps across the product line.

column529:

Keith Bachman - BMO Capital Markets U.S.

"
column530:

In the U.S.

column534: not on growth rate
column535:
but on absolute unit opportunities between the established markets and the emerging markets?
