column536:
"

Timothy Cook

"
column537:
"

I think that the tablet market is
column538: the opportunity is so large
column540:
honestly. I think it\u2019s huge.

column543:
Ben Reitzes.

column544:

Benjamin Reitzes - Barclays Capital

column546: I just wanted to cash out the revenue outlook. Your sequential decline of
column547: I guess
column548: 17% is a little more than last year's
column549: but you have Verizon now for the iPhone. So what components
column550: I guess
column551: other than iPod

column554:
maybe iPhone has some support from Verizon?

"
column555:
"

Peter Oppenheimer

"
column556:
"

Ben
column557: I'll answer your question in a couple of ways. First of all
column558: we're working hard to increase supply of iPhones. Tim has talked about that
column559: but that will come over a period of time and not necessarily
column560: overnight
column561: as we said. In terms of the sequential guidance this year
column562: let me start by saying we are thrilled to be giving you guidance for 63% revenue growth year-over-year
column563: which will translate to a 50% earnings growth. So the business is performing extremely well. We're shipping the best products in Apple history and customer response has been tremendous. But as I said in my prepared remarks
column564: we increased the iPhone and the iPad channel inventory by about 775
column565: 000 units
column566: and this will have a bit of impact on the sequential compare that you referred to. In terms of the products
column567: for Mac

column570: which is typical for us after the holiday season. For iPod
column571: we would also expect to see a large sequential decline
column572: which is also typical for us after the holiday season. For iPhone
column573: we'd expect to see a significant year-over-year increase. And for iPad
column574: this will be our first experience
column575: going from the December to March quarter
column576: so we'll see. However
column577: it was clear to us that the iPad was a hot holiday gift item
column578: which fueled the 75% sequential growth that we saw in the December quarter. And given this
column579: we would expect a sequential decline in the March quarter. So that's what's gone into our thinking
column580:
Ben.

column581:
"

Benjamin Reitzes - Barclays Capital

column582:
"

And then just a follow up for Tim
column583: the last call
column584: maybe
column585: or one of the last calls
column586: Steve had a lot of comments around Android and perhaps
column587: some of its disadvantages versus your platform. Is there any other observations you'd like to make now that
column588: we had a few more months
column589: to see the market develop further and with Verizon
column590: and even more tablet sales on the horizon
column591: feedback you're getting from developers
column592: or anything else you'd like to add on the battle with Android
column593:
kind of updating Steve's recent comments from last quarter?

"
column595:
"

Well
column596: if you look at the iPhone portion
column597: we had record sales on iPhone with 16.2 million units sold in the quarter. And Peter said we believe we could've sold more if we had more supply. From the market estimates that we've seen
column598: it suggests that we grew faster than the market. Obviously
column599: we're working around the clock on increasing supply. We're continuing to expand countries and carriers. And I've talked a little bit of that with Toni's question. We're getting enormous enterprise traction
column600: with 88% of the Fortune 100
column602: I believe. 83% of the Fortune 500
column603: 60% of the FT 100. So the enterprise traction is gaining. We have the highest customer sat [satisfaction] ratings in the industry versus Android or RIM or any -- we have the largest App Store with over 300
column604: 000 apps. We have now sold over 160 million iOS devices. And I mean
column605: this is huge. And we fundamentally believe that our integrated approach delivers a far superior customer experience than the fragmented approach. And you can see this in a variety of ways from the fragmentation of the number of App Stores out there that people are going to pull their hair out
column606: because they're going to have a variety of updating methodologies
column607: and a variety of payment methods
column608: and slightly different derivatives. You can see from surveys
column609: people are doing to see who is on the latest OS
column610: and you'll notice that the iOS is always off the charts on the percentage of people that have the latest version versus the other guys. We are launching with Verizon next month. We believe there's a huge pent-up demand there
column611: and we think that
column612: that will help us in the U.S. And so I think I'd probably just repeat it
column613: much of what he said before. But the net-net is we think that our integrated approach is much better for the end user because it takes out all the complexity for the end user instead of making the end user a systems integrator themselves. I don't know about you
column614: but I don't know very many people that want to be system integrators as a consumer or somebody in the enterprise. And so I think that the more iPhones that we can get out there into people's hands
column615: the more people love them. And I think we've got a very bright future. I think the same thing about iPad. It's the same set of issues at the end of the day. The differences on iPad
column616: of course
column617: is that we have a -- we've been running three quarters without any significant competition of any type. And I think that the customer sat ratings on the iPad are also off the charts. So I don't know if any of that is new
column618:
I doubt that it is. But I think we're in a very good position.

column623: I want to see if you can give us a little more insight on the iPad gross margins going forward. Just given Tim's comments earlier about the bounty of underachievers out there
column626:
should we assume then that Apple can really improve the future set with the next generation and kind of hold pricing stable?

column630: that's not a question I can answer. We don't talk about future products. But I can tell you that in terms of what we're shipping today
column631: we're always aggressively working to lower our costs. And I think we have a good track record in doing so
column632: and our gross margins were stronger than we thought for the December quarter. And I've provided guidance for the March quarter at 38.5%. And we feel very
column633:
very good about the performance of our products and our cost of products.

"
column634:
"

Mark Moskowitz - JP Morgan Chase & Co

"
column637: I apologize if this question has been asked

column640: can you give us any sort of insight in terms of how you're looking at that platform now? Is it kind of a premium tablet? Is this kind of more of a notebook still? I trying to get a sense of just kind of a one-two punch in terms of the iPad
column642: kind of giving you a kind of a double coverage
column646:
"

The way that we look at it is it's the Mac of the future shipping today
column647: and it was a phenomenal part of our growth on the Mac last quarter. It has gotten off to a unbelievable start. The customers love it. They love the precision of it
column650: the instant on and the list is long
column651: I think. And so we're really happy with how it's doing out of the starting blocks. And as you know
column652: we've only been shipping it for less than 90 days
column653:
and so we've just gotten going.

"
column655:
"

We'll go to Jason Maynard with Wells Fargo.

"
column656:
"

Jason Maynard - Wells Fargo Securities
column658:
"

There's been a lot of talk about this consumerization of enterprise technology
column660:
it's being driven by folks bringing their iPhones and iPads to work. I know you said it's some big share gains within your statistics. But I was curious if you think there still are some barriers around maybe developer training at the corporate level or security or things that just sort of naturally need to get worked through before you start to see those penetration numbers even increase further or start to see a wider swathe of employees use iPhones and iPads in business?

"
column662:
"

I think that the consumerization that you speak of
column664: is one of the megatrends that are occurring. I think the most forward-looking CIOs are coming to the realization that the productivity of the person
column665: the creativity of the employees is materially more important than everyone using the same thing. And the ability to write apps in a simple and straightforward manner for the iPhone or the iPad through the SDK is an incredible thing. And you can wind up
column667: running your whole business off of an iPad or an iPhone. And so I think the list of ideas and places that people can go there are -- were unimaginable just a few months ago. And so I see an enormous potential there. The numbers are already incredible. And think about this
column668: the iPad started shipping in April
column669: and we're already up to 80% of the largest companies deploying or piloting the product. This is unheard of
column671: in my dealings with the enterprise over the years. Generally
column672: enterprise is much slower and much more cautious and uses things that have been in the market for a long time. And I think to everyone's credit
column673: they've seen the value of this from a productivity and creativity point of view
column674: and they're really moving fast. And so I think we're just scratching the surface right now. In terms of inhibitors
column675: the iPad has a huge advantage because as you probably remember
column676: as we went to various different iOS releases
column677: we always put in a huge chunk of enterprise features. And so this isn't something that we just started focusing on. We started focusing on this before we shipped the first phone. And with the synergy that exists with the iOS between the different products
column678: other products get the advantage of it
column679:
not just the product that it ships on initially. And so I think there's a huge play here for us.

"

column30: everyone
column31: and welcome to this Apple Inc. Second Quarter Fiscal Year 2011 Earnings Release Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] At this time for opening remarks and introductions
column32: I would now turn the call over to Ms. Nancy Paxton
column33: Senior Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead
column37: and thanks to everyone for joining us today. Speaking today is Apple CFO
column38: Peter Oppenheimer; and he'll be joined by Apple COO
column40: Gary Wipfler
column41:
for the Q&A session with the analysts.

"
column43:
"

Please note that some of the information you'll hear during our discussion today will consist of forward-looking statements
column46: those regarding revenue
column47: gross margins
column48: operating expenses
column49: other income and expense
column50: stock-based compensation expense
column51: taxes

column54:
the Form 10-Q for the first quarter of fiscal 2011 and the Form 8-K filed with the SEC today along with the attached press release. Apple assumes no obligation to update any forward-looking statements or information which speak as of their respective date.

"
column55:
"

"
column56:
"

With that
column57: I'd like to turn the call over to Apple CFO
column58: Peter Oppenheimer
column59:
for introductory remarks.

"
column60:
"

Peter Oppenheimer

"
column61:
"

Thank you
column62: Nancy. Thank you for joining us. We are very pleased to report the highest March quarter revenue and earnings in Apple's history. We set a new all-time quarterly record for iPhone sales
column63: and a new March quarter record for Mac sales
column64:
and we're thrilled with the momentum for iPad.

"
column65:
"

"
column66:
"

Revenue for the quarter was $24.7 billion
column67: which was $11.2 billion over the prior March quarter's result and represents the largest year-over-year quarterly revenue growth we've ever generated. This tremendous increase of 83% was fueled primarily by record iPhone sales
column68: very robust demand for iPad and strong growth in Mac sales. Operating margin was an all-time high of almost $7.9 billion
column69:
representing 31.9% of revenue. Net income was almost $6 billion. This represented 95% growth over the year gross quarter's earnings and translated to earnings per share of $6.40.

"
column70:
"

"
column71:
"

Turning to the details of the quarter. I'd like to begin with our Mac products and services. We established a new March quarter record with sales of 3.76 million Macs
column72: representing 28% growth over the year ago quarter. We're extremely pleased with this very strong growth
column73: particularly given IDC's most recently published estimate of a 3% contraction for the PC market overall. This result makes the March quarter the 20th consecutive quarter that we outperformed the PC market. We experienced strong Mac sales growth in each of our operating segments
column74: most notably in the Asia-Pacific segment
column75: where Mac sales increased 76% year-over-year. The growth in Mac sales was fueled primarily by the continued great popularity of MacBook Air
column76: which was updated in the December quarter
column77: as well as very strong sales of MacBook Pro. We updated the entire MacBook Pro family during the March quarter with the next-generation processors and graphics
column78:
high-speed Thunderbolt I/O technology and a new FaceTime HD camera.

"
column79:
"

"
column80:
"

The new MacBook Pro lineup offers twice the speed of the previous generation and customer response has been excellent. We began at the end of the quarter with between 3 and 4 weeks of Mac channel inventory. During the quarter
column81: we released the developer preview of Mac OS X Lion
column82: which takes some of the best ideas from the iPad and brings them back to the Mac. Lion features Mission Control an innovative new view of everything running on the Mac. Launchpad
column83: a new home for all your Mac Apps
column84:
full screen apps that use the entire Mac display and new multi-touch gestures. Lion is scheduled to ship to customers this summer and we look forward to showing more of its great features at our Developers Conference in June.

"
column85:
"

"
column86:
"

Moving to our music products. We sold 9 million iPods compared to 10.9 million in the year ago quarter. Though lower year-over-year
column87: total iPod sales were ahead of our expectations with iPod touch continuing to count for over half of all iPods sold. iPod share of the U.S. market for MP3 players remains at over 70% based on the latest monthly data published by MPD
column88:
and iPod continue to be the top-selling MP3 player in most countries we track based on the latest data published by GFK.

"
column89:
"

"
column90:
"

We ended the quarter within our target range of 4 to 6 weeks of iPod channel inventory. The iTunes Store turned in its best quarter ever with revenue of almost $1.4 billion
column91: thanks to record revenue from music
column92: video
column93: iOS apps and books. We were very pleased to begin offering a full catalog of 17
column94: 000 ebooks from Random House on the iBookstore during the March quarter. The iBookstore now includes ebooks for more than 2
column95: 500 publishers in over 20 categories
column96:
and customers have downloaded over 100 million books.

"
column97:
"

"
column98:
"

I'd now like to turn to the iPhone. We were thrilled to have sold a record 18.6 million iPhones compared to 8.8 million in the previous March quarter. This represents 113% year-over-year growth which is significantly ahead of IDC's latest published estimate of 74% growth for the global smartphone market overall in the March quarter. Recognized revenue from iPhone handset and accessory sales was $12.3 billion during the quarter compared to $5.45 billion in the year ago quarter
column99:
an increase of 126%. We continue to experience very strong year-over-year iPhone sales growth in all of our operating segments with sales in both the Americas and Asia-Pacific regions more than doubling year-over-year.

"
column100:
"

"
column101:
"

We were able to make a significant increase in our capacity
column102: once again
column103: allowing us to expand distribution and get much-needed supply to our channel partners. We were very pleased to begin selling iPhones on the Verizon network in the U.S. in the March quarter
column104: and we were also happy to add SK Telecom in Korea
column105: as well as Saudi Telecom in Saudi Arabia. Including some carrier consolidation
column106:
we ended the quarter with iPhone distribution through 186 carriers in 90 countries.

"
column107:
"

"
column108:
"

We ended the quarter with about 5.2 million iPhones in channel inventory
column109: a sequential increase of about 1.7 million to support new carrier launches and existing channel partners. This placed us within our target range of 4 to 6 weeks of iPhone channel inventory. iPhone is continuing to see strong growth within the Enterprise segment. Today
column110:
88% of the Fortune 500 are testing or deploying iPhone.

"
column111:
"

"
column112:
"

With strong employee demand and custom app development fueling adoption
column113: we are seeing great scale of iPhone deployments in businesses worldwide. In fact
column114: hundreds of private and public companies worldwide are supporting thousands of iPhones on their corporate networks. Some examples include Cisco
column115: Prudential
column116: Boston Scientific
column117: General Motors
column118: American Airlines
column119: Deloitte
column120:
Yum! Brands and Xerox.

"
column121:
"

"
column122:
"

Turning to iPad
column123: we continue to be thrilled with its momentum. We sold 4.7 million iPads during the March quarter
column124:
launching iPad 2 in U.S. on March 11 and in 25 additional countries on March 25. Customer enthusiasm has been tremendous for iPad 2 and we're working hard to get it into the hands of customers as quickly as possible.

"
column125:
"

"
column126:
"

Including both the original iPad and iPad 2
column127: we had distribution in 59 countries by the end of the March quarter. Given the very strong customer demand and despite the increased geographic distribution
column128: iPod (sic) [iPad] channel inventory declined by 400
column129: 000 from the beginning of the quarter
column130: implying sell-through of about 5.1 million. This resulted in ending channel inventory of below 850
column132:
which was below our target range of 4 to 6 weeks. We sold every iPad 2 that we could make during the quarter and would have liked to end the quarter with more channel inventory. Recognized revenue from sales of iPad and iPad accessories during the quarter was $2.8 billion.

"
column133:
"

"
column134:
"

Employee demand for iPad in the corporate environment remains strong and CIOs continue to embrace iPad in an unprecedented rate. In just over a year since its debut
column135: 75% of the Fortune 500 are testing or deploying iPad within their enterprises. Some recent examples of enterprises that are deploying iPad include FORTUNE 500 companies such as Xerox
column136: AutoNation
column137: Yum! Brands
column138: ADP
column139: Boston Scientific
column140: Est\u00e9e Lauder
column141: Disney
column142: Stryker
column143: Prudential Financial
column144:
Rite Aid and USAA.

"
column145:
"

"
column146:
"

Combining iPhone
column147: iPad and iPod touch
column148: we reached just under 189 million cumulative iOS device sales through the end of the March quarter. In March
column149: we introduced iOS 4.3 with new features including faster Safari mobile browsing performance with the Java Nitro script engine
column150: iTunes Home Sharing
column151:
enhancements to AirPlay and the Personal Hotspot feature for sharing an iPhone 4 cellular data connection over Wi-Fi.

"
column152:
"

"
column153:
"

The App Store continues to be incredibly successful with over 350
column154: 000 apps available and well over 10 billion downloads to date. In February
column155: we announced a new subscription service available to all publishers of content-based apps
column156: including magazines
column157: newspapers
column158:
video and music. Publishers set the price and length of subscription and customers select the subscription and length they want with 1 click. And it was also a great pleasure to announce in March that we have made more than $2 billion in payments to developers since opening the App Store.

"
column159:
"

"
column160:
"

I'd now like to turn to the Apple Retail Stores. We are approaching the Retail Stores 10th anniversary on May 19
column161: and we're on the verge of achieving a major milestone. In the next few days
column162: we will be thrilled to welcome our 1 billionth visitor. Store traffic continues to be amazingly strong. And in the March quarter
column163: we hosted a record 71.1 million visitors in our stores compared to 47 million visitors in the year ago quarter
column164:
an increase of 51%.

"
column165:
"

"
column166:
"

Retail revenue was $3.19 billion compared to $1.68 billion in the year ago quarter
column167: an increase of 90%. Capitalizing on the February MacBook Pro update
column168: the stores delivered another record Mac quarter
column169: selling 797
column170: 000 Macs compared to 606
column171: 000 Macs in the year ago quarter
column172: an increase of 32%
column173:
and about half the Macs sold in our stores during the March quarter were to customers who had never owned a Mac before.

"
column174:
"

"
column175:
"

To further enrich our Apple retail customer experience
column176: we recently launched a program called Personal Setup. When customers buy a Mac
column177: iPad
column178: iPhone or iPod touch
column179: our teams help the customer set up the product in the store so that they are up and running before they leave. Personal Setup includes the customer's e-mail
column180: contacts
column181: calendar
column182: applications and more. In the March quarter
column183: our stores set up over 1 million products. We operated 323 stores during the quarter. Average revenue per store was $9.9 million compared to $5.9 million in the year ago quarter
column184:
an increase of 67%. International retail store sales remain strong with our average international store volume exceeding our very productive average U.S. store volume.

"
column185:
"

"
column186:
"

Retail segment margin more than doubled year-over-year to $807 million compared to $373 million in the year ago quarter. We anticipate opening 40 new stores in fiscal 2011
column187: nearly 3 quarters of which will be outside the United States
column188:
including our fifth store in China.

"
column189:
"

"
column190:
"

Total company gross margin was 41.4%
column191: which was 290 basis points higher than our guidance. More than half of this difference came from better product mix than planned
column192: particularly higher iPhone sales. The remainder was largely a result of leverage on the higher revenue and lower-than-expected commodity
column193:
service and other costs.

"
column194:
"

"
column195:
"

Operating expenses were $2.34 billion and included $236 million of stock-based compensation expense. OI&E was $26 million and the tax rate for the quarter was 24.2%
column196: below our guidance of 25.5% due to changes in our full year forecast of foreign earnings
column197:
R&D tax credit and state taxes.

"
column198:
"

"
column199:
"

Turning to cash. Our cash for short-term and long-term marketable securities totaled $65.8 billion at the end of the March quarter compared to $59.7 billion at the end of the December quarter
column200: a sequential increase of $6.1 billion. Cash flow from operations was $6.2 billion
column201:
an increase of 167% year-over-year. The increase in cash is net of approximately $900 million to combine prepayments and capital expenditures related to the strategic supply agreements that we referred to in our last quarterly call.

"
column202:
"

"
column203:
"

As we move into the June quarter
column204: I'd like to review our outlook
column205: which includes the types of forward-looking information that Nancy referred to at the beginning of the call. We expect revenue to be about $23 billion compared to $15.7 billion in the June quarter last year. We expect gross margin to be about 38%
column206: reflecting approximately $55 million related to stock-based compensation expense. We expect OpEx to be about $2.5 billion
column207:
including about $255 million related to stock-based compensation expense. We expect OI&E to be about $70 million and we expect the tax rate to be about 25%. We are targeting EPS of about $5.03.

"
column208:
"

"
column209:

In closing
column210:
we're thrilled with the results and accomplishments of our record March quarter. We're extremely pleased with customers' response to iPad 2 and are working hard to get it into the hands of customers as fast as we can. We remain very confident in our strategy and are very excited about our new product pipeline.

column224: great. Thanks. Can you comment
column225: Peter
column226: on whether or not you're seeing any supply chain disruptions from the recent earthquake in Japan. And if so
column227:
how should we think about that in terms of that being factored in your guidance?

"
column228:
"

Timothy Cook

"
column229:
"

Bill
column230: this is Tim. Let me sort of step back and talk about Japan in general and sort of try to get all of your questions in advance. First of all
column231: this is an incredible tragedy and our hearts go out to everyone involved. Apple
column232: as a company
column233: has a very long history and has many strong ties to people in Japan
column234: and we're very
column235: very saddened by the situation
column236: and we've undertaken various actions to assist in the relief effort. The economic impact that we'll address today pales in comparison to the human impact. Regarding our business in Japan
column237: we had some revenue impact in Q2 but it was not material to Apple's consolidated results. We believe revenues will be approximately $200 million less in Q3
column238: and this has been factored into the guidance that Peter provided you earlier in his comments. Regarding our global supply chain
column239: as a result of outstanding teamwork and unprecedented resilience of our partners
column240: we did not have any supply or cost impact in our fiscal Q2 as a result of the tragedy
column241: and we currently do not anticipate any material supply or cost impact in our fiscal Q3. To provide a bit more color on this
column242: we sourced hundreds
column243: literally hundreds of items from Japan
column244: and they range from components such as LCDs
column245: optical drives
column246: NAND Flash and DRAM to base materials such as resins
column247: coatings and foil that are part of the production process at several layers back in the supply chain. The earthquake and subsequent tsunami and the associated nuclear crisis caused disruption for many of these suppliers
column248: and many unaffected suppliers have been impacted by power interruptions. But since the disaster
column249: Apple employees have literally been working around the clock with our supplier partners in Japan
column250: and have been able to implement a number of contingency plans. Our preference from the beginning of this tragedy has been to remain with our long-term partners in Japan. And I have to say
column251: they have displayed an incredible resilience that I personally never seen before in the aftermath of this disaster. So while we do not anticipate -- currently anticipate any material impact to our component supply or cost in our fiscal Q3
column252: we do need to caution everyone that the situation remains unpredictable given recent aftershocks
column253: the uncertainty about the nuclear plant and potential power interruptions. Further
column254: there are some supply risks that are beyond the current quarter. And although we know of no issue today that we view as unsolvable
column255: the situation is still uncertain and there's obviously no guarantees. For this reason
column256: it's difficult to predict whether the issues created by the tragedy would impact revenues beyond Q3. However
column257:
I'll be happy to address Q4 on our next call in July.

column258:
"

Bill Shope - Goldman Sachs Group Inc.

{"Apple Management Discusses Q3 2011 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL)

"

Peter Oppenheimer - Chief Financial Officer and Senior Vice President

"
column7:

Timothy Cook - Chief Operating Officer

"
column10:

column12:

"
column28: and welcome to this Apple Inc. Third Quarter Fiscal Year 2011 Earnings Release Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] At this time
column30: I would now like to turn the call over to Ms. Nancy Paxton
column31: Senior Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead
column33:
"

Nancy Paxton

"
column35: and thanks to everyone for joining us. Speaking today is Apple's CFO
column36: Peter Oppenheimer; and he'll be joined by Apple COO
column38: Gary Wipfler for the Q&A session with the analysts. Please note that some of the information you'll hear during our discussion today will consist forward-looking statements
column40: without limitation
column41: those regarding revenue
column46: taxes
column47: earnings per share and future products. Actual results or trends could differ materially from our forecast. For more information
column48: please refer to the risk factors discussed in Apple's Form 10-K for 2010
column49: the Form 10-Q for the first 2 quarters of fiscal 2011
column50: and the Form 8-K filed with the SEC today
column51: along with the attached press release. Apple assumes no obligation to update any forward-looking statements or information
column52: which speak as of their respective date. With that
column53:
I would like to turn the call over to Peter Oppenheimer for introductory remarks.

"
column54:
"

Peter Oppenheimer

"
column55:
"

Thank you
column56: Nancy. Thank you for joining us. We're thrilled to report the highest quarterly revenue and earnings in Apple history. We also set a new all-time quarterly record for iPhone and iPad sales and a new June quarter record for Mac sales and we're extremely pleased with the momentum of our business. Revenue for the quarter was $28.6 billion
column57: representing year-over-year growth of 82%. This record quarterly revenue topped the previous record established in the most recent December quarter by $1.8 billion and was almost $13 billion over the year ago quarter's result. The tremendous year-over-year increase was fueled primarily by dramatic growth in iPhone and iPad sales in addition to strong growth in Mac sales. Operating margin was a record high of $9.4 billion
column58: representing 32.8% of revenue. Net income was $7.3 billion
column59:
topping the previous quarterly record set in the December quarter by $1.3 billion.

"
column60:
"

Net income grew even faster than revenue
column61: increasing 125% year-over-year and translated to earnings per share of $7.79. Turning to the details of the quarter. I'd like to begin with our Mac products and services. We established the new June quarter record with sales of 3.95 million Macs representing a 14% increase over the year ago quarter's result. This growth is more than 4x IDCs most recently published forecast of 3% growth for the PC market overall. Mac sales were particularly strong in our Asia-Pacific segment
column62: where we experienced a 57% year-over-year increase in total Macs sold. We generated healthy Mac growth in both desktop and portable categories. In May
column63: we updated the iMac with the next-generation quad core processors
column64: powerful new graphics
column65: high speed portable I/O technology and a new space time
column66: HD camera. The growth in Mac portable sales was driven by strong sales of MacBook Pro
column67:
as well as MacBook Air. We began to enter the quarter with between 3 and 4 weeks of Mac channel inventory.

"
column68:
"

We are very excited to be launching Mac OS X Lion tomorrow. The Lion includes more than 250 new features such as a multi-touch gestures
column69: system wide support for full screen apps
column70: Mission Control
column71:
which is an innovative view of everything running on your Mac and much more.

"
column72:
"

Moving to our music products. We sold 7.5 million iPods compared to 9.4 million in the year ago quarter. Total iPod sales were ahead of our expectations and iPod touch continues to account for over half of all iPods sold. iPod share of the U.S. market for MP3 players remains at over 70% based on the latest monthly data published by MPD. And iPod continued to be the top-selling MP3 player in most countries we track based on the latest data published by GFK. We ended the quarter within our target range of 4 to 6 weeks of iPod channel inventory.

"
column73:
"

The iTunes store generated strong results with revenue of almost $1.4 billion. iTunes revenue was up 36% year-over-year
column74: thanks primarily to continued strong sales of music
column75: video and apps. With more than 225 million accounts
column76:
iTunes is the #1 music retailer in the world and customers have downloaded more than 15 billion songs today.

"
column77:
"

I'd now like to turn to the iPhone. We were thrilled to sell a record 20.3 million iPhones compared to 8.4 million in the previous June quarter. This represents 142% year-over-year growth
column78: which is more than double IDC's latest published estimate of 67% growth for the global smartphone market overall in the June quarter. Recognized revenue from iPhone handset and accessory sales were $13.3 billion during the quarter compared to $5.3 billion in the year ago quarter
column79: an increase of 150%. We continue to experience very strong year-over-year iPhone sales growth in all of our operating segments. iPhone sales momentum in the Asia-Pacific region was particularly robust with sales almost quadrupling year-over-year. We continue to increase our overall iPhone manufacturing capacity in the quarter. We were pleased to launch a number of new carrier relationships. And by the end of the quarter
column80: iPhone was available through 228 carriers in 105 countries
column81: compared to 186 carriers in 90 countries as of the end of the March quarter. We ended the quarter with about 5.9 million iPhones in channel inventory
column82: a sequential increase of about 700
column83: 000 to support strong iPhone demand
column84:
carrier addition and expanded distribution. We remained within our target range of 4 to 6 weeks of iPhone channel inventory.

"
column85:
"

iPhone continues to be adopted as the standard across the enterprise with 91% of the Fortune 500 deployed or testing the device
column86: up from 88% last quarter. We're also seeing great growth in scale worldwide. Today
column87: 57% of Global 500 companies are testing or deploying iPhone
column88: fueled by strong employee demand and opportunities for custom App development. Some examples of Global 500 companies supporting iPhones on their corporate networks
column89: include AXA
column90: Credit Agricole
column91: Nestl\u00e9
column92: Dow Chemical
column93: GlaxoSmithKline
column94:
SUPERVALU and Comcast.

"
column95:
"

Turning to iPad. We continue to be thrilled with its incredible momentum. We sold a record 9.2 million iPads during the June quarter compared to 3.3 million in the year ago quarter
column96: an increase of 183%. We were able to increase production sequentially by over 4.5 million and we sold every iPad we can make. We launched iPad 2 in an additional 36 countries. And combining the original iPad and iPad 2
column97: we ended the quarter with distribution in a total of 64 countries. Recognized revenue from sales of iPad and iPad accessories during the quarter was over 6 billion
column98: compared to 2.2 billion in the year ago quarter
column99: an increase of 179%. We ended the quarter with about 1.05 million iPads in channel inventory
column100: a sequential increase of about 200
column102: which was well below our target range of 4 to 6 weeks. Today
column103: 86% of the Fortune 500 are deploying or testing iPad within their enterprises
column104:
up from 75% last quarter.

"
column105:
"

We are also seeing strong adoption internationally with 47% of Global 500 companies testing or deploying iPad. In the 15 months since iPad has shipped
column106: we've seen iPads used in the enterprise in ways we could have never imagined. Companies like Boston Scientific
column107: Xerox and Salesforce.com are deploying thousands of iPads and revolutionize in how their sales teams engage their customers. iPad is being used inside the country's top hospitals like HCA and Cedars-Sinai and in retail at Nordstrom and at Este\u00e9 Lauder's Clinique counters. General Electric
column108: SAP and Standard Charter have developed internal Apps for training
column109:
currency tracking and business process management to help make employees even more productive. And Alaska Airlines and American Airlines are using the iPad in cockpit to replace paper-based navigational and reference information pilots carry with him on every flight.

"
column110:
"

We continue to be delighted by the diverse and sometimes
column111: unexpected use cases we see around iPad. Combining iPhone
column112: iPad and iPod touch
column113:
we reached over 222 million cumulative iOS device sales through the end of the June quarter.

"
column114:
"

Last month
column115: we provided a preview of iOS 5
column116: which includes over 200 new features such as notification center for viewing and managing notifications without interruption
column117: iMessage for sending text messages
column118: photos and videos between iOS devices and Newsstand
column119:
a new way to purchase an organized newspaper and magazine subscriptions.

"
column120:
"

With the new PC-free feature
column121:
iOS 5 users will be able to activate and set up iOS devices right out of the box with no computer required. We are looking forward to launching iOS 5 this fall.

"
column122:
"

In June
column123: we also provided a preview of iCloud
column124: our set of free new services that work seamlessly with applications on the customer's iPhone
column125: iPad
column126: iPod touch
column127: Mac or PC to automatically and wirelessly store content in the cloud
column128:
as well as push it to all the users' devices. We think customers will love using iCloud and we look forward to its release in the fall.

"
column129:
"

The App Store continues to be incredibly successful with over 425
column130: 000 apps available in over 15 billion downloads to date. And as we mentioned last month
column131: we're extremely pleased to have reached over 2.5 billion in cumulative payments to iOS developer
column132:
far ahead of any of our competitors.

"
column133:
"

I'd now like to turn to the Apple Retail Stores
column134: which generated record June quarter results. Revenue grew to $3.5 billion from $2.6 billion in the year ago quarter
column135: an increase of 36%. This growth was driven primarily by higher volumes of iPad
column136: iPhones and Macs. The store sold 768
column137: 000 Macs compared to 677
column138: 000 Macs in the year ago quarter
column139: an increase of 13%. And about half of the Macs sold in our stores during the June quarter were to customers who had never owned a Mac before. We opened 4 new stores in the quarter
column140: including 2 in France
column141: 1 in the U.K. and 1 in Germany
column142: ending with a total of 327. With an average of 325 stores open
column143: average revenue per store was $10.8 million compared to $9 million in the year ago quarter
column144: an increase of 20%. Retail segment margin was $828 million compared to $593 million in the year ago quarter. Store traffic continues to be very strong. We hosted 73.7 million visitors in the June quarter compared to 60.5 million in the year ago quarter
column145:
an increase of 22%.

"
column146:
"

Our recently launched
column147: personal setup program is off to a great start. Customers love this new feature the retail store experience that they're up and running with their new products before they leave. During the June quarter
column148: we set up over 2 million Macs
column149: iPhone
column150:
iPads and iPods collectively.

"
column151:
"

We plan to open 30 new stores in the September quarter
column152: including our first store in Hong Kong. That will bring us to a total of 40 store openings in fiscal 2011
column153:
including 28 new stores outside United States.

"
column154:
"

Total company gross margin was 41.7%
column155: which was 370 basis points higher than our guidance. This difference was a result of 3 approximately equal factors: a stronger mix of iPhone; lower commodity and other costs
column156:
which included some one-time items; and leverage on the higher revenue. Operating expenses were $2.54 billion and included $232 million in stock based compensation expense. OI&E was $172 million and the tax rate for the quarter was 23.5%.

"
column157:
"

Turning to cash. Our cash for short-term and long-term marketable securities totaled $76.2 billion at the end of the June quarter compared to $65.8 billion at the end of the March quarter
column158: a sequential increase of $10.4 billion. Cash flow from operations was $11.1 billion
column159:
an increase of 131% year-over-year.

"
column160:
"

I'd now like to talk about the accounting implications of some of the new aspects of our products and services. First
column161: when we deliver Mac OS X Lion to customers
column162: we are now including the right to receive future unspecified minor software upgrades and features when and if they become available for both the Mac operating system and our suite of Mac OS allied [ph] applications. We will continue to charge for standalone sales of our periodic major OS upgrades
column163: such as Lion
column164: as well as major upgrades of iLife. Revenue from these standalone sales will now be fully deferred at the time of sale and recognized over a period of 3 years. In addition to this future software upgrade right
column165: Mac customers will have access to iCloud services when they become available in the fall. We estimate that the combined value of the software upgrade right and iCloud services for Mac customers is $22. Therefore
column166: as of June 6
column167:
we began deferring $22 of the revenue associated with each new Mac sold. And we will recognize these deferred amounts as revenue over a period of 4 years.

"
column168:
"

Purchasers of IOS devices will also have access to iCloud. So beginning on June 6
column169:
we begin to sign a portion of the revenue from each iOS device sold to represent the estimated value of the right to receive iCloud services when they become available. That deferred amount is in addition to the amount that we will already deferring for each iOS device sold to represent the right to receive future iOS software upgrades.

"
column170:
"

As a result
column171: beginning on June 6
column172: we are deferring a total of $16 of revenue for each iPhone and iPad sold and a total of $11 for each iPod touch sold and recognizing those amounts over a period of 2 years. As we move ahead into the September quarter
column173: I'd like to review our outlook
column174:
which includes the types of forward-looking statements that Nancy referred to at the beginning of the call.

"
column175:
"

We expect revenue to be about $25 billion compared to $20.3 billion in the September quarter last year. We expect gross margin to be about 38%
column176: reflecting approximately $55 million related to stock-based compensation expense. We expect OpEx to be about $2.725 billion
column177:
including about $245 million related to stock-based compensation expense.

"
column178:
"

We expect OI&E to be about $50 million and we expect the tax rate to be about 24%. We are targeting EPS of about $5.50.

"
column179:
"

In closing
column180: we're extremely pleased with our record revenue and earnings and the tremendous customer response to our products. Through the first 3 quarters of fiscal 2011
column181: we have generated $35 billion in year-over-year revenue growth translating to a 78% increase. At the same time
column182: we have generated over $9.5 billion in year-over-year earnings growth
column183: representing a 99% increase. We remain very excited about our new product pipeline and we look forward to releasing the Mac OS X Lion tomorrow and bring in the wonderful new features of iOS 5 and iCloud to customers this fall. With that
column184:
I'd like to open the call to questions.

"

"

Nancy Paxton

Yes. I really look more at year-over-year than I do sequential on the Mac. But I am going to get at your -- the answer to your question anyway. I think
column448: first of all
column449: I am proud of the numbers that we achieved. To grow at 14%
column450: when the market is growing at 2.6%
column451: doing 5x the rate of growth is certainly something to be proud of. However
column452: in terms of why isn't the number higher than 14%
column453: obviously
column454: we always focus on that. No matter if the number was 42%
column455: we would focus on that. I think there are 3 things that are the primary factor. And I don't want to try to quantify these for you
column456: but I do want to list them and how we look at it. The first is
column457: as I've said before
column458: I think there were some cannibalization of new Mac by iPad. We shipped a record 9.2 billion iPads during the quarter
column459: which is over 2x the number of Macs that we shipped. And it's clear that some customers chose to purchase an iPad instead of a new Mac. But the thing that really excites us is that more customers chose to buy an iPad than a Windows PC. The second one is
column460: I think
column461: some customers have delayed purchase until Lion becomes available. And as Peter commented on earlier
column462: we are launching Lion tomorrow. And we're looking forward to getting Lion out. It's a fantastic product. The guys have worked very
column463: very hard on it and it's really a revolutionary change. But the third thing that I wouldn't discount it
column464: in the year ago quarter
column465: we launched new MacBook Pro. In this particular quarter
column466: we launched new iMac. Both products were well received
column467: however
column468: the MacBook Pro makes up over the majority of the units that we sell in the Mac area. And so obviously
column469: if you change the MacBook Pro and it's well received
column470:
it's going to make the comp more difficult to compare to. And so those are the 3 things that I think are primarily why the number isn't more than it is. But I don't want to lose site that it is already is 5x the industry and this is the 21st consecutive quarter that we beat the market.

column478: we don't predict unit sales. We aggregate things into a guidance and Peter went through that earlier. So I don't want to make a comment about iPad other than I think Peter said earlier
column479:
which I'm sure that you would have reached conclusion of anyways that we think iPad will grow significantly year-over-year. And we'll leave the rest of it to you to conclude and then we would be very happy to report in October how we did that.

"
column480:
"

Operator

"
column481:
"

From Bank of America
column482:
we'll go to Scott Craig.

"
column483:
"

Scott Craig

"
column484:
"

Tim
column485:
could you maybe provide a bit more color around what exactly the issues are for the iPad ramping up into the sort of levels that you want to get to? And can you hazard a guess as to when you think you'll be at sort of equilibrium on a global basis from a production and supply standpoint?

"
column486:
"

Timothy Cook

"
column487:
"

This is a good sort of problem per se is that the demand is fantastic. And so there's not something that I would point to on a supply side saying that this is creating a huge issue
column488: it's the good problem. And as I said before
column489: and I generally don't do that
column490: but in this case
column491: I am to talk about July. In the first weeks of July
column492: we're now 3 -- a little over 3 weeks into the quarter. Supply has further improved since we ended our June quarter and that further improvement has led some SKUs in some countries to become in supply-demand balance. Now
column493: I'm not going to project what will happen to the other country
column495: we're working very
column496:
very hard to get as many units to customers as we can. And we placed our latest thinking in the guidance obviously.

"
column497:
"

Scott Craig

"
column498:
"

And maybe just a quick follow-up
column499: Tim. Is there anything you guys are doing differently as far as investing in the enterprise sales force
column500: so to speak
column501: or doing anything differently as far as going to market on the enterprise side that you can point us to? And then
column502: I guess
column503:
we'll see the fruits of that labor as we sort of go forward here.

"
column504:
"

Timothy Cook

"
column505:
"

We have a dual-prong strategy with enterprise on both the iPad and the iPhone. As we work with the carrier sales forces and they have very large ones because they're selling their services into enterprise and many of these enterprises want that one of our device is connected to it and so we train and provide quite a bit of help to the carrier forces. Plus we do some sales
column506: directly our sales or act as an overlay sales force to a channel that sells to enterprise. And I would characterize this as we're still building it out and we do a bit better each quarter. We're very
column507: very happy with the numbers that Peter talked about earlier about the level of interest and taking people to the pilot and initial deployment stages. And now our attention is moving to penetration within those accounts versus sort of getting on the standards lists. And I think you'd really look at it fairly to be this far into the enterprise with a product that's only been shipping for 15 months in the case of iPad is absolutely incredible
column508: because the enterprise is typically much more conservative and takes a long time to evaluate products. In this case
column509: people are moving at a speed I haven't seen. Also in a group that's not thought of as enterprise like K-12
column510: our K-12 generally takes a very long time for new product categories
column511: but last quarter
column512: we sold more iPads in K-12 than we did not. And to do that after just 5 quarters is absolutely shocking. We would've never predicted that. And so we feel very
column513:
very good about the different area that iPad is being sold into. It's clear it has a universal appeal in many different markets from consumer to business to government and on and on.

"
column514:
"

Operator

"
column515:
"

From Wedge Partners
column516:
we'll go to Brian Blair.

"
column517:
"

Brian Blair - Wedge Partners

"
column518:
"

Can you just talk a little bit about your views on iCloud and just how you feel as a service it's going to drive more volumes to Mac and maybe just talk about what are your expectations on the halo effect across other iOS devices?

"
column519:
"

Peter Oppenheimer

"
column520:
"

This is Peter. We cannot wait to get iCloud and iOS 5 into the hands of customers in the fall. We really think that we have done it right with iCloud. We're going to deliver customers just a seamless integrated experience that we think that they are going to love. We're going to make it very easy and it didn't go unnoticed back to us yesterday that in the ChangeWave results
column521:
that was one of the reasons cited why the iOS devices are #1 in terms of intent to buy.

"
column523:
"

And maybe just briefly
column524: if you can comment on
column525: just do you feel like you have much of a lead over your competitors and the ability to instantly mirror content across different devices? It feels like it's a real competitive edge for you
column526:
but I'd love to hear your thought if you wouldn't mind sharing any.

"
column527:
"

Peter Oppenheimer

"
column528:
"

Well
column529: we're certainly very
column530: very good with the Internet
column531:
with telecommunications in delivering content. I think we have proven it in Mac for a decade first beginning with iTunes and now with the App Store and our payments to developers exceeding $2.5 billion. So we probably have some things to learn as we go forward. But have a lot of skills and are very excited to get iCloud in the customers' hands.

"
column532:
"

Operator

"
column533:
"

We'll go to Toni Sacconaghi with Sanford Bernstein.

column534:
"

Toni Sacconaghi - Sanford C. Bernstein & Co.
column535:
Inc.

"
column536:
"

Tim
column537: I wanted to revisit China and also prepaid phones. China Mobile recently said it has 5.6 million phones on its net -- iPhones on its network as of the end of May
column538: and was adding them at an incredible rate. Obviously
column539: China Mobile doesn't sell the phone. So that would certainly point to a lot of a prepaid phones or unlocked phones on their network. I believe also your direct distribution in China for the iPhone
column540: both online and retail stores is in a prepaid fashion. So I was wondering if you could tell us how significant prepaid is in China and other emerging markets
column541: how much progress you've made there and what lessons you've learned given that you yourselves are also selling them prepaid? And I have a follow-up
column543:
"

Timothy Cook

"
column544:
"

Prepaid or unlocked phones are
column546: phones sold without a contract are very key in China and very key in a number of the emerging markets
column547: where the credit systems are not as well established as they are in the U.S.
column548: Japan and Western Europe and Australia
column549: et cetera. And so you can look at our volume
column550: Toni
column551: that the iPhone volume for the first 3 quarters of the fiscal year was up 5x year-over-year. And iPhone is the key contributor to Greater China having a cumulative revenue of around $8.8 billion for the first 3 quarters. And so I am not saying at all that we have figured out precisely how to play perfectly in the environment we have and I think we have more to do and more to learn. But I feel very
column552: very good about our progress. I think if any of us would have been told a year ago that we would do $3.8 billion in Greater China in a quarter
column553: I don't think very many of us would've believed it. And I don't think any of you would've believed that. And so we feel very
column554:
very good about it and we're taking those learnings and applying those to other markets as well.

"
column555:
"

Toni Sacconaghi - Sanford C. Bernstein & Co.
column556:
Inc.

"
column557:
"

If I could follow up
column558: your market share data is pretty irrefutable
column559: and it's pretty consistent in terms of your being a share gainer. There are parts of the world in developed countries like U.K.
column560: Germany
column561: France and Japan
column562: where some of the recent market data suggests that you've actually lost share in iPhones on a year-over-year basis in Q2. I was wondering if you could tell us whether gaining share in the smartphone category for iPhone is strategically important to Apple longer term
column563: and how we get our minds around sustained share gains given that most of the market data says smartphones above $300 are going to grow a lot slower than the overall smartphone market. So how do we: a
column564:
are share gains important to Apple in this marketplace; and how do we reconcile where you participate in its market growth rate relative to the overall market?

"
column565:
"

Timothy Cook

"
column566:
"

Share gain is important anywhere where we are going
column567: the opposite way then we're not happy. And you can bet that we're working hard to change that. In terms of playing in different price points
column568: we do offer the 3GS
column570: which in the U.S. is $49 with a contract. And if you step that out into prepaid market
column571: it really depends upon the VAT and duty and channel kind of uplifts as to what it is. So it varies greatly market-to-market. But it's clearly
column572: in a distinctly different price than the iPhone 4 is. Our philosophy is the same as it's always been
column573: Toni. We will only make products that we're proud of
column574: that are the best in the world
column575: and if we can do that and the price is lower then we're great with that. An example of that
column576: that happened some time ago is the iPod shuffle was created. It started at a different price point
column577: but it's now at $49 and that's because it's a product we're very proud of. It's very innovative. A lot of people love that product. So that's always the question for us in the litmus test. We will only make products that we're very proud of
column578: that we want to own
column579: that are the best in the world and regardless of what the price band analysis. Also
column580:
as we've seen and as I'm reminded time and time again as I look at some of the China data is it's up to us to convince people to maybe spend a little more for a materially better experience of product. And we think that people will do that if the product is great and if it's messaged appropriately and we got a lot of experience in both of those areas.

"
column581:
"

Operator

"
column582:
"

We'll hear from Brian Marshall with Gleacher & Company.

"
column583:
"

Brian Marshall - Gleacher & Company
column584:
Inc.

"
column585:
"

I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about what you've learned with respect to media consumption on the iPad thus far?

"
column586:
"

Timothy Cook

"
column587:
"

We learned that people love using it
column588: Brian
column589: for a whole variety of things. And that's the beauty of the iPad is that if you talk to 10 people
column590:
they would likely give you 10 different reasons why they love it. And I think that's the reason it's doing so well among a very diverse group of consumers in a diverse group of people in the market and geographies.

"
column591:
"

Brian Marshall - Gleacher & Company
column592:
Inc.

"
column593:
"

And then perhaps a quick follow-up. With respect to content accumulation in regards to video
column594: can you talk a little bit why we don't have more movie titles on iTunes at this point
column595:
and if we are going to be rectifying that in the future?

"
column596:
"

Peter Oppenheimer

"
column597:
"

Sure. Brian
column598: it's Peter. We have a very
column599:
very broad library of movies and TV shows particularly here in the United States. We are adding more content internationally each quarter and look for some more content later this quarter across the various stores. We have some neat stuff coming.

"
column600:
"

Nancy Paxton

"
column602: Brian. That concludes our Q&A session. A replay of today's call will be available for 2 weeks as a Podcast on the iTunes Store

And then financial analysts can contact either Joan Hoover or me with additional questions. Joan is at (408) 974-4570
column606:
and I'm at (408) 974-5420. And thanks again for joining us.

"

Operator

Ladies and gentlemen
column609:
that does conclude today's presentation. We do thank everyone for your participation.

column1:
{"Apple's CEO Discusses Q4 2011 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL)

"
column6:
"

Peter Oppenheimer - Chief Financial Officer and Senior Vice President

"
column8:

Timothy D. Cook - Chief Executive Officer and Director

column17:

column21:

column38: and welcome to the Apple Inc. Fourth Quarter Fiscal Year 2011 Earnings Release Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded. At this time
column40: I would like to turn the call over to Nancy Paxton
column41: Senior Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead
column45: and thanks to everyone for joining us. Please note that some of the information you'll hear during our discussion today will consist of forward-looking statements including without limitation
column46: those regarding revenue
column47: gross margin
column48: operating expenses
column49: other income and expense
column50: stock-based compensation expense
column51: taxes
column52:
earnings per share and future products. Actual results or trends could differ materially from our forecast.

"
column53:
"

For more information
column54: please refer to the risk factors discussed in Apple's Form 10-K for 2010
column55: Form 10-Q for the first 3 quarters of fiscal 2011 and the Form 8-K filed with the SEC today along with the attached press release. Apple assumes no obligation to update any forward-looking statements or information
column56:
which speak as of their respective dates.

"
column57:
"

I'd now like to turn the call over to Apple CEO
column58: Tim Cook
column59:
for introductory remarks.

"
column60:
"

Timothy D. Cook

"
column61:
"

Thanks
column62: Nancy. Good afternoon
column63: everyone. This is our first earnings call since the passing of Steve Jobs. The world has lost a visionary
column64: a creative genius and an amazing human being. Steve was a great leader and mentor and inspired everyone at Apple to do extraordinary things. His spirit will forever be the foundation of Apple
column65:
and we are dedicated to continuing the amazing work that he loved so much.

"
column66:
"

Only Apple brings together software
column67: hardware and services into such a powerful and integrated experience for our customers. As we move forward
column68:
we will continue doing that with relentless focus. I'd like to take this opportunity to express our gratitude for all of the condolences and expressions of support that we have received following Steve's passing.

"
column69:
"

With that
column70:
I'd like to turn over the call to Peter to discuss our Q4 results. Peter?

"
column71:
"

Peter Oppenheimer

"
column72:
"

Thank you
column73: Tim. We are very pleased to report record September quarter revenues and earnings. We set a new all-time quarterly record for Mac and iPad sales
column74:
and we established a new September quarter record for iPhone sales. We're very proud of these results and with the momentum of our business.

"
column75:
"

Revenue for the quarter was $28.3 billion
column76: representing year-over-year growth of 39%. The year-over-year increase was fueled primarily by strong growth in iPad
column77: Mac and iPhone sales. Operating margin was $8.7 billion
column78: representing 30.8% of revenue. Net income was $6.6 billion
column79:
increasing 54% year-over-year and translating to earnings per share of $7.05.

"
column80:
"

Turning to the details of the quarter. I'd like to begin with our Mac products and services. We established a new all-time quarterly record with sales of 4.89 million Macs
column81: exceeding the previous record set in the last December quarter by 760
column82: 000 Macs
column83:
representing a 26% increase over the year-ago quarter's results. That is more than 6x IDC's most recently published forecast of 4% growth for the PC market overall in the September quarter. Mac sales increased strongly in each of our operating segments led by Asia-Pacific with growth of 61% year-over-year.

"
column84:
"

The increase in Mac sales was fueled by the very strong growth in MacBook Air as well as the continued strong performance of MacBook Pro. In July
column85: we updated the MacBook Air with the next-generation processors
column86: high-speed Thunderbolt I/O technology and a backlit keyboard. And while the portables represented 74% of the total Mac mix
column87:
we also generated record desktop sales in the quarter primarily due to continued strength of iMac.

"
column88:
"

We launched Mac OS X Lion on July 20 and customer response has been tremendous with over 6 million Lion downloads during the September quarter. We began and ended the quarter with between 3 and 4 weeks of Mac channel inventory.

"
column89:
"

Moving to our music products. We sold 6.6 million iPods compared to almost 9.1 million in the year-ago quarter. Though down year-over-year
column90: total iPod sales were ahead of our expectations and iPod touch continue to account for over half of all iPods sold. iPod's share of the U.S. market for MP3 players remains at over 70% based on the latest monthly data published by MPD
column91:
and iPod continues to be the top-selling MP3 player in most countries we track based on the latest data published by GFK. We ended the quarter within our target range of 4 to 6 weeks of iPod channel inventory.

"
column92:
"

The iTunes Store generated record results with revenue in the quarter of almost $1.5 billion. The iTunes catalog continues to grow
column93:
and customers have downloaded over 16 billion songs and 650 million TV shows to date. We've also been very pleased with the growing popularity of the iBookstore with over 180 million downloads of iBooks to date.

"
column94:
"

I'd now like to turn to iPhone. We were very pleased to sell 17.1 million iPhones compared to 14.1 million in the previous September quarter. This represents 21% year-over-year growth and a new September quarter record. We experienced particularly strong iPhone sales growth in our Asia-Pacific segment where iPhone sales more than doubled year-over-year.

"
column95:
"

We were pleased with the iPhone sales growth as we prepared for the transition to the iPhone 4S. We expected iPhone sell-through to decline sequentially from the June quarter as a result of new product rumors following the announcement at our Developers Conference in June that iOS 5 and iCloud would become available in the fall. As we predicted
column96:
iPhone sell-through did decline across the quarter especially in the second half as new product speculation intensified.

"
column97:
"

We ended the quarter with about 5.75 million iPhones in channel inventory
column98: a sequential decline of about 180
column100: which places within our target range of 4 to 6 weeks of iPhone channel inventory. Recognized revenue from iPhone handset and accessory sales was $11 billion during the quarter compared to $8.8 billion in the year-ago quarter
column101:
an increase of 24%.

"
column102:
"

Given the October launch of the iPhone 4S
column103: we opted to defer new carrier and country additions from this September quarter until after the launch. As we indicated 2 weeks ago
column104: we were very pleased to have recently added Sprint and KDDI to our carrier line up. These additions bring us to 230 carriers in 105 countries. For the sixth consecutive time
column105: iPhone ranked highest in consumer reports
column106: wireless consumer smartphone customer satisfaction survey
column107: achieving the highest ratings for overall satisfaction as well as for performance
column108: ease of operations
column109:
features and design.

"
column110:
"

iPhone continues to be adopted as the standard across the enterprise with 93% of the Fortune 500 deploying or testing the device
column111: up from 91% last quarter and 60% of the Global 500 testing or deploying iPhone
column112: up from 57% last quarter. A recent example of iPhone's enterprise success is Lowe's. Lowe's is in the process of rolling out over 40
column113: 000 iPhones with a custom application to allow their store associates to execute realtime inventory checks
column114:
product orders and interactive customers with how-to videos.

"
column115:
"

Additional examples of companies around the world supporting iPhone on their corporate networks include L'Oreal
column116: Royal Bank of Scotland
column117: SAP
column118: Texas Instruments
column119: Jacobs Engineering Group
column120: Tenet Healthcare
column121: Jaguar Land Rover
column122: Takeda Pharmaceuticals
column123: Lincoln National and CSX Corporation. And of course
column124:
we're thrilled to begin shipping iPhone 4S this month.

"
column125:
"

We are extremely enthusiastic about Siri
column126: the iPhone 4 intelligent assistant that helps you get things done by just asking
column127: and we think customers will love the performance of the iPhone 4S' dual-core A5 chip
column128: all-new camera and full 1080p HD video recording. Now shipping in 7 countries
column129:
we are working hard to get iPhone 4S in customers' hands as quickly as possible. We look forward to rolling it out in 22 more countries by the end of this month.

"
column130:
"

Turning to iPad. We continue to be thrilled with its incredible momentum. We set a new record with sales of 11.1 million iPads during the September quarter compared to 4.2 million in the year-ago quarter
column131: an increase of 166%. We've said from the beginning that the tablet market is a huge opportunity for Apple
column132:
and we are very excited with our current performance and the tremendous customer enthusiasm for iPad.

"
column133:
"

We launched iPad 2 in additional 20 countries
column134: ending the September quarter with distribution in a total of 90 countries. Recognized revenue from sales of iPad and iPad accessories during the quarter were $6.9 billion compared to $2.8 billion in the year-ago quarter
column135:
an increase of 146%.

"
column136:
"

We ended the quarter with about 2.5 million iPads in channel inventory
column137: a sequential increase of about $1.45 million
column138: which places within the target range of 4 to 6 weeks. It's been just 18 months since we introduced iPad and the pace at which businesses worldwide are adopting this technology is unprecedented. Today
column139: 92% of the Fortune 500 are testing or deploying iPad within their enterprises
column140: up from 86% last year. Internationally
column141: 52% of the Global 500 are testing or deploying iPad
column142:
up from 47% last quarter.

"
column143:
"

Every day
column144: we learn about innovative new ways our enterprise customers are using iPad. The airline industry is a great example of the momentum we're seeing. United Continental Holdings is putting iPads in every cockpit to replace heavy
column145: paper-based flight bags. In Japan
column146:
All Nippon Airways is now using iPad in training programs for flight attendants.

"
column147:
"

Sonic Automotive is using iPad for customer check-in at the service department and also to provide analytics to regional managers. Aflac
column148: Biogen and General Mills have developed internal apps that their field sales teams leverage daily
column149:
and technicians of Siemens Energy are bringing iPads along when they do maintenance work at the top of their wind turbines.

"
column150:
"

Combining iPhone
column151: iPad and iPod touch
column152: we surpassed the 0.25 billion cumulative iOS device sales in the September quarter. We were very pleased to begin delivering iOS 5 last week and customers are loving its many new features
column153: including Notification Center
column154: iMessage
column155:
Newsstand and Reminders.

"
column156:
"

We're also very excited to launch iCloud last week
column157: with breakthrough services including iTunes in the Cloud
column158:
Photo Stream and Documents in the Cloud. We believe iCloud is the easiest way for customers to manage their content going far beyond anything else available today and early reviews have been excellent.

"
column159:
"

The App Store continues to be incredibly successful with over 500
column160: 000 apps available and over 18 billion downloads to date. We expanded the App Store to 33 additional countries during the September quarter
column161:
ending with a total of 123 countries.

"
column162:
"

I'd now like to turn to the Apple Retail Stores. Revenue was $3.6 billion
column163: an increase of 1% over the prior-year quarter. The stores experienced very strong year-over-year growth in Mac and iPad sales
column164: which was largely offset by decline in iPhone sales given the tough comparisons in the year-ago quarter when iPhone 4 was launched and compounded by speculation about a new iPhone this year. The stores generated record-breaking Mac results
column165: with sales reaching 1.1 million compared to 874
column166: 000 in the year-ago quarter
column167:
an increase of 25%. And about half of the Macs sold in our stores during the September quarter were to customers who had never owned a Mac before.

"
column168:
"

We opened 30 new stores in the quarter
column169: 21 of which were outside United States. On the last weekend of the quarter
column170: we opened 7 stores in 6 countries
column171: including our first store in Hong Kong. With our highest opening day for Mac sales ever
column172: our Hong Kong store joins our 5 other China stores as the highest traffic and among our highest revenue stores in the world. We ended the quarter with a total of 357 stores. With an average of 336 stores opened
column173:
average revenue per store was $10.7 million compared to $11.8 million in the year-ago quarter.

"
column174:
"

Retail segment margin was $679 million compared to $917 million in the year-ago quarter. Store traffic continues to be very strong. We hosted a record 77.5 million visitors in the September quarter. As we look ahead to fiscal 2012
column175: we will continue to focus on international expansion. In total
column176:
we expect to open about 40 stores with approximately 3/4 of them outside United States. We will also be expanding or replacing higher volume stores primarily in the U.S. that are simply too constrained to deliver our desired customer experience.

"
column177:
"

Total company gross margin was 40.3%
column178:
which was 230 basis points higher than our guidance. This difference was almost entirely due to lower component and other product costs. Operating expenses were $2.67 billion and included $253 million of stock-based compensation expense. OI&E was $81 million. The tax rate for the quarter was 24.7%.

"
column179:
"

Turning to cash. Our cash and short-term and long-term marketable securities totaled $81.6 billion at the end of the September quarter
column180: compared to $76.2 billion at the end of the June quarter
column181: a sequential increase of $5.4 billion. This increase was net of cash paid for the acquisition of Nortel patents and the Nokia settlement during the September quarter. Cash flow from operations was $10.4 billion
column182:
an increase of 84% year-over-year.

"
column183:
"

As we move ahead into the December quarter
column184: I'd like to review our outlook
column185: which includes the types of forward-looking information that Nancy referred to at the beginning of the call. I'd also like to remind you that approximately once every 6 years
column186:
we add a week to the December quarter to align our fiscal periods with the December calendar. So this December quarter will span 14 weeks rather than 13 and will end on December 31.

"
column187:
"

We expect revenues to be about $37 billion compared to $26.7 billion in the December quarter last year. We expect gross margin to be about 40%
column188: reflecting approximately $60 million related to stock-based compensation expense. We expect OpEx to be about $3.25 billion
column189: including about $350 million related to stock-based compensation. We expect OI&E to be about $85 million
column190:
and we expect the tax rate to be about 24.25%. We are targeting EPS of about $9.30.

"
column192: we're extremely pleased with the strong conclusion to our record-breaking fiscal 2011. Over the course of the year
column193: we generated revenue of over $108 billion
column194: an increase of $43 billion or 66% over our fiscal 2010 results. We blew past historical records by selling over 72 million iPhones
column195:
32 million iPads and almost 17 million Macs in fiscal 2011.

"
column196:
"

We expanded our reach by opening 40 new retail stores
column197: adding scores of new carrier and leaseholder relationships and broadened our online presence through Apple stores and App Stores around the world. And last but not the least
column198: we generated almost $26 billion in net income during the year
column199: an increase of 85% year-over-year
column200: which was even faster than our revenue growth. We're thrilled to begin selling iPhone 4S and to bring iOS 5 and iCloud to our customers this month
column201:
and we remain very enthusiastic about our new product pipeline.

Timothy D. Cook

column225:

Not entirely. If you look at on the sell-through basis
column226: the sequential comparison is down 2.4 million units. That's 19.7 million from the previous quarter
column227: which had an inventory build in it to bring it to a sell-in of over 20 million and to 17.3 million this quarter
column228: which had an inventory reduction of a little less than 200
column230: which Peter talked about in his opening remarks. That 2.4 million was much less of a reduction than what we were expecting and was a large factor in our revenue exceeding our guidance by over $3 billion. We expected it to be greater than 2.4 million because we knew that there was great anticipation of the June or July new iPhone because that was the pace that we have been on for the last several years. And as we had predicted
column231: that sell-through decline did occur in the quarter
column232: but not nearly to the extent that we fought and therefore
column233: we significantly beat our guidance. The reduction happened largely in the back half of the quarter as the speculation hit extreme highs. However
column234: we're thrilled to be shipping the new iPhone 4S and iOS 5 and iCloud
column235: and we're very confident that we will set an all-time record in the December quarter for iPhone sales. We -- in our wildest dreams
column236:
we couldn't have gotten off to a start as great as we have on the 4S.
