Yes
column261: thanks for the question. Should the China progress has been amazing
column262: if you look at our Greater China revenue
column263: it represented just 2% of Apple in our fiscal year '09. And in the fiscal year we just ended
column264: it accounted for 12%
column265: and if you just look at the quarter that we just ended
column266: it accounted for 16%. So it's our fastest growing major region by far. It delivered $4.5 billion of our revenue for the current quarter
column267: and that's up almost 4x or about 270% year-over-year. That brought the total revenue for the fiscal year to over $13 billion. And to further put that in context
column268: a year ago in fiscal year '10
column269: we were just right above $3 billion. So it is growing at a feverish pace. We have placed new retail stores there as you know. We now have 6 in Greater China. Our online store opened at the end of last year
column270: and so we have still -- we haven't hit our one-year anniversary there yet. We have over 200 Mono-branded stores that we call APRs
column271: which are resellers on there. That's a very premium shopping experience
column272: and we are now up to over 7
column273: 000 point of sales on the iPhone in Greater China. And so we're continuing to make investments in this. How far can it go? Certainly in my lifetime
column274: I've never seen a country with as many people rising into the middle class that aspire to buy products that Apple makes. And so I think it's an area of enormous opportunity
column275: and it has quickly become #2 on our list of top revenue countries very
column276: very quickly and we're obviously placing additional investment. We're building more stores there as well as doing quite a few other things to continue to deliver our great products to the people of China. We're also placing additional focus on some other areas that have shown great promise over this fiscal year such as Brazil. Brazil was up 118% year-over-year and went over the $900 million mark. Russia is also beginning to look more and more promising. As I've mentioned on the last call
column277: the Middle East we believe has significant opportunities. So there's several of these markets that historically Apple has not been strong and that the iPhone has really opened up and introduced Apple to a whole set of customers that didn't get excited about looking at other products that we have. And I think certainly
column278: the iPad will be doing the same. And so I think China
column279: the sky is the limit there
column280:
and I wouldn't discount some of these other places that I've mentioned as well.

It's a very good question. Our hearts go out to all the people in Thailand who have experienced these devastating losses of life and property as a result of the monsoons and the flooding. Like many others
column392: we source many components from Thailand and have multiple factories that supply these components. There are several factories that are currently not operable
column393: and the recovery timeline for these factories is not known at this point. As you can appreciate
column394: the weather really hasn't allowed an ability to assess those. From the work that we have done
column395: we would say that our primary exposure is on the Mac because as you point out
column396: of the number of drives or drive components that are sourced in or -- Thailand is a significant portion of the total of worldwide supply of drives. And so I can't give you a precise accounting. It is something that I'm concerned about. We do expect -- I'm virtually certain there will be an overall industry shortage of disk drives as a result of the disaster. How it affects Apple? I'm not sure
column397:
but we placed our assessment to the degree that we can make one in the guidance that Peter has already given you in the $37 billion number.

And so we'll assess each of those and decide what's in our best interest. But today
column513: I don't have anything to report there. The basic approach in all of the countries are the same as the game plan that we used in China
column514: and it's just a matter of the course
column515: the rate and pace of the rollout and whether to involve every one of the things that we did in China. In China

column517: we're doing in China. We would not be doing that in each of the other countries I named

column524:
"

Tim
column525: I was wondering first call as CEO
column526: any thoughts on
column527: any different strategy as far as cash allocation goes? And by that
column528: I mean
column529: dividend and a possible share buyback and maybe talk about these supplier investments also. And then the second question is
column530:
you mentioned the tablet market potentially being even bigger than the PC market at some point. Can you discuss the cannibalization levels that you think you're seeing right now versus the PC market?

"
column531:
"

Timothy D. Cook

"
column532:
"

Let me start with the second question first. I do believe that we're seeing cannibalization. I think that it's showing up in 2 ways. I think that some people are electing to buy an iPad rather than a Mac. However
column533: I believe a materially larger number of people are electing to buy an iPad instead of a Windows-based PC. And so I think we are overwhelmingly coming out very
column534: very well in that cannibalization question. And I would point out that despite that
column535: the Mac had its best quarter by far ever last quarter. And so even with having the best quarter on iPad with some cannibalizations in Mac
column536: the Mac has its best quarter ever
column537: which is almost unbelievable. And so with cannibalization like this
column538: I hope it continues. On your cash question
column540: we've wanted to maintain flexibility. I think everyone that knows us knows that the cash isn't burning a hole in our pocket and we're not the type of people to do silly things with it. We invest it conservatively. If you look at Gary and his team's track record
column541: they've done a phenomenal job in a extremely difficult market for the last few years. We've also taken money and done things with it that are in Apple's best interest. For example
column542: we've acquired several companies. We've acquired some IP as you know. We've invested in the supply chain
column543: and we used money to build out our stores and provide for a lot of new product tooling and the like. And so I believe what we're doing with cash
column544: the way we're -- this cash that we do spend we're doing an extremely good job of it and we're very frugal about using it and using it in the right places. That said
column545: I'm not religious about holding cash or not holding it. I'm religious about a lot of things but not that one. And so we will continually ask ourselves what's in Apple's best interest and always do what we believe is in Apple's best interest. And so it's a topic for the board on an ongoing basis
column546:
and we'll continue to discuss it.

"
column547:
"

Peter Oppenheimer

"
column548:
"

Scott
column549: I'd like to add to Tim's answer
column550: just to remind everybody that of the little over $81 billion of cash that we ended in the September quarter with
column551:
a bit more than $54 billion or 2/3 of that was offshore.

"
column552:
"

Operator

"
column554:
we'll hear from Mike Abramsky.

"
column555:
"

Mike Abramsky - RBC Capital Markets
column556: LLC
column558:
"

Tim
column559: just following up on your last question
column560: maybe I'll just ask this just absolutely directly. Is buying back shares with your cash
column561: which seems to be sort of the thing that everybody wants you to do
column562: at least certain investors want you to do it
column563:
is that perhaps kind of a philosophical white flag that you're not able to create value through product innovation?

"
column564:
"

Timothy D. Cook

"
column565:
"

Mike
column566: I think anyone looking at us and the track record that we've got would not come to any conclusion that we're waving a white flag on innovation. We've had a series of unbelievable products that we believe the best products in the world and our customers tell us that
column567: which is more importantly than us saying it
column568:
and we've got a pipeline that's unbelievable.

"
column569:
"

Mike Abramsky - RBC Capital Markets
column570: LLC
column571:
Research Division

"
column572:
"

Sorry
column573:
Tim. I didn't mean to convey that you were doing that. I meant to say that would that be holding you back philosophically from buying back shares?

"
column574:
"

Timothy D. Cook

"
column575:
"

No
column576: I view those to be totally separate and distinct things. So no
column577: I don't believe it sends that -- it certainly doesn't send that signal from my point of view. The cash is always a topic
column578: and we'll always conclude to do what we think is in Apple's best interest. And I think we've done that so far
column579: and if you look at where we've spent it
column580:
I think it's -- I think you would agree.

"
column581:
"

Mike Abramsky - RBC Capital Markets
column583:
Research Division

"
column584:
"

Okay. And then the original goal for the iPhone
column585: at the time it was obviously classed as audacious
column586: with 1% of the market in the first fiscal year after launch. And you achieved 5x that
column587: Tim. In the recent presentation when you highlighted that
column588:
there's 95% of the market to go. I'm wondering if in your minds you have established a similarly audacious goal for the next couple of years for market penetration.

"
column589:
"

Timothy D. Cook

"
column590:
"

Not one that I published
column591: but we want the iPhone to be in as many customers' hands as possible because we think it's the greatest phone by far. And that's why we live to do that. And so yes
column592: we aspire to much larger volumes than where we are. And we think the smartphone market will eventually absorb the handset market. As I made a point in that presentation
column593: the handset market is this huge market. It's 1.5 billion handsets. And the smartphone market
column594: depending upon which service you believe
column595: is a bit over 400 million or so. And so there's a huge growth in the smartphone market
column596: and then we think that we can also grow within the sector at all. But the big win is to eat into the 1.5 billion and not just for us but I think for others as well
column597:
and we are very focused on doing that. You can tell that with the moves that we've made recently.

"
column598:
"

Operator

"
column599:
"

We'll go to Keith Bachman with the Bank of Montr\u00e9al.

"
column600:
"

Keith F. Bachman - BMO Capital Markets U.S.

"
column602: first for you. Is the extra week for the quarter truly linear on both the revenues and the expenses? And included
column603: the reason I'm asking is just trying to set up
column604: if you will
column605: for the March quarter
column606:
the potential impact of that extra week on the March quarter.

"
column607:
"

Peter Oppenheimer

"
column608:
"

Sure
column609: Keith. The 14th week will conclude on New Year's Eve day
column610: which has traditionally been a good sell-through week for us but not typically as strong as the weeks between Thanksgiving and Christmas day. We'll provide further details on our January call about what we actually saw. That's some indication in terms of what we would see for sell-through. For our expenses
column611: we certainly will have variable expenses and payroll expenses for that 14th week. But some of our fixed cost such as leases and rents and such are fixed
column612:
so there will be a benefit there as well.

"
column613:
"

Keith F. Bachman - BMO Capital Markets U.S.

"
column614:
"

Okay. And my follow-up is on Japan. In terms of the year-over-year and sequential changes
column615: there was a bigger disparity on units versus revenues
column616:
CPU units versus total revenues in Japan. I was just wondering if you could speak to that if you could.

"
column617:
"

Timothy D. Cook

"
column619:
"

Keith F. Bachman - BMO Capital Markets U.S.

"
column620:
"

In terms of the revenue performance in Japan
column621: it looked to be a bigger disparity between the units and the revenues than was true in the other regions. I was just wondering why the bigger disparity in Japan. Was it FX
column624:
"

A huge percentage of Japan's total revenue in the year-ago quarter was from the iPhone 4 launch. It was iPhone 4's first quarter as you know. And so when you do a year-over-year compare
column625: that adversely affects the revenue compare. The Mac
column627: had an incredible quarter growing at 48% in a market that is barely growing at all. And so we gained significant share on the Mac side of the business. The iPhone was a negative year-over-year compare
column628: but we have gotten off to an unbelievable start in Japan. It was one of the first 7 countries
column629:
and it's very clear that Japan is yet another example of the delay that we were speaking about earlier.

"
column630:
"

Keith F. Bachman - BMO Capital Markets U.S.

"
column631:
"

Okay. So the sequential was then there was perhaps a larger delay in Japan for the iPhone 4S than other regions. Is that the way to think about it?

"
column633:
"

Think about it that iPhone is a bigger portion of the revenue [indiscernible].

"
column635:
"

And that will come from Chris Whitmore with Deutsche Bank.

"
column636:
"

Chris Whitmore - Deutsche Bank AG
column639: I wanted to ask about the medium to longer term iPad opportunity as you see it from an ASP standpoint or segmentation standpoint. And by that
column641: do you see more opportunity to move that product downmarket to drive elasticity
column642:
or upmarket to take on more of the -- or greater percentage on the PC market?

"
column644:
"

I don't want to get into what we might do
column645: which that answer might do. But let me just go back to -- we see the tablet market as a huge market
column646: and we could not be happier with our position in it. And we've got some fantastic things in the pipeline. And after selling 40 million in the first 18 months
column647: which is more than our wildest dreams were and selling 3 out of every 4
column648:
I think we've got a fairly good handle on what to do next.

"
column649:
"

Chris Whitmore - Deutsche Bank AG
column651:
"

Okay. Perhaps I can ask an initial feedback or expectations around the lower price points of the iPhone business into emerging markets. Can you comment at all or give some color on carrier receptivity of that pricing change and any acceleration in carrier engagements on the back of that?

"
column653:
"

Let me -- maybe I can answer that in 2 ways. If you look at the channel inventory on iPhone that was there at the end of Q4
column654: and so this is at the September 24 cutoff point for our quarter
column655: that was the 5.75 million that Peter mentioned in his opening comments. Over half of that has already sold through. And so one portion of the things driving that is the elasticity question that you're getting at there. We also did in a very few countries last quarter
column656: we dropped the 3GS price a bit early particularly in some of the prepaid markets to see what would occur on those markets
column657:
and we were extremely pleased with the results. It gave us even more conviction to follow through with the plan change that we made earlier in October.

"
column660: Chris. A replay of today's call will be available for 2 weeks as a podcast on the iTunes Store
column661:
as a webcast on apple.com/investor and via telephone. And the numbers for the telephone replay are (888) 203-1112 or (719) 457-0820. Please enter confirmation code 2922403. These replays will be available beginning at approximately 5:00 p.m. Pacific Time today.

"
column662:
"

Members of the press with additional questions can contact Steve Dowling at (408) 974-1896. And financial analysts can contact Joan Hoover or me with additional questions. Joan is at (408) 974-4570
column663:
and I'm at (408) 974-5420. Thanks again for joining us.

"
column666:
that does conclude today's presentation. We do thank everyone for your participation.

column1:
{"Apple's CEO Discusses Q1 2012 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL)

"
column6:
"

Peter Oppenheimer - Chief Financial Officer and Senior Vice President

"
column8:
"

Timothy D. Cook - Chief Executive Officer and Director

"
column10:
"

Keith F. Bachman - BMO Capital Markets U.S.

"
column13:

Benjamin A. Reitzes - Barclays Capital
column15:

Mark A Moskowitz - JP Morgan Chase & Co
column17:

Kulbinder Garcha - Cr\u00e9dit Suisse AG
column19:

Shannon S. Cross - Cross Research LLC

"

Research Division

"
column36: and welcome to this Apple Incorporated First Quarter Fiscal Year 2012 Earnings Release Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded. At this time
column38: I would like to turn the call over to Nancy Paxton
column39:
Senior Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

"
column40:
"

Nancy Paxton

"
column41:
"

Thank you. Good afternoon
column42: and thanks to everyone for joining us. Speaking today is Apple CFO
column43: Peter Oppenheimer. And he'll be joined by Apple CEO
column46:
for the Q&A session with the analysts.

"
column47:
"

Please note that some of the information you'll hear during our discussion today will consist of forward-looking statements including
column48: without limitation
column49: those regarding revenue
column50: gross margin
column51: operating expenses
column52: other income and expense
column53: stock-based compensation expense
column54: taxes
column55:
earnings per share and future products. Actual results or trends could differ materially from our forecast.

"
column56:
"

For more information
column57: please refer to the risk factors discussed in Apple's Form 10-K for 2011 and the Form 8-K filed with the SEC today along with the attached press release. Apple assumes no obligation to update any forward-looking statements or information
column58:
which speak as of their respective dates.

"
column59:
"

I'd now like to turn the call over to Peter Oppenheimer for introductory remarks.

"
column60:
"

Peter Oppenheimer

"
column61:
"

Thank you
column62: Nancy. We are thrilled to report the results of a tremendous quarter
column63: generating the highest quarterly revenue and earnings in Apple's history. We established numerous new records during the quarter
column64: including all-time highs for quarterly iPhone
column65:
iPad and Mac sales. We are very proud of these results and are extremely pleased with the momentum of our business.

"
column66:
"

Revenue for the quarter was $46.3 billion
column67: representing year-over-year growth of 73%. The increase was fueled primarily by strong growth in iPhone
column68: iPad and Mac sales
column69: and was also aided by the inclusion of a 14th week in the quarter
column70:
which we indicated previously.

"
column71:
"

Operating margin was $17.3 billion
column72: representing 37.4% of revenue. Net income was $13.1 billion
column73: increasing 118% over the prior December quarter's results
column74:
and equaling half of the net income generated in all of fiscal 2011. The quarter's net income translated to earnings per share of $13.87.

"
column75:
"

Turning to the details of the quarter. I'd like to begin with our Mac products and services. We established a new all-time quarterly record with sales of 5.2 million Macs
column76: setting new records for both desktops and portables. Mac sales grew 26% year-over-year compared to IDC's latest published forecast of 0 growth for the market overall in the December quarter. While total Mac sales benefited from the 14th week
column77: average weekly Mac sales were up strongly year-over-year across the quarter. Mac sales outgrew the market in each of our geographies with particular strength in our Asia-Pacific segment where sales were up 58% year-over-year. The increase in Mac sales was fueled by very strong growth of MacBook Pro and MacBook Air
column78:
as well as the continued strong performance of iMac. We began and ended the quarter with between 3 and 4 weeks of Mac channel inventory on a look-forward basis.

"
column79:
"

As we announced last month
column80: the Mac App Store has been a great success with customers downloading over 100 million apps in less than a year. The Mac App Store offers thousands of apps in education
column81: games
column82: graphics and design
column83: lifestyle
column84: productivity
column85: utilities and other categories
column86:
and has rapidly become a favorite shopping destination for Mac software.

"
column87:
"

Moving to our music products. We sold 15.4 million iPods compared to 19.4 million in the year-ago quarter. Total iPod sales were ahead of our expectations and iPod touch continued to account for over half of all iPods sold. iPod share of the U.S. market for MP3 players remains at over 70% based on the latest monthly data published by MPD. And iPod continued to be the top-selling MP3 player in most countries we track based on the latest data published by GFK.

"
column88:
"

We ended the quarter within our target range of 4 to 6 weeks of iPod channel inventory on a look-forward basis. The iTunes Store generated record results with revenue in the quarter of $1.7 billion. During the quarter
column89: we launched iTunes music stores in Brazil as well as 27 other countries in Latin America and Europe
column90: now offering a catalog of over 20 million songs from major recording labels
column91: as well as thousands of independent artists. And iTunes customers were amazingly busy on December 25
column92:
generating over 140 million downloads of apps and content that day.

"
column93:
"

I'd now like to turn to iPhone. We were thrilled to sell a record 37 million iPhones compared to 16.2 million in the previous December quarter. This represents 128% year-over-year growth compared to 40% growth for the smartphone market overall in the December quarter
column94: based on the latest published estimate from IDC. We experienced very strong iPhone sales growth in all of our segments
column95:
thanks primarily to the tremendous popularity of iPhone 4S.

"
column96:
"

Customers have been captivated by Siri
column97: which let's them use their voices to send messages
column98: place phone calls
column99: schedule appointments and more. Siri understands what users say
column100: knows what they mean and helps them with everyday tasks and information requests. iPhone channel inventory increased sequentially by about 200k
column101: leaving us with a little under 6 million iPhones in the channel at the end of the quarter
column102:
and below our target range of 4 to 6 weeks on a look-forward basis.

"
column103:
"

Recognized revenue from iPhone handset and accessory sales was $24.4 billion during the quarter compared to $10.5 billion in the year-ago quarter
column104: an increase of 133%. Nearly all of the top companies in the Fortune 500 now approve and support iPhone on their networks. This includes companies in markets such as financial services
column105: consumer products
column106: transportation
column107:
healthcare and insurance.

"
column108:
"

iPhone is changing the way companies across the globe use mobile devices for work. In addition to accessing e-mail
column109: calendar and contacts
column110: many of these companies are developing and deploying mission-critical iPhone apps to help improve productivity and give employees secure and immediate access to information anywhere. Many companies around the world have thousands of employees using iPhone and business apps. Some new examples include Royal Dutch Shell
column111: Credit Suisse
column112: Kimberly-Clark
column113: St. Jude Medical
column114: Providian
column115: Teradata
column116: Nike
column117: [indiscernible] and Facebook. We were very pleased to begin shipping iPhone 4S in China and 21 additional countries earlier this month. iPhone 4S is now available in over 90 countries
column118:
making this our fastest iPhone rollout ever.

"
column119:
"

Turning to iPad. We were very pleased with record sales of 15.4 million iPads during the December quarter compared to 7.3 million in the year-ago quarter
column120: an increase of 111%. iPad was extremely popular with holiday season buyers
column121:
and we remain very excited about the potential for this market.

"
column122:
"

Recognized revenue from sales of iPad and iPad accessories during the quarter increased by 99% year-over-year to over $9.1 billion compared to $4.6 billion in the year-ago quarter. iPad sales surpassed our expectations with sell-through exceeding sell-in by about 200
column123:
000 units. We exited the quarter within our target range of 4 to 6 weeks of iPad channel inventory on a look-forward basis.

"
column124:
"

iPad continues its unprecedented adoption in business. Nearly all of the top companies within major Fortune 500 markets including pharma
column125: manufacturing
column126: hospitality
column127: consumer products
column128: financial services
column129: healthcare and retail are actively using iPad to improve workflows
column130: business processes and customer engagements. We are delighted to learn how iPad enables businesses to change the way they work. Real estate agents at Coldwell Banker and Sotheby's access sales presentations and use custom iPad apps in the field. Retail chains such as Bed Bath & Beyond use iPads to deliver key business metrics on the sales floor. Wineries are using iPads in their vineyards to call up weather data and soil profiles
column131: record quality assessments and make decisions on the spot about whether to harvest their grapes. And in this past quarter
column132: Chinese airline
column133: EVA
column134: has also deployed iPads to pilots and crew for flight manuals
column135:
documentation and training.

"
column136:
"

iPad is extremely popular with students
column137: teachers and administrators as a wonderfully engaging and powerful tool for teaching and learning. Today
column138: 1.5 million iPads are already in use in education institutions
column139: including over 1
column140:
000 one-to-one deployments.

"
column141:
"

We were very pleased to announce iBooks 2 last week featuring iBook Textbooks to deliver educational content that is more interactive
column142: current and portable than ever from leading publishers
column143: including Houghton Mifflin
column144: McGraw-Hill and Pearson
column145: as well as thousands of independent publishers. And with iBooks Author
column146: anyone with a Mac can create iBook textbooks
column147: cookbooks
column148: picture books and more
column149: and publish them to Apple's iBook Store. And over 600
column150:
000 copies of iBooks Author have already been downloaded since last Thursday's announcement.

"
column151:
"

We were also happy to announce the all-new iTunes U App last week
column152: allowing students using iPads to have access to the world's largest catalog of free educational content
column153: along with over 20
column154: 000 education apps and hundreds of thousands of books in the iBookstore that can be used in their school curriculum. And as of today
column155:
over 3 million copies of iTunes U App have already been downloaded.

"
column156:
"

Combining iPhone
column157: iPad and iPod touch
column158: we surpassed 315 million cumulative iOS device sales
column159: selling more than 62 million in the December quarter. We were very pleased to launch iOS 5 and iCloud during the quarter. Customers are loving the new features of iOS 5
column160: including Notification Center
column161: iMessage and Reminders. And iCloud is off to a great start with more than 85 million customers signed up as of today. With iCloud
column162: customers can store their music and photos and documents and keep their personal information and content in sync across all their devices
column163:
automatically and seamlessly.

"
column164:
"

The App Store continues to be incredibly successful with over 550
column165: 000 apps available
column166: including 170
column167: 000 apps specifically for iPad. We are thrilled that by the end of this month
column168: our developers will have earned over $4 billion cumulatively from App Store sales
column169:
including over $700 million in the December quarter alone.

"
column170:
"

I'd now like to turn to the Apple retail stores
column171: which also generated record results. Revenue was $6.1 billion
column172: an increase of 59% over the prior year. The stores experienced very strong year-over-year growth in iPhone
column173: iPad and Mac sales
column174: establishing new records for all 3. iPhone sales were extremely robust
column175:
more than doubling year-over-year thanks primarily to the very successful launch of the iPhone 4S.

"
column176:
"

Sales of iPad were also up significantly year-over-year
column177: thanks to continued strength of iPad 2 and strong holiday season buying. The stores also sold 1.1 million Macs compared to 851
column178:
000 in the year-ago quarter. And about half the Macs sold in our stores during the December quarter were to customers who had never owned a Mac before.

"
column179:
"

We opened 4 new stores in the quarter
column180: including our spectacular new store at Grand Central
column181: as well as 3 stores in Europe
column182: bringing us to a total of 361 stores. With an average of 358 stores open
column183: average revenue per store was $17.1 million compared to $12 million in the year-ago quarter
column184:
an increase of 43%.

"
column185:
"

Segment margin reached a new record of over $1.8 billion and 30.3% of retail revenue compared to $1 billion and 26.2% in the year-ago quarter. Store traffic reached new record levels with 110 million visitors compared to 76 million visitors in the year-ago quarter
column186: an increase of 45%. That translates to an average of almost 22
column187: 000 visitors per store per week
column188:
reflecting incredible interest in our stores and our products.

"
column189:
"

Our EasyPay checkout process has significantly enhanced our ability to handle such high customer traffic levels. And now
column190: with personal pick up
column192: iPods or iPads from the Apple online store and pick up most in-stock products within 1 hour at the Apple Retail Store of their choice
column193:
making shopping for Apple products that much easier and faster.

"
column194:
"

Total company gross margin was 44.7%
column195:
which was 470 basis points higher than our guidance. About half of this difference was driven by lower commodity and other product costs. Another quarter was due to leverage on the higher revenue and some onetime items benefiting the quarter. And the remainder was due to better-than-expected mix largely from the record iPhone sales.

"
column196:
"

Operating expenses were $3.36 billion
column197: and included $357 million in stock-based compensation expense. OI&E was $137 million
column198:
and the tax rate for the quarter was 25.25%.

"
column199:
"

Turning to our cash. Our cash for short-term and long-term marketable securities totaled $97.6 billion at the end of the December quarter compared to $81.6 billion at the end of September quarter
column200:
a sequential increase of $16 billion. About $64 billion of the cash was offshore at the end of the December quarter.

"
column201:
"

Cash flow from operations was over $17.5 billion. We are actively discussing uses of our cash balance and don't have anything specific to announce today. In the meantime
column202:
we continue to be very disciplined with the cash and are not letting it burn a hole in our pockets.

"
column203:
"

As we move ahead into the March quarter
column204: which will be 13-week quarter
column205: I'd like to review our outlook
column206:
which includes the types of forward-looking information that Nancy referred to at the beginning of the call.

"
column207:
"

We expect revenue to be about $32.5 billion
column208: compared to $24.7 billion in the March quarter last year. We expect gross margin to be about 42%
column209: reflecting approximately $60 million related to stock-based compensation expense. We expect OpEx to be about $3.05 billion
column210:
including about $350 million related to stock-based compensation.

"
column211:
"

We expect OI&E to be about $125 million
column212:
and we expect the tax rate to be about 25.25%. We are targeting EPS of about $8.50.

"
column213:
"

In closing
column214: we are extremely pleased with customer response to our products and the record-breaking results in the December quarter. We launched iPhone 4S to rave reviews
column215: delivered iOS and iCloud to millions of customers and surpassed all previous records for quarterly iPhone
column216:
iPad and Mac sales. We are very proud to be delivering the strongest product lineup in Apple's history and we are extremely enthusiastic about our new product pipeline.

"
column217:
"

With that
column218:
I'd like to open the call to questions.

"
column219:
"

Benjamin A. Reitzes - Barclays Capital
column226:

column227:
"

Tim and Peter
column228:
can you describe the iPhone momentum as you ended the quarter? And what is included for the iPhone in your guidance and your enthusiasm for the product as we head into the first half of the calendar year? Any more detail in metrics would be helpful.

"
column229:
"

Timothy D. Cook

"
column230:
"

Sure
column231: Ben. This is Tim. We were thrilled with the 37 million iPhones that we sold. It's up 128% against a market rate of growth of about 40%
column232: according to IDC's latest projection. And this is substantially above the 20 million unit previous record. We would attribute it to a -- just a breathtaking customer reception of the iPhone 4S with iOS 5
column233: and key features such as Siri and this incredible camera with advanced optics. Customers are absolutely loving this product. We also attribute it to -- we made a very bold bet entering the quarter as to what the demand would be. And as it turns out
column234: despite it being a very bold bet
column235: we were short of supply throughout the quarter and did end with a significant backlog as Peter has said. That situation has improved some since the end of the quarter
column236: but we still are short in some key geographies currently. I would also attribute the performance to the delayed purchases from the prior quarter as we discussed in the October call as the -- people were anticipating a new iPhone being announced. I think we made the correct decision to go with a broad range of iPhones. It turned out to be a benefit as we thought it would. And of course
column237: the 14th week
column239: is a part of this
column240: although everyone knew that
column241: as we did as well
column242: and factored that into our guidance. Geographically
column243: we saw strength in literally in every key region. But in particular
column244: I would call out that U.S. and Japan
column245: which got billing early in the quarter and had most sale -- many more sales days than most countries. I would also say that was particularly huge with the iPhone sales in Greater China
column246: particularly considering that we did not launch the iPhone 4S in China until in January. And therefore
column247: had no sales into mainland China during last quarter. And so we could not be happier. We felt we were betting bold
column248: as I think many of you would have thought if you would have known what we were doing. But as it turns out
column249:
we didn't bet high enough. Our customers are loving iPhone and we're very happy with that.

"
column250:
"

Benjamin A. Reitzes - Barclays Capital
column252:
"

My follow-up is
column253: as we're doing the math here
column254: it seems like the ASP is up sequentially for the iPhone. So it seems like there was a very good mix of the 4S and the higher capacity 4S
column255:
could you just comment a little bit on that versus the iPhone 4 which you cut the price of?

"
column256:
"

Timothy D. Cook

"
column257:
"

The iPhone 4S was the most popular iPhone during the quarter. And consistent with most launches
column258:
we typically see a higher mix of the front end of the launch.

column275: I would say the demand there has been staggering. We are selling through our reseller stores and our online store. We're not currently selling through a retail store. And the demand is off the charts. And so we're very happy with the demand response there. The other countries that we launched in earlier this quarter were smaller countries in a demand sense. And so we'll see how the quarter goes from a supply-demand point of view. We did make progress as we moved from the end of the quarter until now
column276: as I alluded to earlier
column277: and got caught up in some countries
column278:
but there is still some that we are not caught up. So we'll see how we'll do going forward.

column282: that component environment stays favorable on most key commodities with the exception of hard drives which
column284: was very much affected by the tragic situation in Thailand. And I don't predict Apple having a material supply issue during the quarter
column285:
but we will pay more for drives during the quarter. And that's reflected in our guidance that Peter gave earlier.

column319: which benefited us in the December quarter

Okay. Great. I have a question on the iPad. Obviously
column337: a very strong shipment number for the December quarter. But with that said

column340:

column341:

Timothy D. Cook

column342:

We're really happy with the 15.4 million iPads that we were able to sell. And as Peter said
column343: we did take down the channel inventory slightly. There's the -- underlying sell through was slightly higher than that. This is consistent with our long-term beliefs that we've had since -- before we introduced the product
column344: that this is a huge opportunity for Apple over time. And as I've said before
column345: I truly believe
column346: and many others in the company believe
column347: that there will come a day that the tablet market and units is larger than the PC market. In fact
column348: it's interesting to note that in the U.S.
column349: it's clear from the IDC's recent data on desktop PCs in the U.S.
column350: that tablets exceeded desktop PC sales last quarter in the U.S. And so I think you can already see different indicators that there is significant momentum in this space. In terms of our competitiveness
column351: the ecosystem for iPad is in a class by itself. We strongly believed in optimizing applications from day one to take advantage of the larger canvas
column352: and we now have apps totaling over 170
column353: 000 available for customers. And that compares to what appears to us to be only a few hundred for the competition. And so I think people really want to do multiple things with their tablets. And therefore
column354:
we don't really see these limited function tablets and e-readers being in the same category. There is clearly customers that will buy those. I think they'll sell a fair number of units. But I don't think that people that want an iPad will settle for a limited function.

column355:
"

And in terms of other tablets
column356: last year was supposed to be the year of the tablet. I think most people would agree
column357:
it was the year of the iPad for the second year in a row. And so we're just going to continue to innovate like crazy in this area. And we think we can continue to compete with anyone that is currently shipping tablets or that might enter in the future.

Timothy D. Cook

Each of the models

column373: there's a much smaller difference between what the customer pays in each of these. It's larger in the prepaid markets
column374: and so it's too early to tell given we just started this October as to how this will play out over time. But we're thrilled with the total result
column375:

The factors that are -- Tony
column415: that are going to affect our sequential decline are primarily 3. They are the loss of leverage from the revenue
column416: so we reported $46.3 billion this quarter
column417: which included a 14th week. We see our revenues being $32.5 billion next quarter. So against our fixed cost that will have a significant impact. We did have some onetime items in the December quarter which won't recur
column418: and the dollar is much stronger. So those are the principal 3 reasons. I would also say that 44.7 is a high
column419: high
column420: higher than we have seen since I've been with Apple in 15 years. And it's hard to compare this year versus last because we're in different commodity cycles and different currency levels and where we are with our product cycles as well. Last year
column421: we did have a sequential increase in iPhones
column422: and that was a big contributor to our going up sequentially. We don't see that reoccurring  this year

Okay. And for my follow-up
column517: I wanted to ask about your revenue guidance for the March quarter. If you assume kind of weekly sales are adjust for the 14th week
column518: it looks like you're guiding revenue down to about 25% quarter-on-quarter. However
column519: you started the quarter with a pretty significant backlog of iPhones
column520: et cetera
column521:
pretty strong momentum. Why would revenue be down more than normal seasonal or just historical seasonal end of March?

"
column523:
"

Chris
column524: this is Peter
column525: I'll take that. Let me first start with units and then I'll talk about some points on revenue. iPhone
column526: we would expect to have a significant year-over-year increase and be down sequentially
column527: as we reported from the 14-week December quarter. For iPad
column528: we would expect to have a significant year-over-year increase
column529: and also be down sequentially as reported from the 14-week December quarter and the end of the gift-giving season. And for Mac and iPod
column530: we would expect to be down sequentially consistent with our typical seasonality. From a revenue perspective
column531: I completely understand the question that you're asking
column532:
and I want to talk to you about 5 reasons why I expect the -- us to be down in greater percent sequentially this year than we were last.

"
column533:
"

The first
column534: the December quarter this year included a 14th week
column535: which was the week between Christmas and New Year's. That week accounted for approximately 1/14 of the December quarter's revenue. Second
column536: that week between Christmas and New Year's
column537: fell within the March quarter last year and it will not be included this year. And sales in that week are typically greater than the average for the weekly sales in the March quarter. So when we think about our March quarter on a sequential basis
column538: we would have loved to add that week in the quarter that we're now heading into. Last year
column539: we increased the iPhone channel inventory by about 1.7 million units in the December quarter
column540: so -- or this March quarter
column541: so that benefited the quarter and reduced the comparable. The fourth
column542: our December quarter results this fiscal year benefited from the launch of the iPhone 4S. We believe there were significant pent-up demand for the iPhone 4S heading into the December quarter
column543: and it's been our fastest iPhone rollout ever. The previous iPhone launch took place at the end of June 2010. So in the year-ago December quarter marked the second full quarter of new iPhone availability. So we have some differences in launch timing. And finally
column544: the U.S. dollar has strengthened in recent weeks
column546: and we expect this to have an impact on our sequential compare. Last year
column547: the dollar was relatively flat within the comparable time period. All that being said
column548:
we just reported an amazing quarter and we feel very good about the momentum of our business.

column597: and we've more than begun to go deeper into Brazil. But I don't want to signal that

column599: because I don't envision that occurring in the near term. In India where it is small
column600: the revenue went up over 3x last quarter
column601: but that's on a small base. And so we're beginning to see traction in most of these
column602:
but we recognize we have to focus to deeply understand the point that we can really get to a large revenue figure like Greater China currently is.

"
column603:
"

In terms of more carriers
column604: we have been adding carriers. I anticipate we'll continue to add carriers. We have nothing specific to announce today
column605: but you can bet that we're looking at the same list that you are. In terms of major carriers there
column606: the number is much smaller than the number you quoted
column607: as you know
column608: there is a lot of smaller carriers on there. And the same thing with countries
column609: there's many smaller countries. But all of those are important
column610:
I'd like to get into all of them over time.

"
column611:
"

Operator

"
column612:
"

From JPMorgan
column613:
we'll go to Mark Moskowitz.

"
column614:
"

Mark A Moskowitz - JP Morgan Chase & Co
column615:
Research Division

"
column616:
"

Tim
column617: I want to come back to the tablet market here. Obviously
column618: the iPhone was scintillating in terms of the growth
column619: but I think the iPad growth also really outpaced a lot of our expectations. And the question really is -- it's kind of a loaded question. The question is really around -- do you think that Apple actually benefited from some of these lower cost
column620: reduced features that tablets come into the market
column621: where folks came in to check them out and realized not really that good
column622:
so they trade up to the iPad? And do you see that may be happening as well with the MacBook Air this year? Because this year seems like to be the ultrabook's version of \"Let's try to be like Apple as well.\"

"
column626: particularly in the U.S. on a weekly basis
column627: after Amazon launched the Kindle Fire. And I wouldn't
column629: there wasn't an obvious effect on the numbers plus or minus. The theory that you've got
column630: I have heard clearly from some customers that
column632: that they went in thinking that they would buy that
column633: they'd look at it and decided to buy an iPad. Whether that's happening on a very
column636: my own view is looking at our data in the U.S.
column637: there was no obvious change in the data
column638: for what it's worth. That's how I see it. There is cannibalization clearly of the Mac by the iPad
column639: but we continue to believe there is much more cannibalization of Windows PCs by the iPad and there's many more of them to cannibalize. And so we love that trend. We think it's great for us. The thing that is very different about the iPad is you can see it beginning to appear virtually everywhere. The enterprise has adopted it in a very large percent of the Fortune 500
column640: as Peter talked about earlier. That number is also quite large when you look at the Global 500. In education
column642: we sold twice the number of iPads as we did Macs. And generally speaking
column643: education adopts new technologies fairly slowly
column644: so that's somewhat surprising. And of course
column645: the consumer is -- has moved in a huge way to iPad. And so it's winning market by market
column646: by market. I think that consumers that go in and look at it and think about the ecosystem and the huge advantages and the overall customer experience
column647: I think we will win a fair number of those. And I think you can see that in the results. And so we couldn't be happier with doing over 15 million. And I think it's remarkable that we sold over 55 million iPads
column648: and we've only been in the business April of 2011
column650: when we shipped the first one -- or 2010
column652:
"

Mark A Moskowitz - JP Morgan Chase & Co
column654:
"

And then the other question I have is given your customer data
column655: are you seeing any sort of phenomena now where
column656: because of the accelerated refresh cycles
column657: the widened gap in terms of what Apple has given to the customer base versus the competition's meager efforts
column658: if you will? Are you seeing accelerated refresh rates within your customer base in terms of someone who buys an iPhone
column659: maybe they're buying it quicker or maybe they're also buying now a MacBook Air or an iPad
column660:
do you see an accelerated refresh rate or a halo effect?

"
column664: we've seen iPhones sort of being a catalyst. And the iPad moves after the iPhone. And in several accounts
column665: we've seen the Mac follow that. And so there are clear examples where one product has pulled the other. And at a macro level
column667: it's very difficult to put our fingers on
column672: they're all pointing that out. And as you know
column673: we've seen that phenomenon before with the halo that the iPod created for the Mac back at the early 2002
column675:
2004 range. And so it's not a phenomenon that is new to us.

"
column678:
we'll go to Mike Abramsky with RBC Capital Markets.

"
column679:
"

Mike Abramsky - RBC Capital Markets
column685:
becoming a 2-horse race similar to Mac versus Windows? And how do you see the sustainability of your integrated model versus what happened in terms of the growth of the OEM model in the PC market?

"
column687:
"

I wouldn't classify it like Mac and Windows at all. The Mac has outgrown the market for over 20 quarters in a row
column688: but still has a single-digit percentage of the worldwide market
column690: if you look at phones and tablets
column692: we've sold over 315 million iOS devices. And so I think this compares very favorable to any comparison
column693: and over 62 million of those were done in the last quarter alone. I don't have comparable numbers
column695: on Android. I haven't found a way to get very crisp quarterly reporting like we do that is straightforward and transparent. However
column696: you can see from a momentum point of view
column697: if you look at the MPD data that just came out a few days ago
column699: and this is just looking at October
column700: November and so this had part of our launch in October and then all of it in November
column701: it shows that just the iPhones
column702: looking at phones not total iOS
column703: it shows iPhone at 43% and Android at 47%. The Nielsen data that just came out a few days ago shows iPhone in the October
column705: December timeframe at 45% versus Android at 47%. And the comScore data that also came out on October
column706:
November shows iPhone at 42% versus Android at 41%. And so it seems like all of the data that I've seen in the U.S. would say that it's a very close race in iPhone.

"
column707:
"

I think on the iPad side
column708: although I don't have specific numbers to share from third parties
column709: I think that all of us inherently believe that iPad is way ahead there. And there's really no comparable products to the iPod touch out there. And so iOS is doing extremely well. I wouldn't say it's 2-horse race. There's a horse in Redmond that always suits up and always runs
column710:
and will keep running. And there's other players that we can never count out. And so what we focus on is innovating and making the world's best products. And we'll just keep on doing that and somewhat ignore how many horses there are. And we just want to stay ahead and be the lead one.

"
column711:
"

Mike Abramsky - RBC Capital Markets
column715: just as a quick follow-up. There's 2 developments in the market on -- in smartphones that you sort of haven't approached yet
column716: but Android has at least approached
column717: which would be 4G and larger screens. In the past
column718: you've articulated a fairly firm view both on the iPad and the iPhone of display dimensions
column720: you mentioned that earlier in this call in iPad. Has the popularity
column722: of larger screens on Android phones changed or impacted
column724: your view? And same thing on 4G obviously
column725: some of these phones have challenges to battery life
column726:
but what are your thoughts there?

"
column729: I wouldn't comment on the future roadmap
column730:
I'm sure that's a shock to you. But I would point out that we just sold a record 37 million iPhones. And so I think there's an incredible number of people -- and we could have sold more if we would have had more supply. But there's a lot of people out there that really love what we're doing.

"
column732:
"

A replay of today's call will be available for 2 weeks at the Podcast on the iTunes Store
column733:
as a webcast on apple.com/investor and via telephone. And the numbers for the telephone replay are (888) 203-1112 or (719) 457-0820. Please enter confirmation code 178-9848. And these replays will be available beginning at approximately 5:00 p.m. Pacific time today.

"

"

Members of the press with additional questions can contact Steve Dowling at (408) 974-1896. And financial analysts can contact Joan Hoover or me with additional questions. Joan is at (408) 974-4570 and I'm at (408) 974-5420. And thanks again for joining us.

"
column737:
that does conclude today's presentation. We do thank everyone for your participation.

Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL)

column38: and welcome to this Apple Incorporated Second Quarter Fiscal Year 2012 Earnings Release Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded. At this time
column40: I would like to turn the call over to Nancy Paxton
column41: Senior Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead
column45: and thanks to everyone for joining us. Speaking today is Apple CFO
column46: Peter Oppenheimer; and he'll be joined by Apple CEO
column47: Tim Cook; and Treasurer
column48:
Gary Wipfler for the Q&A session with analysts.

"
column49:
"

Please note that some of the information you'll hear during our discussion today will consist of forward-looking statements
column50: including
column51: without limitation
column52: those regarding revenue
column53: gross margin
column54: operating expenses
column55: other income and expense
column56: stock-based compensation expense
column57: taxes
column58: earnings per share and future products. Actual results or trends could differ materially from our forecast. For more information
column59: please refer to the risk factors discussed in Apple's Form 10-K for 2011
column60: the Form 10-Q for the first quarter of fiscal 2012 and the Form 8-K filed with the SEC today along with the attached press release. Apple assumes no obligation to update any forward-looking statements or information
column61:
which speak as of their respective dates.

"
column62:
"

I'd now like to turn the call over to Peter Oppenheimer for introductory remarks.

"
column63:
"

Peter Oppenheimer

"
column64:
"

Thank you
column65: Nancy. We're very pleased to report the results of our outstanding second fiscal quarter. We established new March quarter records for iPhone
column66: iPad and Mac sales
column67:
leading to our highest March quarter revenue and earnings ever.

"
column68:
"

Revenue for the quarter was $39.2 billion
column69:
representing year-over-year growth of 59%. That's a new record for a March quarter and is second only to the all-time record revenue we reported in the most recent December quarter. The year-over-year increase in March quarter revenue was fueled primarily by very strong growth in iPhone and iPad sales.

"
column70:
"

Operating margin was $15.4 billion
column71: representing 39.3% of revenue. Net income was $11.6 billion
column72:
increasing 94% over the prior March quarter's result. The quarter's net income translated to earnings per share of $12.30.

"
column73:
"

Turning to the details of the quarter
column74: I'd like to begin with our Mac products and services. We established new March quarter records for both desktops and portables
column75: combining for a total of 4 million Macs sold. This represents growth of 7% year-over-year compared to IDC's latest published forecast of 2% growth for the global personal computer market in the March quarter. We began and ended the quarter with between 3 and 4 weeks of Mac channel inventory
column76:
which is below our target range of 4 to 5 weeks.

"
column77:
"

In February
column78: we released the developer preview of Mountain Lion
column79: the ninth major release of Mac OS X. Mountain Lion will bring popular apps and features from iPad to the Mac
column80: including Messages
column81: Notes
column82: Reminders
column83: Game Center
column84: Notification Center
column85: Share Sheets
column86:
Twitter integration and AirPlay Mirroring. We expect Mountain Lion to be available from the Mac App Store in late summer this year.

"
column87:
"

Moving to our music products. We sold 7.7 million iPods compared to 9 million in the year ago quarter. Total iPod sales were ahead of our expectations
column88: and iPod touch continued to account for over half of all iPods sold. iPod's share of the U.S. market for MP3 players remains at over 70% based on the latest monthly data published by MPD
column89:
and iPod continued to be the top-selling MP3 player in most countries we track based on the latest data published by GFK.

"
column90:
"

We ended the quarter within our target range of 4 to 6 weeks of iPod channel inventory.

"
column91:
"

The iTunes Store generated all-time record results with revenue of almost $1.9 billion in the March quarter
column92: an increase of 35% year-over-year
column93: thanks to continued strong sales of music
column94: video and apps. We now have a catalog of over 28 million songs and 45
column95:
000 movies.

"
column96:
"

I'd now like to turn to iPhone. We were thrilled to sell 35.1 million iPhones compared to 18.6 million in the previous March quarter. That represents 88% year-over-year growth compared to 42% growth for the smartphone market overall in the March quarter based on the latest published estimate from IDC. We experienced very strong iPhone sales growth in all of our segments
column97: led by our Asia Pacific and Japan segments where sales more than doubled year-over-year. We continue to see tremendous momentum in Greater China
column98: where iPhone sales were 5x the level of the year ago quarter
column99:
aided by the launch of the iPhone 4S in China in January and the addition of China Telecom as an iPhone carrier in March. IPhone 4S is now available in over 100 countries and is sold through over 230 carriers.

"
column100:
"

We ended the quarter with about 8.6 million iPhones in channel inventory
column101: a sequential increase of about 2.6 million units
column102:
which placed us within our target range of 4 to 6 weeks of iPhone channel inventory.

"
column103:
"

Recognized revenue from iPhone handset and accessory sales was $22.7 billion during the quarter compared to $12.3 billion in the year ago quarter
column104:
an increase of 85%.

"
column105:
"

iPhone momentum in the enterprise has evolved beyond email
column106: calendar and contacts. IT and business line managers across industries see the opportunity to leverage both company and employee-owned devices to improve productivity and efficiencies through iOS in-house app development. In fact
column107:
the majority of the Fortune 500 companies who have approved iPhone on their networks are members of the iOS Developer Enterprise Program and are actively deploying in-house applications to their employee base.

"
column108:
"

Turning to iPad. We were very pleased with sales of 11.8 million iPads during the March quarter compared to 4.7 million in the year ago quarter
column109: an increase of 151%. Customers are loving the new iPad with its stunning Retina display
column110: A5X chip with Quad-core graphics and the 5-megapixel iSight camera. The new iPad is now available in over 40 countries
column111:
and we saw a very strong growth in iPad sales around the world with sales more than doubling in each of our segments.

"
column112:
"

Recognized revenue from sales of iPad and iPad accessories during the quarter was $6.6 billion compared to $2.8 billion in the year ago quarter
column113: an increase of 132%. We ended the quarter with about 2 million iPads in channel inventory
column114: a sequential decrease of about 300
column115: 000 units
column116:
which placed us below our target range of 4 to 6 weeks of iPad channel inventory.

"
column117:
"

The education market's interest in iPad continues to grow. In the March quarter
column118: we sold more than 2 iPads for every Mac to our U.S. K-12 customers while also generating a record quarter for Mac sales. The San Diego School District purchased 10
column119: 000 iPads in the March quarter and plans to purchase over 15
column120:
000 more in the June quarter for middle school and high school programs.

"
column121:
"

iPad continues to open doors to new customers with whom Apple previously had no relationship. As we enter the K-12 institution buying season
column122:
we're hopeful that iPad will be a popular choice.

"
column123:
"

iPad's momentum in business and government also continues to build. The United States Air Force Air Mobility Command is deploying thousands of iPads to serve as electronic flight bags
column124: storing technical publications and operations information for flight crew members and trainers. Companies such as Bechtel and Balfour Beatty are using iPads in the field for project management and viewing blueprints. And thousands of iPads are being deployed as mobile sales tools by companies such as Roche
column125: Amgen
column126: Bayer and Daiichi Sankyo. Combining iPhone
column127: iPad and iPod touch
column128: we surpassed 365 cumulative iOS device sales
column129:
selling more than 50 million in the March quarter. The iOS ecosystem continues to expand and thrive with stores in more than 120 countries.

"
column130:
"

The App Store now offers more than 600
column131: 000 apps
column132: including over 200
column133:
000 apps specifically for iPad. We were very excited to announce the download of the 25th billionth app in March less than 4 years after the launch of the App Store.

"
column134:
"

And iCloud is off to an incredible start
column135:
currently with more than 125 million customers signed up since its launch in October.

"
column136:
"

I'd now like to turn to the Apple retail stores
column137: which also generated record March quarter results. Revenue was $4.4 billion
column138: an increase of 38% over the year ago quarter and was second only to the record quarterly revenue generated in the December quarter. The stores experienced very strong year-over-year growth in iPad and iPhone sales
column139: and they sold 826
column140: 000 Macs compared to 797
column141:
000 in the year ago quarter. And about half the Macs sold in our stores during the March quarter were to customers who had never owned a Mac before.

"
column142:
"

We opened 2 new stores in the quarter
column143: including our first Netherlands store in Amsterdam and a beautiful new store in Houston. We exited the quarter with 363 stores
column144: nearly 1/3 of which are outside the United States. With an average of 361 stores open
column145: average revenue per store was $12.2 million compared to $9.9 million in the year ago quarter
column146: an increase of 23%. Segment margin reached a new March quarter record of over $1.1 billion
column147: which was 26.1% of retail revenue. We welcomed 85 million visitors to our stores during the quarter compared to 71 million visitors in the year ago quarter
column148: an increase of 19%. That translates to an average of 18
column149:
000 visitors per store per week.

"
column150:
"

Total company gross margin was 47.4%
column151: which was 540 basis points higher than our guidance. About half this difference was driven by lower-than-expected commodity and other costs; about 1/4 was due to stronger-than-expected revenue and product mix
column152:
including 35 million iPhones; and the remainder was due to some onetime items that we don't expect to recur in the June quarter.

"
column153:
"

Operating expenses were $3.2 billion and included $361 million in stock-based compensation expense. OI&E was $148 million.

"
column154:
"

Turning to cash. Our cash for short-term and long-term marketable securities totaled $110.2 billion at the end of the March quarter compared to $97.6 billion at the end of the December quarter
column155:
a sequential increase of $12.6 billion. And about $74 billion of the cash was offshore at the end of the March quarter. Cash flow from operations was $14 billion.

"
column156:
"

As we indicated last month
column157: subject to board declaration
column158:
we expect to announce a dividend of $2.65 [ph] per share when we report our third quarter results in July. And we will provide information on the record and payment dates at that time.

"
column159:
"

As we move ahead into the June quarter
column160: I'd like to review our outlook
column161: which includes the types of forward-looking information that Nancy referred to at the beginning of the call. We expect revenue to be about $34 billion compared to $28.6 billion in the June quarter last year. We expect gross margin to be about 41.5%
column162: reflecting approximately $70 million related to stock-based compensation expense. We expect OpEx to be about $3.3 billion
column163:
including about $385 million related to stock-based compensation. We expect OI&E to be about $175 million. And we expect the tax rate to be about 25.25%. We are targeting EPS of about $8.68.

"
column164:
"

In closing
column165: we're extremely pleased with our record March quarter performance with earnings nearly doubling year-over-year. The new iPad is off to a tremendous start and is our fastest iPad rollout ever. We're thrilled with the global success of the iPhone 4S
column166: which is now available in more than 100 countries
column167:
including China.

"
column168:
"

We remain very confident in our strategy
column169: and we're very excited about the fabulous new products in our pipeline. With that
column170:
I'd like to open the call to questions.

"
column171:
"

Nancy Paxton

"
column172:
"

Thank you
column173: Peter. [Operator Instructions] Operator
column174:
may we have the first question?

"
column175:
"

Question-and-Answer Session

"
column176:
"

Operator

"
column177:
"

[Operator Instructions] And your first question will come from Katy Huberty with Morgan Stanley.

"
column178:
"

Katy Huberty - Morgan Stanley
column179:
Research Division

"
column180:
"

As it relates to the June quarter revenue guidance
column181:
it implies a sequential downtick that is worse than the guidance message you provided over the last 3 years. So can you just talk about some of the headwinds sequentially you see on the top line in the June quarter relative to March?

"
column182:
"

Peter Oppenheimer

"
column183:
"

Sure
column184: Katy. It's Peter. The manufacturing ramps for the iPhone 4S and the new iPad were extremely successful for us. They yielded the highest launch supply and the fastest country rollouts for these product families that we've ever had. As a result
column185: we were able to fulfill demand in the March quarter rather than the June quarter this year
column186: and that generated revenue of over $39 billion. Therefore
column187: unlike last year
column188:
we expect a sequential decline in revenue this year. I'd highlight 5 primary factors that have influenced our thinking:

"
column189:
"

The first
column190: the iPhone channel inventory changes. As I discussed in my prepared remarks
column191: we increased our iPhone channel inventory by about 2.6 million units in the March quarter this year
column192: and we exited within our target inventory range of about 4 to 6 weeks. Last year
column193: we continued to add new countries into the June quarter
column194: and we built an additional 700
column195:
000 units of iPhone channel inventory last year in the June quarter. So the combination of these channel builds in the March quarter of this year and the June quarter of last year will impact the sequential comparisons from this year to last.

"
column196:
"

The second factor: fabulous iPhone 4S execution. As we told you in January
column197: we exited December with significant iPhone 4S backlog
column198: which led to a huge January. We launched China and 20 other countries also in January
column199: which completed the rollout of the iPhone 4S into all the countries where iPhone is currently shipping. And as I said before
column200:
we exited the quarter within a supply and demand balance.

"
column201:
"

The third factor: our new iPad execution was also fabulous. We had an incredible start with the new iPad. We launched with significant supply
column202: leading to sales of 3 million units in the first couple of days
column203: which was the -- and also the fastest country rollout ever. We therefore were able to satisfy much more of the demand for the new iPad in the March quarter this year compared to the iPad 2 in the March quarter of last year. This resulted in a shift of iPad volume into March this year versus last
column204:
and it will also affect the sequential compares this year to the last.

"
column205:
"

Fourth
column206:
we decreased the entry price of the entry iPad to $399.

"
column207:
"

And finally
column208: the last factor to point out
column209: the U.S. dollar has strengthened recently
column210: and we expect this to have an impact on the sequential compare
column211:
especially versus last year when the dollar weakened against most currencies over the comparable time periods.

"
column212:
"

We -- look
column213: we've just reported the most amazing March quarter Apple has ever had. We feel very
column214:
very good about our business and our new product pipeline.

"
column215:
"

Katy Huberty - Morgan Stanley
column216:
Research Division

"
column217:
"

Just as a quick follow-up to number 4
column218: the decrease in iPad price. You already saw a 7% sequential decline in March
column219:
which suggests that the uptake of the lower-priced iPad 2 was pretty phenomenal in March. Is that the right way to read it? And what does that demand tell you about the potential to move to lower price points on the iPad over time and see significant incremental demand?

"
column220:
"

Peter Oppenheimer

"
column221:
"

Look
column222: Katy
column223: we're just learning about be the elasticity of demand and the $399 price point. It's doing well. But I have to tell you
column224: the new iPad is on fire
column225: and we're selling them as fast as we can make them. So we'll learn more over this quarter especially as we get through the education buying season
column226:
which looks terrific for us especially on the iPad.

"
column227:
"

Operator

"
column228:
"

From Citigroup
column229:
we'll go to Richard Gardner.

"
column230:
"

Richard Gardner - Citigroup Inc
column231:
Research Division

"
column232:
"

I recognize that you outgrew the market in Macs yet again. But I did want to get your views on the slowdown in year-over-year growth rate within the category and what factors you would attribute that to. Are we -- is it product transition related? Were the inventories down quarter-over-quarter? iPad cannibalization? Any other color that you can provide would be helpful.

"
column233:
"

Timothy D. Cook

"
column234:
"

Yes
column235: Rich
column236: it's Tim. As you said
column237: we did outgrow the market. Macs grew at about 7% where the market grew about 2%. And so this is the 24th straight quarter that we've outgrown the market
column238: and so we're extremely pleased with that. The compare to last year is largely affected by the fact that we changed the bulk of our portable line
column239: or the MacBook Pros
column240: in the February time frame of 2011. And so it's a very tough compare. Specifically
column241: the portables last year were up 53% year-on-year. And obviously

column244: I think there was some cannibalization from iPad and the market is slow. But the much
column245: much larger factor and in fact
column246:
in -- it might be the vast majority of the difference is the compare to a year ago.

The -- as a second question
column280: I was wondering if you can talk about how you think about the markets for tablet and PC devices going forward. I think you've been fairly clear about saying that you believe that tablets will eclipse PCs in volume at some point. And I think you've also said they're somewhat discrete markets. There seems to be a lot of work
column281: particularly on PC-based platforms
column282:
towards trying to combine the PC and tablet experience going forward in part because Windows 8 will be able to -- is a touch-based operating system as well. Can you comment about why you don't believe the PC or the Ultrabook and tablet markets or your MacBook Air and tablet markets won't converge? Isn't it realistic to think in a couple of years we're going to have a device that's under 2 pounds with great battery life that we can all carry around and open as a notebook or close up in a clever way and use as a tablet? Can you comment on why you don't think that product might not come or why you believe these markets are separate?

"
column284:
"

I think
column285: Tony
column286: anything can be forced to converge. But the problem is that products are about trade-offs
column287: and you begin to make trade-offs to the point where what you have left at the end of the day doesn't please anyone. You can converge a toaster and a refrigerator
column288: but those things are probably not going to be pleasing to the user. And so our view is that the tablet market is huge. And we've said that since day one. We didn't wait until we had a lot of results. We were using them here
column289: and it was already clear to us that there was so much you could do and that the reasons that people would use those would be so broad. And that's precisely what we've seen. We -- the iPad has taken off not only in consumer in a meaningful way but in education and in enterprise
column290: and it's sort of everywhere you look now. And the applications are so easy to make very meaningful for someone
column291: and there -- the -- there's such an abundance of those that -- and as the ecosystem gets better and better and as we continue to double down on making great products
column292: I think that the limit here is nowhere in sight. We've now -- through the last quarter
column293: I should say
column294: which is just 2 years after we shipped the initial iPad
column295: we\u2019ve sold 67 million. And to put that in some context
column296: it took us 24 years to sell that many Macs and 5 years for that many iPods and over 3 years for that many iPhones. And we were extremely happy with the trajectory on all of those products. And so I think iPad
column297: it's a profound product. It -- the breadth of it is incredible
column298: and the appeal of it is universal. And so I am -- I could not be happier with being in the market
column299: and the level at which we're innovating in both the product and the ecosystem here is incredible. Now in terms of the market itself
column300: IDC and Gartner and Forrester had some numbers out there. I think Gartner is saying there's somewhere around 375 or so by 2015. Forrester is 375
column301: somewhere around there. And so basically
column302: the -- they're in the mid-300s
column303: which is about where the PC market is today. And 2015 is only 3 years from now. And so I think even the more formal predictors outside of us are beginning to see these lines cross. And so I strongly believe that they will. Now having said that
column304: I also believe that there is a very good market for the MacBook Air
column305: and we continue to innovate in that product. And -- but I do think that it appeals to somewhat -- someone that has a little bit different requirements. And you wouldn't want to put these things together because you wind up compromising in both and not pleasing either user. Some people will prefer to own both
column307: too. But I think to make the compromises of convergence
column308: so -- we're not going to that party. Others might. Others might from a defensive point of view
column309:
particularly. But we're going to play in both.

column315: there's been quite a bit of concern both in the press and within the investment community around carrier subsidies. And I think the concerns are generally twofold: First
column316: that carriers will attempt to stretch out the replacement cycle. And second
column317: that over time
column318: carriers across the globe will attempt to reduce subsidies significantly. I mean
column319:
how do you think about this risk? And do you think there are factors that could pressure subsidies going forward? And how would that impact Apple?

"
column320:
"

Timothy D. Cook

"
column321:
"

Well
column323: our focus is on making the very best smartphone in the world. And a phone that delivers a -- just an off-the-charts user experience that customers want to use every day of their lives. And at the end of the day
column324: I think that carriers
column325: the vast majority of carriers
column327: want to provide what their customers want to buy. And that's what they're motivated for. And so the most important thing by far is for Apple to continue making great products that customers want. And we are deeply committed to doing this and are innovating at a rate and pace that's unbelievable in this area. For -- from a carrier's perspective
column328: I think it's important to remember that the subsidy is not large relative to the sum of the monthly payments across a 24-month contract period. And any delta between iPhone and maybe another phone is a -- an even smaller level of difference. And the iPhone has some distinct advantages for the carrier over competing smartphones. For example
column329: many of the carrier executives have told me that churn from iPhone customers is the lowest of any phone they sell in their whole -- in all of the phones they carry. And that has a significant direct financial benefit to the carrier. Also
column330: our engineering teams work extremely hard to be efficient with data and differently than some others. And we believe that as a result of this
column331: that iPhone has far better data efficiency compared to other smartphones that are using sort of an app-rich ecosystem. Finally
column332: we think that the -- and this is the most important
column333: is that iPhone is the best smartphone on the planet to entice a customer who is currently using a traditional mobile phone to upgrade to a smartphone. This is by far the largest opportunity for Apple
column334: for our carrier partners and is a great
column335:
fantastic experience to the customer. And so there's a win-win-win there. And so I think all of these factors are -- some of these factors are missed in this general discussion of subsidy.
