column578: investing in R&D to introduce the most innovative products in the market. We are also spending on marketing
column579: advertising
column580: opening more of our own retail stores and expanding our indirect channels around the world to increase sales. And we're investing in infrastructure to support our growth and also stock-based comp for our employees. We are very confident in the investments that we're making. We're thinking about the long term
column581:
and we're confident in the returns that we're going to get in -- on these investments.

"
column583:
"

Scott
column584: in terms of component costs for the quarter we just finished
column585: Q2 component costs were better than we had planned
column586: and this assisted us in exceeding our gross margin guidance
column587: as Peter talked about earlier. Displays and NAND flash drove the majority of the favorable commodity cost benefit. In terms of the June quarter and the -- what we factored into our guidance
column588: NAND and mobile DRAM supply continued to exceed demand. And because of that
column589: we expect pricing will continue to be favorable. For most LCDs
column590: we expect pricing to stabilize as the market moves to a supply-demand balance. The hard drive market has moved to a supply-demand balance
column591:
and we expect marketing -- market pricing to decline but will still be higher than the pre-flood level from the tragedy in Thailand. Most other components are expected to fall in line with or somewhat faster than historical trends.

"
column592:
"

Operator

column593:
"

column594:
"

Kulbinder Garcha - Cr\u00e9dit Suisse AG
column595:
Research Division

column596:

column598:
and I'm just wondering how much conservatism is in your gross margin guidance. And then I have a follow-up for Tim afterwards.

"
column599:
"

Peter Oppenheimer

"
column600:
"

Sure
column602: the 2/3 that I talked about
column603: the sequential decline

column605: a full quarter of selling the current lineup of the iPad or the current iPad lineup
column606:
and then a loss of leverage on the sequentially lower revenue. So those 3 factors we see driving 2/3 of the sequential decline.

"
column607:
"

Kulbinder Garcha - Cr\u00e9dit Suisse AG
column608:
Research Division

"
column609:
"

Okay
column610: great. And then
column611: Tim
column612: just a question on the enterprise side. You mentioned a couple of times how the iPad is being taken into new markets
column613: new verticals
column614:
whether it's because of the price point of the innovation. I'm just wondering specifically what resources is Apple dedicating to have a much more direct relationship with the enterprise? Can you speak on what's changed in the last 6 or 12 months and what you think you need to do to become a more credible or significant enterprise player?

"
column615:
"

Timothy D. Cook

"
column616:
"

Initially
column617: our focus was on working with the Fortune 500 and the Global 500 to get the iPad certified for their particular enterprise. And I'm pleased to report that 94% of the Fortune 500 are testing or deploying iPads and 75% of the Global 500 are testing or deploying the iPad. So these numbers are just off the charts for a product that's only 24 months old. And so we are moving our focus away from this and focusing on penetration within these accounts. Peter alluded to some of the wins that we have had in the -- his opening comments. The incredible things about these are that they span across many verticals
column620: and many different functions within the enterprise. It's absolutely the most broad-based product I have ever seen in my whole career in terms of adoption rate into the enterprise. And so yes
column621:
this means that we're applying more resources in Fes [ph] and salespeople to interact directly with these customers. We also work with our carrier partners and our reseller partners in delivering both the products and services that are wrapped around that to these customers.

"
column623:
"

We'll go to Chris Whitmore with Deutsche Bank.

"
column627:
"

Chris Whitmore - Deutsche Bank AG
column629:
"

Hello? Can you hear me?

"
column633:
"

Chris Whitmore - Deutsche Bank AG

column637: it seems to imply that you expect iPhone unit sales to be down about 10 million units quarter-on-quarter. First
column638: is that in the right ballpark? And secondly
column639:
are you just being conservative with respect to the outlook? Or have you seen a change in the end demand environment for the phone?

"
column642: let me sort of go in reverse order. We are incredibly confident in our business
column643: our strategy and what we're doing. When we give you guidance
column644: we give you guidance that we have reasonable confidence in achieving. And finally
column645: we do expect a sequential decline in iPhone sales driven by the fact that we built 2.6 million units of channel inventory in the March quarter
column646: which we needed to do. We're now within our target range of 4 to 6 weeks
column647: and we entered the March quarter with significant backlog
column649:
in January. And we're able to fulfill that and launch 20 countries in the month of January. So \u2013- we have immense confidence in what we're doing and are very pleased with the way our business is performing.

"
column650:
"

Chris Whitmore - Deutsche Bank AG
column654: on iPad. It is supply constrained across many geos
column655:
as you talked about. Is there a specific component issue? Do you have visibility on resolution? When do you expect to be able to meet demand in the iPad?

column657:

It's hard to answer meet the demand. What I'm confident about

column661: very confident about that. It's tough to know precisely that it will balance until you get there
column662:
but I'm very confident with the improving supply and that the total number will be very significant.

"

Apple Inc. (NASDAQ:AAPL)

column28: and welcome to this Apple Incorporated Third Quarter Fiscal Year 2012 Earnings Release Call. Today\u2019s call is being recorded. At this time
column30: I would like to turn the call over to Nancy Paxton
column31:
Senior Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

"
column33:
"

Thank you. Good afternoon
column34: and thanks to everyone for joining us. Speaking today is Apple\u2019s CFO
column35: Peter Oppenheimer; and he\u2019ll be joined by Apple\u2019s CEO
column37:
Gary Wipfler for the Q&A session with analysts.

"
column38:
"

Please note that some of the information you\u2019ll hear during our discussion today will consist of forward-looking statements
column40: without limitation
column41: those regarding revenue
column46: taxes
column47:
earnings per share and future products. Actual results or trends could differ materially from our forecast.

"
column48:
"

For more information
column49: please refer to the risk factors discussed in Apple\u2019s Form 10-K for 2011
column50: the Form 10-Q for the first and second quarters of fiscal 2012 and the Form 8-K filed with the SEC today along with the attached press release. Apple assumes no obligation to update any forward-looking statements or information
column51:
which speak as of their respective dates.

"
column52:
"

I\u2019d now like to turn the call over to Peter Oppenheimer for introductory remarks.

"
column53:
"

Peter Oppenheimer

"
column54:
"

Thank you
column55: Nancy. We\u2019re pleased to report the results of our third fiscal quarter. We established new all-time quarterly record for iPad unit sales and new June quarter records for iPhone and Mac unit sales
column56:
leading to our highest June quarter revenue and earnings ever.

"
column57:
"

Revenue for the quarter was $35 billion
column58:
representing year-over-year growth of 23%. The $6.5 billion increase over the prior June quarter\u2019s result was driven primarily by strong growth in iPad and iPhone sales.

"
column59:
"

Operating margin was $11.6 billion
column60: representing 33% of revenue. Net income was $8.8 billion
column61:
increasing 21% over the prior June quarter\u2019s results. The quarter\u2019s net income translated to diluted earnings per share of $9.32.

"
column62:
"

Turning to the details of the quarter
column63: I\u2019d like to begin with our Mac products and services. We sold 4 million Macs establishing a new June quarter record. This represents 2% growth year-over-year
column64:
compared to IDCs latest published estimate of 1% contraction of the global personal computer market in the June quarter.

"
column65:
"

Last month
column66: we updated the entire MacBook lines with faster processors
column67: graphics
column68: memory
column69: flash storage and USB 3.0 connectivity. We also introduced the all-new 15 inch MacBook Pro with Retina Display
column70:
all flash architecture and quad core processors and customer response has been excellent.

"
column71:
"

While receiving tremendous momentum for the iPad in education
column72: which I\u2019ll discuss later
column73:
we also experienced our best quarter ever for U.S. education institution Mac sales with Portables representing nearly three quarters of total Mac sales.

"
column74:
"

Notable large education transaction closed during the June quarter
column75: include Rutherford County
column76: North Carolina
column77: which has purchased 6
column78: 000 MacBook Airs to support its 21<sup>st</sup> Century Digital Learning Environment
column79: and Pueblo Colorado School District 70 were all high school students and K-12 staff in the 22 School District will convert to MacBook Air. We began and ended the quarter with between three and four weeks of Mac channel inventory
column80:
which is below our target range of four to five weeks.

"
column81:
"

Tomorrow
column82: we will release Mountain Lion
column83: the ninth major release of OS X. Mountain Lion introduces more than 200 features including all-new messages app
column84: notification center
column85: system wide sharing
column86: and Facebook integration. We built iCloud into the foundation of Mountain Lion
column87:
making it easier than ever for customers to keep content up-to-date across all their devices.

"
column88:
"

Moving to our music products
column89:
we sold 6.8 million iPods compared to 7.5 million in the year ago quarter. Total iPod sales were ahead of our expectation and iPod Touch continue to account for over half of all iPod sold. iPod share of the U.S. market for MP3 players remained at over 70% based on the latest monthly data published by NPD and iPod continue to be the top selling MP3 player in most countries we track based on the latest data published by GfK.

"
column90:
"

We ended the quarter within our target range of four to six weeks of iPod channel inventory. The iTunes Store generated very strong results in the quarter with revenue of over 1.8 billion
column91: thanks to continued strong sales of music
column92: apps and other content. We are pleased to launch the iTunes Store in 12 countries including Hong Kong
column93: Singapore
column94:
and Taiwan last month. Customers can choose from over 20 million songs to purchase and download from iTunes.

"
column95:
"

We\u2019re continuing to see great interest in iTunes U. Since rolling it out in January
column96: there have been over 40 million downloads of the iTunes U app. Over 700 new K-12 schools and districts and over 125 colleges and universities have enrolled in the iTunes U program
column97:
while over 750 new courses have been published.

"
column98:
"

I\u2019d now like to turn to iPhone. We sold 26 million iPhones compared to 20.3 million in the previous June quarter; that represents 28% year-over-year growth and was ahead of the amount we factored into our guidance following very strong sales in channel inventory build we achieved in the March quarter. We added several small regional carriers during the quarter and now have iPhone distribution through over 250 carriers in over 100 countries.

"
column99:
"

We ended the quarter with about 8.3 million iPhones in channel inventory
column100: a sequential decline of about 300
column101: 000 iPhones
column102: and we remained within our target range of four to six weeks of iPhone channel inventory. Recognized revenue from iPhone handset and accessory sales was $16.2 billion during the quarter compared to $13.3 billion in the year ago quarter
column103:
an increase of 22%.

"
column104:
"

Enterprises across the globe continue to choose iPhone as the standard device for their employees. We estimate that the number of iPhones in the Fortune 500 has more than doubled in the past year. iPhone is helping businesses and employees to be more productive wherever they are.

"
column105:
"

PepsiCo has deployed thousands of iPhones with an in-house app build specifically for their field merchandisers. This app has eliminated paper reports and provides real-time information to managers
column106:
sales teams and delivery drivers.

"
column107:
"

German insurance provider ERGO has built an in-house app for iPhone that thousands of agents use to process insurance claims
column108:
which has significantly reduced paper work and improved processing time and customer satisfaction.

"
column109:
"

Turning to iPad
column110: we were thrilled with sales of over 17 million iPads during the June quarter compared to 9.2 million in the year ago quarter
column111:
an increase of 84%. We saw very strong year-over-year growth in iPad sales around the world and are pleased to be selling iPad in 97 countries.

"
column112:
"

Recognized revenue from sales of iPad and iPad accessories during the quarter was $9.2 billion compared to $6.0 billion in the year ago quarter
column113: an increase of 52%. We ended the quarter with about 3.2 million iPads in channel inventory
column114: a sequential increase of about 1.2 million units
column115:
which left us just within our target range of four to six weeks of iPad channel inventory.

"
column116:
"

\t

"
column117:
"

The iPad continues to be a great success in the U.S. education market
column118: with sales setting a new quarterly record and nearly doubling year-over-year to just under 1 million iPads. While interest in the new iPad was high
column119: sales of the reduced price iPad 2 in the K-12 market were particularly strong. And even though
column120: as I mentioned earlier
column121:
we achieved all time record Mac sales to U.S. education institutions during the quarter. We sold more than twice as many iPads as Macs to U.S. education institutions. We are extremely pleased with these results.

"
column122:
"

One great example of iPad adoption in education is the Mansfield Texas Independent School District
column123: which has purchased 11
column124: 000 iPads. This fall
column125: every Mansfield High School student and teacher will receive an iPad under the district\u2019s Power Up initiative. Some teachers will use a flipped classroom concept
column126: putting their lessons and resources online where students can access them anytime with their iPads. As a result
column127:
students take responsibility for their own learning and teachers are able to increase their interactions and personalize content time.

"
column128:
"

iPad continues its rapid adoption within the enterprise. We estimate that the number of iPads in the Fortune 500 has more than tripled in the past year. iPad has become an indispensable tool worldwide to help employees across industries do their jobs more effectively. British Airways has incorporated thousands of iPads across their business from customer support at check-in to cabin service directors replacing paper printout to details customer preferences and provide real-time updates. And homebuilder Dialogue House in Japan is actively building smart homes that will be controlled by iPads
column129:
and their sales reps are using iPads to show floor plans and upgrade options.

"
column130:
"

Combining iPhone
column131: iPad and iPod Touch
column132: we surpassed 410 million cumulative iOS device sales
column133: selling more than 45 million in the June quarter. With App Stores in 155 countries
column134: the iOS ecosystem continues to grow. The App Store now offers more than 650
column135: 000 apps
column136: including over 225
column137: 000 apps specifically for iPad. We\u2019re extremely pleased to report that we have surpassed $5.5 billion in payment to developers
column138: and customers are loving iCloud. Since its launch in October
column139:
more than 150 million people are using iCloud services.

"
column140:
"

In June
column141: we previewed many of the exciting new features of iOS 6 at our Developers Conference
column142: including our fabulous new maps app
column143: new functionality and broader language support for Siri
column144: direct Facebook integration
column145: shared photo streams via iCloud and Passbook
column146: the simplest way to get all your passes in one place. We believe iOS 6 will significantly enhance the experience of one in an iPhone
column147: iPad or iPod Touch
column148:
and we can\u2019t wait to get it into the hands of customers this fall.

"
column149:
"

I\u2019d now like to turn to the Apple retail stores. Revenue was $4.1 billion
column150: an increase of 17% over the year-ago quarter
column151: with growth yield primarily by all-time record iPad sales and strong growth in iPhone sales. The store sold 791
column152: 000 Macs compared to 768
column153:
000 in the year-ago quarter. And almost half the Macs sold in our stores during the quarter were the customers who had never owned a Mac before.

"
column154:
"

We opened a total of nine new stores in the quarter and exited the quarter with 372 stores
column155: including 123 stores outside the United States. With an average of 367 stores opened
column156: average revenue per store was $11.1 million compared to $10.8 million in the year-ago quarter. Segment margin was $868 million compared to $802 million in the year-ago quarter. We welcomed 83 million visitors to our stores during the quarter
column157: compared to 74 million visitors in the year-ago quarter
column158: an increase of 12%. That translates to an average of 17
column159:
000 visitors per store per week.

"
column160:
"

Total company gross margin was 42.8%
column161: which was 130 basis points higher than our guidance. We experienced upside from better than expected commodity
column162: warranty and other costs. These factors were partially offset by a stronger mix of iPad sales
column163: a higher mix of lower priced iPhones
column164:
and a stronger U.S. dollar relative to our expectations. Operating expenses were $3.4 billion and included $378 million in stock-based compensation expense. OI&E was $288 million and the tax rate was 25.6%.

"
column165:
"

Turning to cash
column166: our cash for short-term and long-term marketable securities totaled $117.2 billion at the end of the June quarter compared to $110 billion at the end of the March quarter
column167: a sequential increase of $7 billion
column168:
and about $81 billion of the cash was offshore at the end of the June quarter. Cash flow from operations was $10.2 billion.

"
column169:
"

Today
column170: we\u2019re announcing that our Board of Directors has declared a dividend of $2.55 per common share payable on August 16
column171: 2012 to stockholders of record after the close of business on August 13
column172: 2012. Going forward
column173: subject to declaration by our Board
column174: we expect to announce record and payment dates for future dividends concurrently with our quarterly earnings announcements. Also
column175: as we previously announced
column176: our Board has authorized a three-year $10 billion share repurchase program starting in our fiscal 2013
column177: which begins on September 30
column179:
"

As we move ahead into the September quarter
column180: I\u2019d like to review our outlook
column181: which includes the types of forward-looking information that Nancy referred to at the beginning of the call. We expect revenue to be about $34 billion compared to $28.3 billion in the September quarter last year. We expect gross margin to be about 38.5%
column182: reflecting approximately $70 million related to stock-based compensation expense. We expect OpEx to be about $3.5 billion
column183:
including about $390 million related to stock-based compensation. We expect OI&E to be about $175 million and we expect the tax rate to be about 25.50%. We are targeting EPS of about $7.65.

"
column184:
"

In closing
column185: we\u2019re pleased with our record June quarter results
column186:
including sales of over 17 million iPads. We established new June quarter records for unit sales of iPhone and Macs and posted our best quarter ever for U.S. education. We remain extremely confident in our strategy and the investments we are making in our business. We\u2019re very excited to be launching Mountain Lion tomorrow and iOS 6 in the fall and we have some more amazing new products in our pipeline that we look forward to discussing with you later.

"
column187:
"

With that I\u2019d like to open the call to questions.

"

Question-and-Answer Session

Nancy Paxton

Katy.

So

Nancy Paxton

we will hear from Bill Shope.

column264:

column270:

We exited the June quarter in supply and demand balance and we were within our four to six week inventory target. column271:

column274: which also put us in our four to six week inventory target. These increases in channel inventory will impact both the year-over-year and sequential compares for iPad. The current iPad lineup that we're selling includes the very successful $399 price point
column275: which we did not have in the year-ago quarter. So this
column276:
along with mix in the line will impact the ASPs in the September quarter.

column282: Australian Dollar

column285:
we very much look forward to introducing iOS 6 in the fall and we remain very confident in our business and our new product pipeline.

column664:

Thanks very much. I wanted to follow-up on the pricing question and as specifically around the iPad as to whether or not you think the lower price point drove elasticity of demand for that product
column666: were your sales incrementally higher or as a result of this economic environment
column667: did you see customers migrate down market to lower-priced products
column668:
because spending is a little tighter these days?

"
column671: it\u2019s Tim. The reason that we did it was because we believed that the sales would be incrementally larger that there was price elasticity and that there was a buyer that really wanted the best product and that needed it to be a little less expensive
column672: and so I believe that we saw that. I think it did help our sales. I think it\u2019s particularly helping in K-12. The adoption rate of iPad in education is something I\u2019d never seen from any technology product in history. Usually
column673:
education tends to be a fairly conservative institution in terms of buying or K-12 does and we\u2019re not seeing that at all on the iPad. And so I think it was \u2013 it\u2019s been a big help for us and I am really glad that we did it.

"
column674:
"

Chris Whitmore \u2013 Deutsche Bank Securities

"
column676: I wanted to ask about the opportunity that you see in India. A few years back
column677: you talked about initial investments in China
column678: and having cracked the China code
column679: why hasn\u2019t Apple been more successful in India
column680:
and what is your outlook for growth in that geography specifically going forward?

"
column682:
"

You know of course I love India
column683: but I believe that Apple has some higher potential in the intermediate term in some other countries. And that doesn\u2019t mean that we\u2019re not putting emphasis in India
column684: we are. We have a business there
column686: but the sort of the multilayer distribution there really adds to the cost of getting products to market. And so
column687: we\u2019re going to continue putting some energies there
column688:
but my own perspective is that in the intermediate term there will be larger opportunities outside of there.

"
column689:
"

Chris Whitmore \u2013 Deutsche Bank Securities

"
column695: Chris. Could we have the next question
column700:
we will hear from Shaw Wu.

"
column704:
"

Okay. Thanks for having on. Just a quick question in terms of component availability particularly new components? Thanks.

"
column707: it\u2019s Tim. We factored supply into the guidance that Peter has given you. Generally
column708: I should say that we have been short of the MacBook Pro with the Retina displays
column709:
we ended the quarter with backlog and we are working really hard to deliver those to customers quickly and we believe that we will be in supply and demand balance in August.

"
column710:
"

In terms of new products
column711: I obviously don\u2019t talk about new products nor the parts that are in them
column712: and so it\u2019s sort of a limit to what I can say there other than anything that we know about
column713: we\u2019ve obviously included in the guidance and if we were short of something
column714:
you can bet that we would all be spending our energies on trying to mitigate that.

"
column718:
"

Okay. Thanks for that color. Just a follow up on
column719: I don't know if you could talk about in terms of the new iPad with the Retina display
column724: the new iPad ended the quarter in just over the four-week line
column725: which we associated with our target of four to six weeks and \u2013 in terms of channel inventory. Now that said
column727: we did not ship the new iPad in Mainland China until the quarter that we\u2019re now and in Q4
column729:
we feel like we ended in a balanced situation.

"
column737: could we have the next question
column740:
"

And that will come from Brian Marshall with ISI.

"
column743: thanks guys. Clearly Apple's design philosophy has been about building great products as opposed to kind of going in the market
column744: hitting certain price points. But how do you think about the opportunities to address maybe some of those opportunities that are down at some of those lower price points
column745:
with your existing products without essentially compromising the core features that basically make Apple\u2019s products great.

"
column748: it\u2019s Tim. Our North Star is to maniacally focus on making the world\u2019s best products and economic turmoil
column749: may push us side to side
column750: but we\u2019re going to stay on that journey and stay focused on making the best product
column751: and not deviate from that. We\u2019ve seen
column752: again and again throughout the years
column753: that during these type of periods are where we distanced ourselves further from people that don\u2019t innovate and it increases the gap between us
column754:
and so that\u2019s what we\u2019re focused on.

"
column756: when we can do that and hit more aggressive price points
column757: we\u2019re also going to do that. And I think you\u2019ve seen that with what we did with the $399 iPad
column758: just a few months ago. And the iPhone 3GS is free in the United States
column759: and in several other countries. And there has been quite a lot knocked off the price of that in certain other markets. And so
column760: our North Star that will be making the best products in the world
column762:
that\u2019s why we live and we\u2019re not changing that.

"
column765: when you think about how the iPhone has penetrated the planet
column767: we\u2019ve had some pretty phenomenal success
column769: there\u2019s been some downside to that as well with respect to volatility about the rumors and speculation about kind of future products being announced. And so
column770: could you talk a little bit about how you try to manage sort of the iPhone transitions and the carrier ramp as well
column772: you mentioned not going to be launching any major countries or carriers in the September quarter
column773:
but it\u2019s widely speculated that we\u2019re going to see something later on in the year. So if you can talk a little bit about how you kind of manage that whole sort of transition/carrier ramp up that would be great? Thank you.

"
column776: we try very hard to keep our product roadmap secret and confidential
column778: do extreme activities to try to do that. That however doesn\u2019t stop people from speculating or wondering and we\u2019ll never do that. And so it\u2019s a great thing about this country
column779: people can say what they think and so forth. And so I'm not going to spend any energy trying to change that
column780: that\u2019s just the environment we are in. I\u2019m glad that people want the next thing. I\u2019m super happy about it. And there is obviously
column781: quite a few that what we\u2019re currently doing as well and as witnessed by the amount of products that we\u2019re selling. And so
column782:
I\u2019m not going to put any energy into try to get people to stop speculating. I don\u2019t think it would \u2013 I don\u2019t think that\u2019s going to amount anything.

"
column791: Brian. A replay of today\u2019s call will be available for two weeks as a Podcast on the iTunes Store
column792:
as a webcast on Apple.com/investor and via telephone. And the numbers for the telephone replay are 888-203-1112 or 719-457-0820; and please enter confirmation code 1260435. These replays will be available by approximately 5:30 PM Pacific Time today. Members of the press with additional questions can contact Steve Dowling; he is at 408-974-1896. And financial analysts can contact either Joan Hoover or me with additional questions. Joan is at 408-974-4570 and I\u2019m at 408-974-5420. And thanks again for joining us.

"
column795:
that does conclude today\u2019s presentation. We do thank everyone for your participation.

column28: and welcome to this Apple Incorporated Fourth Quarter Fiscal Year 2012 Earnings Release Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded. At this time
column30: I would like to turn the call over to Nancy Paxton
column31: Senior Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead
column33:
"

Nancy Paxton

"
column35: and thanks to everyone for joining us. Speaking today is Apple CFO
column36: Peter Oppenheimer; and he'll be joined by Apple CEO
column38:
Gary Wipfler for the Q&A session with analysts.

"
column39:
"

Please note that some of the information you'll hear during our discussion today will consist of forward-looking statements
column40: including
column41: without limitation
column46: stock-based compensation expense
column47: taxes
column48: earnings per share and future products. Actual results or trends could differ materially from our forecast. For more information
column49: please refer to the risk factors discussed in Apple's Form 10-K for 2011
column50: the Form 10-Q for the first three quarters of fiscal 2012 and the Form 8-K filed with the SEC today along with the attached press release. Apple assumes no obligation to update any forward-looking statements or information
column51:
which speak as of their respective dates.

"
column52:
"

And I'd now like to turn the call over to Peter Oppenheimer for introductory remarks.

"
column53:
"

Peter Oppenheimer

"
column54:
"

Thank you
column55: Nancy. Thank you for joining us. We're pleased to report the results of our fourth fiscal quarter. We established a new September quarter records for iPhone
column56: iPad and Mac unit sales
column57:
leading to our highest September quarter revenue and earnings ever.

"
column58:
"

Revenue for the quarter was $36 billion
column59:
representing year-over-year growth of 27%. That's a $7.7 billion increase over the prior September quarter\u2019s results and was driven primarily by strong growth in iPhone and iPad sales.

"
column60:
"

Operating margin was $10.9 billion
column61: representing 30.4% of revenue. Net income was $8.2 billion
column62:
increasing 24% over the prior September quarter's result. The quarter's net income translated to diluted earnings per share of $8.67.

"
column63:
"

Turning to the details of the quarter
column64:
I'd like to begin with our Mac products and services. We sold over 4.9 million Macs establishing a new September quarter record. This represents 1% growth year-over-year compared to IDC's latest published estimate of 8% contraction of the global personal computer market in the September quarter.

"
column65:
"

Portable sales grew 9% year-over-year and represented an all time high of 80% of Mac unit mix
column66:
thanks to strong sales of MacBook Pro and MacBook Air.

"
column67:
"

Earlier this week we unveiled the stunning new design for iMac that packed high performance technology and a brilliant new display with reduced reflection into an incredibly sleek aluminum and glass enclosure. We also introduced an even thinner and lighter version of our most popular Mac
column68: the 13-inch MacBook Pro
column69:
featuring a retina display with over 4 million pixels in all flash storage. We began and ended the quarter with between three and four weeks of Mac channel inventory which is below our target range of four to five weeks.

"
column70:
"

Moving to our music products
column71:
we sold 5.3 million iPods compared to 6.6 million in the year ago quarter. iPod touch continue to account for over half of all iPods sold. iPod share of the U.S. market for MP3 players was over 70% in the September quarter based on the latest data published by MPD and iPod continue to be the top selling MP3 player in most countries we track based on the latest data published by GFK.

"
column72:
"

We\u2019re very excited to be shipping our newest iPods as of two weeks ago. The new iPod touch is the thinnest iPod touch yet
column73: comes in five great colors and features of 4-inch Retina display
column74: a 5 megapixel iSight camera
column75: our powerful A5 chip and Siri. The new iPod Nano is the thinnest iPod ever featuring a 2.5-inch Multi-Touch display
column76: convenient navigation buttons
column77:
and built-in Bluetooth for wireless listening. The Nano comes in seven great new colors and we think our full range of iPods will make wonderful gifts this holiday season.

"
column78:
"

The iTunes Store generated all time record results
column79: with revenue almost $2.1 billion thanks to continued strong sales of music
column80: apps and video. We look forward to launching the new iTunes featuring the completely redesigned player
column81: seamless integration with iCloud and a new look for the iTunes Store. The new iTunes has a dramatically simpler and clearner interface
column82: so customers\u2019 music
column83:
movie and TV purchases on any of their iOS devices or computers are conveniently displayed in their iTunes library and are available whenever they want them.

"
column84:
"

I\u2019d now like to turn to iPhone. we\u2019re very pleased to have sold 26.9 million iPhones compared to 17.1 million in the previous September quarter. That represents 58% year-over-year growth compared to IDC\u2019s latest published estimate of 45% growth for the smartphone market overall during the quarter. We launched iPhone 5 in nine countries on September 21 and 22 more countries on September 28
column85:
and demand has been phenomenal.

"
column86:
"

Customers have responded tremendously to the iPhone 5 all-new slim and light design and beautiful new 4-inch Retina display
column87: the powerful performance of the A6 chip and the great new ultrafast wireless technology. Demand for iPhone 5 continues to outstrip supply
column88:
and we are working very hard to get more into customer\u2019s hands as quickly as possible.

"
column89:
"

We ended the quarter with about $9.1 million iPhones in channel inventory
column90: a sequential increase of about 800
column91:
000 iPhones and ended the quarter below our target range of four to six weeks of iPhone channel inventory on a look-forward basis.

"
column92:
"

Recognized revenue from iPhone handsets and accessories sales was $17.1 billion during the quarter compared to $11 billion in the year-ago quarter
column93: an increase of 56%. Businesses around the world continue to make iPhone
column94: an essential device for their employees. Virtually
column95:
every type of enterprise in the small business is using iPhone along with the business apps from the app store and custom apps developed in-house to drive efficiencies that were simply not possible before.

"
column96:
"

Canon has provided its field sales team iPhones with secure access to its customer relationship management system
column97: sales reps can now access customer information and input meeting notes anywhere giving them more time with customers. Amtrak has deployed thousands of iPhones to train conductors
column98: the use an in-house app that changes the entire ticketing and reporting workflow. The app enabled print-at-home ticket validation delivers a more accurate passenger manifest and makes the accounting data available to Amtrak\u2019s revenue systems in near real time
column99: revolutionizing the paper-based process
column100:
the company used in the past.

"
column101:
"

And news organizations around the world are using iPhone to transform the way they capture and deliver news. reporters for BBC
column102: the Wall Street Journal
column103: Mexican newspaper
column104:
Milenio and Canada\u2019s CTV News are using their iPhone cameras to capture HD video on location and send it directly back to headquarters for broadcast on TV or streaming on the web.

"
column105:
"

Turning to iPad
column106:
we were very pleased with sales of 14 million iPads during the September quarter compared to 11.1 million in the year ago quarter and the increase of 26%. iPad sales were ahead of our expectations and we saw a strong year-over-year growth in iPad sales in every geographic region.

"
column107:
"

Earlier this week
column108: we introduced the iPad Mini
column109: the thinnest
column110: lightest
column111: smallest iPad we\u2019ve ever build. it has all the power
column112: performance and capability
column113: customers have come to expect from an iPad and you can hold it in one hand. We also introduced the fourth generation iPad with the beautiful 9.7-inch Retina display
column114:
an A6 chip with twice the performance of the iPad we announced earlier this year.

"
column115:
"

Together with the iPad 2
column116: these two new iPads run more than 275
column117: 000 apps in the App Store. Recognized revenue from sales of iPad and iPad accessories during the quarter was 7.5 billion compared to 6.9 billion in the year-ago quarter and the increase of 9%. we ended the quarter with about 3.4 million iPads in channel inventory
column118: a sequential increase of about 200
column120: which left as just over our four weeks of iPad channel inventories
column121:
target on a look-back basis.

"
column122:
"

iPad is fundamentally changing work processes across industries around the world. With apps developed in-house
column123:
iPad is helping companies deliver better service; streamline manufacturing and then power workforces with critical data and information.

"
column124:
"

Volkswagen has developed more than 30 in-house apps for vital processes across the company including monitoring and tracking of vehicles on the production line
column125:
scheduling the vehicle transportation at assembly plants and greeting customers when they pick up new cars. Ping An Insurance in China has deployed thousands of iPads to their sales agents and service teams.

"
column126:
"

Apps developed in-house are used by car accident inspectors to carry out onsite inspections involve claims
column127: which significantly shortens processing time and improves customer satisfaction. In Brazil
column128: Banco Bradesco is using iPads to redefine the customer experience in their bank branches. Beyond completing customer transaction
column129: employees use iPad to inform and educate customers about bank services
column130:
and Bradesco apps in the App Store.

"
column131:
"

Combining iPhones
column132: iPads and iPod touch
column133: we sold over 44 million iOS devices in the September quarter. The App Store now offers more than 700
column134: 000 apps
column135: including over 275
column136: 000 apps specifically for iPad. We established a new all-time record for quarterly app sales in the September quarter
column137:
and we were very pleased to report that we have reached $6.5 billion in cumulative payments to developers. Customers are embracing iPad in growing numbers. With over 190 million account sign ups in the first year of the service.

"
column138:
"

With iCloud
column139: customers can access their music
column140: photos
column141: calendars
column142: contacts
column143: documents and more from whatever device they are using. And it is built into every new iOS device and every new Mac. And we launched iOS6 last month
column144: and it\u2019s already on over 200 million devices. iOS 6 includes over 200 new features
column145: including broader language support for Siri
column146: Facebook integration
column147: shared photo streams and more. We\u2019ve made a number of improvements in maps over the past month
column148:
and we will work non-stop until maps lives up to our incredibly high standards.

"
column149:
"

I would now like to turn to the Apple retail stores. Revenue was $4.2 billion
column150: which is a new September quarter record and an increase of 18% over the year-ago quarter
column151: with growth yield primarily by the store\u2019s best iPhone launch ever. The stores also established a new quarterly record for Mac sales
column152: selling just over 1.1 million Macs. We opened a total of 18 new stores in 10 countries during the quarter
column153: including our first store in Sweden. We also opened our second store at Hong Kong
column154: at Festival Walk overwhelming response
column155:
resulting in our biggest store opening of the year.

"
column156:
"

We exited the quarter with 390 stores
column157: 140 of which are outside the United States. With an average of 376 stores open
column158: average revenue per store was $11.2 million
column159: compared to $10.7 million in the year-ago quarter. Segment margin was $848 million
column160: compared to $652 million in the year-ago quarter. We hosted 94 million visitors to our stores during the quarter
column161: compared to 77.5 million visitors in the year-ago quarter
column162: an increase of 22%. That translates to an average of 19
column163: 000 visitors per store
column164:
per week.

"
column165:
"

Total company gross margin was 40%
column166: which was 150 basis points higher than our guidance. About half this difference was due to better than expected
column167:
commodity and other costs. Another quarterly difference was due to leverage on the higher-than-expected sales and more favorable foreign exchange. The remainder was due to some items that we do not expect to recur in the December quarter.

"
column168:
"

Operating expenses were $3.5 billion
column169: and included $379 million of stock-based compensation expense. OI&E was a net expense to $51 million. The interest income and investment gains were more than offset by higher-than-expected currency hedging expense. Under the accounting rules
column170: foreign exchange fluctuations late in the quarter required us to accelerate recognition of premium expense related to Q1 and Q2 hedges. This will result in less premium expense being recognized in Q1 and Q2 the tax rate for the quarter was 24.5%
column171:
bringing us to a tax rate for the full fiscal year of 25.2%.

"
column172:
"

Turning to cash
column173: our cash for short-term and long-term marketable securities totaled $121.3 billion at the end of the September quarter
column174: compared to $117.2 billion at the end of the June quarter
column175: a sequential increase of over $4 billion. The increase in cash was net of $2.5 billion of dividend paid in August. About $83 billion of our total cash was offshore at the end of the September quarter. Cash flow from operations was $9.1 billion. Our board of directors have declared a dividend of $2.65 per common share
column176: payable on November 15
column177: 2012. The shareholders of recorded as of the close of business on November 12
column179:
"

In August
column180: we entered into a rule 10b5-1 compliant accelerated share repurchase program
column181:
with the financial institution to purchase out the $2 billion of Apple stock during fiscal year \u201913.

"
column182:
"

In addition to shares purchased through the accelerated share repurchase program
column183: we may also purchase shares in open market transaction in compliance with our applicable securities laws. As we move ahead into the December quarter
column184: I\u2019d like to review our outlook
column185: which includes the types of forward-looking information that Nancy referred to at the beginning of the call. As a reminder
column186: year-over-year comparison will be impacted by the fact that our December quarter this year will span 13 weeks
column187:
whereas the December quarter last year included a 14th week.

"
column188:
"

As we indicated previously
column189:
revenue in that 14th week last year was approximately one 14th of the quarter\u2019s total revenue. We expect revenues to be about $52 billion compared to $46.3 billion in the December quarter last year. We expect gross margin to be about 36% reflecting approximately $90 million related to stock-based compensation expense.

"
column190:
"

We expect OpEx to be about $4.05 billion including about $485 million related to stock-based compensation expense. We expect OI&E to be about $380 million
column191:
and we expect the tax rate to be about 26%. We are targeting EPS of about $11.75.

"
column192:
"

In closing
column193: we\u2019re extremely proud to conclude an amazing fiscal year 2012. We generated revenue of over $156 billion
column194: which is up 45% year-over-year
column195: and reflects growth of $48 billion in revenue. We sold over $200 million iOS devices including 125 million iPhones reflecting 73% growth year-over-year
column196:
and 58 million iPads reflecting 80% growth.

"
column197:
"

We sold a record $18 million Macs and shipped 35 million iPods. And we expanded the reach of iTunes music stores to 63 countries around the world. We launched stunning new versions of OS X and iOS
column198:
and time it altogether; we launched iPod with customers reaching over 190 million and growing.

"
column199:
"

And finally
column200: we generated net income of $41.7 billion
column201:
an increase of 61% year-over-year. We enter this holiday season with our strongest product lineup ever and remain very confident in our new product pipeline.

"
column202:
"

With that
column203:
I\u2019d like to open the call to questions.

"
column204:
"

Nancy Paxton

"
column205:
"

Thank you
column206: Peter. And we ask that you limit yourself to one question and one follow-up. Operator
column207: may we have the first question
column208:
please?

"
column209:
"

Question-and-Answer Session

"
column210:
"

"
column211:
"

Operator

"
column212:
"

(Operator Instructions) Your first question will come from Katy Huberty with Morgan Stanley.

"
column213:
"

Katy Huberty \u2013 Morgan Stanley & Co. LLC\t

"
column214:
"

Hey
column215: thanks. Good afternoon. If your guidance comes to fruition
column216: December will be the first quarter in a very long time
column217: but Apple EPS declined year-on-year despite what has been the broadest product refresh in the company\u2019s history over the past two months
column218: the [bares] will point out that may be the company\u2019s price premium or supply kind of advantage is weakening
column219: so just curious how you would respond to that? And then as a follow-up
column220:
Peter if you can comment on what\u2019s driving the significant gross margin down-tick in December given you should have decent iPhone mix? Thank you.

"
column221:
"

Peter Oppenheimer

"
column222:
"

"
column223:
"

Sure. Katy
column224: let me begin
column225: I\u2019ll address many of the things you asked
column226: and then Tim can add a few points. The change year-over-year is being driven by a couple of things
column227: so first of all
column228: last year included a 14<sup>th</sup> week
column229: this year\u2019s Q1 is a normal 13-week quarter. That along with a stronger U.S. dollar
column230: and the change in gross margin
column231: so let me talk to you about what we see for gross margin
column232: but I\u2019m going to go through some detail on a sequential basis
column233:
but not year-over-year.

"
column234:
"

As you pointed out
column235: this is the most prolific product period in Apple\u2019s history. We have an unprecedented number of new product introductions over the last six weeks
column236:
and this has led to record levels of demand. New or re-priced versions of our products announced during this time frame represent over 80% of the total expected December quarter revenue.

"
column237:
"

But there are costs associated with such dramatic change and demand. The iPhone 5
column239: iMac
column240: MacBook Pro 13-inch
column241: iPod Touch and iPod Nano have completely new form factors with great new features
column242: and we\u2019ve never before introduced so many new form factors at once. All of these products have higher costs than their predecessors
column243:
and therefore lower gross margins as they are at the height of the cost curve.

"
column244:
"

This has been the case with new products in the past
column245: so nothing new. The difference this time is the sheer number of new products we are introducing in a very short period of time. Additionally
column246: we lowered the price of the iPhone 4S and iPhone 4
column247:
delivering incredible value to our customer.

"
column248:
"

We head into this holiday quarter with the strongest iPhone line-up that we have ever had with the iPhone 4 starting at three in the subsidized markets. We also added the iPad Mini to our iPad line-up. The iPad Mini has the full iPad experience
column249: and we priced it aggressively at $329
column250:
delivering incredible value to our customers. Its gross margin is significantly below the corporate average.

"
column252: we expect our gross margin to decline by about 400 basis points sequentially. We expect the benefit from positive leverage on a sequentially higher revenue and a greater mix of iPhone
column253:
but we expect these benefits will be more than offset by a number of factors.

"
column254:
"

First
column255: margins on new products are lower than their predecessors including the iPhone 5 and we have been aggressive with the iPad Mini. Second
column256: we\u2019ve lowered the price of the iPhone 4S and the iPhone 4. Third
column257: we will experience transitionary cost associated with multiple new product ramp. Fourth
column258:
the high anticipated volume of iPhone and other new products will generate significantly greater deferred revenue sequentially.

"
column259:
"

As you are aware
column260: we defer a portion of our revenue with every device we sell
column261: and amortize it back into revenue over the life of the device. In periods of exceptionally strong sales like the December quarter
column262: the deferred amounts are significantly higher than the revenue amortized in from past sales. And fifth
column263:
the favorable items that benefited the gross margin in the September quarter are not expected to repeat in the December quarter.

"
column264:
"

We will work hard to try and get down the cost curves and improve our manufacturing and other efficiencies as we successfully have done in the past. We ended this holiday season with our strongest product line-up ever
column265:
and we have great choices for customers. To be in a position to anticipate over $50 billion of demand for our products in a single quarter is a reflection of the incredible strength of our products and our business.

column757:
the sequential declining in gross margin that we see in the December quarter is largely being driven by many new form factor changes and some price reductions that we\u2019ve taken that I went through in great detail. And we believe that over 80% of the revenue that we will see in the December quarter will come from products that we\u2019ve just introduced in the last six weeks. And so while having lower gross margins on a new product is not something that\u2019s new for us. What is different this time is just a sheer number of new products that we\u2019ve introduced in the last six weeks. And we just have not had that magnitude in the past. So I don\u2019t see something that\u2019s structurally different. And we have a big focus on wanting to make a lot of these products to get them in customers\u2019 hands as quickly as we can. But we are often going to work to try and get down the cost curves and improve manufacturing and other efficiencies as we have successfully done in the past. So no change in what we\u2019re going to try and work on. And we\u2019ll report to you in January how we did.

{"Apple's CEO Discusses F1Q 2013 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Apple Inc. (NASDAQ:AAPL)

column28: everyone
column29: and welcome to this Apple Incorporated First Quarter Fiscal Year 2013 Earnings Release Conference Call. Today\u2019s call is being recorded. At this time
column30: for opening remarks and introductions
column31: I would like to turn the call over to Nancy Paxton
column32: Senior Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead
column33:
ma\u2019am.

Nancy Paxton

"
column35: and thanks to everyone for joining us. Speaking today are Apple\u2019s CEO
column38: and they will be joined by Treasurer
column39:
Gary Wipfler for the Q&A session with the analysts.

Please note that some of the information you will hear during our discussion today will consist of forward-looking statements
column40: including without limitation
column41: those regarding revenue
column46: taxes
column47: and future products. Actual results or trends could differ materially from our forecast. For more information
column48: please refer to the Risk Factors discussed in Apple\u2019s Form 10-K for 2012 and the Form 8-K filed with the SEC today along with the attached press release. Apple assumes no obligation to update any forward-looking statements or information
column49:
which speak as of their respective dates.

I\u2019d now like to turn the call over to Tim Cook for introductory remarks.

"
column50:
"

Tim Cook

Thanks
column51:
Nancy and good afternoon everyone and thank you for joining us. We are incredibly pleased to report an extraordinary quarter with $54.5 billion in revenue and new records for iPhone and the iPad sales. No technology company has ever reported these kinds of results.

Apple is in one of the most prolific periods of innovation of new products in its history. Just in the last few months
column52: we have introduced new products in every category that we make. Each one of these reflects our dedication to making the very best products in the world. At Apple
column53:
we think about the smallest details and we are unwilling to cut corners in delivering the best customer experience in the world. This relentless commitment to innovation and excellence is the reason our customers choose to buy our product and this will always be the driving force behind Apple.

Apple today is over 80
column54: 000 people strong and we are one team working together to surprise and delight our customers. Part of my job is to preserve our culture and drive it forward
column55: so we remain the world\u2019s most innovative company. People join Apple to do the very best work of their life and there is no greater reward than seeing how customers love to use our products. We continue to believe that our fundamental
column56: our remarkable people
column57: our clear and focused strategy
column58: our new product pipeline
column59: our booming ecosystem
column60:
and more than 400 Apple retail stores will serve us well in the coming months and years ahead.

Tomorrow marks the anniversary of a revolution. On January 24
column62: Steve introduced the first Macintosh right here at a shareholder meeting in Cupertino. On the evening news that night
column63: they said it was supposed to be one of the easiest computers to use
column64: and thanks to the new mouse
column65: you hardly have to touch the keyboard. We have come a long way since 1984
column66: but we rely on the same spirit and drive that brought the original Mac and other revolutionary products like the iPod
column67:
the iPhone and the iPad into the world.

You are going to hear a lot of impressive numbers during this call
column68: but they are not the only way that we measure success at Apple. The most important thing to us is that our customers love our product
column69: not just buy them
column70: but love them. Everyone here is laser focused on creating an unprecedented customer experience. We have now sold well over 0.5 billion iOS devices
column71:
including a staggering 10 per second last quarter alone. We couldn\u2019t have achieved these milestones without the very best products in the world and unmatched execution by our engineering operations and sales teams to deliver so many innovative and beautifully designed products. It\u2019s simply phenomenal.

Everyone at Apple has their eyes on the future
column72:
a future driven by the incredible hard work and dedication by the most talented and creative team on earth who all share a common purpose of continuing to create the world\u2019s best product and in doing so enrich the lives of our customers. Today we\u2019re proud to share with you our latest results. Peter will review the highlights of our Q1 earnings and I\u2019ll be back for the Q&A. Peter.

Peter Oppenheimer

"
column73:
"


Thanks Tim. We\u2019re very pleased to report the results of Apple\u2019s first fiscal quarter. We established new all-time quarterly records for iPhone and iPad sales
column74: significantly broadened our eco-system and generated Apple\u2019s highest quarterly revenue and net income ever. Revenue for the quarter was 54.5 billion compared to 46.3 billion in the year ago quarter
column75: an increase of 8.2 billion year-over-year. As a remainder our first quarter this fiscal year spanned 13 weeks whereas the first quarter last year included a 14th week. As such average weekly revenue was 4.2 billion in the current year quarter compared to 3.3 billion in the year ago quarter
column76: an increase of 27%. The strong year-over-year growth was fuelled by record iPhone
column77:
iPad and iTune sales.

Operating margin was 17.2 billion representing 31.6% of revenue. Net income was a record 13.1 billion just ahead of the amount generated in last year\u2019s 14 week quarter and translated to diluted earnings per share of $13.81. Beginning this fiscal year we\u2019re reorganizing the presentation of our results to provide greater transparency. First
column78: we\u2019ve established a new operating segment of Greater China given the very significant contribution of that region to our overall business. We define Greater China to include Mainland China
column79: Hong Kong and Taiwan. Second
column80:
for segment reporting purposes we\u2019re allocating certain manufacturing cost and variances including cost related to product tooling and manufacturing process equipment to our operating segments instead of including these expenditures in corporate expenses as we have done in the past.

We have recast our operating income for each quarter in fiscal 2011 and 2012 to reflect this change and have provided a reconciliation on Apple.com/Investor. These changes have no impact in overall reported operating income. And third
column81: we have realigned the presentation of product information in our summary data schedule to provide greater visibility to revenue by product category. Under this new format revenue from iPhone
column82: iPad
column83: Mac and iPod sales is presented exclusive of related service and accessory revenue. All revenue from iTunes
column84:
stand-alone Apple and third party software and services is presented as a single line item and revenue from all Apple and third party accessory sales is presented as a single line item.

"
column85:
"

We believe this presentation provides a logical grouping of revenue sources and also provides greater transparency into our results.

"
column86:
"

As for the details of this quarter
column87: I'd like to begin with iPhone. We were very pleased to sell 47.8 million iPhones compared to 37 million in the year ago quarter
column88:
an increase of over 10 million iPhones.

This represents a rate of almost 3.7 million iPhones per week in the current year quarter compared to 2.6 million per week in the year ago quarter. That\u2019s an average increase of 39% per week consistent with IDC\u2019s latest published forecast for the global smartphone market in the December quarter.

And on a sequential basis iPhone sales grew 78% over the September quarter\u2019s results. That\u2019s over 3.5 times IDC\u2019s latest published projection for sequential growth of the overall market resulting in iPhone market share growth. We experienced strong iPhone growth in each of our geographic segments most notably Greater China where iPhone sales more than doubled year-over-year. In the U.S. Kantar Worldpanel Comtech estimates that iPhone shares of smartphones sales increased from 45% in the year ago quarter to over 51% in the current year quarter.

iPhone sales were driven by the tremendous popularity of iPhone 5 which we\u2019re extremely proud to have launched in 100 countries by the end of December resulting in the fastest iPhone rollout ever. We ended the quarter with about 10.6 million iPhones in channel inventory a sequential increase of about 1.5 million iPhones and ended the quarter within our target range of four to six weeks of iPhone channel inventory on a look forward basis. While other mobile devices and operating systems faced increasing security risks and fragmented inconsistent user experiences
column89:
iPhone and iOS continued to deliver an exceptional experience that people love.

They also provide a secure and trusted eco-system that IT departments require. iPhone continues to be embraced by government agencies and businesses across the globe. Many U.S. government agencies are issuing iPhones by the 1000s as part of their new mobile strategies. Some examples include NASA
column90: the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Association
column91: Immigration and Customs Enforcement
column92:
and the Transportation Security Administration.

We are also seeing continued iPhone growth in business across the board from companies replacing existing smartphone deployments to businesses adding first-time smartphone users. Companies around the world like Neiman Marcus
column93: Skanska
column94:
and Volvo are issuing iPhones to their employees to improve interactions with customers and give workers access to essential corporate data.

Turning to iPad
column95: we were thrilled to sell 22.9 million iPads during the quarter compared to 15.4 million in the year ago quarter. That translates to over 1.7 million iPads per week in the current year quarter compared to 1.1 million per week in the year ago quarter
column96: an average increase of 60% per week
column97:
ahead of IDC\u2019s latest published estimate of 56% growth for the tablet market. Customers are loving the fourth generation iPad with its faster performance and spectacular Retina display. And the iPad mini has been a tremendous hit offering the full iPad experience in an incredible design that you can hold in one hand.

In addition to the tremendous response from consumers
column98: iPad continues to be the tablet of choice for businesses and government agencies transforming the way their employees work. Financial institutions like Barclays
column99: Nomura Securities
column100: and Bank of Beijing are deploying iPad to enable employees to better service customers and work securely with financial portfolios and products. In particular
column101:
Barclays roll out of over 8000 iPads has generated tremendous employee engagement and feedback making it the most successful IT deployment in Barclays\u2019 history.

"
column102:
"

State and local governments in the United States are also rapidly adopting iPad. Court systems
column103: county inspectors
column104: and law enforcement agencies use iPad to streamline processes and replace huge amounts of paper. And state legislatures in Virginia
column105: Texas
column106:
and West Virginia are all using iPads to give lawmakers instant access to government documents and information.

Outside the U.S.
column108: 000 iPads are being deployed as part of broad adoption of a local government workflow solution in Sweden and over 5
column109:
000 iPads have been purchased by the government in the Netherlands for the Dutch Tax Authority and the Dutch Court System. We began and ended the quarter with about 3.4 million iPads in channel inventory. That left us below our target range of four to six weeks of iPad channel inventory on a look-forward basis.

Turning to Mac
column110: we sold 4.1 million units in the quarter compared to 5.2 million in the year ago quarter. IDC estimates the global personal computer market contracted by 6% during the December quarter. We introduced the new 13-inch MacBook Pro Retina display as well as our stunning new iMacs in October. As we projected a quarter ago
column111: we were significantly constrained with respect to the new iMacs and were only able to ship them for the final month of the December quarter. We believe our Mac sales would have been much higher absent those constraints. We began and ended the quarter with between three and four weeks of Mac channel inventory on a look-forward basis
column112:
which is below our target range of four to five weeks.

Moving to iPod
column113:
we sold 12.7 million iPods compared to 15.4 million in the year ago quarter. iPod touch was a popular item in the holiday season and continues to account for over of half of all iPods sold during the December quarter. iPod\u2019s share of U.S. market for MP3 players was over 70% in the December quarter based on the latest data published by MPD and iPod continued to be the top selling MP3 player in most countries we track based on the latest data published by GFK.

iTunes generated record results with revenue of $2.1 billion in the quarter. We established new all-time quarterly records for revenue from music
column114: from movies
column115: and from apps. We significantly expanded the footprint of our ecosystem during the quarter adding iTunes music stores in 56 countries
column116: including Russia
column117: Turkey
column118: India and South Africa. That brings us to a total of 119 countries
column119:
where customers can choose from over 20 million songs to purchase and download.

The App Store had a record-breaking December quarter with over 2 billion downloads in the month of December alone. The App Store now offers more than 775
column120: 000 apps to over 0.5 billion accountholders in 155 countries
column121: including over 300
column122:
000 native iPad apps. Cumulative app downloads have now surpassed 40 billion and we\u2019re delighted to have paid our app developers over 7 billion for sales of their incredible work. iPod continues to grow at amazing rate now with 250 million accounts and our customers love our iMessage service sending a staggering 2 billion plus iMessage\u2019s per day.

I would now like to turn to the Apple retail stores
column123: revenue was in all-time high of over 6.4 billion with growth yield primarily by record iPhone and iPad sales. We opened in total 11 new stores during the quarter including four new stores in Greater China. We excited the quarter with 401 stores
column124: a 150 of which are outside United States. We also relocated or expanded 14 stores that had outgrown their former space during the quarter. With an average of 396 stores opened
column125:
average revenue per store was 16.3 million or 1.25 million per store per week compared to 1.22 million per store per week in the year ago quarter. Retail segment income was 1.6 billion.

We hosted a record 121 million visitors to our stores during the quarter compared to a 110 million in the year ago quarter. That translates to 23
column126: 000 visitors per store per week
column127: a 7% increase year-over-year. Total company gross margin was 38.6% which was about 260 basis points higher than our guidance. About half of this difference were driven by lower products and transitory cost that we reflected in our guidance while the remainder resulted from a higher mix of iPhone\u2019s
column128:
a weaker U.S. dollar and leverage on the higher revenue.

Operating expenses were 3.9 billion included 460 million in stock based compensation expense. (Inaudible) was 462 million and the tax rate for the quarter was 26%. Turning to cash
column129: our cash plus short term and long term marketable securities totaled a 137.1 billion at the end of the December quarter compared to a 121 billion at the end of the September quarter
column130:
a sequential increase of almost 16 billion.

The increase in cash was net of 2.5 billion in dividends paid and 2 billion in an upfront payment in conjunction with our accelerated share repurchase program. Over 94 billion of our total cash was offshore at the end of the December quarter. Cash flow from operations was a record 23.4 billion growing by almost 6 billion year-over-year of 33% increase. Our Board of Directors has declared a dividend of $2.55 for common share payable on February 14th
column131: 2013 the shareholders at record as of the close of business on February 11th
column132:
2013.

As we move ahead into the March quarter I would like to review our outlook which includes the types of forward-looking information that Nancy referred to at the beginning of the call. In addition to the reporting changes that I\u2019ve already mentioned to further increase transparency into our business we\u2019re changing our approach to how we provide guidance. In recent years our guidance reflected a conservative point estimate of results every quarter that we have reasonable confidence in achieving. Going forward we plan to provide a range of guidance that reflects our belief of what we\u2019re likely to achieve.

"
column133:
"

Well we cannot forecast with complete accuracy we believe we\u2019re likely to report within the range of guidance we provide. Therefore for the March quarter we\u2019re providing revenue guidance of between 41 billion and 43 billion compared to 39.2 billion in the year ago quarter. We expect gross margin to be between 37.5% and 38.5% reflecting approximately 90 million related to stock based compensation expense. We expect OpEx to be between 3.8 billion and 3.9 billion including about 480 million related to stock based compensation.

We expect other income/(expense) to be about $350 million and we expect the tax rate to be about 26%. In closing we\u2019re thrilled to have generated over 54 billion of revenue in a 13 week period while executing multiple major product transitions. We sold over 75 million iOS devices during the quarter which is a staggering number. We\u2019re producing our best products ever and the execution by our engineering
column134: operations and sales teams to deliver 10s of millions of such innovative
column135: beautifully designed products in such a short time frame is phenomenal. We\u2019re very pleased with our record iPhone and iPad sales
column136:
our record music moving and app sales and continued expansion of our robust eco-system. And finally we remain very confident in our new product pipeline.

"
column137:
"


With that

I\u2019d like to open the call to questions.

Nancy Paxton

Thank you

Katy

we returned about $4.5 billion of cash this quarter and we started the buyback program and expect to return about $45 billion over three years to our shareholders. We do consider increasing these programs and we\u2019ll do what we think is in the best interest of our shareholders.

Katy Huberty - Morgan Stanley

From Goldman Sachs

we\u2019ll hear from Bill Shope.

column155: great. Thank you. Katy had alluded to this

do you think that\u2019s a valid point of differentiation? And do you think there is a long-term case for a larger screen size or at least the larger variety of screen sizes for iPhones and for the smartphone category in general?

Tim Cook

column256: about half this difference was driven by lower product in transitory cost and we had reflected in our guidance and the rest came from a higher mix of iPhone\u2019s
column257:
a weaker dollar and leverage on the higher revenue.

As we look forward we think the gross margin will be somewhere between about 10 basis points and a 110 basis points lower sequentially. We believe that there are two primary factors that will benefit gross margins sequentially
column258:
first being the largest of the two. Our teams have made meaningful progress in reductions in product and transitory cost from the actions that they have been working on to get down to the cost curve. So we expect the benefit in the March quarter beyond what we saw in the December quarter and second we expect a more typical level of deferred revenue from device sales. We expect these factors to be more than offset by 10 to a 120 basis points by the loss of leverage coming out of the December quarter which is very typical for us and a different mix of our current products.

And regarding mix as an example as we indicated last quarter the iPad mini gross margin is significantly below the corporate average and we expect to be able to meet demand for this product in the March quarter which again we could not in the December quarter.

column421: Chris

column423: but let me give you some things we thought about in coming up with the range of $41 billion to $43 billion. It is that range is a 5% to 10% year-over-year increase. And there are few factors that are impacting the year-over-year results making the strong performance of the business a little bit harder to see. So
column424: let me point a few of these out. First of all
column425: as we have talked about several times on the call
column426: last year in the March quarter
column427: we\u2019ve built 2.6 million units of iPhone channel inventory
column428: which allowed us to get into our 4 to 6-week range. That increased the revenue in the year ago quarter by $1.6 billion. And as Tim talked about that was sell-in that was not sell-through
column429: we are thinking about the business on a sell-through basis. So
column430:
don\u2019t lose sight of the 1.6 billion.

"
column431:
"

"
column432:
"

Second
column433: the iPhone 5 rollout this year
column434: has been our fastest ever. We are selling in 100 countries by the end of December. Last year
column435: we did not achieve this country distribution until the March quarter
column436: which included China that we launched in January. Third
column437: we made a very good strategic decision to introduce the iPad mini which customers love and to keep the price reduced iPad 2 in the line. As a result of this
column438: we saw a reduction in our iPad ASPs of about $101 year-over-year in the December quarter. And you can see that
column439:
our iPad units grew faster than our iPad revenue in the December quarter. We would expect iPad ASPs to be down quite a bit in the March quarter on a year-over-year basis for the same reasons.

"
column441:
"

And then finally
column442: the PC market grew 4% last year in the March quarter
column443: and this year IDC is projecting that to decline by 3%. So
column444: considering these factors
column445:
the underlying performance of the business is much stronger than the 5% to 10% year-over-year growth implies and we remain very confident in our business and our new product pipeline.

"
column446:
"

"
column447:
"

Chris Whitmore - Deutsche Bank

"
column448:
"

"
column449:
"

And for my follow-up I wanted to come back to something Tim said earlier about that you are not fearing cannibalization; I wanted to ask in context of your iPhone business given the strength you are seeing at the low end of your product line the iPhone 4 being stocked out during the quarter. There seems to be a lot of demand at lower price points for the iPhone
column450:
why not get more aggressive at lower price bands and move down market in the iPhone business? Thanks.

"
column451:
"

"
column452:
"

Tim Cook

"
column453:
"

"
column454:
"

I am not going to go into our pricing strategy
column455:
but we feel great about the opportunity of getting products to customers and a percentage of those buying other Apple products. And that we have obviously seen evidence of that through history and continue to see evidence of that today.

"
column456:
"

Nancy Paxton

Thank you Chris. A replay of today's call will be available for two weeks as a podcast on the iTunes Store
column457: as a webcast on apple.com/investor
column458: and via telephone
column459: and the numbers for the telephone replay are 888-203-1112 or 719-457-0820. Please enter confirmation code 1474555. These replays will be available by approximately 5.30 pm Pacific Time today. Members of the press with additional questions can contact Steve Dowling at 408-974-1896 and financial analysts can contact Joan Hoover or me
column460: with additional questions. Joan is at 408-974-4570
column461:
and I'm at 408-974-5420. Thanks again for joining us.

Operator

Ladies and gentlemen that does conclude today\u2019s presentation. We thank everyone for your participation.

"

column1:
{"Apple's CEO Discusses F2Q13 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Apple Inc. (NASDAQ:AAPL)

"
column8:
"

Nancy Paxton \u2013 Senior Director-Investor Relations

"
column9:
"

Tim Cook \u2013 Chief Executive Officer

"
column10:
"

Peter Oppenheimer \u2013 Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer

"
column14:
"

Katy Huberty \u2013 Morgan Stanley & Co. LLC

"
column15:
"

Bill C. Shope \u2013 Goldman Sachs & Co.

"
column16:
"

Steven M. Milunovich \u2013 UBS Securities LLC

"
column17:
"

Toni M. Sacconaghi \u2013 Sanford C. Bernstein & Co. LLC

column18:

Ben A. Reitzes \u2013 Barclays Capital
column20:

Shannon S. Cross \u2013 Cross Research LLC
