"
column28: we are about to begin. Good day
column30:
and welcome to this Apple Incorporated Second Quarter Fiscal Year 2013 Earnings Release Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded.

"
column31:
"

At this time for opening remarks and introductions
column32: I would like to turn the call over to Nancy Paxton
column33: Senior Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead
column37: and thanks to everyone for joining us. Speaking today are Apple's CEO
column38: Tim Cook; and CFO
column39: Peter Oppenheimer; and they'll be joined by Treasurer
column40:
Gary Wipfler for the Q&A session with analysts.

"
column41:
"

Please note that some of the information you'll hear during our discussion today will consist of forward-looking statements
column46: other income and expense
column47: stock-based compensation expense
column48: taxes
column49:
future products and capital allocation plans. Actual results or trends could differ materially from our forecast.

"
column50:
"

For more information
column51: please refer to the risk factors discussed in Apple's Form 10-K for 2012
column52: the Form 10-Q for the first quarter of 2013 and the Form 8-K filed with the SEC today along with the associated press releases. Apple assumes no obligation to update any forward-looking statements or information
column53:
which speak as of their respective dates.

"
column54:
"

I'd now like to turn the call over to Tim Cook for introductory remarks.

"
column55:
"

Tim Cook

"
column56:
"

"
column57:
"

Thanks
column58: Nancy. Hello everyone
column59:
and thank you for joining us. We have a lot of news to share with you today about the details of our March quarter as well as a significant increase to our capital return program.

"
column60:
"

First
column61: I would like to talk about our business and the road ahead. We are now half way through our fiscal 2013
column62: and we\u2019ve accomplished a tremendous amount. We\u2019ve introduced and ramped production of an unprecedented number of new products
column63: and we\u2019ve set many new sales records. Our revenue for the first half was over $98 billion and our net income was over $22 billion. During that time
column64: we sold 85 million iPhones and 42 million iPads. These are very
column65: very large numbers
column66:
unimaginable even to us just a few years ago.

"
column67:
"

Despite producing results that met or beat our guidance as we have done consistently
column68: we know they  didn't meet everyone's expectations
column69: and though we\u2019ve achieved incredible scale and financial success
column70:
we acknowledge that our growth rate has slowed and our margins have decreased from the exceptionally high level we experienced in 2012.

"
column71:
"

Our revenues grew about $13 billion in the first half of this fiscal year. Even though that\u2019s like adding the total first half revenue of five Fortune 500 companies
column72: our average weekly growth slowed to 19% and our gross margins are closer to the levels of a few years ago. Our fiscal 2012 results were incredibly strong and that\u2019s making comparison very difficult this year. Last year
column73: our business benefited from both high growth and demand for products and a corresponding growth in channel inventories along with a richer mix of higher gross margin products
column74: a more favorable foreign currency environment
column75:
and historically low costs.

"
column76:
"

These compares are made further challenging until we anniversary the launch of the iPad mini
column77: which as you know
column78: we strategically priced at a lower margin. As Peter will discuss
column79:
we are guiding to flat revenues year over year for the June quarter along with a slight sequential decline in gross margins.

"
column80:
"

The decline in Apple\u2019s stock price over the last couple of quarters has been very frustrating to all of us. But Apple remains very strong and we will continue to do what we do best. We can\u2019t control items such as exchange rates and world economies and even certain cost pressures
column81:
but the most important objective for Apple will always be creating innovative products and that is directly within our control.

"
column82:
"

We will continue to focus on the long-term
column83: and we remain very optimistic about our future. We are participating on large and growing markets. We see great opportunities in front of us
column84: particularly given the long-term prospects of the smartphone and tablet market
column85: the strength of our incredible ecosystem
column86: which we plan to continue to augment with new services
column87: our plans for expanded distribution
column88:
and the potential of exciting new product categories.

"
column89:
"

Take the smartphone market for example
column90: IDC estimates that this market will double between 2012 and 2016 to an incredible 1.4 billion units annually
column91:
and Gartner estimates that the tablet market is growing at an even faster rate from 125 million units in 2012 to a projected 375 million by 2016.

"
column92:
"

Our teams are hard at work on some amazing new hardware
column93: software
column94:
and services that we can\u2019t wait to introduce this fall and throughout 2014. We continue to be very confident in our future product plans.

"
column95:
"

Apple has many distinct and unique advantages as the only company in the industry with world-class skills in hardware
column96: software
column97: and services. We have the strongest ecosystem in the industry with App Stores in 155 countries
column98: iTunes music stores in 119 countries
column99: hundreds of millions of iCloud users around the world
column100: and most importantly
column101: the highest loyalty and customer satisfaction rates in the business. And of course
column102: we have a tremendous culture of innovation with a relentless focus on making the world\u2019s best products that change people\u2019s lives. This is the same culture and company that brought the world the iPhone and the iPad
column103:
and we\u2019ve got a lot more surprises in the works.

"
column104:
"

A little over a year ago
column105: we announced a plan to return $45 billion to shareholders over three years. Since we began paying dividends last August and began share buybacks last October
column106: we\u2019ve already returned $10 billion under that program. We continue to generate cash in excess of our needs to operate the business
column107: invest in our future
column108:
and maintain flexibility to take advantage of strategic opportunities.

"
column109:
"

We remain firmly committed to our objective of delivering attractive returns to shareholders through both our business performance and return of capital. So today
column110: we are announcing an aggressive plan that more than doubles the size of the capital return program we announced last year to a total of $100 billion by the end of calendar year 2015. The vast majority of our incremental cash return will be in the form of share repurchases. As the Board and management team deliberated among the various alternatives to returning cash
column111:
we concluded that investing in Apple was the best.

"
column112:
"

In addition to the share repurchases
column113: we are increasing our current dividend by 15% to further appeal to investors seeking yield. And as part of our updated program
column114:
we will access the debt markets. Peter will provide more details about all of this in a moment.

"
column115:
"

We appreciate the input that so many of our shareholders have provided us on how best to deploy our cash. We will review our cash allocation strategy each year
column116: and we will continue to invest confidently in the business to bring great new products to market
column117: strategically deploy capital in our supply chain
column118: our retail stores and our infrastructure
column119: and make acquisitions to expand our capabilities. We will be disciplined in what we do
column120:
but we will not underinvest.

"
column121:
"

I\u2019d now like to turn the call over to Peter to discuss the details of the March quarter. Peter?

"
column122:
"

Peter Oppenheimer

"
column123:
"

Thank you
column124: Tim. We are pleased to report the results of our second fiscal quarter. We established new March quarter records for iPhone and iPad sales and new all-time record for iTunes sales
column125:
leading to Apple\u2019s strongest March quarter revenue ever.

"
column126:
"

Revenue for the quarter was $43.6 billion compared to $39.2 billion in the year ago quarter
column127:
an increase of $4.4 billion or 11% and $600 million over the high end of our guidance range. The year-over-year revenue increase was fueled primarily by strong growth in iPad and iTunes sales as well as continued strong revenue from iPhone and Mac.

"
column128:
"

Operating margin was $12.6 billion
column129: representing 28.8% of revenue. Net income was $9.5 billion translating to diluted earnings per share of $10.09. As for the details of the quarter
column130: I\u2019d like to begin with iPhone. We sold 37.4 million iPhones compared to 35.1 million in the year-ago quarter
column131: an increase of over 2.3 million or 7%. We ended the quarter with about 11.6 million total iPhones in channel inventory
column132:
a sequential increase of about 1 million iPhones and we ended the quarter within our target range of four to six weeks of iPhone channel inventory.

"
column133:
"

Based on research published earlier this month by comScore
column134: iPhones garnered the number one spot in the U.S. smartphone market for the three-month period ended in February with 39% share
column135: up from 35% in the previous survey period. And in Japan
column136:
IDC Japan announced that iPhone gained the number one position for all of calendar year 2012 as well as for calendar Q4 2012 in both handsets and smartphones. This is also the first time a non-Japanese company has achieved the number one spot for an entire year.

"
column137:
"

In addition
column138: Apple was ranked number one in Nikkei\u2019s 2013 Japan Brand Survey
column139: achieving the top spot for the second year in a row
column140: which is unprecedented for a non-Japanese company. Around the world
column141: based on its latest published estimates
column142:
IDC ranked iPhone number one or two in smarphone sales in over half the countries IDC tracks.

"
column143:
"

A recent study by Kantar measured 95% loyalty rate among iPhone owners
column144: substantially higher than the competition
column145: and iPhone remains top in customer experience. Last month
column146:
we were very pleased to receive the number one ranking in smartphone customer satisfaction from J.D. Power and Associates for the ninth consecutive time.

"
column147:
"

Businesses around the world continue to scale iPhone across their workforces. Globally
column148: nearly 30
column149:
000 companies are developing and distributing iOS apps for corporate use by their employees.

"
column150:
"

Cisco\u2019s Bring Your Own Device program across 80 countries has resulted in a 50% increase in the number of iPhones connecting to its corporate network in the past year.

"
column151:
"

GlaxoSmithKline has developed more than 50 in-house iOS apps to support the thousands of iPhones and iPads connecting to its corporate network. Other companies such as AXA
column152: Nordstrom\u2019s
column153: Eaton  Corporation
column154: and Takeda Pharmaceuticals are supporting thousands of iPhones
column155:
and are continually adding new in-house apps to better serve customers and help employees work more efficiently.

"
column156:
"

Turning to iPad
column157: we were thrilled to sell 19.5 million iPads during the quarter compared to 11.8 million in the year ago quarter
column158:
that\u2019s an increase of 7.7 million units or 65%.

"
column159:
"

iPad experienced very strong year-over-year growth in every operating segment
column160: particularly in Greater China and Japan where sales more than doubled year over year. Both iPad and iPad mini continue to be extremely popular
column161:
and we were pleased with sales of both.

"
column162:
"

We were able to sell significantly more iPad minis in the March quarter than in the December launch quarter and to expand availability to China. Customers love the combination of experience
column163: performance
column164: and size that iPad mini offers
column165:
and our early market research indicates that the overwhelming majority of iPad mini purchasers are first-time iPad customers.

"
column166:
"

We ended the quarter with about 4.8 million iPads in channel inventory
column167: a sequential increase of about 1.4 million. All of the sequential increase was attributable to iPad mini. As we discussed previously
column168:
we were not able to meet demand for iPad mini in the December quarter and entered the March quarter below our target range of channel inventory. This sequential increase places us within our target range of four to six weeks of total iPad channel inventory.

"
column169:
"

The most recent survey published by ChangeWave indicated a 96% satisfaction rate among iPad customers. Not only is iPad a huge hit among consumers
column170:
but it also continues to be widely adopted by business customers as well. iPad and the iOS ecosystem are driving innovation across industries and in companies large and small.

"
column171:
"

We are delighted by the number of companies that are choosing iPad for their most important business tasks as well as the rapid adoption of iPad in emerging countries around the world. Doctors at the Columbia Cardiovascular Foundation in South America are using an in-house app to perform remote diagnostics for patients in inaccessible parts of the country.

"
column172:
"

First National Bank
column173: the oldest bank in South Africa has issued iPads to wealth managers to help enhance customer relationships and interactions. And in the education market
column174: Grupo Santillana has developed UNO Internacional and integrated educational system that uses iPads to create digital learning environment in more than 700 private K-12 schools in Latin America. UNO Internacionalhas deployed more than 60
column175: 000 iPads to schools in Mexico
column176: Colombia
column177: and Brazil including 17
column178:
000 iPads for teachers and students in Brazil in the March quarter alone.

"
column179:
"

Turning to Mac
column180: we sold just under 4 million Macs
column181: which is a 2% decline from the year-ago quarter. IDC estimates that the global personal computer market contracted by 14% during the March quarter. We experienced strong year-over-year growth in desktop sales following the December quarter launch of our stunning new iMacs
column182:
offset by a decline in portable sales given a weaker personal computer market overall. We ended the quarter within our four to five-week target range in Mac channel inventory.

"
column183:
"

Moving to iPod
column184: we sold 5.6 million iPods compared to 7.7 million in the year ago quarter. iPod Touch continued to account for over half of all iPods sold during the March quarter. iPod\u2019s share of U.S. market for MP3 players was over 70% in the March quarter based on the latest data published by NPD
column185:
and iPod continues to be the top-selling MP3 player in most countries we track based on the latest data published by GfK.

"
column186:
"

The Apple ecosystem continues to grow and thrive and we believe it\u2019s a very important driver of our incredibly strong customer satisfaction and retention
column187: as well as developer interest and success. This Sunday marks the 10th anniversary of the introduction of the iTunes Music Store
column188:
which revolutionized the distribution of digital content.

"
column189:
"

Today
column190: our iTunes store offer the broadest combination of geographic reach in content depth in the industry
column191: and they surpassed quarterly billings of $4 billion for the first time ever in the March quarter
column192: that\u2019s a $16 billion annual run rate making our digital content stores the largest in the world. The quarter\u2019s iTunes billings translated to record quarterly iTunes revenue of $2.4 billion
column193: up 28% from the year ago March quarter with new quarterly revenue records for music
column194: movies
column195:
and apps.

"
column196:
"

The strong iTunes sales in addition to other service revenue helped us achieve for the first time more than $4 billion in combined quarterly revenue from iTunes
column197: software
column198: and services. We are thrilled with the growth of these revenue streams. Today
column199: we have music stores in 119 countries offering a combined catalog of 35 million songs. We sell movies in 109 countries offering 60
column200: 000 titles
column201: and we have iBookstores in 155 countries offering 1.75 million iBooks for sale
column202: and with App Stores in 155 countries that encompass almost 90% of the world\u2019s population
column203: our developers have created more than 850
column204: 000 iOS apps
column205: including 350
column206:
000 apps made for iPad.

"
column207:
"

Cumulative app downloads have surpassed 45 billion and app developers have made over $9 billion for their sales through the App Store
column208: including $4.5 billion in the most recent four quarters alone. Canalys estimate the sales from our App Store accounted for 74% of all app sales worldwide in the March quarter. We believe this is in large part due to the great development environment
column209: broad distribution
column210: large and active user base
column211:
and seamless integration that the iOS platform offers.

"
column212:
"

Developer such as Backflip Studios have seen explosive growth in their business
column213: thanks to the success of their apps on the iOS platform. With 70 people
column214: this company maintains a growing suite of titles that has seen over 275 million downloads equating  to nearly 5 million daily active users and 34 million monthly active users. With annual App Store sales approaching $100 million
column215:
Backflip\u2019s iOS sales comprised approximately 95% of the company\u2019s revenues in 2012.

"
column216:
"

Another tremendous success story is Supercell
column217: founded in 2010. Based in Finland
column218: Supercell\u2019s Hey Day and Clash of Clans titles available only on iOS have been the top most in iPad games in over 60 countries helping the company generate $8.5 million in revenue per employee in 2012. And in the enterprise
column219: iOS devices have a strong lead over Android. In its most recently published quarterly enterprise device activations report
column220:
Good Technologies found iOS devices accounted for 77% of all activations by its corporate customers.

"
column221:
"

And thanks to careful App Store curation for the quality of apps
column222: the iOS platform offers a much more secure environment. Recent research by McAfee Labs found that 97% of identified mobile malware was on the Android platform
column223:
with the remainder primarily on the Symbian and Java ME platforms. But perhaps the most important measure of the success of our ecosystem is how engaged our customers are with our products and services.

"
column224:
"

In its most recently published update
column225: Chitika found that iPad accounted for 82% of all North American Tablet Web Traffic in March. Interest in apps remained very strong in the March quarter with over 800 apps downloaded per second and year-over-year iOS app revenues more than doubling in the quarter. And since launching iCloud just 18 months ago
column226:
we now have 300 million people using it every day. We will continue to invest in the ecosystem and have some great new features and capabilities in the pipeline.

"
column227:
"

I\u2019d now like to turn to the Apple Retail Stores. Revenue for the quarter was $5.2 billion compared to $4.4 billion in the year ago quarter
column228: an increase of 19%. This growth was fueled  primarily by strong sales of iPhone and iPad. We ended the quarter with a total of 402 stores
column229: including a 151 outside the United States. We expect to open about 30 new stores in total in fiscal 2013 and to complete at least 20 store remodels. With an average of 401 stores open in the March quarter
column230: average revenue per store was $13.1 million
column231:
compared to $12.2 million in the year ago quarter. Retail segment income was $1.1 billion.

"
column232:
"

We hosted 91 million visitors to our stores during the quarter compared to 85 million in the year-ago quarter. That translates the 17
column233: 500 visitors per store per week. Total company gross margin was 37.5%
column234:
which was at the low end of our guidance range of 37.5% to 38.5%. Operating expenses were $3.8 billion and included $488 million in stock based compensation expense. OI&E was $347 million and the tax rate for the quarter was 26%

"
column235:
"

And turning to our cash
column236: we ended the quarter with $144.7 billion in cash plus  short-term and long-term marketable securities compared to $137.1 billion at the end of the December quarter
column237: a sequential increase of $7.6 billion. Over $102 billion of our total cash was offshore at the end of the March quarter
column238: and cash flow from operations was $12.5 billion. We paid $2.5 billion in dividends in the March quarter
column239: and earlier this month
column240: we concluded the $1.95 billion accelerated share repurchase program that we initiated in the December quarter
column241:
resulting in cumulative retirement of over 4 million shares of Apple stock.

"
column242:
"

As Tim discussed
column243: we are pleased to announce that we are more than doubling our return of capital program to $100 billion by the end of calendar year 2015
column244: which translates to an average of about $30 billion per year. We will continue to return capital to shareholders through dividends
column245: share repurchases
column246: and cash used to net-share-settle vesting RSUs. To facilitate our program
column247:
we will access the debt markets.

"
column248:
"

Let me provide more details regarding the three key elements of our plan. First
column249: our Board has increased the share buyback authorization to $60 billion from the original $10 billion announced last year
column250: that\u2019s a $50 billion increase. This is the largest share buyback authorization of any company in history. We are very confident in Apple\u2019s future and believe so strongly that repurchasing our shares represents an attractive use of our capital that we have dedicated a vast majority of the increase in our capital return program to share repurchases. We will buy shares under this authorization beginning this month. We will also continue to net-share-settle employee RSUs as they vest
column251:
and expect to use about $1 billion of cash annually to do this.

"
column252:
"

Second
column253: we are increasing our quarterly dividend from $2.65 to $3.05 per share
column254: a 15% increase. We plan to review our quarterly dividend payment annually. Our Board of Directors has declared a dividend of $3.05 per common share payable on May 16
column256: to shareholders of record as of the close of business on May 13
column257:
2013. We are very proud that Apple is among the largest dividend payers in the world with annual payments of about $11 billion.

"
column258:
"

Third
column259:
we will access the U.S. debt markets over time and have recently secured credit ratings from S&P and Moody\u2019s. We are continuing to generate significant cash offshore and repatriating this cash would result in significant tax consequences under current U.S. tax law.

"
column260:
"

Incorporating debt into our capital structure will provide several benefits including access to attractively priced capital
column261: a reduction in our overall cost of capital and an efficient leverage of our very strong balance sheet. We expect to fund the capital return program from existing domestic cash
column262: future cash generated in the U.S.
column263:
and from borrowing in the U.S. We will maintain sufficient domestic liquidity to grow the business and execute capital expenditures and acquisitions. The program announced today will result in returning an average of $30 billion annually to shareholders.

"
column264:
"

To put this in perspective
column265: the $30 billion would have represented substantially all of our fiscal year 2012 fully tax free cash flow had we repatriated our foreign earnings. Between now and the end of calendar year 2015
column266:
we would expect both our foreign cash and our domestic borrowing to grow. We will continue to review each element of our capital return program on an annual basis.

"
column267:
"

In conclusion
column268: our capital return program is designed to facilitate our objective of delivering attractive returns to our shareholders on an efficient basis
column269:
while maintaining the flexibility to invest in the incredible opportunities that we continue to see for our business.

"
column270:
"

Now
column271: as we move ahead into the June quarter
column272: I\u2019d like to review our outlook
column273:
which includes the types of forward-looking information that Nancy referred to at the beginning of the call. We expect revenue to be between $33.5 billion and $35.5 billion compared to $35 billion in the year-ago quarter. We expect gross margin to be between 36% and 37% reflecting approximately $90 billion related to stock-based compensation expense. We expect OpEx to be between $3.85 billion and $3.95 billion including about $500 million related to stock-based compensation. We expect OI&E to be about $300 million and we expect the tax rate to be about 26%.

"
column274:
"

In closing
column275:
we are pleased with our record March quarter revenue and record March quarter iPhone and iPad sales. We\u2019re very proud of the breadth and depth of our tremendous ecosystem and our new all-time record for iTunes sales. We are also in the fortunate position to be able to more than double our return of capital program to $100 billion with the larger share repurchase authorization in history and to be one of the largest dividend payers in the world with annual payments of about $11 billion. We remain very confident in our product pipeline.

column646: and touting the benefits of Microsoft and some of the other OS\u2019s that are out there in terms of security and interoperability in some of the enterprise companies. So I\u2019m curious what you\u2019ve heard from your customers
column647:
have you seen much displacement and what are sort of the discussions that you have with enterprise customers with regard to iPads and fitting into their systems? Thanks.

"
column649:
"

We seem to be doing really well and Peter had referenced earlier
column650: the Good Technology\u2019s data that says that iOS accounted for 77% of all their activations by their corporate customers. Now that would not include BlackBerry
column651: but it would include all the other guys. and so we seem to be doing really well and honestly
column652: I don\u2019t see the recent announcements changing that at all. I\u2019ve seen more and more people developing more and more custom apps for their businesses on iOS to be used on iPad and we\u2019re very
column653: very bullish on it. As a matter of fact
column654: just to quote you some numbers
column655: iPad now is being used in 95% of the Fortune 500 and what\u2019s even more impressive probably is on the global 500 companies
column657:
"

Shannon S. Cross \u2013 Cross Research LLC

"
column663:
Shannon. Can we have the next question please?

"
column665:
"

We\u2019ll go to Mark Moskowitz with JPMorgan.

"
column666:
"

Mark A. Moskowitz \u2013 JPMorgan Securities LLC

"
column668: earlier you talked about how the December quarter had a very big and broad product refresh
column669:
were there any learning points from that experience in terms of maybe it\u2019s better to stage or kind of stagger out launches over multi-quarters versus one quarter. How should we think about that going forward?

"
column671:
"

It\u2019s a good question. I don\u2019t spend a lot of time looking back except to learn from it
column672: and if we could run it over frankly
column673: I would have announced the iMac after the turn of the year
column674: because we felt our customers had to wait too long for that specific product; or the iPad mini was in shortage in the December quarter I would not have done that differently
column675: because we were able to get the iPad mini out to many millions of customers who really wanted that product for their holiday. And so
column678: our teams fortunately can do a lot
column681: I sort of wish it were after the turn of the year
column682:
because our customers would not have had to wait as long as they did.

"
column683:
"

Mark A. Moskowitz \u2013 JPMorgan Securities LLC

"
column684:
"

Okay. And then my follow-up question is back to the ecosystem. Are there other metrics or milepost you can share with us
column685: you acknowledged earlier that the growth of revenue at Apple have slowed for some of your key products. But how about the ecosystem in terms of usage rates
column686:
are you seeing slowing there or are you actually seeing the opposite where there\u2019s maybe acceleration within each user?

"
column688:
"

We see incredible usage in every study that we see. These aren\u2019t just done by us
column689:
as a matter of fact the vast majority of them come from other people. The usage of iOS devices are staggering compared to others. It\u2019s a phenomenal difference. And I think that shows the strength of the ecosystem.

"
column690:
"

Mark A. Moskowitz \u2013 JPMorgan Securities LLC

"
column693:
"

And Mark this is Peter. I will add that
column694:
we are now paying very happily our developers more than $1 billion every quarter.

"
column695:
"

Mark A. Moskowitz \u2013 JPMorgan Securities LLC

"

and I\u2019m at 408-974-5420. And thanks again for joining us.

that does conclude today\u2019s presentation. We do thank everyone for your participation.

"

column62: and operating margin was $9.2 billion representing 26% of revenue. Net income was $6.9 billion translating to the diluted earnings per share of $7.47. Channel inventories declined sequentially by $1 billion during the June quarter this year meaning that sell-through was $36.3 billion. In contrast
column63: channel inventory increased $700 million from the beginning to the end of the June quarter last year meaning that sell-through was $34.3 billion in that quarter. As such
column64: our June quarter sell-through increased by $2 billion
column65:
or 6% year-over-year ahead of our 1% [selling and] [ph] revenue growth.

column66:

column68: an increase of 5.2 million
column69: or 20%. We had a sequential decrease of about 600

column71: UK

column77:
"

iPhone unit sales in the U.S. increased 51% compared to the year ago quarter and based on research recently published by comScore
column78: iPhone once again achieved the number one spot in the U.S. smartphone market for the three months period ended in May with over 39% share. iPhone sales were also very strong in Japan growing [66%] [ph] year-over-year. iPhone is the top selling smartphone in Japan based on the latest published quarterly data from IDC and Apple is the number one or number two selling smartphone manufacturer in most markets IDC tracks including North America

column85:
Malaysia and Singapore.

column87: an unprecedented nine consecutive times it has also received the top customer satisfaction ranking in a number of surveys including the recent Quality Insights survey of smartphone customers in South Korea. iPhone also continues to be the smartphone of choice for business. column96:

000 units in the June quarter this year.

its highest level this year.

In every major industry around the world companies are developing

column141: which provides the state\u2019s little school and high school students and teachers with personal computing solutions allowed individual school districts to choose which products to purchase rather than standardized on a single statewide solution. column143:

column146:

column155:
000 TV episodes as well as the world\u2019s largest collection of music on the iTunes Store.

With an average of 405 stores opened in the June average revenue per store was 10.1 million compared to 11.1 million in the year ago quarter.

a sequential increase of 1.9 billion. A 106 billion of our total cash was offshored at the end of the June quarter and cash flow from operations with 7.8 billion. In early April we concluded the 1.95 billion accelerated share repurchase program that we initiated in December quarter resulted in cumulative retirement of over 4 million shares of Apple stock under that program.

column184:

including about $495 million related to stock-based compensation. We expect OI&E to be about $200 million and we expect the tax rate to be about 26.5%.

We had announced in March and so that was our first full quarter and so from what Peter and I expected 90 days ago we hit within the midpoint of the range that we expected to hit on iPad unit sales and so it was not a surprise to us.

which speak as of their respective dates.

I\u2019d now like to turn the call over to Tim Cook for introductory remarks.

column48:

Tim Cook

"
column49:
"

Thanks
column50: Nancy. Good afternoon
column51:
everyone and thank you very much for joining us. We are eager to share with you the results of the final quarter of Apple\u2019s fiscal 2013 with a strong finish to an amazing year and Peter will provide details about the September quarter shortly.

"
column52:
"

But first I\u2019m happy to tell you that Apple\u2019s business is stronger than ever. We are in a unique position of having world class hardware
column53: software and service skills under one road
column54: which enables us to provide an unparallel user experience to 100s of millions of customers. And working with our vibrant developer community
column55:
we\u2019ve built a large and thriving ecosystem.

"
column56:
"

We are winning with our products in all the ways that are most important to us
column57: in customer satisfaction
column58:
in product usage and in customer loyalty. Our relentless focus on providing innovation that enhances our customer\u2019s lives is evident in extraordinary list of products that we\u2019ve launched in just the last couple of months.

"
column59:
"

From the colorful iPhone 5c and forward thinking iPhone 5s to the powerful new iMac
column60: MacBook Pro and Mac Pro to the stunning iPad Mini with Retina display and the dramatically thinner
column61:
lighter and more powerful iPad Air.

"
column62:
"

Thanks to a deep collaboration between our design and engineering teams. We also launched iOS 7 with a stunning new redesign
column63:
powerful new features and a great new service called iTunes Radio. We introduced OS X Mavericks bringing new core technologies for breakthrough power efficiency and performance to our Mac and we introduced next generation iLife and iWork apps for iOS and OS X. And we\u2019re making all of this incredible software free because we want our customers to have access to the greatest new features. All of these are products that only Apple could have delivered and most companies would be proud to just have one of them.

"
column64:
"

Looking back
column65: we\u2019re very pleased with Apple\u2019s many accomplishments during fiscal 2013. Our customers had an incredible response to our product line up
column66: buying a 150 million iPhone
column67:
71 million iPads and 16 million Macs across the fiscal year.

"
column68:
"

We expanded the breadth and depth of our ecosystem and we generated over $16 billion revenue from iTunes software and services. We also welcomed almost 400 million visitors to our retail stores and opened or remodeled 49 new stores and for the second year in a row we produced over $50 million in revenue per store.

"
column69:
"

We generated record total company revenue of $171 billion
column70: earnings of $37 billion and operating cash flow of $54 billion. We paid over $8 billion in capital expenditures to both to our supply chain
column71:
expand our infrastructure and increased our retail footprint. We also completed 15 strategic acquisitions. That\u2019s an average of one acquisition every three to four weeks.

"
column72:
"

We more than doubled the size of our capital return program to a $100 billion
column73:
including the largest share repurchase authorization in history and we become one of the largest dividend payers in the world.

"
column74:
"

In fact
column75:
we returned over $36 billion to shareholders to dividend and share repurchases in the last five quarters alone. We remain firmly committed to our objective of delivering attractive returns to shareholders through both our business performance and a return of capital. We review our capital program regularly and our orders engaged in the discussion of capital allocation on an ongoing basis.

"
column76:
"

We have solicited feedback on our capital return program from shareholders in the past. We greatly appreciated their suggestions and we will actively seek their input again this year. As we\u2019ve in the past
column77:
the Board and the Management team will consider a wide range of issues and be thoughtful and deliberate and we will announce any changes to our current program in the first part of the new calendar year.

"
column78:
"

We are off to a great start in fiscal year \u201914. We continue to be very confident in Apple\u2019s future and we see significant opportunities ahead of us and both current product categories and new ones. We are participating in large and growing markets. Today smartphone penetration of the global handset market is only a little over 50%.

"
column79:
"

The smartphone category is expected to grow significantly in the next few years from about 1 billion units per year this year to over 1.7 billion in 2017. And the tablet market is growing at an even faster way from about 225 billion units this year to over 400 million in 2017. We are continuing to invest in R&D and distribution
column80: we\u2019re expanding our geographic coverage and we\u2019re building upon a phenomenal
column81:
but still very young retail store presence.

"
column82:
"

We are also proud to be a force for good in the world beyond our products
column83: whether its improving working conditions of the environment
column84: standing up for human rights
column85: helping eliminate AIDS or reinventing education
column86:
Apple is making substantial contributions to society.

"
column87:
"

I would like to thank all of our customers and our long-term shareholders for their loyalty and I\u2019d also like to thank Apple\u2019s many talented employees who have worked tirelessly to bring us this far and who are passionately focused on making great products that enrich people\u2019s lives.

"
column88:
"

I\u2019d now turn the call over to Peter to discuss the details of the most recent quarter. Peter?

"
column89:
"

Peter Oppenheimer

"
column90:
"

Thank you
column91:
Tim.

"
column92:
"

We are pleased to report the results of the final quarter of Apple\u2019s fiscal year \u201913 with record four quarter iPhone sales
column93:
driving our highest September quarter revenue ever.

"
column94:
"

Revenue for the quarter was $37.5 billion
column95: up $1.5 billion or 4% from the year-ago quarter
column96: and slightly above the high end of the guidance range. Gross margin was 37% at the high end of our guidance range
column97: and operating margin was $10 billion
column98:
representing 26.8% of revenue. Net income was $7.5 billion translating to diluted earnings per share of $8.26.

"
column99:
"

As for the details of the quarter
column100: I would like to begin with iPhone. We sold 33.8 million iPhones compared to 26.9 million in the year-ago quarter
column101:
an increase of 6.9 million or 26% and a new September quarter record. iPhone sales were ahead of our expectations and grew stronger year-over-year in each of our geographic segments.

"
column102:
"

We were particularly pleased with growth in a number of developing markets with unit sales up sharply year-over-year in Latin America
column103: the Middle East
column104: Russia and India. We were also very happy to add NTT Docomo to our carrier line up in Japan
column105:
a country where demand to iPhone has been especially strong.

"
column106:
"

iPhone sales remain very robust in the U.S with comScore estimating that Apple was the leading smartphone manufacture with a 40.7% smartphone subscribership for the three months ending in August. And among North American customers polled by ChangeWave late last month
column107: we plan to purchase the smartphone with a 90 days
column108:
63% indicated they plan to purchase an iPhone.

"
column109:
"

We exited the quarter with about 14.3 million total iPhones in channel inventory
column110:
which represented a sequential increase of 3.3 million from the June quarter and placed us at the low end of our target range of 4 to 6 weeks of iPhone channel inventory on a look forward basis.

"
column111:
"

Customers are loving their iPhones. Based on the most recently published research
column112: ChangeWave measured a 96% customer satisfaction rate among iPhone users and Kantar measured a 92% customer loyalty rate
column113: significantly higher than the competition. And we believe that a great customer experience translates to much higher usage. In fact
column114:
Experian reported that iPhone users spend an average of 53% more time each day on their phone than android phone users.

"
column115:
"

iPhone continues to be a key productivity tool for organizations around the world aided by apps from the app store as well as those custom built for internal use. In fact
column116: nearly 35
column117:
000 companies representing millions of employees worldwide are building custom apps that address specific workflow improvements with their iPhones and iPad users.

"
column118:
"

In the U.S.
column119: over 14
column120: 000 employees of Johnson Controls are using iPhones for work. The company has created in-house apps that have enhanced field technician service delivery and customer communications. In China
column121: AVIC International
column122: a unit of Aviation Industry Corporation of China has equipped 27
column123: 000 employees with iPhones to access internally developed apps for office
column124: administrative documentation
column125:
approval processes in key business intelligent systems.

"
column126:
"

Turning to iPad
column127: we sold 14.1 million iPads during the quarter compared to 14 million in the year-ago quarter. iPad sales exceeded our expectations in the September quarter as we approach our new product introductions. We experienced robust year-over-year sales growth in Japan
column128: Russia
column129: the Middle East and we were pleased with strong back-to-school demand for iPad in the U.S. and Canada. iPad sell-through was roughly equal to sell-in
column130:
so we exited the quarter with about 4.1 million units of iPad channel inventory within our target range of four to six weeks on a look-back basis.

"
column131:
"

Interest in iPad remains incredibly strong. In an August survey by ChangeWave
column132: consumers who intend to purchase tablets within 90 days
column133: 55% indicated they find the purchase of iPads more than four times the rate of the next most popular alternative. And of those who already own iPads
column134:
the survey measured a 99% customer satisfaction rate. The momentum of iOS devices in enterprise also remains incredibly strong.

"
column135:
"

In its latest Mobility Index Report
column136:
Good Technology indicated that the iOS platform accounted for 95% of enterprise mobile app activations and 72% of all mobile device activations in the September quarter while iPad accounted for 90% of total tablet activations. Companies around the world are using iPads with custom apps to reinvent their legacy business processes; improving efficiencies across organizations and job sections.

"
column137:
"

For example
column138:
direct store delivery reps at Dr Pepper Snapple Group uses iPads to facilitate communications and streamline the product delivery process. East Japan Railway personnel use iPad Minis to stay informed about schedule changes and access conductor manual. And Swedish manufacturer SKS uses a custom iPad app to calculate the life of their ball bearing products saving 10 to 15 minutes per calculation for every engineer several times per day.

"
column139:
"

Schools around the world continue to adopt iPad to transform teaching and learning in the classroom. In the U.K. the number of iPads sold to K-12 schools has more than doubled year-over-year and in Latin America; over 70
column140:
000 iPads are being used by systemic learner students [ph] across 800 schools to improve their learning experience.

"
column141:
"

Here in the U.S.
column142: school districts continue to rollout large iPad initiatives to students. The Coachella Valley School District in California is currently distributing over 19
column143: 000 iPads to its entire student body. In South Carolina every one of the Horry County School District's 10
column144: 000 middle school students will receive an iPad this year. These broad deployments are in part driven by the great educational content available on iPad and we're pleased to report that iBooks textbooks are now available across the U.S.
column145:
U.K. and Australian national high school curricula.

"
column146:
"

Last week we were thrilled to introduce new iPads featuring the A7 chip with 64-bit desktop-class architecture
column147: ultrafast wireless and expanded LTE connectivity. The new iPad Air features a beautiful retina display in an elegant unit body design that is 20% thinner and 28% lighter than the fourth generation iPad and the iPad Mini with retina display packs all the pixels of the iPad Air into its stunning 7.9 inch display and runs over 475
column148:
000 iPad apps available in the app store.

"
column149:
"

Turning to Mac
column150: sales with 4.6 million Macs were above our expectations
column151: which is a 7% decline from the year-ago quarter. IDC estimates that the global personal computer market contracted by 10% during the September quarter indicating that Macs continues to gain share just as they have with 29 of the last 30 quarters. We were especially pleased with strong year-over-year growth in sales of MacBook Air which we updated in June. In late September we updated iMac with fourth generation Intel quad-core processors
column152: new graphics
column153:
next generation Wi-Fi and faster PCIe flash storage options.

"
column154:
"

Last week we launched new versions of MacBook Pro with retina display featuring fourth generation Intel core processors
column155: faster graphics
column156: long rate battery life and a more affordable price. Also last week we launched Mavericks
column157: the 10th major release of OS X with more than 200 new features. Mavericks brings iBooks and Maps to the Mac
column158: includes the new version Safari
column159: enhances multi-display support
column160:
introduces Finder Tabs and Tags and delivers core technologies for breakthrough power efficiency and performance and is now free. We ended the quarter with Mac channel inventory that was just below our four to five week target range.

"
column161:
"

We continue to be very pleased with the growth of iTunes software and services in the strength of the Apple ecosystem. Our iTunes Stores generated record billings of $4.4 billion in the September quarter thanks to continued strong growth in sales of apps. The quarter's iTunes billings translated quarterly iTunes revenue $2.4 billion
column162: up 15% from the year-ago quarter. The strong iTunes sales combined with other software and service revenue resulted in total quarterly revenue 4.3 billion from iTunes software and services
column163:
an increase of 22% year-over-year.

"
column164:
"

Cumulative app downloads have reached 60 billion and our app developers have now earned 13 billion from sales to the App Store
column165: half of which they've earned in the last year. We had a tremendously successful launch of iOS 7 last month with hundreds of millions of downloads in the first few days alone
column166:
making it the fastest software upgrade ever. Last week we reported nearly two-thirds of iOS devices were already running iOS 7; that's significantly higher than the percentage of users running the latest versions of other mobile operating systems. This rapid transition to the latest version of iOS not only means that more customers are having the most advanced experience possible but it also enables developers to offer their latest app innovations to hundreds of billions of users in a single software release.

"
column167:
"

iOS offers something now for everyone with its great new design and features such as control center
column168: AirDrop and iTunes Radio. In fact the number of unique listeners who have tried iTunes Radio is now 20 million and growing. iOS 7 also includes significant features that make iPhones and iPads more secure in users to manage in corporate environments
column169:
offering new ways to configure and deploy devices at scale.

"
column170:
"

New device management capabilities include control sharing of documents and attachments
column171: App Store license management
column172: wireless managed app setup and streamline mobile device management and enrollment. In terms of security
column173: iOS 7 offers enterprise single sign-on
column174:
default third party app data protection and per app VPNs automatically connect stored corporate apps to the network without the need for users to change complicated settings.

"
column175:
"

I'd now like to turn to the Apple retail stores. The revenue for the quarter was 4.5 billion
column176: up 6% from the year-ago quarter. The stores produced very strong iPhone sales with unit growth of 36% per store per week compared to the September quarter last year. W completed the remodels of two stores and opened eight new stores during the quarter ending with a total of 416 stores including 162 outside the United States. We are projecting a total of approximately 30 new store openings in fiscal year '14
column177:
about two-thirds of which will be outside U.S.

"
column178:
"

We also plan to remodel about 20 stores over the course of fiscal year '14. With an average of 411 stores opened in the September quarter
column179: average revenue per store was 10.9 million compared to 11.2 million in the year-ago quarter. Retail segment income was 709 million. We hosted 99 million visitors to stores during the quarter which translates to 18
column180:
500 visitors per store per week. Operating expenses were 3.8 billion and included 467 million in stock-based compensation expense. OI&E was 113 million and the tax rate for the quarter was 25.9%.

"
column181:
"

Turning to our cash
column182: we ended the quarter with 146.8 billion in cash plus short term and long term marketable securities
column183: a sequential increase of $100 million from the June quarter. Our domestic cash was 35.5 billion at the end of the September quarter
column184: a sequential decline of 5.2 billion largely attributable to our share repurchase activity. $111.3 billion or 76% of our total cash was offshore at the end of the September quarter
column185:
and cash flow from operations was $9.9 billion.

"
column186:
"

We paid $2.8 billion in dividends in the quarter and we executed an additional $5 billion in repurchases up 10.4 million shares of Apple stock during the quarter. This brings us to a cumulative total of $36 billion in payments for dividends and share repurchases over the last five quarters of which share buybacks were $23 billion. This has resulted in cumulative retirement of almost 47 million shares and represents 5% of the total shares outstanding prior to the launch of our repurchase program. More than 44 million of these shares have been retired in the past two quarters alone.

"
column187:
"

Finally given that our capital return program must be funded from domestic cash
column188: and as a result of our payments to date
column189: the cash that we can net domestically and return to shareholders to stop accumulating. In fact we give return to shareholders who invested essentially all of the increase in available net cash generated since the beginning of our capital return program in 2012. Our Board of Directors has declared a dividend of $3.05 for common share payable on November 14
column190: 2013 to shareholders of record as in the close of this on November 11
column192:
"

Now
column193: as we move ahead into the December quarter
column194: I would like to review our outlook which includes the types of forward-looking information that Nancy referred to in the beginning of the call. First
column195:
I was to explain a bit about revenue deferrals. We believe that our software and services play a tremendous role in delivering an overall experience that our customers have come to know and love. Over the last few years we have added significantly to the offering that we provide our customers a no incremental charge from operating system upgrade rights to non-software services such as Siri and iCloud.

"
column196:
"

So
column197: iLife and iWork has become as essential for the user experience as mail
column198: messages and calendar. So we\u2019re now making iPhoto
column199: iMovie
column200: Pages
column201:
Numbers and Keynotes available as free downloads to customers who purchase new iOS devices and we\u2019re also making Mavericks and future OS X upgrades as well as iLife and iWork free to our Mac customers. As a result of the traditional rights and features we are deferring a greater portion of the sale of each iOS device in Mac sold. We anticipate that the additional deferral per device sold coupled with our sequentially greater unit volume expectations in the December quarter will result in about a $900 million sequential increase in the net amount of revenue deferred for software upgrade rights and non-software services.

"
column202:
"

In total we expect revenue to be between $55 billion and $58 billion compared to $54.5 billion in the year ago quarter. We expect gross margins to be between 36.5% and 37.5% reflecting approximately a $105 million related to stock-based compensation expense. We expect OpEx to be between $4.4 billion and $4.5 billion including about $585 million related to stock-based compensation expense. We expect OI&E to be about $200 million and we expect the tax rate to be about 26.25%.

"
column203:
"

In closing
column204: we are very pleased with the results of the final quarter of our fiscal year \u201913. We enter fiscal year \u201914 with an incredible lineup of products including our amazing new iPhones and iPads. We remain committed to delivering great innovative products and services that delight our customers and enhance their lives
column205:
and we\u2019re very confident in our new product pipelines.

"

"

With that

I\u2019d like to open the call to questions.

Nancy Paxton

both of these I think are the most important person here obviously is what our customers think and these new innovations on the 5s and the 5c combined led us to have our best iPhone launch ever with selling about nine million units through the weekend. So it was -- we\u2019re off to a great start.

Tony
column285: I didn't say in April that you would see them in this year and the first half of next year just to be clear on that. But what I have said is \u2013 I have said that you would see some exciting new products from us in the fall of this year and across 2014. And I obviously stand by that and you've seen a lot of things over the last couple of months. In terms of new product categories
column286: specifically if you look at the skills that Apple has from hardware
column287: software and services and at incredible app ecosystems
column288: these set of things are very
column289:
very unique. I think no one has a set of skills like us and we obviously believe that we can use our skills in building other great products that are in categories that represent areas where we do not participate today. So we're pretty confident about that.

"
column290:
"

Antonio Sacconaghi - Sanford C. Bernstein

"
column291:
"

Okay. As a follow-up I wanted to revisit the question your pricing strategy. Last quarter you spoke very buoyantly about elasticity that you experienced on the iPhone 4 and you had lowered the price in many emerging markets to about $400. Yet when the new products came out
column292: the 4s was actually at a notably higher price than the 4 had been the previous quarter. The 5c was obviously in line with what we had seen before with the 4s and 5s was in line with the 5. So if anything one of the common themes that came out on last earnings call was the desire to embrace the elasticity of the iPhone
column293: but as best I can tell price points across the board seem to be a little bit higher than they were three months ago despite the significant success you had there. So I'm wondering how we should think about what lessons you learned from the 4 pricing changes
column294:
why you didn't choose to keep the 4 given that it was an extraordinary strong seller as best we could tell last quarter and how you proceed \u2013 how you expect to try and continue to address the lower priced segments of the smartphone market?

"
column295:
"

Tim Cook

"
column296:
"

Tony
column297: the 400 number just to clarify your number not mine
column298: what we did with our lineup this time was the 4s is replacing the 4 and so if you look at the U.S. as an example
column299: the 4s is now 3
column300: the 4 previously was 3. When you translate that out of the U.S.
column301:
it depends on the market as to what specifically is happening. As you know currency changes and the strength of the dollar doesn't play in our favor in some geos from that perspective. But generally we see the 4s as our entry iPhone offer that gives somebody the ability to access the entire ecosystem with a fantastic product. And we clearly understand that there is elasticity in that market and we'll move accordingly.

"
column302:
"

Nancy Paxton

"
column303:
"

Thank you
column304:
Tony. Can we have the next question please?

"
column305:
"

Operator

"
column306:
"

We'll hear from Ben Reitzes with Barclays.

"
column307:
"

Ben Reitzes - Barclays Capital

"
column308:
"

Hi. Thanks a lot. First question is on China. Tim
column309: congrats on being I think the only company in my sector that grew in China this quarter. I'd have to check that but got to be one of them. You returned to growth I believe at 6%
column310:
if my math is right. What happened and do you see that growth rate accelerating? We're hoping you have new partnerships there and how can you expand distribution?

"
column311:
"

Tim Cook

"
column312:
"

Yes. Ben we had a pretty good quarter in China. We obviously want to do better. But if you look at the quarter
column313: we did grow by 6%. Underneath that
column314: iPhone units were up 25% year-over-year despite significant constraints on iPhone 5s that affected the whole company [ph]. However
column315: we were able to launch in our first round this time in China and that was a big change in the result of a close work relationship with the carriers in China and the government. And so we feel really good about that. We are able to do that on the iPad as well as we announced last week. For the full year
column316: the Greater China region generated over $27 billion in sales for us
column317: up 14% year-over-year. So we have a reasonable sized business there. In the year-ago quarter
column318: iPad launched. It launched late in China and so that pressure
column319:
the 6% down some otherwise it would have been I think even a stronger quarter given the strength of iPhone. So we are continuing to invest in stores. We opened one additional store in Greater China in the last few weeks. We're investing in indirect distribution. Our point-of-sales are up by about 50% year-over-year on the iPhone and we're continuing to go out to more cities. Initially we were very focused on just the large cities and so we're working on both coverage on launching earlier and execution and continuing to build on our retail practice there.

"
column320:
"

Ben Reitzes - Barclays Capital

"
column321:
"

Okay. And I guess nothing to announce more but my second question is for Peter. There's some confusion around the revenue deferral and I was just hoping you could clarify it for gross margins. The $900 million is about \u2013 I don't know I guess 160 basis points if I have that right on gross margins. How much of that should we say is pressuring gross margin down in your guidance? I mean do we take about \u2013 would your gross margin guidance had been about half the difference there higher if it weren't for this revenue deferral? And then when do we recoup that margin? How many quarters does it take to recoup and how will that flow back to the model? Thanks.

"
column323:
"

Sure
column324: Ben. We have been defying revenues for the sale of each iOS device and Mac given that we have been providing updates to software. Given the announcements that we made last week and that I went through it in my prepared remarks
column325: we have actually increased those deferrals. iPhone and iPad
column326: we are differing between $15 and $25. That's up as much as $5 per device and Mac has been some $20 to $40
column327: so up an additional $20. On a sequential basis
column328: given the increased deferral rates that we have as a result of increase in the software that we are providing to customers for free coupled with our sequential unit increases
column329: we will defer we think about $900 million more in revenue in the December quarter than we deferred in the September quarter. So you can calculate the impact to gross margin on that. We will also and that goes straight through the margin
column330: its revenue and a dollar-for-dollar reduction in gross margin. We will then record that revenue that we\u2019ve deferred for iOS devices across a two year period of time ratably and for Max over a four year period of time. So
column331: Ben just to summarize
column332: we happen to frame revenue on both iOS devices and Max for a number of years given the software that we have been giving away for free. We have increased those rates beginning in September for the iOS devices and in October for the Max
column333:
and it will come back into those products over two and four years as I said.

"
column334:
"

Ben Reitzes - Barclays Capital

"
column335:
"

Great
column336:
thanks. That\u2019s a pretty good guide for gross margin if you take that out -- if you\u2019re leaving that out. Thanks.

"
column337:
"

Peter Oppenheimer

"
column338:
"

Ben
column339: I\u2019d just add on to that
column340: thank you for saying it and I agree; and I would also say that we\u2019re really happy to be guiding gross margin flat not only because of the deferral but in addition to all of the new products that we\u2019ve introduced with higher cost structures and lower prices and we\u2019ll -- no hard and fast commitments
column341:
but we\u2019re going to work really hard to get down the cost curves as we have successfully in the past.

"
column342:
"

Ben Reitzes - Barclays Capital

"
column343:
"

Thanks a lot. I appreciate it.

"
column344:
"

Nancy Paxton

"
column345:
"

Thanks

Ben. Can we have the next question please?

column348:

From Piper Jaffray

we\u2019ll go to Gene Munster.

Gene Munster - Piper Jaffray

Hey

column354:
"

Peter Oppenheimer

Probably in that range

Gene Munster - Piper Jaffray

column362:
but are there some structural things that have changed the profitability of the iPhone it would be good to know as we think about our models in 2014.

column363:
"

Peter Oppenheimer

"
column364:
"

I don\u2019t know if there\u2019s any structural difference\u2019s

We\u2019re benefiting this quarter as I talked about in answering Katy\u2019s question from the benefits of leverage given the very big sequential increase in revenue. Leverage cut both ways
column366: so presumably that would go against us in the March quarter. However we would expect to defer less for the software deferrals in the March quarter as well. And as I noted at the end of Ben\u2019s question
column367: we will endeavor to work very hard to get down cost curves as we have in the past
column368:
no change.

"
column369:
"

Gene Munster - Piper Jaffray

"
column370:
"

Okay. And then my follow-up question
column371: in terms of the iPad and the Mini price change I guess just broader thinking around the iPad we\u2019ve seen some fluctuations in the growth rate. How do you think about that segment in terms of growing at or above or below market growth rates around tablets? And separately is there any differences in terms of how often people are upgrading their iPad\u2019s versus the iPhone\u2019s
column372: it feels like they\u2019re upgrading them every three years versus a little bit over every two years for the iPhone
column373: is that accurate. So
column374:
the size of the opportunity and then maybe just any sort of nuances and the upgrade behaviors between the iPhone and the iPad.

"
column375:
"

Tim Cook

"
column376:
"

Gene
column377: its Tim. We continue to view the tablet market as huge. We see it as a large opportunity for us. We are not solely focused on unit share as I\u2019ve said many times
column378: but we\u2019re focused on usage in customer\u2019s side
column379: the loyalty and other things that are very important to us. We do believe that this has been or the announcement last week was our largest iPad announcement ever and we\u2019re confident we\u2019re going to grow year-over-year
column380: and if you look back we had a very
column381: very strong quarter a year ago. We get off to a great start this weekend with iPad Air. And then later in the months we\u2019ll begin shipping the new Mini. We do feel that we wanted to reduce the price of the iPad Mini and so we did that and now we\u2019re coming in at $299 which is an incredible value to get access to the whole of the ecosystem and so forth. And iPad Air is just
column383: the best iPad we have ever done. And so
column384: I think all of these are \u2013 [ph] thus these products are going to do really well. I think it\u2019s going to be an iPad Christmas and -- but we will see
column385: we will report the numbers back to you in January how we did
column386:
but we are pretty confident.

"
column387:
"

Nancy Paxton

"
column388:
"

Thanks
column389:
Gene. Could we have the next question please?

"
column390:
"

Operator

"
column391:
"

From Cross Research
column392:
we will go to Shannon Cross.

column393:
"

Shannon Cross - Cross Research

"
column394:
"

Thank you very much. Tim
column395:
can you talk a bit more about your decision to offer the Mac OS for free and provide iWork and iLife with new device purchases? How are you thinking about it vis-\u00e0-vis some of the competition?

"
column396:
"

Tim Cook

"
column397:
"

Our primary reason for doing it Shannon was that we wanted it to become a part of what it meant to own a Mac and what it meant to own an iOS device. We saw iWork had become the best selling productivity app on a mobile device. We wanted all of our customers to have access to our very latest software
column398: so they would have access to our best features. And so we decided to make the bold move of making it free and I know some other folks charge a $199 or so for each of these actually for the OS and the productivity apps. But we really wanted to make it a part of the experience and so we are making it free and we are going back all the way to Snow Leopard on the OS side and iWork is free for all new Macs and so I think it\u2019s a very strong offer
column399: I think it\u2019s just another reason that everyone should buy Mac and we think it was great decision to do so
column400:
but most importantly we think it\u2019s great for customers.

"
column401:
"

Shannon Cross - Cross Research

"
column402:
"

Great. And then -- I just had a question on education which somewhat ties into this since iWork and iLife I think are some of these operating systems run through that
column403: I\u2019m curious with the -- what your thoughts are with regard to Chromebook Google apps
column404: any kind of foothold that we are seeing with Google taking share in education because as we\u2019ve seen some of the price points for the devices are pretty low
column405:
but clearly you guys are able to sell into education as well. So I\u2019m kind of curious as to how you view the competition and how you position your products vis-\u00e0-vis some of the things that are fairly low priced?

"
column407:
"

It\u2019s a good question. We had our best education quarter ever. We went over a $1 billion in revenues for the first time ever. We were up strongly year-over-year up 8%. iPad was up 22% year-over-year and the Mac was up 8% and as you know the PC market was down 10% in the aggregate and likely down even more in education. And so we feel like we\u2019re doing great on both fronts
column408: both in the iPad space and in the Mac space for people wanting to buy Mac. And we do see Chromebook\u2019s in some places
column409: but the vast majority of people are buying PC/Mac or an iPad. Our share of tablet in education is 94%. I mean it\u2019s -- yeah
column410:
it\u2019s sort of unheard of. I have never seen a market share that high before. So we feel like we are doing really well here and are great to be making -- feel great to be making a contribution to education.

"
column411:
"

Shannon Cross - Cross Research

"
column412:
"

Thank you.

"
column413:
"

Nancy Paxton

"
column414:
"

Thank you
column415:
Shannon. The next question please.

column416:

Operator

"
column418:
we will go to Steve Milunovich.

"
column419:

Steve Milunovich - UBS Securities

"
column420:
"

Thanks. Could you talk a little bit about the supply side? There has been some thoughts that the fingerprint technology has been a little bit hard to manufacture and you indicated that the Retina mini would be out later in November. So kind of curious
column421:
if you\u2019re going to be able to lead the demand for the holidays with the mini that you would like to or may be some general supply comments and also comments on component cost.

"
column422:
"

Tim Cook

"
column423:
"

Sure. Steve it\u2019s Tim. In terms of supply
column424: iPhone 5s into the quarter with a very significant backlog. We are still -- we still have a significant backlog. However
column425: our supply is building each week and we\u2019re -- we\u2019ve been -- and we\u2019re very confident of our ability to keep ramping and so we rolled out 30 more countries with the iPhone 5s and 5c as of last Friday and we'll roll out another 16 this week. And so we're right on where we would like to be in terms of achieving 100 countries by the end of the calendar year. In terms of the retina or the iPad Mini with the retina display
column426: we'll start shipping later in November. It's unclear whether we will have enough for the quarter or not. We now have mini \u2013 we will have but you really don't know the demand until after you start shipping and so we'll see how that goes. But I think we'll do fairly well with iPad as I had mentioned before. We felt like it's going to be a really great holiday season. On terms of component cost
column427:
both DRAM and NAND were up last quarter from the previous quarter. DRAM we believe will continue to be up in this quarter. We think NAND will be flat and other commodities will fall sequentially.

"
column428:
"

Steve Milunovich - UBS Securities

"
column429:
"

Okay. And then Peter
column430:
about a year ago you indicated that the December quarter would benefit by about 200 basis points in gross margin due to a combination of mix shift toward phones and higher volume. Is that the sort of uplift you would expect from those factories this December quarter?

"
column431:
"

Peter Oppenheimer

"
column432:
"

Steve
column433: I don't want to put a precise amount on it but we \u2013 I see us benefiting from a couple of things in the quarter; the leverage on the higher revenue by far being the biggest. As Tim mentioned
column434:
we expect to have a positive commodity environment and selling iPhones is never a bad thing from the margin perspective.

"
column435:
"

Steve Milunovich - UBS Securities

"
column436:
"

Thanks.

column437:
"

Nancy Paxton

column439:

column441:

We'll go to Mark Moskowitz with JPMorgan.

column442:

Mark Moskowitz - JPMorgan

"
column443:
"

Yes. Thanks. Good afternoon. The first question for Tim just regarding the channel inventory levels of 14.3 million for the iPhone
column444:
much higher than we've seen in the quarters past. Is there similar sort of message there in terms of you not having much broader coverage in terms of incremental coverage or is there a much bigger incremental upgrade cycle from your installed base or both?

"
column445:

Tim Cook

"
column446:
"

I think the way \u2013 the number one thing to know on the channel inventory is that our range as you know for iPhone is four to six weeks and we were at the low end of our range. And so that to me is the most \u2013 that's the most important thing I look at anyway I should say. You can choose to look at the thing that's most important to you. In terms of a changing from where it's been in the past
column447: the things that you should consider are the \u2013 China was in wave one this year
column448: so there was a lot more point-of-sales there. We added DOCOMO in Japan. And so that's a large carrier to add. And what probably were not in the opening comments was that of the 14 million
column449:
1.8 million of those were iPhones that were in transit and therefore not available to sale in the channel. And we always count those in channel inventory because they are in our sales line. And so that's how I look at the iPhone inventory.

"
column450:
"

Mark Moskowitz - JPMorgan

"
column451:
"

Okay. And then just a follow-up
column452: if I could. A year ago you had a very ambitious multi-product ramp in terms of new products coming out. At the same time you did have some impacts related to supply constraints. Just to kind of follow up on Steve's question. Do you feel that four months later
column453:
fast forward to the future now that you're in a much better shape to kind of avert or navigate some of these big supply constraints that inflicted some problems on you last year or can we see a similar situation as we move to the quarter?

"
column454:
"

Tim Cook

"
column455:
"

As I mentioned on the iPhone 5s I feel like we're doing really well on supply. The demand is very robust. And so we are in backlog right now. But I feel confident about us continuing to ramp and do quite well for the quarter. On the iPad Mini we'll start shipping later this month and it's very difficult to forecast exactly when supply and demand will balance there. We'll also see about the iPad Air as we go out this week. I think we'll have a really good weekend. It may be that not everyone can find what they want more [ph]. I think versus last year I think one key difference is we announced one of our key Macs
column456: the iMac but we didn't begin shipping until the end of December. And so we went for more than two months with minimal iMac sales and therefore from a Mac point of view year-over-year last year
column457: we had \u2013 our only down a quarter
column458:
down versus the market that is in the last 30 quarters. And so I don't envision that happening this year. I feel really good about the way the MacBook Pros have gotten off last week. They've gotten off to a huge start. I feel great about Mac growing year-over-year this quarter. I feel great about iPad growing year-over-year this quarter as well. You can tell that from the strong guidance numbers that Peter gave earlier.

"
column459:
"

Nancy Paxton

"
column460:
"

Thank you
column461:
Mark. Can we have the next question please?

column462:
"

Operator

"
column463:
"

column464:

Chris Whitmore - Deutsche Bank

"
column465:
"

Thanks very much. I wanted to ask about iPhone ASPs. They were down about 7% year-on-year in the quarter and down sequentially. Last year they were up sequentially on the launch. Was that a product supply availability issue? And how do you think about ASPs going forward?

"
column466:
"

Peter Oppenheimer

"
column467:
"

Chris
column468: it's Peter. Sequentially we were relatively flat
column469: so I'll comment on a year-over-year basis. They were down 7% as you indicated and this was primarily due to a significant increase in the sales of our entry SKUs where we had made them more affordable to attract more first-time smart buyers. We've also encouraged some FX headwinds from the yen
column470:
the Australian dollar and a number of the emerging markets which impacted us as well. I don't want to forecast ASPs for the December quarter. We'll report to you in January what they were. But the FX headwinds will likely continue given where exchange rates are today.

"
column471:
"

Chris Whitmore - Deutsche Bank

"
column472:
"

And just to follow-up on Mark's earlier question around channel inventories
column473:
that 14 million unit number was I think higher than a lot of people expected. Was that also SKU-ed [ph] towards the low end of the product stack given the 5s was short exiting the quarter?

"
column474:
"

Tim Cook

"
column475:
"

The 5s was in huge backlog and so any kind of 5s that was in the channel was a transitionary kind of move \u2013 maybe perhaps in transit and so forth. We did have as I mentioned before
column476:
we had 1.8 million units of total iPhone units in transit at the end of the quarter. So that's a pretty substantial number.

"
column477:
"

Chris Whitmore - Deutsche Bank

"
column478:
"

And just lastly I wanted to ask about subsidies. That wasn't mentioned as a potential impact to phone margins but can you comment on carrier subsidies more generally? How sustainable are they given the competitive environment and how are carriers responding to the pricing stack of your phone line? Thanks a lot.

"
column479:
"

Peter Oppenheimer

"
column480:
"

I think carriers like to sell as many units as they can and get as many people in their service. And in most regions walk into the un-serviced contracts and so they're very predictable and reliable and I don't really see that changing. I think the carriers have come up with some different or some carriers have come up with different sales programs that might appeal to someone who wants to upgrade their phone annually instead of every other year. I think those programs in general probably reduce the subsidy somewhat in the aggregate for people that take these up. But customers may due to such a fair exchange for getting the upgrade more often
column481:
so there's a customer proposition for it. Other than that I think we have great relationships with the carriers. I think they were as we were very happy with the iPhone rollout.

"
column482:
