Nancy Paxton

"
column483:
"

Thank you

column1:
{"Apple's CEO Discusses F1Q 2014 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Apple Inc. (NASDAQ:AAPL)

"
column10:
"

Luca Maestri - Vice President and Corporate Controller

"
column21:
"

Keith Bachman - BMO Capital Markets

"
column22:
"

Andy Hargreaves - Pacific Crest Securities

"
column23:
"

Mark Moskowitz - JPMorgan

"
column24:
"

Gene Munster - Piper Jaffray

"
column28: and welcome to the Apple Incorporated First Quarter Fiscal Year 2014 Earnings Release Conference Call. Today\u2019s call is being recorded. At this time
column30: I would like to turn the call over to Nancy Paxton
column31: Senior Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead
column33:
"

Nancy Paxton

"
column35: and thanks to everyone for joining us. Speaking first today is Apple CFO Peter Oppenheimer. And he\u2019ll be joined by CEO Tim Cook
column36:
and Vice Vice President and Corporate Controller Luca Maestri for a Q&A session with analysts.

"
column37:
"

Please note that some of the information you\u2019ll hear during our discussion today will consist of forward-looking statements
column38: including without limitation
column40: gross margins
column41: operating expenses
column46:
"

Actual results or trends could differ materially from our forecast. For more information
column47: please refer to the risk factors discussed in Apple\u2019s Form 10-K for 2013 and the Form 8-K filed with the SEC today
column48: along with the associated press release. Apple assumes no obligation to update any forward-looking statements or information
column49:
which speak as of their respective dates.

"
column50:
"

I\u2019d now like to turn the call over to Peter Oppenheimer for introductory remarks.

"
column51:
"

Peter Oppenheimer

"
column52:
"

Thank you
column53: Nancy. We\u2019re very pleased to report the results of the first quarter of Apple\u2019s fiscal year \u201914. We established new all-time quarterly records for iPhone and iPad sales and had one of our best Mac quarters ever
column54:
driving the highest quarterly revenue and operating profit in Apple\u2019s history. We were also very pleased with our results in emerging markets around the world.

"
column55:
"

Revenue for the quarter was $57.6 billion
column56: up $3.1 billion
column57: or 6%
column58: from the year ago quarter and near the high end of our guidance range. No technology company has ever generated that much revenue in a single quarter

column269:
enabling shoppers to receive iPhone notifications about products and services via the Apple Store app.

column270:
"

iBeacon transmitters use Bluetooth wireless technology to sense a shopper\u2019s exact location inside an Apple Store and send messages based on the aisle or product the customer is near. For example
column271: customers walking by an iPhone table could receive a message offering to help them check their upgrade eligibility or trade-in value of an existing phone. We expect to see many innovative uses of iBeacon technology from other businesses and developers in the coming months
column272:
including retailers and professional sports.

column353: and we increased inventory in the March quarter by 1.4 million units. In contrast

I have one for Tim
column450: and then a follow up
column451: please. Tim
column452: I wanted to just step back and talk a little bit about iPhone market share. The market data isn\u2019t out for Q1
column453: but if we look at your prior four quarters
column454: fiscal \u201913
column455: Apple grew its iPhone units about 20%. The market grew in the 40s. I think this quarter
column456: even with a new product and having China front loaded
column457:
the iPhone is going to grow at a fraction of ultimately what the market is likely to grow at.

"
column458:
"

And I know your belief and philosophy historically has been that you want to make the best product
column459: and that\u2019s the most important thing
column460: but in Macs
column461: you\u2019ve actually succeeded in making the best product and being able to gain share. You cited again how you\u2019ve gained share in 30 out of the last 31 quarters in Mac. But in iPhone
column462:
that is not happening.

"
column463:
"

And so my question is
column464: what is different about the smartphone market that is not allowing you to hold or gain unit share despite apparently having the best product
column465: and do you propose to do anything differently going forward
column466: because I think it\u2019s great to have an aspiration to make the best products
column467:
but I think that\u2019s in the spirit of ultimately growing at least in line with or faster than the market. And that doesn\u2019t appear to be happening.

"
column468:
"

Tim Cook

"
column470: our objective has always been to make the best
column471: not the most. And we feel we\u2019re doing that. If you look at what we did this year
column472: we announced two iPhones for the first time
column473: rather than one. And looking at last quarter
column474: if you looked at our sell through - so not sell in
column475: but the sell through - of what I\u2019ll just call our entry phone
column476: or mid phone
column477: and our top phone
column478: with the 5S
column479:
all of those grew year over year versus the phones that were in those categories previously.

"
column480:
"

If you look at the emerging markets
column481: which is one of the things that I\u2019ve alluded to that we have to grow in these areas and grow at reasonable amounts
column482: in Latin America we grew at 76% year over year. In the Middle East and Africa
column483: we grew at 65%. In central and eastern Europe
column484: we grew 115%. In China
column485: we grew at 20%. However
column486: as you know
column487: we just added China Mobile
column488: the largest carrier there
column489: in this quarter
column490:
and did not have channel load in China Mobile last quarter. We just started selling those in January.

"
column491:
"

Also
column492: in Japan
column493: as we\u2019ve added Docomo
column495: when you translate that performance into revenue in Japan
column496: and we have the issue with the yen that Peter spoke about earlier
column497: and so the revenue growth looks much less than that
column498:
because of the strength of the dollar there.

"
column499:
"

In North America
column500: we did not do as well
column501: and this weighed our results. Our North American business contracted somewhat year over year. And if you look at the reason for this
column502: one was that as we entered the quarter
column503: and forecasted our iPhone sales
column504: where we achieved what we thought
column505:
we actually sold more iPhone 5Ss than we projected.

"
column506:
"

And so the mix was stronger to the 5S
column507: and it took us some amount of time in order to build the mix that customers were demanding. And as a result
column508: we lost some sort of units for part of the quarter in North America and relative to the world
column509: it took us the bulk of the quarter
column510: almost all the quarter
column511:
to get the iPhone 5S into proper supply.

"
column512:
"

The other thing that happened in North America specifically was that some carriers changed their upgrade policies. And this affected last quarter
column513:
and will have some effect on the current quarter. This restricted customers who are used to upgrading earlier than the 24 months that they\u2019re allowed and sort of stretched the time out to be a hard and fast 24 months. And so that\u2019s a major factor playing into the North American results.

"
column514:
"

So as I back up and sort of zoom out on this
column515: and look at it
column516: one of the most important things for us in the iPhone business was to do really well in emerging markets
column517: and we had the best quarter ever from that respect. Another was to grow in China
column518: because I think you can\u2019t be in the business that we\u2019re in and not have a reasonable China business. And you can see how we did last quarter
column519:
and we\u2019ve now followed that up with a deal with China Mobile. And so I feel great about that.

"
column520:
"

I think part of what\u2019s happening in North America is a short term effect because of these upgrade policy changes. This affects the period of time
column521: three to six months
column523: and then it washes through. So as I look at it
column524: I feel very good about where we are
column525: and I would guess that the market numbers
column526: some of the stuff that you\u2019ve been seeing
column527: will actually be decreased as the revisions come out
column528:
given what you\u2019re hearing and what everyone is saying.

"
column529:
"

Toni Sacconaghi - Sanford Bernstein

"
column530:
"

I\u2019d like to follow that up
column531:
just on your comments on China. You\u2019ve characterized the agreement with China Mobile as huge. Could you tell me what would define success for you in China Mobile one and three years out? What ultimately should we be looking at to measure and ultimately determine whether this was huge?

"
column532:
"

Tim Cook

"
column533:
"

I\u2019m not going to give you a forecast for it. I think if you just back up and look at it from a common sense point of view
column534: China Mobile has more subscribers than anyone in the world. They have three quarters of a billion
column535: and so I do see it as a watershed moment for Apple
column536:
and have a very strong belief in the ability of those two companies to do great things together.

"
column538:
"

Ben Reitzes with Barclays.

"
column540:
"

My question is for Tim. You\u2019re at the midpoint of your guidance. It obviously implies a decline in revenue in the quarter coming up
column541: and you haven\u2019t done that forever. You came pretty close a couple of quarters ago
column542: but you had some growth. And my question is
column543: are you still a growth company? And should we expect the growth rate to accelerate as we go throughout the year? And why
column544:
if that\u2019s the case?

"
column546:
"

I think it\u2019s important to listen to what Peter said about the guidance
column547: and about the compares year over year
column548: and the point that he made that the underlying sell through
column549: that we\u2019re very confident of growth year over year. And that is the way we look at it. Some people just look at the numbers on a piece of paper
column550: but the way I\u2019d look at the business is our business from a sell through point of view less iPod
column551:
because I think all of us have known for some time that iPod is a declining business.

"
column552:
"

And when you do that
column554: and the deferral
column555: which we\u2019ve just increased
column556: as Peter went through
column558: and look at the numbers from last quarter
column559: it comes up to a double digit growth. And we\u2019re proud of that. I think that\u2019s a pretty good result. We\u2019ll see how we do in the March quarter
column560:
but I do think it\u2019s important in the March quarter to take into consideration sell through versus just a view of sell in.

"
column561:
"

Ben Reitzes - Barclays

"
column562:
"

And I guess there\u2019s been a lot of things in the media about your potential to buy back more stock
column563: and shares are around $500 tonight. I was wondering if you thought this was a good level
column564: and whether it was time to accelerate the buyback from current levels. You obviously generated a ton of cash in the quarter
column565:
and what are your latest thoughts there?

"
column566:
"

Tim Cook

"
column567:
"

We\u2019ve been buying back stock. As you know
column568: last year we increased the program overall
column570: doubling it to $100 billion. And $60 billion of that is buyback
column571: and we\u2019ve been progressing on that. Luca can give you the precise numbers of it. So we\u2019re a big believer in buying back the stock
column572: and that doesn\u2019t change today
column573:
whether the stock goes up or down.

"
column574:
"

Operator

"
column575:
"

From UBS
column576:
we\u2019ll go to Steve Milunovich.

"
column577:
"

Steve Milunovich - UBS

"
column578:
"

"
column579:
"

Could you talk a bit more about the gross margin? It did provide an upside surprise to your guidance in the quarter. What were the factors? And then looking forward
column580:
what are some of the gives and takes for the March quarter?

"
column581:
"

Luca Maestri

"
column582:
"

Let me answer that one. Let me start with the quarter. We were above the guidance range. It was primarily for two factors. We had favorable product mix
column583: and we had favorable commodity pricing. And so those were the two things that actually helped us come in above the guidance range. For the quarter
column584: for Q2
column585: we\u2019re guiding 37% to 38%
column586: compared to 37.9% in the December quarter. We\u2019re going to have some loss of leverage
column587: as you can imagine
column588:
because of the usual seasonal decline in revenue. But we expect that loss of leverage to be largely offset by cost improvements and also by less deferred revenue that we\u2019re going to have in Q2.

"
column589:
"

Steve Milunovich - UBS

"
column590:
"

And then regarding overall demand
column591: one thing you didn\u2019t mention
column592: Tim
column593: is maturity of the particularly high end smartphone market. I know in our surveys we\u2019re finding
column595: a lot higher percentage or Apple buyers already have an Apple handset. So I\u2019m curious if you think the Western world can show decent unit growth over the next year or two. And I was also wondering
column596:
the 5C generally is viewed as having turned out to be pretty light in the mix. What are you going to do with that product going forward?

"
column597:
"

Tim Cook

"
column598:
"

Well
column599: I\u2019ll sidestep the last question
column600: of course
column601: because it\u2019s about future products. But to your question about the 5S in particular
column602: if I look at the sell through year over year
column603: there was growth in that portion of the line
column604: despite adding an entirely new phone underneath it. And so I think that\u2019s a good sign
column605:
and that\u2019s despite it being in short supply for the bulk or virtually all of the quarter.

"
column606:
"

And so I do believe that that category of product can grow in those markets
column607: if you\u2019re thinking about the U.S. and western Europe
column608: for example
column609: and Japan. In Japan
column610:
we grew 40% last quarter. That\u2019s fairly good.

"
column611:
"

Operator

"
column612:
"

Brian Marshall with ISI Group.

"
column613:
"

Brian Marshall - ISI Group

"
column614:
"

Obviously the iPhone business grew about 7% year over year
column615:
$200 million in [unintelligible] unit sales now. And that\u2019s with two new [unintelligible] being launched in the quarter. Can you help us think about how you guys view the iPhone new user growth out there in the marketplace versus simply a solid replacement cycle that the company has in its installed base?

"
column616:
"

Tim Cook

"
column617:
"

We saw a significant new to iPhone number. It\u2019s not a number that we throw out
column618: but we particularly saw that on the 5C
column619: which is what we wanted to see. So it\u2019s clearly not just upgraders. As a matter of fact
column622: would have been less than we thought
column623:
because of the changes in the upgrade policy that I talked about earlier.

"
column625:
"

And then with respect to innovation at the company
column627: iPad came out in 2010. 2013 came around
column630:
but nothing really from our new product category. Do you care to comment on the innovation cycle of the company and the cadence there?

"
column632:
"

It\u2019s never been stronger. I\u2019m very confident with the work that\u2019s going on
column633:
and I think our customers are going to love what we\u2019re going to do.

"
column635:
"

We\u2019ll go to Keith Bachman with Bank of Montreal.

"
column636:
"

Keith Bachman - BMO Capital Markets

"
column637:
"

I had a question and a follow up. And Tim
column640: to follow up from Brian\u2019s question
column641: you\u2019re growing iPhones about 7%. I think the market is going to end up looking up to be 14%. Are you happy with the pricing umbrella that you currently have? When you originally brought out iPhones
column642: in subsequent periods you talked about wanting to push some pricing umbrellas. But are you happy with the pricing umbrellas that you have? In particular
column644:
I think most of the industry views have panned the product as not being enough features for that price point. But if you could just talk about the positioning of your broader product portfolio on iPhones. Are you happy where you are?

"
column646:
"

I think last quarter we did a tremendous job
column647: particularly given the mix was something very different than we thought. It was the first time we\u2019d ever run that particular play before
column648: and demand percentage turned out to be different than we thought. We obviously always look at our results
column649: and conclude what to change moving forward. And if we decide it\u2019s in our best interest to make a change
column650:
then we\u2019ll make one. Obviously I\u2019m not going to predict price changes on the earnings call.

"
column651:
"

Keith Bachman - BMO Capital Markets

"
column654:
but at least product position. Are you willing to expand the product portfolio into new categories within the phone family?

"
column656:
"

We\u2019re willing to make any product that\u2019s a great product. Where our line in the sand is
column657:
it\u2019s making something that\u2019s not fantastic.

"
column658:
"

Keith Bachman - BMO Capital Markets

"
column659:
"

Okay. Then my follow up for you Peter is
column660: you mentioned four factors that influenced guidance. In particular
column661: you talked about inventory. I think most investors would conclude then December wasn\u2019t as good as it looked
column662:
if you had increases in channel inventory. So I was hoping you could peel off a little bit and talk about the foreign exchange impact and the higher deferrals. Is there a way to quantify that impact on the guidance in March in particular?

"
column664:
"

As I had said to one of the early questions
column666: we expect to be over $2 billion. And the inventory is the largest
column667:
and then the other three are less than the inventory and not too terribly far apart.

"
column671:
"

Andy Hargreaves - Pacific Crest Securities

"
column672:
"

Just a quick follow up to some of your comments about demand mix being significantly different
column673: or different than what you thought
column674:
in the quarter. Do you have any thoughts on why it was so much different than what you expected it to be?

"
column677: people are really intrigued with Touch ID. It\u2019s a major feature that has excited people. And I think that
column678: associated with the other things that are unique to the 5S
column679:
got the 5S to have a significant amount more attention and a higher mix of sales.

"
column680:
"

Andy Hargreaves - Pacific Crest Securities

"
column681:
"

And then just on the comments on R&D and working on things that aren\u2019t visible to us
column682: you guys have done a lot of things in recent years
column683: sort of in support of the existing products. Are we to read those comments that you\u2019re working on things that are material new revenue drivers
column684:
new potential legs of the stool? Or are these more services that would support the existing customer base?

"
column686:
"

What Luca is saying is that we\u2019re working on things that are things that you see that we\u2019re shipping today but that we\u2019re working on things that you can\u2019t see today.

"
column688:
"

The next question will come from Mark Moskowitz with JPMorgan.

"
column690:
"

What\u2019s your user data kind of telling you right now in terms of the replacement cycle? Are you starting to see a lot of heritage Apple users now refresh their iPhone every three years plus
column691: or their iPad every two years plus
column692:
versus previous? Are you seeing any major changes there?

"
column694:
"

We don\u2019t have great data yet from last quarter. And so I don\u2019t know the answer to your question.

"
column696:
"

And then the follow up is around this opex being flat relative to the revenue guidance. Is there something around the vertical in terms of maybe increasing focus on the enterprise vertical that you see an opportunity to take advantage of
column697:
maybe hiring more folks to service that industry?

"
column699:
"

It\u2019s clear that the enterprise area has huge potential
column700: and we\u2019re doing well from a percentage of companies that are using iPhone and iPad. It\u2019s up to unbelievable numbers. The iPhone is used in 97% of the Fortune 500
column702: and iPad is used in 98% of the Fortune 500 and 93% of the Global 500. And we have a number of accounts
column703: some of which Peter reviewed in the opening remarks
column704:
that have tens of thousands of iOS devices working.

"
column706: as I think was mentioned earlier
column707: 90% of tablet activations in corporations are iPads. And 95% of total app activations were on iOS. And I think that\u2019s an incredible measure of ultimately how sticky the products are
column708:
because you can get so much productivity out of an iPad and an iPhone.

"
column709:
"

And so I think the road in enterprise is a longer one. The arc is longer than in consumer
column710: which can immediately go out and buy things
column711: etc. And I think we\u2019ve done a lot of the groundwork as you can tell from these numbers that I\u2019ve given you
column712:
and I would expect that it would have more and more payback in the future.

"
column714:
"

And the next question will come from Gene Munster with Piper Jaffray.

"
column716:
"

Just a follow up to some of the previous questions. Tim
column717: I\u2019ve got to ask it. In the previous quarters
column718: you\u2019ve talked about specifically product categories multiple
column719: and that\u2019s different than variations of existing products. And that would be by the end of 2014. I just want to be clear that\u2019s still on track
column720:
and consistent with some of the expenses that we talked about earlier in the call?

"
column726: and this goes back to some of the other themes on the call here too
column727: but you\u2019re obviously going to have a big year in terms of new product categories. And maybe even thinking beyond 2014
column728: when the new products come out and they kind of ramp in 2015
column729: how do you think about the trajectory of the platform
column730:
or what would you say to investors to say this is just a product cycle story?

"
column733: innovation is deeply embedded in everybody here
column734: and there\u2019s still so much of the world that is full of very complex products
column735: etc. We have zero issue coming up with things we want to do that we think we can disrupt in a major way. The challenge is always to focus to the very few that deserve all of our energy. And we\u2019ve always done that
column736:
and we\u2019re continuing to do that.

"
column738:
"

A replay of today\u2019s call will be available for two weeks as a podcast on the iTunes store
column740:
and via telephone. And the numbers for the telephone replay are 888-203-1112 or 719-457-0820. And please enter confirmation code 9268358. These replays will be available by approximately 5 p.m. Pacific time today.

"
column741:
"

And members of the press with additional questions can contact Steve Dowling at 408-974-1896
column742: and financial analysts can contact Joan Hoover or me with additional questions. Joan is at 408-974-4570
column744:
"

Thanks again for joining us.

column1:
{"Apple's CEO Discusses F2Q 2014 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Apple Inc. (NASDAQ:AAPL)

"
column7:
"

Timothy D. Cook \u2013 Chief Executive Officer

"
column8:
"

Luca Maestri \u2013 Vice President of Finance and Corporate Controller

"
column10:
"

Katy Huberty \u2013 Morgan Stanley & Co. LLC

"
column11:
"

Bill C. Shope \u2013 Goldman Sachs & Co.

"
column13:
"

Steven M. Milunovich \u2013 UBS Securities LLC

"
column14:
"

Shannon S. Cross \u2013 Cross Research LLC

"
column19: and welcome to the Apple Incorporated Second Quarter Fiscal Year 2014 Earnings Release Conference Call. Today\u2019s call is being recorded. At this time
column21: I would like to turn the call over to Nancy Paxton
column22: Senior Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead
column24:
"

Nancy Paxton

"
column26: and thanks to everyone for joining us today. Speaking first today are Apple CEO
column28: and Vice President and Corporate Controller
column30: and they will be joined by CFO
column31:
Peter Oppenheimer for the Q&A session with the analysts.

"
column32:
"

Please note that some of the information you\u2019ll hear during our discussion today will consists of forward-looking statements
column33: including without limitation
column38: stock-based compensation expense
column40:
future products and capital allocation plans.

"
column41:
"

Actual results or trends could differ materially from our forecast. For more information
column42: please refer to the risk factors discussed in Apple\u2019s Form 10-K for 2013
column43: the Form 10-Q for the first quarter of fiscal 2014
column44: and the Form 8-K filed with the SEC today
column45: along with the associated press release. Apple assumes no obligation to update any forward-looking statements or information
column46:
which speak as of their respective dates.

"
column47:
"

I\u2019d now like to turn the call over to Tim for introductory remarks.

"
column48:
"

Timothy D. Cook

"
column49:
"

Thanks
column50: Nancy. Good afternoon
column51: everyone. We have a lot to share with you over the next hour
column52:
and I\u2019d like to start right away with the very strong results we\u2019re reporting for the March quarter.

"
column53:
"

We generated $45.6 billion in revenue
column54: which was ahead of our expectations and represents a new March quarter record
column55: and is our strongest non-holiday quarter ever. Our underlying business performance was even stronger than our reported results imply. When you take into account changes in channel inventory this year versus last year and foreign exchange had wins that we faced in several of our international markets. Setting foreign exchange and inventory changes aside
column56:
our underlying growth rate would have been close to double digits.

"
column57:
"

These strong revenue results combined with our best gross margin percentage since September of 2012 resulted in earnings per share growth of 15%
column58: which is our highest earnings growth rate in the last six quarters. iPhone was key in driving our stronger-than-expected results. We sold almost 44 million iPhones
column59:
setting a new March quarter record. These stronger results were broad-based both from a product point of view with demand for each of our three iPhone stronger than its predecessor and from a geographic standpoint.

"
column60:
"

We gained smartphone share in many developed and emerging markets including the U.S.
column61: the UK
column62: Japan
column63: Canada
column64: Germany
column65: France
column66: Vietnam and Greater China
column67: just to mention a few. In fact
column68:
we established a new all-time record for total iPhone sales in the BRIC countries.

"
column69:
"

iTunes software and services revenue continue to grow at a double-digit rate
column70: thanks to an incredible ecosystem and our very large
column71: loyal and engaged customer base. With its strong momentum in growing profitability
column72: iTunes is a very important driver of our business not only here in the United States
column73: but around the world. We now have an almost 800 million iTunes accounts
column74:
most of these with credit cards. This is a staggering number.

"
column75:
"

We continue to gain share in the personal computer market as well. We defied industry trends again by growing while the market contracted. Our bold decision to make OS X free has resulted in the largest ever percentage of the Mac installed base running on the latest version of the operating system just months after its release.

"
column76:
"

iPad sales came in at the high end of our expectations
column77: but we realized they were below analyst estimates
column78: and I would like to proactively address
column79: why we think there was a difference. We believe almost all of the difference can be explained by two factors. First
column80: in the March quarter last year
column81: we significantly increased iPad channel inventory
column82:
while this year we significantly reduced it. Luca will go into more detail about this later.

"
column83:
"

Second
column84: we ended the December quarter last year with a substantial backlog with iPad mini that was subsequently shipped in the March quarter
column85:
whereas we ended the December quarter this year near supply demand balance. We continue to believe that the tablet market will surpass the PC market in size within the next few years and we believe that Apple will be a major beneficiary of this trend.

"
column86:
"

When we look at our company performance on a geographic basis
column87: we\u2019re especially proud of our very strong results in Greater China
column88: where we established an all time quarterly revenue record of almost $10 billion including the results from our retail stores. And in Japan
column89:
where revenue was up 26% in spite of the foreign exchange headwinds and where our smartphone market share reached an incredible 55%.

"
column90:
"

We are continuing to invest in our retail stores and since our last call
column91: we had opened our first stores in Brazil and Turkey and we now have retail stores in 15 countries around the world. I\u2019m looking forward to welcoming our new retail and online leader
column92: Angela Ahrendts
column93: who will be joining Apple\u2019s Executive Team next week. Stepping back
column94:
we are now just passed the halfway mark for fiscal 2014.

"
column95:
"

Our strong March quarter results bring us to total revenues of over $103 billion for the first six months of the year and earnings per share growth close to double-digits. We estimate that over the last six months
column96: we\u2019ve added over $60 million new registered users of our four product categories. Additionally
column97: over two-third\u2019s of people registering an iPad in the last six months
column98: were new to iPad
column99:
while over half of the people registering iPhones were new to iPhone.

"
column100:
"

It is wonderful to add tens of millions of first time Apple product users
column101: especially considering the strong halo effect
column102: we\u2019ve seen over and over again in our history. Customers who have a great experience with their first Apple products
column103:
often become loyal and happy owners of the multiple Apple products overtime.

"
column104:
"

As always
column105:
I\u2019d like to thank our talented employees who make these results possible through their creativity and passion they bring to their work everyday. And I\u2019d like to thank our hundreds of millions of customers for their loyalty and enthusiasm and for continually inspiring us to surprise and delight them.

"
column106:
"

In addition to our quarterly results
column107: we are also announcing an update to our capital return program today
column108:
and I\u2019d like to share a few thoughts about our guiding principles for capital allocation and our conclusion on the changes we are making for this year. Apple has created tremendous value for shareholders by developing great products that enrich people\u2019s lives and that will always be our top priority and driving force.

"
column109:
"

We\u2019ll continue to innovate by investing in research and development and capitalizing on our strengths in hardware
column110: software and services. We\u2019ll keep investing in our supply chains promote scale and efficiencies
column111: expanding our global presence by building retail stores
column112:
investing in marketing and distribution and extending our reach into new markets.

"
column113:
"

We are expanding Apple\u2019s products and services into new categories and we are not going to under invest in this business. We are also investing through acquisitions and we\u2019ve acquired 24 companies in the past 18 months. To invest organically and to make acquisition strategically
column114: we need to maintain financial flexibility. With this framework in mind
column115: Apple\u2019s Board and management team
column116:
will do capital allocation regularly and we solicit input on our program from a broad base of shareholders.

"
column117:
"

We very much appreciate all of the input that so many of our shareholders have provided us on how the best to deploy our cash. We\u2019ve continued to seek investor input going forward and we\u2019ll update you on our conclusions around this time each year.

"
column118:
"

This regular process allows us to continually evaluate return of capital in light of the most current information available and it enables us to be thoughtful about the size
column119:
mix and pace of the program. We continue to be in the fortunate position of being able to return significant capital to shareholders. We started doing so two years ago when we announced our first program of $45 billion and we more than doubled the program last April to $100 billion.

"
column120:
"

Today
column121:
we are announcing that we are increasing the size of our program once again with an addition of over $30 billion for a total program size of over $130 billion. The size and pace of our program is unprecedented and we still expect to complete it by December of 2015 as we announced last year.

"
column122:
"

We think very deliberately about how much and in which way to return cash to our shareholders. We decided to continue to allocate the vast majority of the incremental capital return to share repurchases because we believe our current stock price does not reflect the full value of the company. The size of the share back increases the signal of the Board and the management team\u2019s strong confidence in the future of Apple.

"
column123:
"

We also understand the importance of the dividend to many of our investors and we are increasing it for the second time in less than two years. We believe this is a meaningful increase for those shareholders who value income and we are planning for annual dividend increases going forward.

"
column124:
"

Now
column125:
I would like to turn the call over to Luca for the details of our quarterly results as well as more information about our capital return program.

"
column126:
"

Luca Maestri

"
column127:
"

Thank you Tim and good afternoon everyone. As Tim said revenue for the March quarter was $45.6 billion
column128:
up $2 billion or 5% from a year ago and above our guidance range. Sales in each of our major product categories were at the high end of our expectations or better and the vast majority of the revenue upside came from strong sales of iPhone.

"
column129:
"

Gross margin was 39.3%
column130: also above our guidance range and operating margin was $15.6 billion
column131:
representing 29.8% of revenue. Net income was $10.2 billion translating to diluted earnings per share of $11.62.

"
column132:
"

For details by product
column133:
I\u2019d like to start with iPhone. We sold 43.7 million iPhones which was a March quarter record. That\u2019s an increase of 6.3 million iPhones over last year that represents 17% growth. The addition of China Mobile coupled with great response to our more affordably priced iPhone 4S led to an all time quarterly record for iPhone sales in Greater China. We look forward to broadening our relationship with China Mobile as they expand points of sale and continue to build out their 4G network.

"
column134:
"

In Japan
column135: iPhone sales were up over 50% year-over-year resulting in significant market share gains
column136:
as Tim mentioned we\u2019ll try strong growth and share gains in many other major developed markets based on IDCs latest estimates for the March quarter.

"
column137:
"

iPhone also continued to perform exceptionally well in many developing markets. In Greater China
column138: Brazil
column139: Indonesia
column140: Poland and Turkey. iPhone sales grew by strong double-digits year-over-year
column141:
and in India and Vietnam sales more than doubled.

"
column142:
"

We exited the quarter with 15.4 million total iPhones in channel inventory
column143: which represents a sequential increase of about 100
column144:
000 from the December quarter and left us within our target range of four to six weeks.

"
column145:
"

In the enterprise market progressive organizations are leading the charge to replace legacy devices and systems
column146: and are using iPhone and iOS to drive innovation at their companies. Deutsche Bank has nearly 20
column147:
000 iPhones running on its network and has created 40 internal apps that extend the capabilities of its mobile workforce.

"
column148:
"

Siemens have 30
column149: 000 iPhones on its network and has deployed over 50 internal apps for field service teams
column150:
sales associates and corporate executives for solution that are only possible with iOS and iPhone. We are really happy with the continued growth and strength of the Apple ecosystem.

"
column151:
"

Total revenue from iTunes software and services was $4.6 billion
column152: an increase of 11% year-over-year at an all time quarterly record. Our iTunes stores generated record billings of $5.2 billion in the March quarter
column153: up 24% year-over-year driven by very strong growth in App Store sales. These iTunes billings translated to quarterly iTunes revenue of over $2.6 billion
column154: up 9% from the year ago quarter
column155:
and also a new all-time record.

"
column156:
"

Software and services revenue was over $1.9 billion
column157: up 14% from a year ago. App Store momentum is incredibly strong as cumulative app downloads at 70 billion
column158:
87% of iOS devices are now running iOS 7 and our highly engaged users are a great audience for developers.

"
column159:
"

According to App Annie
column160:
the App Store generated 85% more global revenue than Google Play in the March quarter despite the differences in unit market share between iOS and Android devices.

"
column161:
"

Now
column162: I\u2019d like to talk about the Mac. We saw 4.1 million Macs compared to just under 4 million in the year ago quarter. Thanks to strong performance from MacBook Pro and MacBook Air and Macs have now gained global market share for 31 of the last 32 quarters. Response to Mavericks has been great
column163:
and we are very proud of the fact that so many of our Mac customers are taking advantage of the most advanced and secured experience possible. We ended the quarter with Mac channel inventory slightly below our four to five week target range.

"
column164:
"

Turning to iPad
column165: we saw 16.4 million units. As Tim explained earlier
column166: our iPad results and the comparison to the March quarter last year were heavily influenced by channel inventory changes. Specifically
column167:
this year we saw 16.4 million iPads into our channels and sold through almost 17.5 million reducing our channel inventory by 1.1 million units.

"
column168:
"

Last year we sold over 19.4 million iPads into our channels and sold through 18 million and therefore increased channel inventory by 1.4 million units. As a result
column169: the year-over-year sell through decline was only 3% compared to the sell in decline of 16%. We exit the March quarter with 5.1 million units of iPad channel inventory
column170:
which left us within our target range of four to six weeks.

"
column171:
"

iPad continues to lead all other tablets by far in terms of user engagement
column172: size of ecosystem
column173:
customer satisfaction and e-commerce. A recent study by Chitika Insights found that iPad users in North America generate almost four times the web traffic of all Android tablet users combined.

"
column174:
"

In a February survey
column175:
ChangeWave measured a 98% customer satisfaction rate for both iPad Air and iPad Mini with Retina display. And also found that among people planning to purchase a tablet within 90 days two-thirds plan to buy an iPad. iPad continues to allow companies around the world to reimagine the way they use technology to drive efficiency and improve employee satisfaction. Thousands of iPads are used at FedEx everyday. In an industry where efficiency is critical FedEx pilots and maintenance crews around the world use iPad to transform operational processes and save the company millions of dollars.

"
column176:
"

Eli Lilly has deployed over 20
column177:
000 iPads and 50 internal apps as part of a laptop replacement program that dramatically increased the productivity and capabilities of its employees.

"
column178:
"

The U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs is on its way to deploying iPads to 11
column179: 000 providers to transform the way doctors and patients interact. As part of this initiative
column180: a suite of applications is being developed to allow quick access to real-time secure medical information. In education
column181: according to the latest data published by IDC
column182: iPad has over 95% share of the U.S. education tablet market as teachers and students increasingly benefit from the growing range of engaging iBooks
column183:
textbooks and solutions that are helping to transform the education experience.

"
column184:
"

Let me now turn to our cash position. We ended the quarter with $150.6 billion in cash plus marketable securities
column185: a sequential decline of $8.3 billion. Our domestic cash was $18.4 billion at the end of the March quarter
column186:
a sequential decline of $16 billion and $132.2 billion or 88% of our total cash was offshore. Cash flow from operations was very strong at $13.5 billion for the quarter.

"
column187:
"

In total
column188: we executed almost $21 billion worth of capital return activities during the March quarter. First
column189:
we launched our third accelerated share repurchase program in late January through which we will acquire an additional $12 billion of Apple stock. We received an initial delivery of 19.2 million shares under this ASR and we received a balance of shares due when the program concludes by December of this year.

"
column190:
"

Second
column191: we paid $2.7 billion in dividends in February. And finally
column192: we spent $6 billion on open market purchases of 11.4 million shares throughout the March quarter. At the end of March
column193: we also settled our second ASR program
column194: which was launched in April of last year
column195:
resulting in the retirement of an additional 1.1 million shares.

"
column196:
"

I would like now to go into more detail about the expansion of our capital return program that we\u2019re announcing today. Let me start by summarizing the progress that we\u2019ve made on the program we updated a year ago. By the end of March 2014
column197: we\u2019ve already taken action of $46 billion of the current $60 billion share repurchase authorization
column198:
over 75% of the program with seven quarters remaining to its completion.

"
column199:
"

We have acted aggressively and opportunistically and have delivered on our intention to return capital to shareholders at a fast pace. Including dividends and net-share-settlements
column200:
we\u2019ve taken action on $66 billion of total $100 billion program announced last year.

"
column201:
"

Today we\u2019ve taken additional steps that will increase the overall size of the program from $100 billion to over $130 billion within the same timeframe of December 2015 as before. There are two elements to the expansion of the program. First
column202: we\u2019re increasing the size of our share repurchase authorization from $60 billion to $90 billion. We are very confident in Apple\u2019s future
column203: and we believe our current stock price does not reflect the full value of the Company. That\u2019s why the vast majority of our capital program continues to be allocated to share repurchases. We will also continue to net-share-settle
column204:
restricted stock units and expect to utilize about $1 billion of cash annually for that purpose.

"
column205:
"

Second
column206: our Board has declared a dividend of $3.29 per common share payable on May 15
column207: 2014 to shareholders of record as of May 12
column208: 2014. That represents an increase of about 8% in our quarterly dividend. We understand the importance of dividend increases to many of our investors
column209: and we\u2019re increasing the dividend for the second time in less than two years. We are planning for continued annual increases and we\u2019re very proud that Apple is one of the largest dividend payers in the world
column210:
with annual payments of $11 billion.

"
column211:
"

All our capital return activities must be funded by domestic cash which as I mentioned was about $18 billion as we exited the March quarter
column212: and down from $39 billion in the quarter that we paid our first dividend. We would maintain sufficient domestic liquidity to grow the business and execute capital expenditures and acquisitions. Thanks to Apple\u2019s strong growth in international expansion in recent years. We have built substantial offshore cash balances to repatriate our fall in cash on the current U.S. tax law
column213:
we will incur significant cash tax consequences and we don\u2019t believe this would be in the best interest of our shareholders.

"
column214:
"

We continue to advocate for comprehensive corporate tax reform and streamlining the tax code which we believe would be of great benefit to the U.S. economy. To execute our updated capital return program in a tax efficient manner and leverage our very strong balance sheet
column215: we intend to access the debt markets again. We plan to be active in both the domestic and international bond markets during 2014 for an amount of term debt financing similar to what we issued in 2015
column216:
with a break down between markets currencies and tenures to be determined over the course of the year and subject to prevailing conditions in each market.

"
column217:
"

We have also prepared ourselves to access the commercial paper market given the substantial short term liquidity and flexibility that this channel can provide.

"
column218:
"

Now
column219: as we move ahead into the June quarter
column220:
I\u2019d like to review our outlook which includes the types of forward-looking information that Nancy referred to at the beginning of the call. We expect revenue to be between $36 billion and $38 billion compared to $35.3 billion in the year ago quarter. We expect gross margins to be between 37% and 38%.

"
column221:
"

We expect OpEx to be between $4.4 billion and $4.5 billion. We are continuing to invest heavily in R&D for current revenue generating categories as well as future products and services. We expect OI&E to be about $200 million and we expect the tax rate to be about 26.1%.

"

And now

Timothy D. Cook

Thanks Luca. In addition to the changes to our capital return program today. We are also announcing a seven-for-one split of Apple common stock which will occur in June of this year. We are taking this action to make Apple stock more accessible to a larger number of investors. Each shareholder of record at the close of business on June the 2nd
column226: 2014 will receive six additional shares for every outstanding share held on the record day and trading will begin on a split-adjusted basis on June the 9th
column228:
"

Finally
column229: before we start the Q&A
column230: I would like to take a minute to talk about my dear friend and colleague Peter Oppenheimer. As you know
column231: Peter will be transitioning from the CFO role in June. Peter has been Apple\u2019s CFO for 10 years and the list of his accomplishments is immense. Apple is now more than 20 times the size it was when Peter became our CFO and his expertise
column232: leadership and incredibly hard work had been instrumental to the company\u2019s success. I\u2019d like to thank him very publicly for his contributions to Apple
column233:
from the very bottom of my heart and wish him all the best in his approaching retirement at the end of September.

"
column234:
"

And I\u2019d also like to recognize him that he has never missed guidance in the 10 years as CFO which must be an all-time record for CFOs. We\u2019re really happy and fortunate to have someone with Luca\u2019s talent on Board to replace Peter. He has over 25 years of experience
column235: building and leading finance teams in global companies and has an exceptionally broad international background
column236:
which you might be able to detect from his accent. He\u2019s been managing most of Apple\u2019s financial functions since coming on Board last year and has done an outstanding job. I\u2019m looking forward to working with Luca even closer as Apple\u2019s next CFO.

"

"

"

And so
column381: if you really look at it in just four years after we launched the very first iPad
column383: which is more than we or I think anyone thought was possible at that period of time. And it\u2019s interesting to note that that\u2019s almost twice as many iPhones that we\u2019ve sold in a comparable period of time
column384: and over seven times as many iPods as we\u2019ve sold in the period of time. So
column385: I think it\u2019s important to kind of to put that in perspective. We\u2019ve come a long way very
column386:
very quickly.

"
column387:
"

Looking at it by market a bit
column388: which I think is important. I think Luca mentioned a little bit of this in his comments. In the education market in the U.S.
column389: we have a 95% share. And so the focus in education is on penetration
column390: is on getting more schools to buy and my belief is the match has been lit
column391: and it\u2019s very clear to the educators that have studied this is that student achievement is higher with iPad in the classroom than without it. And so I\u2019m confident we\u2019ve got a really great start in education far beyond the U.S. now. This is happening in many
column392:
many parts of the world.

"
column393:
"

In the enterprise market
column394: we\u2019re seeing virtually all
column395: 98% of the Fortune 500 that using iPad. And we\u2019re seeing
column396: according to Good Technology who looks at activations of tablets
column397: the latest data we have from them is that 91% of the activation of tablets in enterprise were iPads. And so this is also an astonishing number and many of those enterprises are writing apps that are key proprietary apps for running that business
column398: and this is great for that company because they\u2019re more productive as a result of that. And so once again
column399: just like in education in a way
column400: what we have to do in enterprise is focus on penetration. It has to be deeper and broader. But in terms of having people begin the process
column401: beginning writing apps
column402:
we\u2019re doing a pretty good job of that.

"
column403:
"

In the retail market
column404: if you look at the U.S. as a proxy
column405: the NPD numbers for March just came out a few days ago and we had 46% share and embedded in that 46%
column406: there\u2019s a lot of things in there that I personally wouldn\u2019t put in the same category as iPad and that are weighing the share down. It\u2019s certainly a market we wouldn\u2019t play in and a type of product you would never see an Apple brand on. So we feel like we\u2019re doing well there. Office
column407: I believe does help. It\u2019s very unclear to say how much. I believe if it would have been done earlier
column408:
it would have been even better for Microsoft frankly.

"
column409:
"

There is a lots of alternatives out there from a productivity point of view
column410: some of which we brought to the market
column411: some of which many
column412: many innovative companies have brought. But I do see that Office is still a very key franchise in the enterprise
column413: in particular. And I think having it on iPad is good
column414: and I wholeheartedly welcome Microsoft to the App Store to sell Office. Our customers are clearly responding in a good way that it\u2019s available. So
column415:
I do think it helps us particularly in the enterprise area.

"
column416:
"

The other things you look at on iPad that are just blow away as customer sat is 98. There is almost nothing in the world with a 98% customer sat and the intention to buy numbers look good with two-thirds of the people planning to buy a tablet or planning to buy an iPad. The usage numbers are off the chart
column418:
four times the web traffic of all Android tablets combined.

"
column419:
"

And so
column420: when I backup from all of these
column421: I feel great. That doesn\u2019t mean that every quarter
column422: every 90 days is going to be a number that everybody is thrilled with. But what it means to me is that the trend over the arc of time that things look very
column423: very good
column424: that iPad has a great future. And of course the thing that drives us more than any of this are the next iPads if you will
column425: the things that are in the pipeline
column426:
the things that we can do to make the product even better and there is no shortage of work going in on that nor any shortage of ideas.

"
column427:
"

And so when I backup from all of this
column428:
I can\u2019t help but still be extremely excited about where we are.

"
column429:
"

I think we did a reasonable job of explaining what we think the disconnect was between what we had expected
column430:
which we hit it at the high end of our expectation and the street's view of this one. I believe the vast majority of it is that first thing was just channel inventory that maybe we should have been even clearer on last quarter to take into account. But I'm very bullish on iPad.

"
column431:
"

Steven M. Milunovich \u2013 UBS Securities LLC

"
column432:
"

Okay
column433: very complete thank you. One other question
column434: when you look at Google and Amazon and Facebook
column435: they've very much diversified their business over time in a way that one has rarely seen. Apple
column436: sort of the opposite. People say you ought to buy this or that and you'll do acquisitions
column437: but you're obviously very focused. Is that because it's just a management philosophy of wanting to be more focused than some of these other companies? Or is there something about Apple's products that particularly being more hardware oriented that kind of prevents you from saying
column439: let's go make TV shows or let's go often do something else
column440:
even though you probably have the money and the technical capability to do all these things?

"
column441:
"

Timothy D. Cook

"
column442:
"

The key thing for us
column444: is to stay focused on things that we can do best and that we can perform at a really high-level of quality that our customers have come to expect. And so we currently feel comfortable in expanding the number of things we're working on. So we've been doing that in the background and we're not ready yet to pull the string on the curtain. But we've got some great things there. We're working on them. Very
column445: very proud of and very
column446:
very excited about.

"
column447:
"

But for us
column448: we care about every detail and when you care about every detail and getting it right
column449: it takes a bit longer to do that and that's always been the case
column450: that's not something that just occur. As you probably know from following us for a long time
column451: we didn't ship the first MP3 player
column452: nor the first smartphone
column453: nor the first tablet. In fact
column454: there were tablets being shipped a decade or so before then
column455: but arguably
column456:
we shipped the first successful modern tablet and the first successful modern smartphone and the first successful modern MP3 player. And so it means much more to us to get it right than to be first.

"
column457:
"

I think you can see so many examples out in the marketplace
column458: where it's clear that the objective has been to be first. But customers at the end of the day don't care about that. That's not what they look for from Apple. They want great
column459: insanely great and that's what we want to deliver
column460:
and so that's the way we look at it.

"
column461:
"

From an acquisition point of view
column462: we have done 24 in 18 months. That shows that we're on the prowl
column463:
I suppose you could say. We look for companies that have great people and great technology and that fit culturally. And we don't have a rule that says we can't spend a lot or whatever. We'll spend what we think is a fair price. What's important to us is that strategically it makes sense and that it winds up adding value to our shareholders over the long haul. We are not in a race to spend the most or acquire the most. We're in a race to make the worlds' best product that really enrich people's lives.

"
column464:
"

So
column465: to the tune that acquisitions can help us do that and they've done that and continue to do that
column466:
then we will acquire it. And so you can bet that you will continue to see acquisitions and some of which we'll try to keep quiet and some of which seems to be impossible to keep quiet.

"
column467:
"

Nancy Paxton

"
column468:
"

Thank you
column469:
Steve. Could we have the next question please?

"
column470:
"

Operator

"
column471:
"

From Cross Research
column472:
we\u2019ll hear from Shannon Cross.

"
column473:
"

Shannon S. Cross \u2013 Cross Research LLC

"
column474:
"

Thank you. First I just want to tell Peter
column475: thank you very much
column476: we've really enjoyed working with you over the past 10 years. But then secondly
column477: in terms of a question for Tim
column478: can you talk a bit about the competitive landscape for smartphone? If you look at some of your competitors seem to be have cut prices fairly quickly in the most recent product cycle
column479: perhaps faster than before. You've got Microsoft about to close on Nokia. Lenovo is buying Motorola
column480:
there is a lot going on from a sort of competitive standpoint. So I'm curious as to how you're seeing the market?

"
column481:
"

Timothy D. Cook

"
column482:
"

Yes
column483: there is a lot of moving parts
column484: a lot of acquisitions
column485: a lot of people giving up to some degree and deciding to do other things. But at the end of the day we see it much like we've always seen it
column486: as the part of the market that we're interested in is the market of people that really want the best smartphone and that doesn't mean that they're all at the high end of the price stand. I mean
column487:
we have smartphones that go down to a very affordable price with the 4S because we're proud to ship that product.

"
column488:
"

I think that this quarter
column489: if you were unsure
column490: hopefully this quarter demonstrates to you that we can do well in a number of geographies from emerging markets to develop markets. Some of the numbers that we've experienced just to quote some of the more historic prepaid market through the first half of 2014; Brazil was up 61%
column491: Russia was up 97%
column492: Turkey was up 56%
column493: India was up 55%
column495:
"

I could go on
column496: but the point is that there's a number of markets out there where we are beginning to really catch on to a number of customers
column497:
and I am particularly proud of the results in these markets because these have not been historic strong points for Apple. We've been working at China for a while and have learned a lot and I'm very proud of what we've done there. But I think some of these other numbers I just read demonstrates that we're beginning to have really nice success outside of there as well.

"
column498:
"

Shannon S. Cross \u2013 Cross Research LLC

"
column499:
"

Great and then
column500: if you can just
column501: actually as a follow-up on the China side
column502: I think it grew at 13% year-over-year
column503: and you mentioned obviously China Mobile has been the driver of that. But can you talk about some of the other categories as well
column504:
and perhaps some of the other carriers in terms of where you're seeing demand out of China?

"
column505:
"

Timothy D. Cook

"
column506:
"

Yes
column507: really great question. We did have an all-time revenue record in Greater China
column508: just under $10 billion at $9.8 billion. iPhone sales were up 28%
column509: that's versus the IDCs market forecast of 20% growth. So we gained share. Mac units were up double-digit
column510: in particular they were up 13%
column511:
and that's far outpacing IDCs PC market forecast of a negative 8%. So we gained share there as well.

"
column512:
"

If you look at the iTunes software and services revenue in China
column513: we more than doubled it. Year-over-year
column514: we were in the triple digits percentages. And if you look at iPad and you take out the channel inventories
column515: ins and outs and look at demand instead of sell in
column516: we grew by 6% and that compares to IDC\u2019s forecast of a flat tablet market in China for last quarter. And so we literally did well in every single area in China. It wasn\u2019t just because we were able to come to an agreement with the world\u2019s largest carrier. That was certainly key
column517:
but as you can tell from the rest of these numbers there are other things going on.

"
column518:
"

Also
column519: I\u2019d mentioned this briefly with Steve
column520: but I think it\u2019s important to point out that if you look at some of the numbers we\u2019re seeing on first-time iPhone buyers
column521: people that bought the iPhone 4s
column523: and the 5c
column524: 69% first-time iPhone buyers. So these are extraordinary
column525: and as you would expect
column526:
these are also heavily Android switchers. 62% of the people that bought the 4s switched from Android. 60% of the people that bought the 5c switched from Android. And so we\u2019re incredibly pleased with this.

"
column527:
"

For the first half
column528: including our retail stores
column529: Greater China revenue topped $19 billion. So this is a 21% year-over-year
column530: and is our fastest growing region. So
column531:
we\u2019re looking at this data and deciding to continue investing in a big way. We plan to triple the number of Apple Retail Stores over the next two years. We\u2019re continuing to expand in online. We\u2019re continuing to build out channels.

"
column532:
"

We\u2019re up to 40
column533: 000 points of sales now in iPhone
column534: but we\u2019re not nearly where we need to be on the rest of our product line and even the 40
column535: 000 is a low number in considering the broad landmass and the number of folks in China. And so
column536: I feel like there\u2019s still loads of opportunity there
column538:
really good about how we\u2019re doing.

"
column539:
"

Shannon S. Cross \u2013 Cross Research LLC

"
column540:
"

Thank you.

"
column541:
"

Nancy Paxton

"
column543:
Shannon. Could we have the next question please?

"
column544:
"

Operator

"
column545:
"

And from Piper Jaffray we got Gene Munster.

"
column546:
"

Gene Munster \u2013 Piper Jaffray

"
column547:
"

Hey
column548: good afternoon and I\u2019ll add congratulations to Peter on itinerary for the record there. And Tim
column549: I want to talk a little bit about some of your comments at the recent shareholder meeting. You mentioned that Apple TV is no longer a hobby. Wanted to hear a little bit about why you made that distinction? And separately
column550: it would be interesting to hear your feedback on the HBO Amazon announcement today and what you think that means
column551: if anything
column552:
in terms of some content partners being a little more \u2013 work with some more players like yourself? Thanks.

"
column554:
"

Good questions
column555: Gene. The reason that I stripped off the hobby label is that when you look at the sales of the Apple TV box itself
column556: and you look at a content that was bought directly off of Apple TV for 2013
column557: that number was over $1 billion. And so
column558: it didn\u2019t feel right to me to refer to something that\u2019s over $1 billion as a hobby. Also from an investment point of view
column559:
we continue to make the product better and better. And so it doesn\u2019t feel right from that point of view either.

"
column560:
"

We had HBO GO already on Apple TV and you have to authenticate in order to use it
column561:
but you have to do that with Amazon service as well from my brief read of their announcement. I think they in addition to that got some older content from HBO to put on there.

"
column562:
"

I haven't had a chance to evaluate exactly what it is and don't have a personal point of view on that yet. But if I look broadly at the content on Apple TV
column563: I think it compares extremely favorable to the content that is on the Amazon box. We've sold now
column564: Gene
column565: about 20 million of the Apple TV
column566:
and so we've got a pretty large installed base there. And I'm feeling quite good about that business and where it can go.

"
column567:
"

Gene Munster \u2013 Piper Jaffray

"
column568:
"

Excellent
column570:
"

Timothy D. Cook

"
column571:
"

You bet.

"
column572:
"

Nancy Paxton

"
column573:
"

Thank you

and I'm at 408-974-5420. Thanks again for joining us.
