column1:
{"Apple's (AAPL) CEO Tim Cook On Q3 2014 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Apple Inc. (NASDAQ:AAPL)

"
column6:
"

Nancy Paxton - Senior Director of Investor Relations

"
column8:
"

Luca Maestri - SVP and CFO

"
column10:
"

Katy Huberty - Morgan Stanley

"
column21: and welcome to the Apple Incorporated Third Quarter Fiscal Year 2014 Earnings Release Conference Call. Today\u2019s call is being recorded. At this time
column23: I would like to turn the call over to Nancy Paxton
column24:
Senior Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

"
column27: and thanks everyone for joining us today. Speaking first is Apple CEO
column28: Tim Cook; and he will be followed by CFO
column30: and then we'll open the call for questions from analysts. Please note that some of the information you\u2019ll hear during our discussion today will consist of forward-looking statements
column31: including without limitation
column33: gross margins
column38:
"

Actual results or trends could differ materially from our forecast. For more information
column39: please refer to the risk factors discussed in Apple\u2019s Form 10-K for 2013
column40: the Form 10-Q for the first two quarters of fiscal 2014
column41: and the Form 8-K filed with the SEC today
column42: along with the associated press release. Apple assumes no obligation to update any forward-looking statements or information
column43:
which speak as of their respective dates.

"
column44:
"

I\u2019d now like to turn the call over to Tim for introductory remarks.

"
column46:
"

Thanks
column47: Nancy. Good afternoon
column48: everyone. It\u2019s been a very busy and exciting time at Apple and I'd like to review some of the highlights of our June quarter. We hosted our best ever Worldwide Developer\u2019s Conference last month with over 20 million people from around the world watching our keynote session
column49: which is the a record. We've had overwhelming response from customers and developers to the new features we previewed in OS X Yosemite and iOS 8. Yosemite has been redesigned with a fresh look and powerful new apps and iOS 8 is the biggest release since the launch of the App Store. With powerful continuity features
column50:
these upcoming releases will allow Macs and iOS devices to work together in even smarter ways.

"
column51:
"

Customers can start on activity like writing an email on one device and pass it to another
column52: picking up where they left off without missing a beat. They will even be able to make and receive iPhone calls on their Mac with just a click. These are features that only Apple can deliver. With iOS 8
column53: we have opened over 4000 APIs providing more flexibility and opportunity for developers than ever before. iOS 8 provides developers with amazing new frameworks
column54:
enables wide use of Touch ID to securely authenticate users within apps and lets developers further customize the user experience with major extensibility features such as third-party keyboards.

"
column55:
"

We have also introduced Swift
column56: an innovative new programming language for both iOS and OS X. Swift is the result of the latest research on programming languages
column57: combined with decades of experience within building Apple platforms. It makes writing code interactive and fun
column58: eliminates entire classes of unsafe code and generates apps that run lightning fast. It's easy to learn
column59: allowing even more people to dream big and create whole new categories of apps. We believe our new OS releases
column60: combined with Swift will result in a huge leap forward for the Apple ecosystem and we can\u2019t wait to what developers will create with Yosemite
column61:
iOS 8 and Swift.

"
column62:
"

When we introduced iOS 7 years ago
column63: it was a revolutionary operating system for iPhone. Over the years we've extended it to the iPod family with iPod Touch and later to a tablet form factor with iPad. An explosion of apps
column64: accessories and services for these devices has created an incredibly vibrant ecosystem. We\u2019re extending iOS in even more dimensions as customers around the world make iPhones and iPads an essential part of their lives
column65: at home
column66: at school
column67: at work and on the go. We\u2019re putting a huge effort into delivering the best experience to our customers wherever they use iOS. That includes a safe and intuitive user interface for driving
column68: called CarPlay
column69: which is being integrated by 29 major car brands including Audi
column70: BMW
column71: Ford
column72: General Motors
column73: Honda
column74: Hyundai
column75: Mercedes
column76:
Toyota and Volvo; and after-market systems like Pioneer and Alpine.

"
column77:
"

We\u2019ve created a new tool for developers called HealthKit
column78: which allows health and fitness apps work to together and empowers customers to choose what health data they share. We're taking the first steps in this area in collaboration with the Mayo clinic
column79: whose new apps can automatically receive data from a blood pressure app
column80: for example and share it with a physician
column81:
or a nutrition app can inform fitness apps how many calories are being consumed each day. Our ARM health app will provide an easy to read dashboard of all health and fitness data.

"
column82:
"

We're enabling new ways to control light and doors and thermostats and other connected devices around the house using Siri with the HomeKit feature of iOS 8. And in the Enterprise
column83: we are including new security
column84: productivity and device management features in iOS 8. We forged a relationship with IBM to deliver a new class of mobile business solutions to enterprise customers around the world. We are working together to provide companies access to the power of Big Data analytics
column85: right on every employee's iPhone or iPad. Using Swift
column86: we will collaborate to bring over 100 Mobile First apps to enterprise clients
column87:
each addressing a specific industry need or opportunity.

"
column88:
"

This is a radical step for Enterprise and opens up a large market opportunity for Apple but more importantly
column89: it\u2019s great for productivity and creativity of our enterprise customers. From the pocket to the car
column90: to the workplace
column91: home and gym
column92:
we have a very large vision of what iOS can be and we're incredibly excited about our plans.

"
column93:
"

Turning to our financial results
column94: today we are reporting record June quarter revenue
column95: thanks to the very strong performance of iPhone
column96: Mac and the continued growth of revenue from the Apple ecosystem. Our teams executed brilliantly during the quarter with earnings per share up 20% year-over-year
column97:
our highest growth rate in seven quarters.

"
column98:
"

We sold over 35 million iPhones
column99: setting a new third quarter record. We generated healthy growth in our entry priced
column100: mid-tier and lead iPhone categories. I'm especially happy about our progress in the BRIC countries
column101:
where iPhone sales were up a very strong 55% year-over-year.

"
column102:
"

We also had a record June quarter for Mac sales
column103: with growth of 18% year-over-year in a market that is shrinking by 2% according to IDC\u2019s latest estimate. Demand has been very strong for our portables in particular and we've have had a great customer response to the new higher performance
column104:
lower priced MacBook Air. It was another strong performance for the App Store and the other services contributing to the thriving Apple ecosystem.

"
column105:
"

In fact for the first nine months of this fiscal year
column106: the line item that we call iTunes software and services has been the fastest growing part of our business. iTunes billings grew 25% year-over-year in the June quarter and reached an all-time quarterly high
column107: thanks to the very strong results from the App Store. We're continuing to invest in our incredible ecosystem
column108: which is a huge asset for Apple and a very important differentiator of our customer experience. iPad sales met our expectations but we realized they didn\u2019t meet many of yours. Our sales were gated in-part by a reduction in channel inventory and in-part by market softness in certain parts of the world. For example IDC\u2019s latest estimate indicates a 5% overall decline in the U.S. tablet market
column109:
as well as a decline in the Western European tablet market in the June quarter.

"
column110:
"

But what\u2019s most important to us is that customers are enjoying their iPads and using them heavily. In a survey conducted in May by ChangeWave
column111: iPad Air registered a 98% customer satisfaction rate
column112: while iPad Mini with retina display received an astonishing 100% customer satisfaction rate. The survey also found that among people planning to purchase a tablet within 90 days
column113:
63% plan to buy an iPad and our own data indicates that more than half of customers purchasing an iPad are buying their very first iPad.

"
column114:
"

Another recent study by Custora found that iPad accounts for 80% of all U.S. tablet based e-commerce purchases. We're very bullish about the future of the tablet market and we're confident that we can continue to bring significant innovation to this category through hardware
column115: software and services. We think our partnership with IBM
column116: providing a new generation of mobile enterprise applications
column117:
designed with iPad\u2019s legendary ease of use and backed by IBM\u2019s cloud services and data analytics will be one such catalyst for future iPad growth.

"
column118:
"

Looking ahead
column119: we are very excited about our agreement to purchase Beats Electronics and Beats Music. We think its part of Apple\u2019s DNA and we think the addition of Beats team will be great for music lovers. Beats provides Apple with a fantastic subscription music service
column120: access to rare talent and a fast growing line up of products that we can build upon. Not counting Beats
column121:
we've completed 29 acquisitions since the beginning of fiscal year 2013 including five since the end of the March quarter and we have brought some incredible technology and more importantly some incredible talent into Apple in the process. We are hard at work and investing heavily on exciting opportunities across our business and we have an incredible pipeline of new products and services that we can\u2019t wait to show you.

"
column122:
"

With that I would like to turn the call over to Luca to discuss our Q3 results in more detail.

"
column123:
"

Luca Maestri

"
column124:
"

Thank you
column125: Tim and good afternoon everyone. We set a new June quarter record for revenue at $37.4 billion
column126: up $2.1 billion or 6% year-over-year. This result was towards the high end of our guidance range
column127: despite a reduction in channel inventory for both iPhone and iPad. The revenue growth was driven by strong sales of iPhones and Macs
column128: as well as the continued great performance of iTunes softwares and services. Gross margin was 39.4%
column129: above our guidance range and operating margin was $10.3 billion
column130: representing 27.5% of revenue. Net income was $7.7 billion
column131: translating to diluted earnings per share of $1.28
column132:
a 20% year-over-year increase.

"
column133:
"

For details by product
column134: I'd like to start with iPhone. We sold 35.2 million iPhones
column135: an increase of 4 million over last year
column136: representing 13% growth. As Tim mentioned
column137: iPhone sales grew well across all three of our entry-price
column138:
mid-tier and lead product categories.

"
column139:
"

In the U.S.
column140: iPhone accounts for 41.9% of the smartphone subscriber base according to the latest data from ComScore
column141: up from 41.3% in the previous measurement period. Also based on the latest survey by ChangeWave
column142: iPhone earned a 97% customer satisfaction rate and among responders planning purchase a smartphone within 90 days
column143: 50% planned to purchase an iPhone
column144:
up from 42% in the March quarter and 44% a year ago.

"
column145:
"

iPhone sales were at the high end of our expectations
column146: despite new product rumors that we believe resulted in purchase delay. In addition
column147: tax increases and the regulatory environment in Japan affected smartphone sales in what has been one of iPhone\u2019s fastest growing markets in recent quarters. Considering these factors
column148: the performance of iPhone was even more impressive in the June quarter and it boosts our confidence for the future. We reduced iPhone channel inventory by about 150
column149: 000 from the end of the March quarter
column150:
leaving us within our target range of four to six weeks.

"
column151:
"

Apple continues to innovate through hardware
column152: software and services to make iPhone the best smartphone for business. Today
column153: companies have equipped millions of employees with iPhones and they are seeing tremendous benefits in productivity
column154: employee satisfaction and profitability. For instance medical device leader Medtronic has developed over 175 internal iOS apps for over 16
column155: 500 iPhones used by its employees to facilitate sales
column156: improve productivity and ensure that essential marketing materials are up to date. Throughout the global offices of Nestle
column157: the largest food company in the world
column158: over 25
column159: 000 iPhones are accessing corporate networks
column160: improving communication and connecting employees to critical internal resources. And at NASA over 26
column161: 000 iPhones are in use by scientists
column162: flight crew members
column163:
technicians and researchers.

"
column164:
"

Turning to iPad
column165: we sold 13.3 million units
column166: compared to 14.6 million in the June quarter last year. iPad sales grew overall in the developing markets with particularly strong year-over-year growth in the Middle-East
column167: where iPad sales were up 64%
column168: in China where they grew 51%
column169: and in India
column170: where they were up 45%. This growth was more than offset by lower sales in more mature markets. We reduced iPad channel inventory by 500
column171: 000 from the end of the March quarter
column172:
which left us within our target range of four to six weeks.

"
column173:
"

In the Enterprise
column174: global companies are using iPad to improve customer service
column175: boost work and productivity and enhance critical processes. iPad continues to be the standard for teams across the airline industry. Qantas Airlines has over 15
column176: 000 iPads deployed to pilots as well as cabin
column177: customer service and ground crews to enhance key processes across the daily operations and governments are deploying thousands of iPads worldwide. One of the largest examples is Sweden
column178: where over 100
column179:
000 iPads are being used by local government offices across the country.

"
column180:
"

In education
column181: iPad remains the tablet of choice with 85% share of the U.S. education tablet market according to the latest published estimate from IDC. We\u2019ve now sold 13 million iPads to education customers globally. We\u2019re bringing teachers and students great new tools to build an experience educational count into an iPad. As of this month
column182: teachers using the free iTunes U app can create
column183: edit and manage entire courses that are on iPad for the first time and students can discover new ways to collaborate
column184:
including the ability to start class discussions and ask questions right from their iPad.

"
column185:
"

Next
column186: I'd like to talk about the Mac. We sold 4.4 million Macs
column187: compared to under 3.8 million in the year ago quarter
column188: an increase of 18% year-over-year and a new June quarter record. The increase was driven by portables
column189: thanks to very strong growth of MacBook Air. We achieved strong double digit Mac growth across many countries
column190: including the U.S. Canada
column192: the UK
column193: Germany
column194: France
column195: Australia
column196: China
column197: India and the Middle-East. This growth is particularly impressive
column198:
given the contraction of the overall PC market. Macs have now gained global market share for 32 of the last 33 quarters.

"
column199:
"

Macs performed well in the U.S. education buying season with double-digit growth in the K to 12 market
column200: driven primarily by large deployments of MacBook Air. The Shawnee Mission School District in Kansas chose Apple to provide an entire solution that will equip every teacher with a MacBook Air and an iPad Air
column201:
every high school student with a MacBook Air and every middle school and elementary student with an iPad. The Rowan-Salisbury School System in North Carolina is deploying thousands of MacBook Airs to students and teachers in grades 9 to 12 as part of the district's digital learning initiatives.

"
column202:
"

We ended the quarter with Mac channel inventory slightly below our four to five week target range. The Apple ecosystem continues to grow and thrive. Total revenue from iTunes software and services was $4.5 billion
column203: an increase of 12% year-over-year. Our iTunes stores generated all time record billings of $5.4 billion in the June quarter
column204: up 25% year-over-year
column205: driven by very strong growth in App Store sales. These items billings translated to quarterly iTunes revenue of almost $2.6 billion
column206: up 8% from the year ago quarter. Software and services revenue was $1.9 billion
column207:
up 19% from a year ago.

"
column208:
"

App Store momentum remains very strong and cumulative app downloads has topped 75 billion. We continue be amazed by our vibrant and diverse developer community and we are extremely proud that our developers have now earned over 20 billion for sales of their apps through the App Store
column209: nearly half of which have been earned in the past 12 months. This number truly stands out among our competition as our developers continue to benefit from the broad reach and powerful design of the App Store
column210: coupled with Apple\u2019s large
column211:
loyal and very engaged customer base.

"
column212:
"

Let me now turn to our cash position. We ended the quarter with $164.5 billion in cash plus marketable securities
column213: a sequential increase of $13.9 billion. Our domestic cash was $26.8 billion at the end of the June quarter
column214:
a sequential increase of $8.3 billion and $137.7 billion or 84% of our total cash was offshore. Cash flow from operations was $10.3 billion.

"
column215:
"

We executed another very successful debt offering in April
column216: issuing a total of 12 billion in notes across 3
column219: 10 and 30 year maturities. In addition
column220: during the quarter
column221:
we entered the commercial paper market for the first time with $2 billion in short-term obligations outstanding as of the end of June. We also continued to execute our shareholder return program with $8.3 billion of capital returned to inventors during the June quarter. We spent $5 billion to repurchase 59 million Apple shares to open market transactions. We paid almost $2.9 billion in dividends and equivalents and utilized over $400 million to net share settle vesting employee RSUs.

"
column222:
"

We've now taken action on over $74 billion of our $130 billion capital return program
column223: including $51 billion in share repurchases with six quarters remaining to its completion. And finally our Board has declared a dividend of $0.47 per common share payable on August 14
column224: 2014 to shareholders of record as of record as of August 11
column226:
"

Now as we move ahead into September quarter
column227: I\u2019d like to review our outlook which includes the types of forward-looking information that Nancy referred to at the beginning of the call. We expect revenue to be between $37 billion and $40 billion
column228: compared to $37.5 billion in the year ago quarter. We expect gross margin to between 37% and 38%. We expect OpEx to be between $4.75 billion and $4.85 billion. We expect OI&E to be about $250 million and we expect the tax rate to be about 26.1%. Finally
column229:
we expect the Beats transaction to close this quarter and we expect the acquisition to be accreted to our earnings in our fiscal 2015.

column366: iPhone units were actually up 10%. Your more macro question; what I understand to be your macro question of do I think there is some sort of cannibalization going on trade-in programs on new product sales? What I think is happening in the aggregate if you look across the world is that trade-ins are actually hugely beneficial for our ecosystem because people wind up -- we have more people that are able to join the party when we have a trade-in
column367: because in essence
column368: it winds up being used by -- probably the prime example someone else within the family or in the example that has become more common in the last year

someone trades it in and then that goes to either somebody else in that country that is very price sensitive or somebody in a different country and I see all of this as good.

column372: because you wind up having -- you wind up attracting people that are much more price sensitive in there. I think the great thing is that our products command a much higher resale value than others do. And so that leads to a larger trade-in and from my perspective
column373: that being the larger ecosystem

column453: I feel the same way. I think you can only do so many partnerships well
column454: and so it is unusual that we enter into a partnership. But in this particular case
column455: I think arguably the companies are so complementary
column456: and I've gotten to know Gini fairly well over the last couple of years and I think we see the importance of the customer
column457: a lot of the same way and both feel that Mobile and Enterprise is just an enormous opportunity. And we\u2019re not competing with each other. And so I think a partnership in that case is particularly great. Would we do more of either of the things we did? We\u2019re always looking in the acquisition space
column458:
but we don\u2019t let our money burn a hole in our pocket and we don\u2019t do things that aren\u2019t strategic.

"
column459:
"

And so with Beats we felt we were getting an incredible subscription service
column460: a very rare set of talent that we think can do great things in Apple and access to a very fast growing businesses in their headphone and earphone space. And culturally we felt there was a match and music has been deeply embedded in Apple\u2019s DNA for many
column461: many years. And so it was a great marriage and I think the partnership with IBM is a great marriage as well. It\u2019s more like that
column462: presented themselves -- or I think we can manage more things. I think that we have a very
column463:
very strong executive team and can do that. But it\u2019s not my goal to acquire certain number of companies or spend a certain amount of money. We want to do things that help us make great products that are great for our customers and so forth.

"
column464:
"

Ben Reitzes - Barclays

"
column465:
"

I am sorry
column466: just really quick on the IBM. Does this say something about Apple doing more in Big Data
column467:
and taking a cut maybe of some of the analytics opportunities as well?

"
column468:
"

Tim Cook

"
column470: we didn\u2019t talk about how the business model is going to work. But generally speaking
column471:
I think that each of us have revenue streams in the enterprise and each of us went from having those revenue streams. So that\u2019s how I look at that. And we win if we can drive that penetration number I spoke about from 20% to 60%. That would be incredibly exciting here. The walls would shake. And so that\u2019s what I hope for.

"
column472:
"

Nancy Paxton

"
column473:
"

Thank you Ben. Could we have the next question please?

"
column474:
"

Operator

"
column475:
"

We will hear from Ben Schachter with Macquarie.

"
column476:
"

Ben Schachter - Macquarie

"
column477:
"

Tim
column478: I just wanted to talk about the app market for Enterprise. Right now I believe that app developers can sell to the enterprise directly and therefore that they can bypass sharing revenue from these app sales with Apple. Is Apple going to allow that to continue
column479:
and can you also just more broadly discuss how Apple thinks about the opportunity to sell apps directly to the enterprise?

"
column480:
"

Tim Cook

"
column481:
"

We have no plans to change the rules with Enterprise. Some enterprises like proprietary apps that they do not want to offer to others and so we obviously have a way for them to distribute those into their enterprise or just the employees that they want to and so I'm not worried about changing that. We\u2019re also taking friction out of the system and not adding it. Again
column482: the big thing for us is getting the penetration number
column483: I think getting our product
column484:
iPhones and iPads and Macs in more people hands and we think there is a huge opportunity in Enterprise to do that.

"
column485:
"

Nancy Paxton

"
column486:
"

Thank you Ben. A replay of today's call will be available for two weeks as podcast on the iTunes Store
column487:
as a webcast on apple.com/investor and via telephone and the numbers for the telephone replay are 888-203-1112888-203-1112 or 719-457-0820719-457-0820 and please enter confirmation code 76136258 [ph]. These replays will be available by approximately 5.00 PM Pacific Time today. Members of the press with additional questions can contact Steve Dowling at 408-974-1896408-974-1896 and financial analysts can contact Joan Hoover or me with additional questions. Joan is at 408-974-4570408-974-4570 and I'm at 408-974-5420408-974-5420. And thanks again to everyone for joining us.

"
column488:
"

Operator

"
column489:
"

And ladies and gentlemen
column490:
that does conclude today\u2019s presentation. We do thank everyone for your participation.

"

column1:
{"Apple's (AAPL) CEO Tim Cook On Q4 2014 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Apple Inc. (NASDAQ:AAPL)

"
column2:
"

Q4 2014 Results Earnings Conference Call

"
column7:
"

Nancy Paxton - Senior Director of Investor Relations

"
column9:
"

Luca Maestri - SVP and CFO

"
column10:
"

Analysts

"
column18:
"

Keith Buckman - Bank of Montreal

"
column23:
and welcome to the Apple Incorporated Fourth Quarter Fiscal Year 2014 Earnings Release Conference Call. Today\u2019s call is being recorded.

"
column24:
"

At this time
column26: I would like to turn the call over to Nancy Paxton
column27:
Senior Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

"
column28:
"

Nancy Paxton

"
column30: and thanks everyone for joining us today. Speaking first today is Apple's CEO
column31: Tim Cook; and he will be followed by CFO
column33:
and after some final remarks we'll open the call for questions from analysts.

"
column34:
"

Please note that some of the information you\u2019ll hear during our discussion today will consist of forward-looking statements
column38: operating expenses
column40:
taxes and future products.

"
column41:
"

Actual results or trends could differ materially from our forecast. For more information
column42: please refer to the risk factors discussed in Apple\u2019s Form 10-K for 2013
column43: the Form 10-Q for the first three quarters of fiscal 2014
column44: and the Form 8-K filed with the SEC today
column45: along with the associated press release. Apple assumes no obligation to update any forward-looking statements or information
column46:
which speak as of their respective dates.

"
column47:
"

And I\u2019d now like to turn the call over to Tim for introductory remarks.

"
column48:
"

Tim Cook

"
column49:
"

Thanks
column50: Nancy. Good afternoon
column51: everyone and thanks for joining us. Since we spoke in July
column52: it's been an exciting and very busy time
column53:
so we have lots of great things to talk about today.

"
column54:
"

Just last month
column55:
we launched the biggest advancements in iPhone's history with iPhone 6 and iPhone 6 Plus. These iPhones are the best we have ever created and customers absolutely love them.

"
column56:
"

Our operational team has done an extraordinary job executing the manufacturing ramp throughout the entire supply chain. Today we've launched in 32 countries including China and our new iPhones will be shifting in 69 countries and territories by the end of this month
column57:
making this our fastest and most successful iPhone launch ever.

"
column58:
"

Demand for the new iPhones has been staggering and geographically broad-based markedly higher in every single country where we've launched compared to the iPhone 5s a year ago.

"
column59:
"

We're working hard to fill orders as fast as possible and we're on track to be in more than 115 countries by the end of December.

"
column60:
"

Last month we introduced two new categories; the first is Apple Pay
column61: an entirely new way to pay for things in stores and in apps. It makes mobile payments easier
column62:
more secure and more private. Apple Pay went live today and now making purchases and participating stores happens with just a touch of a finger.

"
column63:
"

Paying within apps is as easy as selecting Apple Pay and placing a finger on Touch ID. Today Apple Pay supports credit and debit cards from the three major payment networks and the top U.S. banks and over 500 additional banks have signed on and will be supporting Apple Pay beginning this year and early next year. Apple Pay is being supported by many of the nation's top retailers and we continue to sign more retailers.

"
column64:
"

The second new category is Apple Watch
column65:
our most personal device ever and one that has already captured the world's imagination. We can't wait to get Apple Watch to customers beginning in early calendar 2015. We'll be providing more details on Apple Watch as we get closer to the shipment day.

"
column66:
"

Last week we launched the new iPad Air 2 and iPad Mini 3 with innovations that make them dramatically better than previous generation and the stunning new iMac with a Retina 5K display.

"
column67:
"

We released iOS 8 last month and our customers are enjoying new ways to use their iPhone
column68:
iPad or iPod Touch with intuitive new features and groundbreaking security.

"
column69:
"

Last week
column70: we also released OS X Yosemite
column71:
with an all new design and continuity features that deliver an even more fluid experience across all of our iOS devices and Mac.

"
column72:
"

These introductions reflect years of innovation and hard work by teams all across Apple and they demonstrate the seamless integration of hardware
column73:
software and services that provides unparallel user experiences for our customers. These are things that only Apple can do.

"
column74:
"

We've also communicated and demonstrated our commitment to respecting and protecting users' privacy with strong encryption and strict policies that govern how our data is handled.

"
column75:
"

Today we're also reporting very strong results for Apple's fourth fiscal quarter. We generated our strongest revenue growth rate in seven quarters far surpassing our expectations we communicated in July and establishing a new record for Apple's September quarter revenue.

"
column76:
"

We're also reporting gross margin of 38% compared to 37% last year
column77: leading to a very strong EPS growth of 20%. Fueled by the launch of iPhone 6 and 6 Plus and strong demand for our previous iPhone models
column78:
we set a new September quarter record for iPhone with revenue growth of 21% year-over-year.

"
column79:
"

Demand for iPhone was strong across all geographies with global unit sell-through growth of 26% and we exited the quarter with significant backlog for both iPhone 6 and 6 Plus.

"
column80:
"

We established an all-time quarterly record for Mac sales with revenue growing 18% year-over-year
column81:
thanks in particular to the very strong performance of our portables.

"
column82:
"

We're especially proud of our Mac results considering the overall contraction of the global PC market this year and we achieved our highest quarterly market share since 1995.

"
column83:
"

We also set an all-time record for the App Store revenue
column84:
thanks to the tremendous momentum and ongoing success of our developer community. App Store revenue grew 36% over last year and cumulative app downloads have now topped 85 billion.

"
column85:
"

These results bring to a close a record breaking fiscal 2014. Over the last four quarters
column86: our products and services have generated a $183 billion in revenues
column87: an increase of $12 billion over last year. We sold 243 million iOS devices and 19 million Macs
column88:
both all-time highs.

"
column89:
"

Our revenue from iTunes software and services reached $18 billion
column90: which was more than the annual sales of two thirds of the companies in the Fortune 500 and we generated $6.45 in earnings per share
column91:
which is 14% higher than last year and also set a new record.

"
column92:
"

We made big investments in our business and have continued to expand our global footprint. Today we have 437 Apple retail stores in 15 countries and our partners are selling Apple products in hundreds of thousands of locations around the world.

"
column93:
"

We're continuing to invest in developing markets where revenues approached $50 million in fiscal year '14
column94:
up 16% over last year and twice the rate of growth of the company overall.

"
column95:
"

We [forged] (ph) a landmark partnership with IBM to provide a new generation of mobile enterprise application designed with our products legendary ease of use and backed by IBM's cloud services and data analytics.

"
column96:
"

Our partnership aims to redefine the way work is done
column97:
address key industry mobility challenges and sparked true mobile-led business change.

"
column98:
"

Developer teams have been working closely to develop the first wave of Mobile First solutions and these solutions will be ready for customers beginning next month across six sectors; banking
column99: government
column100: insurance
column101: retail
column102:
travel and transportation and telecommunication.

"
column103:
"

We brought tremendous new talent and technology into Apple through 20 acquisitions in fiscal '14 including seven alone in the September quarter. We closed the Beats transition in July and we're off to a great start with some wonderful plans we'll share with you in the future.

"
column104:
"

Our strong results continue to generate significant cash and we're extremely happy that this has enabled us to make substantial investments in Apple's future
column105:
while retaining -- while returning cash to our shareholders.

"
column106:
"

We had executed aggressively against our share repurchase program
column107:
spending $17 billion in the September quarter alone and $45 billion in the last year.

"
column108:
"

In addition to Apple's strong business performance over the past four quarters
column109: I am incredibly proud of all of our work to protect the environment
column110: to advance human rights
column111:
to improve working conditions in the supply chain and to change the way teachers teach and students learn.

"
column112:
"

I'd like to thank all of our customers
column113: employees
column114:
developers and business partners for making fiscal 2014 Apple's best year yet and I'd like to thank all of our shareholders for their continued support. I could not be more excited about the road ahead in fiscal 2015.

"
column115:
"

With that
column116:
I'd like to turn the call over to Luca to discuss our September quarter results in more detail.

"
column117:
"

Luca Maestri

"
column118:
"

Thank you
column119: Tim
column120: and good afternoon
column121: everyone. During the September quarter we generated record revenue of $42.1 billion
column122:
an increase $4.7 billion or 12% year-over-year. These results exceeded our guidance range due to better than expected sales of iPhones and Macs for which customer demand grew strongly year-over-year in all our segments.

"
column123:
"

Gross margin was 38% at the high end of the guidance range
column124: operating margin was $11.2 billion representing 26.5% of revenue. Net income was $8.5 billion
column125: a new September quarter record translating to diluted earnings per share of $1.42
column126: a 20% year-over-year increase. Cash flow from operations was very strong
column127: a $13.3 billion
column128:
also a new Q4 record.

"
column129:
"

For details by product
column130: I will start with iPhone. We sold 39.3 million iPhones
column131:
an increase of 5.5 million over last year or 16% growth. Underlying demand was even stronger with sell-through growth of 26%.

"
column132:
"

iPhone sales grew across both developed and emerging markets. Unit sales in the U.S. grew 17% year-over-year
column133:
and in Western Europe they were up 20%. We saw even stronger growth in Latin America and the Middle East with sales up more than 50% and in Central and Eastern Europe where sales more than doubled.

"
column134:
"

We increased iPhone channel inventory by just under one million units during the September quarter this year
column135:
significantly less than the 3.3 million unit increase in the September quarter a year ago.

"
column136:
"

Based on the very strong demand for our new iPhones
column137:
this left us below our target range of four to six weeks for channel inventory on a look forward basis.

"
column138:
"

iPhone momentum in enterprise market remains very strong. The latest data published by IDC indicates that iPhone have 69% share of the U.S. commercial smartphone market.

"
column139:
"

Also
column140:
In August ChangeWave survey of U.S. corporate IT buyers found that among those planning to purchase smartphones in the December quarter 75% plan to purchase iPhones. An iPhone continues to fuel innovation of companies around the world.

"
column141:
"

Schindler
column142: a leading global escalator and elevator manufacturer has deployed over 20
column143: 000 iPhones and 20 customer apps to improve customer engagements for safety and to allow service technicians to access vital documentation
column144:
repair and safety functions when they are in the field.

"
column145:
"

Baidu
column146: China's top search provider currently has over 20
column147: 000 employees using iPhones and the company has developed over 30 in-house iOS apps to help its employees work more efficiently
column148:
track sales leads and manage internal IT infrastructure and processes.

"
column149:
"

Next
column150: I would like to talk about the Mac. We sold 5.5 million Macs
column151:
an increase of almost a million over last year. That represents 21% growth year-over-year and an all-time quarterly record. We saw great demand in the back-to-school season for both desktops and portables with especially strong growth for MacBook Pro and MacBook Air.

"
column152:
"

We achieved double-digit Mac growth across most markets around the world
column153:
with particularly impressive performance in emerging markets where Mac sales were up 46%.

"
column154:
"

These results are truly remarkable given the contraction in the global PC market and we now gain market share for 33 of the last 34 quarters. We ended the quarter with Mac channel inventory slightly below our four to five week target range.

"
column155:
"

Turning to iPad
column156: we sold 12.3 million units compared to 14.1 million in the September quarter last year. In anticipation of our October new product announcement we reduced iPad channel inventory by 500
column157: 000 from the end of the June quarter
column158:
which left us within our target range of channel inventory on a look-back basis.

"
column159:
"

iPad sales were consistent with our expectations and we experienced very strong results in Japan where iPad sales were up 46% year-over-year. Customers continue to love their iPads. In an August survey by ChangeWave iPad Mini with retina display earned an incredible 100% satisfaction rate
column160: and among consumers planning to purchase a tablet within 90 days
column161:
the survey indicated a 55% plan to buy an iPad.

"
column162:
"

We continue to see some momentum in enterprise for iPad. Progressive IT organizations around the world continue to deploy
column163:
manage and develop amazing in-house apps for iPad.

"
column164:
"

Healthcare leader Sanofi has over 25
column165:
000 iPads and over 450 in-house apps for sales teams and corporate employees to get their products and information into the hands of doctors and other healthcare providers.

"
column166:
"

Premium eyewear designer Luxottica has deployed over 10
column167: 000 iPads to improve how customers experience the size
column168: fit and overall look of eyewear in a retail environment. Importantly
column169:
since the announcement of the partnership with IBM hundreds of corporations around the world have expressed interest in MobileFirst solutions and we are actively working with over 50 of them to become foundational client for MobileFirst solutions in their industries.

"
column170:
"

iPad continues to lead the U.S. education tablet market with 90% share based on the latest data from IDC. In the September quarter the St. Paul public school in Minnesota purchased over 22
column171: 000 iPad Airs and over 5
column172:
000 iPad Minis in the first race of the district's personalized learning through technology plan that will ultimately equip every student with an iPad.

"
column173:
"

We are fully consistent and continue to strive. Our item store generated all time record billings of $5.4 billion in the September quarter
column174: up 22% year-over-year
column175: thanks to the tremendous momentum of the app store. Developers around the world have embraced the iOS platform and keep broadening the appeal of our thoughtfully designed app store to a large
column176:
loyal and engaged customer base.

"
column177:
"

Across all of our programs the number of registered app developers has grown by 22% in the last year and we are rapidly approaching 10 million. We are seeing especially strong interest in the enterprise with a number of registered developers is up 39% over a year ago.

"
column178:
"

Our retail stores also generated strong results. Revenue for the quarter was $5.1 billion
column179: up 15% from a year ago and a new September quarter record. We opened 10 new stores and completed the remodels of three stores during the quarter ending with a total of 437 stores
column180:
41% of which are outside the United States.

"
column181:
"

We are projecting a total of approximately 25 new store openings in fiscal '15
column182:
about three quarters of which will be outside the U.S. We also plan to remodel about five stores over the course of the year.

"
column183:
"

With an average of 432 stores opened in the September quarter average revenue per store was $11.9 million compared to $10.9 million in the year ago quarter. We hosted 102 million visitors to our stores during the quarter
column184: which translates to over 18
column185:
000 visitors per store per week.

"
column186:
"

Let me now turn to our cash position. We ended the quarter with $155.2 billion in cash plus marketable securities
column187:
a sequential decline of $9.3 billion. We are continue to execute our capital return program aggressively with the total spend of over $20 billion in just the September quarter.

"
column188:
"

We launched our fourth accelerated share repurchase program at the end of August spending $9 billion. We also spent $8 billion to repurchase $81 million Apple's shares to open market transactions
column189:
paid $2.8 billion in dividends and equivalence and utilized over $300 million to net share sell vesting employee RSUs.

"
column190:
"

So
column191:
we've already taken action on over $94 billion of our $130 billion capital return program including $68 billion in share repurchases with five quarters remaining to its completion. We remained firmly committed to our objective of delivering attractive returns to shareholders through both business performance and return of capital.

"
column192:
"

As we said before
column193:
we review our capital allocation regularly. We have solicited feedback on our capital return program from shareholders in the past and we will continue to do so. We plan to report on our conclusions in a timeframe similar to last year.

"
column194:
"

Now
column195: as we move ahead into the December quarter
column196:
I'd like to review our outlook which includes the types of forward-looking information that Nancy referred to at the beginning of the call. We expect revenue to be between $63.5 billion and $66.5 billion compared to $57.6 billion in the year ago quarter.

"
column197:
"

This represents a double-digit revenue increase despite significant foreign exchange headwinds from the recent strengthening of the U.S. dollar against most currencies. We expect gross margin to be between 37.5% and 38.5%. We expect OpEx to be between $5.4 billion and $5.5 billion. We expect OI&E to be about $325 million and we expect the tax rate to be about 26.5%.

"
column198:
"

Also today our Board has declared a dividend of $0.47 per common share payable on November 13
column200: to shareholders of record as of November 10
column202:
"

With that
column203:
I will hand it over to Nancy for some final remarks.

"
column204:
"

Nancy Paxton

"
column205:
"

Thanks
column206:
Luca. We'd like to let you know about some reporting changes that we'll be making beginning with the release of our Q1 '15 results.

"
column207:
"

First
column208:
to better serve our customers and optimize our results around the world we are collaborating like never before across our direct and indirect channels.

"
column209:
"

Accordingly
column210: beginning in Q1 '15
column211:
we'll be including the results of our retail stores in the geographic segments where the stores are located providing a consolidated view of regional performance that is consistent with the way our executive team measures the business.

"
column212:
"

This means that going forward our reportable segment will be Americas
column213: Europe
column214: Greater China
column215:
Japan and the rest of Asia-Pacific with the retail no longer classified as a segment.

"
column216:
"

Second
column217: to better reflect our evolving products and services
column218: we'll be making some changes to our product summary reporting. We will continue to report iPhone
column219: iPad and Macs as separate line items and we'll also have a category that we refer to as services and this will encompass everything we report under the heading of iTunes software and services today including content
column220: apps
column221:
licensing and other services and beginning this month it will also include Apple Pay.

"
column222:
"

We'll be creating a new reporting category called other products. This will encompass everything we report in the accessories category today including Beats headphones and speakers
column223: Apple TV and peripherals and accessories for iPhone
column224: iPad
column225:
Mac and iPod.

"
column226:
"

In addition
column227:
we will begin to include iPod sales in the other products category and we will also reflect sales of Apple Watch in this line item once it begins shipping in early calendar 2015.

"
column228:
"

So to recap
column229: beginning in Q1 '15. our products reporting categories will be iPhone
column230: iPad
column231: Mac
column232:
services and other products. We wanted to give analysts and investors a heads up on these plans so you can reflect them in your models accordingly.

"
column233:
"

We'll also reclassify historical results to be consistent with these newer groupings and we'll provide that information on our Investor Relations website when we release Q1 results.

"
column234:
"

And finally
column235: our distribution channels have evolved and expanded significantly in the last couple of years including traditional resellers
column236: consumer electronic stores
column237: mass retailers
column239: and each of these channels have the different distribution model. Today
column240: iPhone is sold in over 200
column241: 000 locations around the world and iPad is sold in more than 100
column243:
"

In addition
column244:
revenue from emerging markets has increased considerably over the last few years and now accounts for over quarter of our sales. And channel inventory requirements in those markets tend to be much longer.

"
column245:
"

So
column246: due to the size
column247: complexity and different needs of our channels around the world we've determined that a five to seven week average range for both iPhone and iPad channel inventory is more appropriate and that will be our target range going forward. However
column248: given the backlog for our new products
column249:
we expect to exit the December quarter within our old four to six weeks target range.

"
column250:
"

So with that let's open the call to questions and we ask that you please limit yourself to one one-part question and one follow-up.

"
column252:
"

Operator

"
column253:
"

(Operator Instructions) Your first question will come from Shannon Cross with Cross Research.

"
column254:
"

Shannon Cross - Cross Research

"
column255:
"

Thank you very much. Good afternoon. My first question is with regard to Apple Pay
column256: which we actually used this afternoon and where it was rolled out it actually worked pretty well which was nice
column257: but could you provide some more color
column258: Tim and Luca
column259:
on how you see the business model for Apple?

"
column260:
"

And maybe from a high level perspective
column261: if you see there's more over time becoming a standalone business like you look at iTunes
column262:
or is this more just a way to sell incremental product?

"
column263:
"

Tim Cook

"
column264:
"

Shannon
column265: hi
column266:
it's Tim. The -- what we wanted to achieve with Apple Pay was first and foremost to have an incredible consumer experience. And so we focused very much on making it elegant and simple and hopefully your trails have proven them. I know I used it over the weekend and it worked fantastically.

"
column267:
"

We also wanted to focus on security and privacy
column268: and so we see huge issues with the security of the traditional credit card system. And many people that have entered mobile payments are doing still in a way that they want to monetize the data that they collect from the customers and we think customers in general do not want this that they'd like to keep their data private. And so
column269: we wanted to have ease of use
column270:
security and privacy and maximize all three.

"
column271:
"

By doing so
column272:
we think we will sell more devices because we think it's a killer feature. It's far better than reaching in your pocket book and trying to find the card that you're looking for and half the time it's not working.

"
column273:
"

There -- we do not charge the customer for the benefit. We do not charge the merchant for the benefit. However
column274: there are commercial terms between Apple and the issuing banks
column275: but we're not disclosing what they are
column276:
like any other contractual arrangement those are private things.

"
column277:
"

And so as Nancy was saying in her closing comments
column278: we'll be reporting Apple Pay in the services line item on the data sheet. And so
column279:
we see it as an incredible service that is the most customer-centric mobile payment system that there is. And we are very proud of it and can't wait to sign up more retailers and also extend it around the world.

column293:

column296: these hedges roll off and get replaced by new hedges at new spot levels
column297: and so the protection that you get from hedging program is temporary. But again

column584: Tim

I was wondering if you could characterize China a little bit. The numbers I understand weren't as good as the rest of the company this quarter but presumably that was all the delay of the iPhone.

"
column586:
"

So I'm really asking if you talk about the last few weeks and more importantly as you look at December quarter in particular related to some of the political backdrop including the carriers have been mandated not to spend the same level of subsidies.

"
column587:
"

Do you see any of that impacting your opportunities for Apple broadly speaking but more specifically for iPhones as it relates to subsidy levels?

"
column588:
"

Tim Cook

"
column589:
"

That's a good question. If you -- if you just -- if you look at Greater China Q4 of '14 compared to Q4 of '13
column590: the obvious difference is that we launched the 5s in Q4 of '13 and in this year
column591:
we didn't have a new product launch. We were launching in this quarter in Q1 of '15.

"
column592:
"

The second thing that's not as apparent probably
column593: but is more related to that is that last year we increased our channel inventory by $1.3 million. This year
column594:
we actually decreased it slightly. And so you have a compounded effect of their launch and a huge change in channel inventory on a year-over-year basis.

"
column595:
"

So the way that I assess the strength of the market is I look at unit sell-through and to share with you what it was in Greater China
column596:
iPhone unit sell through despite no launch in Q4 was up 32% year-over-year.

"
column597:
"

The market was projected by IDC to only grow 13%. So we feel incredibly great about that. Macs were up 54% year-over-year and that's against the IDC's estimate of the market contraction in China of 7% and so those are two stalwarts that were really driving results and so the underlying results look totally different than the reported results because of the channel inventory kind of differences.

"
column598:
"

The App Store in China is also doing great. The growth there is phenomenal. iPad concreted some during the quarter
column599:
but for the full year we did grow -- we were up 9% year-over-year for the full year and so I see lots of positives.

"
column600:
"

As you know China is on the early stages of their huge 4G rollout.

"
column602:
"

Yes.

"
column603:
"

Tim Cook

"
column604:
"

And this weekend -- this past weekend we launched it with China Mobile
column605:
China Unicom and China Telecom. This was the first time we've launched a new iPhone with all three carriers and we've done it at the early stages of the 4G rollout and so I am incredibly bullish over it.

"
column606:
"

In terms of subsidies there are regulatory pressures on subsidies. We have -- we've seen that. However
column607:
only 20% of the iPhones that we've been selling in China have had a traditional subsidy applied to it and so the vast majority don't.

"
column608:
"

And so will it make a difference with that 20%
column609: I don't know yet. Intuitively you were thinking
column610: it would
column611:
but it's at least a percentage of a 20% instead of a percentage of 100%.

"
column612:
"

And so when I look at China
column613:
I see an enormous market where there are more people graduating into the middle class than any nation on earth in history and just an incredible market where people brought the latest technology and products that we were providing.

"
column614:
"

And so we're investing like crazy in the market. We're more than doubling our stores. We've got 15 in Greater China today. We're going to be close to 40 in the next couple of years. We've expanded our online store to cover now 315 cities in China. The revenue results for Q4 were up more than double the previous year.

"
column615:
"

The App Store is growing. Chinese developers have now created a 150
column616: 000 apps -- of the apps on the App Store and so I see lots of very
column617:
very positive factors there and I couldn\u2019t be more excited.

"
column619:
"

Okay. And then as my follow-up if I could
column621: you mentioned before on a previous comment on iPad where you saw I think 50% to 70% in the top six countries were new buyers and related to a previous question
column622:
wondered if you could give that same range. I understand it's probably a pretty wide range for iPhones and that was to the June quarter I think.

"
column624:
how does that number change at least your guess as you look out over the next couple quarters given the launch of the 6 and the 6 Plus.

"
column626:
"

For iPhone I really have it by model from the June quarter and as I had mentioned before
column627:
the highest percentage is the 4s buyer in China over 80% of the people were buying their first iPhone.

"
column628:
"

And for a 5s in China
column629: 50% were and so I think what that says. Those numbers are so high
column630: the 80 that I think are great -- my gut tells me
column631:
a great percentage of 6 and 6 Plus buyers will eventually -- a great percentage of those will be new to iPhone. That's what I would predict.

"
column633:
"

Okay. That's it for me guys. Thank you.

"
column638:
"

Thank Keith. A replay of today's call will be available for two weeks as a podcast on the iTunes Store
column639:
as a webcast on apple.com/investor and via telephone and the numbers for the telephone replay are 888-203-1112 or 719-457-0820 and please enter a confirmation code 1997837.

"
column640:
"

And these replays will be available by approximately 5.00 PM Pacific Time today. Members of the press can contact Kristin Fugate and financial analysts can contact Joan Hoover or me with additional questions. Thanks again for joining us.

"
column643:
that does conclude today\u2019s presentation. We do thank everyone for your participation.

"
