column1:
{"Apple's (AAPL) CEO Tim Cook on Q1 2015 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Apple Inc. (NASDAQ:AAPL)

"
column9:
"

Luca Maestri - SVP and CFO

"
column10:
"

Analysts

"
column18:
"

Amit Daryanani - RBC Capital Markets

"
column22:
"

Good day ladies and gentlemen and welcome to this Apple Incorporated First Quarter Fiscal Year 2015 Earnings Release Conference Call. Today\u2019s call is being recorded. At this time for opening remarks and introductions
column23: I would like to turn the call over to Nancy Paxton
column24:
Senior Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead ma\u2019am.

"
column27: and thanks to everyone for joining us. Speaking first today is Apple's CEO
column28: Tim Cook; and he will be followed by CFO
column30: and after that we\u2019ll open the call to questions from analysts. Please note that some of the information you\u2019ll hear during our discussion today will consist of forward-looking statements
column31: including without limitation
column33: gross margins
column37:
"

Actual results or trends could differ materially from our forecast. For more information
column38: please refer to the risk factors discussed in Apple\u2019s Form 10-K for 2014 and the Form 8-K filed with the SEC today
column39: along with the associated press release. Apple assumes no obligation to update any forward-looking statements or information
column40: which speak as of their respective dates. And I\u2019d also just like to remind you that as we indicated in our last quarterly call
column41:
we\u2019re now including the results of our retail stores in the geographic segments where the stores are located and retail is no longer classified as an operating segment.

"
column42:
"

We\u2019ve also updated our product summary reporting and we\u2019re now reflecting five categories of results; iPhone
column45:
Services and Other Products. We\u2019ve prepared schedules showing reclassifications of historical operating segment and product results for each of the last 12 quarters to conform to these new groupings and they are available now on our Web site at apple.com/investor.

"
column46:
"

So I\u2019d now like to turn the call over to Tim for introductory remarks.

"
column47:
"

Tim Cook

"
column48:
"

Thanks
column49: Nancy. Good afternoon
column50: everyone and thank you for joining us. Today we\u2019re reporting on a historic quarter and I'm incredibly proud of everyone who contributed to the amazing results you\u2019re about to hear. Interest in Apple products is at an all time high
column51: with over 0.5 billion customer visits to our physical and online stores during the quarter. Demand for iPhone has been staggering
column52: shattering our high expectations with sales of over 74 million units
column53: driven by the unprecedented popularity of iPhone 6 and iPhone 6 Plus. This volume is hard to comprehend. On average we sold over 34
column54: 000 iPhones every hour
column55: 24 hours a day
column56:
everyday of the quarter.

"
column57:
"

The execution by all of our teams to achieve these results was spectacular. By the end of the quarter
column58: our new iPhones were available in 130 countries around the world
column59: making this our fastest and most successful roll out ever. Additionally
column60: the App Store and the Mac each set new records for quarterly revenues. Mac units were up 14% to 5.5 million
column61:
while the rest of the PC market continued to decline. App Store revenues was up a remarkable 41%. Demand was strong around the world. Flurry estimated that Apple products accounted for over half of all mobile device activations globally from December 19th to December 25th.

"
column62:
"

It was truly a momentous quarter for iOS. On November 22nd we shipped our 1 billionth iOS device. It was a Space Gray 64 gigabyte iPhone 6 Plus
column63: which we\u2019ve saved here at Apple. 1 billion devices is an almost unfathomable milestone
column64: and we are all incredibly proud to be a part of it. Apple\u2019s mission is to make the greatest products on earth and enrich the lives of others. Through the success of iOS we have provided hundreds and millions of people with powerful personal technology that is simple and fun to use. Our customers are using Apple products to transform education
column65:
discover new ideas for business and express their creativity in ways that no one could have imagined when we sold the first iPhone less than eight years ago. It\u2019s amazing to watch and it reminds that people and great ideas are the reasons we make the things we make.

"
column66:
"

Our strong overall performance in the December quarter resulted in total company revenue of $74.6 billion
column67: and earnings of $18 billion. Both of these numbers are all-time records for us
column68: with revenues up 30% and earnings up 38% over last year. And due to our very large capital return activities
column69: earnings per share were up even more at 48% to $3.06
column70: also an all-time quarterly record. Our results would have been even stronger
column71:
absent fierce foreign exchange volatility.

"
column72:
"

We\u2019ve also made great progress on a number of very exciting new initiatives to further strengthen our ecosystem. We\u2019ve been blown away by the reaction to Swift
column73: our new programing language. Inventing a new programing language is something very few companies can do
column74:
and we believe it will have a profound effect on our ecosystem. Swift became available in September as part of the Xcode tools and in the first month those tools were downloaded over 11 million times. A recent report from Redmonk showed that Swift has had unprecedented growth and is quickly climbing the list of the most popular programing languages.

"
column75:
"

We\u2019ve seen many of our developers choosing Swift as they build significant new projects
column76: and we are seeing fantastic work with Swift going on in education. Very recently
column77: Stanford University released their Developing iOS 8 Apps with Swift course
column78:
which was posted to iTunes University making this amazing resource available to everyone in the world.

"
column79:
"

There has also been incredible interest in HealthKit with over 600 developers now integrating it into their apps. Consumers can now choose to securely share their health and wellness metrics with these apps and this has led to some great
column80: new and innovative experiences in fitness and wellness
column81:
food and nutrition and healthcare.

"
column82:
"

For example
column83: with apps such as an American Well
column84: users can securely share data such as blood pressure
column85: weight or activity directly with physicians
column86: and leading hospitals such as Duke Medicine
column87:
Stanford Children and Penn Medicine are integrating data from HealthKit into their electronic medical record so that physicians can reach out to patients proactively when they see a problem that needs attention.

"
column88:
"

With HealthKit and the iOS health app
column89: we believe we\u2019re just at the beginning of amazing new health and wellness solutions for our customers. Our extensions of iOS in the home with HomeKit and in the car with CarPlay also continue to progress and this year we are looking forward to amazing HomeKit enabled products from several companies
column90:
and CarPlay enabled vehicles from over 30 automotive brands.

"
column91:
"

Also as you know
column92: we introduced two new categories in the fall and we\u2019re making great progress on both of them. Apple Pay is off to a very strong start and the feedback that we are getting from both individuals and institutions is extremely positive. Today about 750 banks and credit unions have signed on to bring Apple Pay to their customers
column93: and in just three months after launch
column94:
Apple Pay makes up more than $2 out of $3 spent on purchases using contactless payment across the three major U.S. card networks.

"
column95:
"

In merchants who already accept Apple Pay
column96: the rates are even higher. Panera Bread tells us Apple Pay represents nearly 80% of their mobile payment transactions
column97: and since the launch of Apple Pay
column98: Whole Foods Market had seen mobile payments increased by more than 400%. You can use Apple Pay up and down Mainstreet
column99: to pick up a prescription at Walgreens at Duane Reade
column100: get office or school supplies at Office Depot and Staples and shop for groceries at national and regional stores from coast-to-coast
column101: including BI-LO
column102: Harvey\u2019s
column103: Save Mart
column104: Wegmans Food Markets
column105:
Whole Foods and Winn-Dixie among others.

"
column106:
"

More merchants are excited to bring Apple Pay to their customers and adoption is strong. Just today USA Technologies announced they made Apple Pay available at about 200
column107: 000 places where everyday payments happen
column108: including vending machines and businesses
column109: airports and schools
column110: commercial laundry machines and colleges
column111: universities and laundromats and parking meters and payment kiosks in lots across the country. Point-of-sale suppliers tell us they are seeing unprecedented demand from merchants
column112: and all of our partners and customers simply love this new service. With all of this momentum in the early days
column113:
we are more convinced than ever that 2015 will be the year of Apple Pay.

"
column114:
"

Development for Apple Watch is right on schedule and we expect to begin shipping in April. Developers are hard at work on apps
column115: notifications and information summaries that we call Glances
column116:
all designed specifically for the Watch's user interface. The creativity and software innovation going on around Apple Watch is incredibly exciting and we can\u2019t wait for our customers to experience them when Apple Watch becomes available.

"
column117:
"

We\u2019re also making great progress in our partnership with IBM and our collaboration is winning over new customers. In December
column118: we delivered the first 10 MobileFirst for iOS apps for banking
column119: retail
column120: insurance
column121: financial services
column122: telecommunications
column123: governments and airlines
column124: making iPhone and iPad even more productive for enterprises by providing [Apple] [ph] Cloud services with IBM's Big Data and analytics capabilities. Another 12 apps will be released this quarter
column125: including three new industries
column126: healthcare
column127: energy and utilities
column128:
and industrial products. This will bring us to a total of 22 apps and we\u2019re on track to have over 100 by the end of 2015.

"
column129:
"

In just over a month
column130: more than a dozen enterprise customers have signed on as foundation clients to transform their companies with iPhone
column131: iPad and IBM MobileFirst solutions including Miami Dade County
column132: the seventh largest county in the United States by population
column133: and American Eagle Outfitters
column134: which operates more than 1
column135:
000 retail stores and ships to over 80 countries worldwide. And the list of new customers is expanding rapidly. IBM is engaged with more than 130 additional companies looking to empower their employees with MobileFirst for iOS solutions and the list keeps growing. We couldn\u2019t be more pleased with this partnership.

"
column136:
"

In addition to all these initiatives
column137: we have a robust product and services pipeline that we are very excited about
column138: and we look forward to sharing more about them with you throughout the year. In addition to the contributions we make to humanity through our products
column139: we made great progress on imported projects during the quarter including ConnectED and (PRODUCT)RED. With ConnectED we\u2019re focused on making a difference for students in communities who need it the most. We recently chose 114 schools across 29 states to receive an Apple ConnectED grant. Despite their economic challenges
column140:
all of these schools share a vision of what their students' lives would be like with Apple technology and we\u2019re proud to help them bring that to life.

"
column141:
"

And in December
column142: we undertook our largest ever initiative to help (PRODUCT)RED achieve the goal of an AIDS free generation. To commemorate World AIDS Day
column143: we worked with some of our developer partners to create and donate the proceeds from 25 special apps and we also contributed a portion of sales at our retail and online stores on two of the year\u2019s busiest shopping days. As a result
column144:
Apple\u2019s donation set a new record.

"
column145:
"

Delivering the results we\u2019re reporting today reflects months and years of focus and determination from teams across Apple as well as our amazing developers and business partners. I\u2019d like to thank all of them for their commitment and performance and I\u2019d also like to thank our incredible customers for their ongoing loyalty and enthusiasm.

"
column146:
"

With that
column147:
I\u2019d like to turn the call over to Luca to discuss our December quarter results in more detail.

"
column148:
"

Luca Maestri

"
column149:
"

Thank you
column150: Tim and good afternoon everyone. In the December quarter we generated all time record revenue of $74.6 billion
column151: an increase of $17 billion
column152:
or 30% year-over-year. We achieved this exceptional performance despite significant foreign exchange headwinds from many currencies.

"
column153:
"

Our growth was broad based across the world
column154: with revenue from developed countries up 20% and revenue from emerging countries up 58%. The performance of our Greater China segment was particularly impressive
column155:
with revenue up 70%. Sales were well ahead of our expectations in a number of areas. The unprecedented demand for iPhone 6 and 6 Plus combined with our tremendously successful production ramp allowed us to build and ship several million more iPhones than we had expected when we provided guidance back in October. And also Mac revenue and services revenue reached all-time highs.

"
column156:
"

Gross margin was 39.9% above our guidance range and operating margin was $24.2 billion
column157: representing 32.5% of revenue
column158: and our highest operating margin percentage in 10 quarters. Net income was $18 billion
column159: surpassing our previous all-time record by almost $5 billion. This translated to diluted earnings per share of $3.06
column160: a 48% year-over-year increase. Cash flow from operations was exceptional at $33.7 billion
column161:
also a new all-time record.

"
column162:
"

For details by product I will start with iPhone. We sold 74.5 million iPhones
column163: an increase of 23.4 million over last year
column164: representing 46% growth. iPhone sales grew strongly in both developed and emerging markets. Among many great results around the world
column165:
unit sales were up 44% in the U.S. and up 97% in the BRIC countries.

"
column166:
"

Sales doubled year-over-year in China
column167: our second largest iPhone market
column168: as well as in Brazil and in Singapore. Thanks to the popularity of iPhone 6 Plus
column169: and the increased value customers saw in our higher storage capacity offerings
column170: iPhone ASPs were $687
column171: an increase of $50 over the year ago quarter. This led to iPhone revenue growth of 57% year-over-year
column172:
with quarterly sales exceeding $50 billion for the first time ever.

"
column173:
"

We had a 200
column174: 000 unit decline in iPhone channel inventory during December quarter this year
column175: compared to an increase of about 1 million iPhones during the year ago period
column176: and we were not able to reach supply demand balance until this month. This left us below our target range of five to seven weeks of channel inventory on a look forward basis. We\u2019re now working with about 375 carriers
column177: representing 72% of the world\u2019s mobile phone subscriber base
column178: and we have over 210
column179:
000 points of sale for iPhone across the globe.

"
column180:
"

Our customers love their iPhones. A December ChangeWave survey measured a 97% customer satisfaction rating for iPhone. A study published by Chitika Insights last month indicated that iPhone accounts for 53% of North America smartphone web traffic
column181: almost twice the level of the next closest brand. And in the corporate market ChangeWave found that among IT buyers planning to purchase smartphones in the March quarter this year
column182:
77% intend to purchase iPhones.

"
column183:
"

Next I\u2019d like to talk about the Mac. We sold 5.5 million Macs
column184: an increase of almost 700
column185: 000 units over last year
column186: a 14% growth rate. Thanks for the popularity of our stunning new iMac with Retina 5K display
column187: Mac ASPs increased by $58 sequentially
column188: driving all time record revenue for Mac of 6.9 billion. We achieved double-digit year-over-year unit growth in both desktops and portables. These results are truly remarkable
column189:
given the contraction in the global PC market which IDC estimates declined by 3% in the quarter. We have now gained market share for 34 of the last 35 quarters. We ended the quarter with Mac channel inventory slightly below our four to five week target range.

"
column190:
"

Turning to iPad
column191: we sold 21.4 million units compared to 26 million in the December quarter last year. Given the introduction of new iPads in October
column192: we increased iPad channel inventory by 1.1 million units during the quarter
column193:
compared to an increase of about 2.1 million in the December quarter last year. This left us within our five to seven week target range of channel inventory on a look forward basis.

"
column194:
"

Customer experience and usage data for iPad continue to be excellent. In our November survey
column195: ChangeWave measured a 98% customer satisfaction rate for iPad Air
column196: and also found that among people to finding a purchase a tabled within 90 days
column197: 60% plan to purchase an iPad. And among businesses planning to purchase tablets
column198:
the intent was even stronger at 78%.

"
column199:
"

Chitika Insights' most recent report indicated that iPad users in North America generate over 70% of tablet based web traffic
column200:
more than six times the web traffic of the next closest competitor and Custora\u2019s latest e-commerce report indicates that iPad accounts for 82% of all U.S. e-commerce transactions from tablets.

"
column201:
"

All these results are consistent with usage data from the holiday shopping season. IBM\u2019s digital analytics benchmark service found that iOS devices accounted for more than twice the online traffic and almost four times the e-commerce sales on Android devices during November and December. The Apple ecosystem continues to thrive. Combining all of our services
column202: revenue grew to 4.8 billion in the December quarter
column203:
a new all-time high and an increase of 9% year-over-year.

"
column204:
"

This record performance was driven primarily by the tremendous momentum of the App Store
column205: with revenue growing 41% in the December quarter. Our iOS developers have earned over $25 billion from the App Store to date
column206: and we\u2019re thrilled with their success. Total sales of media and software from iTunes were $2.6 billion
column207:
compared to $2.4 billion in the year ago quarter.

"
column208:
"

Our direct China performance was also outstanding. We welcomed more visitors than ever before and generated record revenue in both our physical and online stores. We opened 10 new retail stores during the quarter
column209: bringing us to a total of 447
column210:
182 of which are outside the United States. We\u2019ve opened two new stores this month in Greater China and we\u2019re on track towards 40 stores in Greater China by mid-2016.

"
column211:
"

Let me now turn to our cash position. We ended the quarter with $178 billion in cash plus marketable securities
column212: a sequential increase of $22.7 billion. We completed our first international debt offering
column213: issuing 2.8 billion euro denominated notes at very attractive interest rates and greatly diversifying our debt investor base. We spent 5 billion to repurchase 45 million Apple shares through open market transactions
column214: paid 2.8 billion in dividends and equivalents
column215:
and utilized over 500 million to net share settle vesting employee RSUs. We also retired an additional 8 million shares in connection with our accelerated share repurchase programs.

"
column216:
"

We have now taken action on almost $103 billion of our $130 billion capital return program
column217: including $73 billion in share repurchases
column218: with four quarters remaining to its completion. In the last 12 months alone
column219:
we have returned over $57 billion to our investors. We review our capital return program on an ongoing basis. We continue to solicit feedback from a broad base of investors and we're on track to announce an update to the program in April when we report our second quarter results.

"
column220:
"

Now as we move ahead into the March quarter
column221: I\u2019d like to review our outlook
column222: which includes the types of forward looking information that Nancy referred to at the beginning of the call. We expect revenue to be between $52 billion and $55 billion
column223: compared to $45.6 billion in the year ago quarter
column224: and this represents a very significant revenue increase
column225:
despite growing foreign exchange headwinds from the continued strengthening of the U.S. dollar against most currencies.

"
column226:
"

We expect gross margin to be between 38.5% and 39.5%
column227: we expect OpEx to be between $5.4 billion and $5.5 billion and we expect OI&E to be about $350 million and we expect the tax rate to be about 26.3%. Also today our Board has declared dividend of $0.47 per common share payable on February 12
column228: 2015 to shareholders of record as of February 9
column230:
"

With that let's open the call to questions.

"
column231:
"

Nancy Paxton

"
column232:
"

And we ask that you limit yourself to one part question and one follow-up. Operator may we have the first question please.

"
column233:
"

Question-and-Answer Session

"
column234:
"

Operator

"
column235:
"

[Operator Instructions] First we\u2019ll hear from Shannon Cross with Cross Research.

"
column236:
"

Shannon Cross

"
column237:
"

Thank you very much and nice iPhone numbers. Can you talk about Luca about currency? How you are thinking about it? What it did this quarter? What it does to gross margin? And what\u2019s it\u2019s going to do during the year? Because that\u2019s clearly a big topic of conversation?

"
column239:
"

Yes
column240: Shannon I\u2019ll do that now. I\u2019ll talk about Q1. I\u2019ll talk about what we are looking for Q2 and possibly even further. Obviously
column241: what we\u2019ve seen during Q1 has been unprecedented movements in currencies. I would say during the course of the quarter the biggest impact came from the Japanese yen
column242: the Russian rubel
column243: but also from euro
column244: Australian dollar
column245:
Canadian dollar. Our revenue growth during Q1 would have been four percentage points higher on a constant currency basis.

"
column246:
"

On a profitability standpoint
column247: our hedging program partially mitigated the impact from the volatility in currencies. As we look forward
column248: and we look into particularly the March quarter
column249:
the foreign exchange headwinds will be stronger in Q2 than they were in Q1 for two main reasons. The first one is the fact that the U.S. dollar has continued to appreciate against foreign currencies during the last few weeks. And the other one is the fact that our existing hedges expire. They get replace by new contracts at current levels and therefore the protection that is provided to us by our hedging program diminishes over time.

"
column250:
"

What that means to us going forward for the March quarter is that revenue growth on a year-over-year basis in constant currency would be five point higher than what we are guiding to
column251: if it wasn\u2019t for the FX movements. In terms of gross margins
column252: and you know that we look our gross margins on a sequential basis
column253:
the gross margin percentage after the offset that we're getting from the hedging program will be impacted by over 100 basis points.

column254:

Now having said that
column255: we have factored the impact that I just described into the guidance that we provided to you. So that\u2019s where we are right now. Of course
column256: as you look further out
column257: you know we do not provide guidance past the March quarter
column258: but it goes without saying that at current levels
column259: again those headwinds will continue to become stronger for the reason I explained earlier
column260: that our hedges continue to expire
column261:
they get replaced by new hedging contracts at current levels and so -- and there is the impact that we would see during the course of the year.

column262:

It goes without saying strong U.S. dollar has negative impact on our international business. Having said all that
column263: we have provided what we believe is very strong guidance for the March quarter. We remain very
column264: very confident about the portfolio of products and services that we have in the market today and we remain very
column265:
very confident in the pipeline of products and services that we have.

column376:

One of them is the fact that last year in January we launched China Mobile and we had the subsequent channel sale for China Mobile. That of course is not going to repeat this year. And we also had a very

column403: I mean that if you look in some of the developed market like the U.S.
column404: Japan

Yes Rod. Typically
column470: we have clearly active hedging programs of winning the market almost every day
column471: but we tend to hedge three to 12 months out. There are cases where maybe we\u2019ve had to go a bit longer
column472: if we feel that we have a strong conviction about certain currencies. Otherwise again the typical period is three to 12 months. And as hedges roll off
column473: we replace them with new hedges. We take into account the exposures that we have around the world
column474:
taking into account our most recent forecast and we hedge accordingly. We feel very good about our hedging position and the decisions that we\u2019ve made particularly during the summer when we felt that maybe we needed to hedge a bit more than we have done historically.

Tim Cook

"
column538: at this point
column540: we don\u2019t have all of our research in from all of the people that bought last quarter. But in the aggregate
column541: as I've mentioned before
column542: we saw more new customers to iPhone than we had ever seen before. And we had a higher rate of Android switchers than we had in the three previous launches. And it\u2019s not that we had more in the fourth one
column543: and I don\u2019t what those numbers are
column544: and whether it's something we're looking at. And so between the switchers and the people that are just new to smartphones and selected an iPhone
column546: which we\u2019re very happy with
column547: but represent a small fraction of our installed base
column548:
we feel really great about what\u2019s in front of us.

"
column549:
"

Bill Shope

"
column550:
"

Makes sense. And then a follow up on your Apple Pay commentary. When we look at the opportunity outside of the U.S. are there unique hurdles we should consider as we think about the timing of the rollouts in Europe and Asia
column551:
or is it really just about following partnerships together?

"
column552:
"

Tim Cook

"
column553:
"

Each has a different implementation. And so in some ways
column554: like there is a different set of carriers in every country
column555: there is a different set of banks. In a lot of the countries
column556:
some of the processes with the merchants are different. And so it\u2019s an area where there is quite a bit of difference country to country to country and so there's clearly heavy lifting involved to scale. However it\u2019s not something that scares us or that\u2019s preventing us from viewing it as a big opportunity.

"
column558:
"

Thank you
column559: Bill. A replay of today's call will be available for two weeks as a podcast on the iTunes Store
column560:
as a webcast on apple.com/investor and via telephone and the numbers for the telephone replay are 888-203-1112 or 719-457-0820 and please enter a confirmation code 8259681.

"
column561:
"

And these replays will be available by approximately 5.00 PM Pacific Time today. Members of the press with additional questions can contact Kristin Fugate at 408-974-2414 and financial analysts can contact Joan Hoover or me with additional questions. Joan\u2019s at 408-974-4570 and I am at 408-974-5420. Thanks again for joining us.

"

column1:
{"Apple's (AAPL) CEO Tim Cook on Q2 2015 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL)

"
column2:
"

Q1 2015 Results Earnings Conference Call

"
column10:
"

Luca Maestri - SVP and CFO

"
column19:
"

Keith Bachman - BMO Capital Markets

"
column22: and welcome to this Apple Incorporated second quarter fiscal year 2015 earnings release conference call. Today\u2019s call is being recorded. At this time for opening remarks and introductions
column23: I would like to turn the call over to Nancy Paxton
column24: Senior Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead
column28: and thanks to everyone for joining us. Speaking first today is Apple's CEO Tim Cook
column29: and he will be followed by CFO
column30: Luca Maestri. After that
column31:
we\u2019ll open the call to questions from analysts.

"
column32:
"

Please note that some of the information you\u2019ll hear during our discussion today will consist of forward-looking statements including
column33: without limitation
column38: taxes
column40: and plans for dividends
column41: share repurchases
column43:
"

Actual results or trends could differ materially from our forecast. For more information
column44: please refer to the risk factors discussed in Apple\u2019s Form 10-K for 2014
column45: the Form 10-Q for the first quarter of 2015
column46: and the Form 8-K filed with the SEC today
column47:
along with the associated press releases.

"
column48:
"

Apple assumes no obligation to update any forward-looking statements or information
column49:
which speak as of their respective dates. I\u2019d now like to turn the call over to Tim for introductory remarks.

"
column50:
"

Tim Cook

"
column51:
"

Good afternoon everyone
column52: and thanks for joining us. We have a lot of great news to talk about
column53: so I\u2019ll jump right in. Today
column54: we\u2019re reporting our strongest March quarter ever
column55:
with 27% revenue growth and 40% earnings per share growth year over year.

"
column56:
"

We\u2019re seeing fantastic results for iPhone
column57: with revenue growth of 55% year on year
column58: and we\u2019re seeing a higher rate of switchers than we\u2019ve experienced in previous iPhone cycles. The success of iPhone has been extremely strong in emerging markets
column59:
where unit sales were up 63% year on year.

"
column60:
"

The App Store had its best quarter ever
column61: with a record number of customers making purchases
column62:
driving a new record for revenue and 29% year on year growth. We also reached an all-time quarterly record of $5 billion in total services revenue.

"
column63:
"

We also continue to defy the trend of declining global PC sales
column64:
with double digit Mac unit growth in a market that IVC estimates contracted by 7%.

"
column65:
"

We\u2019re now halfway through fiscal 2015 and our year to date results have been simply staggering. We sold over 135 million iPhones
column66: 34 million iPads
column67: and 10 million Macs in the first six months of the year. Our revenue has grown by 28% to over $132 billion
column68: net income has increased 36% to over $31 billion
column69:
and EPS has grown by 44%.

"
column70:
"

We\u2019re making many strategic investments in Apple\u2019s future
column71: in research and development
column72: in our supply chain
column73: and in our infrastructure
column74: and we\u2019ve made 27 acquisitions in the last six quarters. We\u2019re in the very fortunate position of generating more cash than we need to run our business
column75:
and keep making these important investments.

"
column76:
"

So today
column77: we\u2019re announcing another significant update to our capital return program
column78:
expanding its size to $200 billion through March of 2017 to reflect our strong confidence in what lies ahead for Apple. Luca will go into this in more detail in a moment.

"
column79:
"

We\u2019re also making great progress in many other areas. The Apple ecosystem continues to expand in exciting ways. We\u2019re seeing great momentum with Apple Pay. Discover announced today that its cardmembers in the United States will be able to make contactless payments in participating stores through Apple Pay beginning this fall.

"
column80:
"

And last month
column81: we said that the number of locations accepting Apple Pay has tripled
column82: and we continue to see great progress with merchants. Best Buy
column83: which has been a longtime
column84: strong partner of ours
column85:
has just announced that it\u2019s now offering Apple Pay in-app and later this year will offer Apple Pay in all of their U.S. stores.

"
column86:
"

And merchants aren\u2019t the only ones jumping onboard. Earlier this month
column87: a leading healthcare payment network announced acceptance of Apple Pay for its clients
column88: so over 50 major hospitals across the country
column89: including Stanford Healthcare and Aspen Valley
column90:
will accept Apple Pay this year for copays and bill payments at registration and check in.

"
column91:
"

We\u2019re also incredibly inspired by the momentum we\u2019re seeing in health-related solutions. Since we released HealthKit with iOS 8 last September
column92: over 1
column93: 000 apps have been developed to transform how people track
column94: manage
column95:
and interact with their health and they\u2019re now available on the App Store.

"
column96:
"

Just this past weekend
column97: Cedars-Sinai in Los Angeles turned on the largest HealthKit integration to date
column98: giving more than 87
column99: 000 patients the ability to share their health and fitness data seamlessly with their MyCS link app
column100:
which syncs with their electronic medical record.

"
column101:
"

And last month we announced ResearchKit
column102: an open source software framework that helps doctors and scientists gather data from medical research participants more efficiently and accurately using iPhone applications. The response so far has been simply amazing
column103:
far exceeding our expectations.

"
column104:
"

The first research apps developed using ResearchKit study asthma
column105: breast cancer
column106: cardiovascular disease
column107: diabetes
column108: and Parkinson\u2019s disease
column109: and have enrolled over 60
column110:
000 iPhone users in just the first few weeks of being available on the App Store.

"
column111:
"

Over 1
column112: 000 researchers have contacted us expressing interest in performing studies through ResearchKit. We think these types of solutions have the potential to revolutionize medical studies in life-changing ways
column113:
and we\u2019re proud that Apple is helping make this possible.

"
column114:
"

Last quarter
column115: we also announced a major economic investment in Europe
column116:
where we will spend $2 billion to build data centers in Ireland and Denmark. These will be our largest data centers in the world.

"
column117:
"

Apple is now responsible for creating over 670
column118: 000 jobs across the European continent. Most of them have grown out of the success of the App Store
column119:
which has generated more than $7.5 billion for European developers since just 2008. We feel great about the economic contribution we\u2019ve been able to make in Europe.

"
column120:
"

The two data centers we\u2019re building will run on 100% renewable energy from day one. This is just part of the work we\u2019re doing to protect the environment and leave the world better than we found it.

"
column121:
"

Today
column122: 100% of Apple\u2019s U.S. operations and 87% of global operations are powered by renewable energy. Just before Earth Day
column123:
we announced our plan to move to renewables in China. We\u2019re undertaking a groundbreaking partnership with several companies to build a 40 megawatt solar farm in Szechuan Province that will generate far more than the amount of energy used by all of our offices and retail stores in China combined.

"
column124:
"

We also announced an innovative new partnership with the Conservation Fund to permanently protect more than 36
column125:
000 acres of working forest in Maine and North Carolina to help offset the impact our packaging has on the world\u2019s supply of sustainable virgin fiber. Apple is deeply committed to these initiatives and will continue to make them a priority.

"
column126:
"

The June quarter is off to an exciting start with great new products and services. Three of them in particular are giving our customers a glimpse of the future and we are very happy with the reception that each of them is receiving.

"
column127:
"

First
column128: the all-new MacBook began shipping just over two weeks ago
column129: and we are very happy with the response we\u2019re getting from customers. The new MacBook is our lightest
column130: most compact Mac notebook ever
column131:
and you really have to see it to believe it.

"
column132:
"

It features a stunning 12 inch retina display
column133: a new force touch trackpad
column134: all day battery life
column135: and a revolutionary new keyboard. We believe
column136: and I think most everyone agrees
column137:
this is the future of the notebook.

"
column138:
"

Second is the new streaming service from HBO
column139: which is available on Apple TV and iOS. We teamed up with HBO last month to help launch HBO Now
column140: a standalone service that lets customers stream the content they love from HBO on the devices they love from Apple
column141: all without requiring a subscription to cable. HBO now has been incredibly popular with Apple TV users since its debut
column142:
and it has been one of the top downloaded apps on the U.S. App Store as well.

"
column143:
"

And third
column144: of course
column145: is Apple Watch. It\u2019s been really great to see the reaction of customers since their watches began arriving on Friday morning. All around the world
column146:
we\u2019ve seen the excitement on social networks as people start using their Apple Watch. The response has been overwhelmingly positive.

"
column147:
"

Adding to the surprise and delight of Apple Watch are the more than 3
column148:
500 apps that are already available. Our developer community has already seen the potential in this new category and put some of their best thinking into what wearable technology can do. We can\u2019t wait to see more of the inspiring apps developers dream up for Apple Watch as we head into our Worldwide Developer Conference six weeks from now.

"
column149:
"

I\u2019d like to thank all of those developers and our hundreds of millions of customers for their loyalty and support. I\u2019d also like to thank all of the Apple employees around the world for their creativity
column150: tireless effort
column151:
and passion for delivering the very best products in the world.

"
column152:
"

With that
column153:
I\u2019ll turn the call over to Luca.

"
column154:
"

Luca Maestri

"
column155:
"

Thank you
column156: Tim. Good afternoon everyone. As Tim mentioned
column157: we just completed another outstanding quarter. Revenue for the March quarter was $58 billion
column158:
an increase of $12.4 billion or 27% year over year.

"
column159:
"

Growth was driven primarily by the very strong performance of iPhone and the continued strength of the App Store and Mac sales. We achieved these terrific results despite growing foreign exchange headwinds.

"
column160:
"

Our performance was particularly impressive in our Greater China and rest of Asia Pacific segments. In Greater China
column161: we established an all-time quarterly record for revenue
column162: which grew 71% year over year
column163:
to $16.8 billion.

"
column164:
"

Gross margin was 40.8%
column165: ahead of our expectations
column166: mainly due to stronger than expected iPhone results. Operating margin was 31.5% of revenue and net income was $13.6 billion
column167:
a new Q2 record.

"
column168:
"

Diluted earnings per share were $2.33
column169: a 40% year over year increase
column170: and cash flow from operations was $19.1 billion
column171: also a new March quarter record. For details by product
column172:
I will start with iPhone.

"
column173:
"

We sold 61.2 million iPhones in the quarter
column174: representing 40% year over year growth and demand for iPhone 6 and 6 plus has remained incredibly strong. IPhone sales more than doubled in Korea
column175: Singapore
column176: Taiwan
column177: and Vietnam
column178: and they were up 80% or more in several other markets including Canada
column179: Mexico
column180: Germany
column181:
and Turkey.

"
column182:
"

The strong mix of iPhone 6 and 6 plus combined with the popularity of higher capacity offerings led to iPhone ASPs of $659
column183: an increase of $62 year over year
column184:
despite the very significant foreign exchange headwinds I already mentioned.

"
column185:
"

We increased iPhone channel inventory by 1 million units during the quarter
column186:
which allowed us to get into the low end of our target range of 5 to 7 weeks of channel inventory.

"
column187:
"

Next
column188: I\u2019d like to talk about the Mac. We sold 4.6 million Macs
column189: representing 10% year over year growth
column190:
which is particularly impressive in the context of IDC\u2019s latest estimate of a 7% global PC market contraction. The growth was led by portables and spurred by the updates to MacBook Air and MacBook Pro in March. We ended the quarter within our 4 to 5 week target range for Mac channel inventory.

"
column192: we sold 12.6 million
column193: compared to 16.4 million in the year ago quarter. iPad sellthrough was 13.7 million
column194: as we reduced channel inventory by about 1.1 million units
column195:
coming off the holiday quarter. This left us within our 5 to 7 week target range of iPad channel inventory.

"
column196:
"

We set a new March quarter record for iPad sales in Japan
column197: and an all-time record for iPad sales in China
column198: but performance in other markets was more muted during the quarter. iPad turns five years old this month
column199: and in every year since its introduction
column200: it has been the number one tablet in sales
column201: in quantity and quality of tablet apps
column202: in usage
column203: and most importantly
column204: in customer satisfaction. And based on the latest data from NPD
column205:
iPad maintains a very strong leadership share in all the price bands where we compete.

"
column206:
"

iPad has also consistently been the number one tablet in enterprise. A recent Changewave survey found that among corporate buyers planning to buy tablets in the next six months
column207: 77% plan to purchase iPads. In fact
column208:
we are seeing very high interest from companies who want to use iPads to transform how work gets done.

"
column209:
"

The vast majority of the app opportunities that have been identified as part of the Apple and IBM partnership are specifically for iPad. In addition to IBM
column210: we working closely with more than two dozen other leading business software and solution providers including Box
column211: Docusign
column212: Microstrategy
column213: Revel
column214:
and ServiceMax to bring a broad range of innovative mobile solutions to more customers on iPad.

"
column215:
"

Turning to services
column216: revenue grew to a new all-time record of $5 billion
column217: an increase of 9% year over year. The growth was led by the App Store
column218: which remains incredibly popular with our customers around the world
column219: with revenue up 29% in the March quarter. According to App Annie
column220: the App Store generated 70% more global revenue in the March quarter than Google Play
column221:
up from a 60% lead in the September quarter.

"
column222:
"

Traffic to our retail and online stores was excellent
column223: with a 22% year over year increase in customer visits. We\u2019re progressing well with our plans for retail store expansion in Greater China
column224: where we added six new stores in the past quarter alone
column225:
bringing us to 21 stores in 11 cities. We\u2019re on track to have 40 stores open in Greater China by the middle of next year.

"
column226:
"

Let me now turn to our cash position. We ended the quarter with $193.5 billion in cash
column227: plus marketable securities
column228: a sequential increase of $15.6 billion. Over $171 billion of this cash was offshore. In the March quarter
column229:
we issued 6.5 billion U.S. dollar denominated notes and 1.3 billion Swiss franc denominated notes as we continue to diversify our global debt investor base.

"
column230:
"

We\u2019ve now raised a total of $40 billion of term debt at very attractive rates. We spent $7 billion to repurchase 56.4 million Apple shares through open market transactions
column231: paid $2.7 billion in dividends and equivalents
column232: and utilized about $100 million to [net share] settle vesting employee RSUs. We also retired an additional 13.3 million shares during the quarter
column233:
with the conclusion of the accelerated share repurchase program we launched last August.

"
column234:
"

We have executed our capital return program aggressively
column235: and we\u2019ve now taken action on over $112 billion of our $130 billion program
column236:
including $80 billion in share repurchases at an average price of $85.

"
column237:
"

As we\u2019ve said consistently
column238:
creating value for shareholders by developing great products that enrich people\u2019s lives will always be our top priority and the key factor driving our investments and our capital allocation decisions.

"
column239:
"

With this framework in mind
column240: Apple\u2019s board and management team continue to review capital allocation regularly
column241: and we solicit input on our program from a broad base of shareholders. This process allows us to be thoughtful about the size
column242: the mix
column243:
and the pace of the program. We very much appreciate all the input that many shareholders have provided us.

"
column244:
"

We continue to be in the fortunate position of being able to return significant capital to shareholders. We first announced our capital return program three years ago with an initial size of $45 billion
column245: and we\u2019ve increased it annually since then. Today
column246: we\u2019re announcing the third update to our program
column247:
expanding its size by the largest amount yet and extending its duration.

"
column248:
"

The existing program was set to conclude at the end of this calendar year
column249: and we\u2019re now extending the program by five quarters to the end of March 2017. Once again
column250: with this update we\u2019re allocating the majority of the expansion of the program to share repurchases
column251:
given our strong confidence in the future of Apple and the value we see in our stock.

"
column252:
"

The board has increased the share repurchase authorization by $50 billion
column253:
raising it from the current $90 billion to $140 billion. We will also continue to net share settle vesting employee restricted stock units.

"
column254:
"

We also understand that the dividend is very important to many of our investors and we\u2019re raising it for the third time in less than three years. The quarterly dividend will grow from $0.47 per share to $0.52 per share
column255: an increase of 11%. This effective with our next dividend
column256: which the board has declared today and is payable on May 14
column257: 2015 to shareholders of record as of May 11
column259:
"

We believe this is a meaningful increase for those shareholders who value income
column260: and we continue to plan for annual dividend increases going forward. With over $11 billion in annual dividend payments
column261: we\u2019re proud to be one of the largest dividend payers in the world. In total
column262: the size of our revised capital return program will increase by over 50%
column263:
from approximately $130 billion to $200 billion.

"
column264:
"

As we\u2019ve done in the past
column265: we expect to fund our capital return program with U.S. cash
column266: future U.S. cash flow generation
column267:
and borrowing from both domestic and international debt markets. And we plan to provide the next update on our program at about this time next year.

"
column268:
"

Now
column269: as we move ahead into the June quarter
column270: I\u2019d like to review our outlook
column271: which includes the types of forward-looking information that Nancy referred to at the beginning of the call. We expect revenue to be between $46 billion and $48 billion
column272:
compared to $37.4 billion in the year ago quarter. We expect gross margin to be between 38.5% and 39.5%. We expect opex to be between $5.65 billion and $5.75 billion. We expect YNE to be about $350 million and we expect the tax rate to be about 26.3%.

"
column273:
"

With that
column274:
let\u2019s open the call to questions.

"
column275:
"

Nancy Paxton

"
column276:
"

Thank you
column277: and we ask that you limit yourself to one one-part question and one follow up. Operator
column278: may we have the first question
column279:
please?

"
column280:
"

Question-and-Answer Session

"
column281:
"

Operator

"
column282:
"

[Operator instructions.] Your first question will come from Bill Schultz
column284:
"

Q \u2013 Bill Schultz

"
column285:
"

When we look at the effect of currency on your gross profit
column286: which I think was far less than anyone anticipated
column287:
have you be able to reduce some of the pressure by adjusting the terms of your suppliers? Or is that something we should expect to see more of as you progress through the year?

"
column288:
"

A \u2013 Luca Maestri

"
column289:
"

I\u2019m gonna give you some numbers on the currency
column290: because I know it\u2019s a topic that is top of mind. You\u2019re asking about gross margin
column291: and you know
column292:
we look at this on a sequential basis. And I mentioned during the call in January that we were expecting FX to have a negative impact on a sequential basis of about 100 basis points after the effect of the hedges.

"
column293:
"

And that is exactly what happened in our actual results. So that was pretty much in line with what we were anticipating. Of course
column294: we expect this headwind to continue. And on a sequential basis
column295: when we look into the June quarter
column296:
we expect to see another 40 basis points of negative impact from currency.

"
column297:
"

We\u2019re dealing with these headwinds. They\u2019re part of business
column298: and so we\u2019re dealing with them in many ways. We are looking at
column299: in some cases
column300: at the potential to increase prices in certain markets. We\u2019re looking of course at our cost structure
column301:
and we try to remain as competitive as possible.

"
column302:
"

So we feel very good about the gross margins that we\u2019ve generated in the March quarter
column303: and we feel very good about the guidance that we provided
column304:
given the severity of the impact.

"
column305:
"

Q \u2013 Bill Schultz

"
column306:
"

And then as a follow up
column307: obviously
column308: I guess one of the incremental tailwinds to gross margin continues to be the iPhone upside relative to expectations. Can you give us a bit more color on the dynamics of the customer mix for the iPhone? You had mentioned you\u2019re very excited about the new iPhone rate so far
column309: but if you could just give us a bit more color
column310: as we had last quarter
column311: on folks that are new to iPhone
column312: Android switchers
column313:
versus replacements?

"
column315:
"

Bill
column316: we continue to see a higher rate of switchers than we have seen in previous cycles
column317: and so we\u2019re extremely excited about that. We also continue to see a reasonable percentage of first time buyers
column318: particularly in some of the emerging markets. And if you look at emerging markets in general
column319: I think Luca covered some of this
column320: the revenue from emerging markets
column321: just for the March quarter
column322: was up 58% year on year. And a big piece of what is driving that is iPhone. Obviously
column323:
those results would have been higher without some of the FX headwinds that Luca mentioned earlier.

"
column324:
"

Operator

"
column325:
"

We\u2019ll hear from Katie Huberty with Morgan Stanley.

"
column327:
"

You\u2019ve said in the past that the watch may take longer to ramp given the new category and new interface to customers. Is that in fact playing out? Is the watch ramping slower than past product categories?

"
column328:
"

A \u2013 Tim Cook

"
column329:
"

Katie
column330: when you use the word \u201cramp
column331:
\u201d I assume you\u2019re talking about supply?

"
column332:
"

Q \u2013 Katie Huberty

"
column333:
"

Yeah
column334: preorders and first week in sales
column335: and any other data points that you track in terms of interest versus
column336: say
column337:
when the iPad launched in 2010.

"
column338:
"

A \u2013 Tim Cook

"
column339:
"

Let me talk about supply and demand and sort of separate those two. Right now
column340: demand is greater than supply. And so we\u2019re working hard to remedy that. We\u2019ve made progress over the last week or so
column341:
and we were able to deliver more customers an Apple Watch over the weekend than we had initially anticipated.

"
column342:
"

We\u2019re going to keep doing that
column343: and so we\u2019ve already sent some notes out today
column344: moving the customers and versus what we had communicated to them previously. So I\u2019m generally happy that we\u2019re moving on with the ramp. It is a new product for us
column345: and with any kind of new product
column346:
you wind up taking some time to fully ramp.

"
column347:
"

Having said that
column348: I think we\u2019re in a good position and by sometime in late June
column349:
we currently anticipate being in a position that we could begin to sell the Apple Watch in additional countries. And so that\u2019s our current plan.

"
column350:
"

From a demand point of view
column351: it\u2019s hard to gauge when you don\u2019t have product in stores and so forth. So we\u2019re filling orders completely online at the moment. The customer response from people that have gotten theirs over the weekend have been overwhelmingly positive
column352:
and we\u2019re far ahead of where we expected to be from an application point of view.

"
column353:
"

To give you a comparison
column354: when we launched the iPhone
column355: we had about 500 apps that were ready. When we launched iPad
column356: we had about a thousand. And so our internal goal was to be able to beat the thousand level
column357: and we thought it would be great if we were able to do that by a little bit. And as I mentioned before
column358: we now have over 3
column359:
500 apps in the App Store for the watch.

"
column360:
"

And so we couldn\u2019t be happier about how things are going from that point of view. We are learning quickly about customer preferences between the different configurations. There\u2019s a much larger breadth of possibilities here for customers than in our other products. And in some cases
column361: we called that well. In some cases
column362:
we\u2019re making adjustments to get in line with demand. But I\u2019m really confident that this is something we really understand how to do and will do.

"
column363:
"

And so I\u2019m really happy where we are currently
column364:
and happy enough that we\u2019re looking forward to expanding into more countries in late June.

"

Q \u2013 Katie Huberty

"
column366:
"

And then as a follow up
column367: research and development spend continues to track well ahead of revenue growth. And that has happened for many quarters now. Can you talk about what\u2019s driving that? Is there a broader set of projects that you\u2019re working on? Are you making bigger bets
column368:
entering bigger markets? What\u2019s driving such a long period of elevated R&D spend?

"
column369:
"

A \u2013 Luca Maestri

"
column370:
"

Of course
column371: we\u2019ve said this several times now. When you look at our current product portfolio
column372:
it is much broader than it used to be. We\u2019ve now developed two new iPhones over the year. We were not doing that a few years ago. Developed two iPads. And of course now we have the Apple Watch.

"
column373:
"

We\u2019re also developing some core foundational technologies more in house now than we were in the past. And of course we\u2019re also spending ahead of some of the products that will generate revenues in the future. So when you combined all these factors
column374:
that is the reason why you see these research and development increases year over year. Research and development is the core of the company. Innovation is the core of the company.

"
column375:
"

And we\u2019re very proud of the fact
column376: when you look
column377: for example
column378: at the last two quarters
column379: the first half of 2015
column380: our revenue growth has been higher than our opex growth. And when you look at our expense to revenue ratio
column381: which
column382: for the first half of the year
column383: has been 8.2%
column384: it\u2019s lower than it was a year ago
column385: and it\u2019s definitely something that we consider extremely competitive
column386:
and we\u2019re very proud of.

Tony Sacconaghi

the power of it.

And I haven\u2019t even seen this

Shannon Cross

Tim

Tim Cook

Yeah

column519: and so we have the help of a strong holiday season
column520:
much like the U.S. has a strong season in December. China\u2019s is obviously in the March quarter.

column521:
"

iPhone led the way. It was up over 70% year on year. And the current estimates from Kantar are that that would mean that we would gain more than 9 points of share on a year over year basis. And so by everything I can see
column523:
"

The Mac also had an unbelievable quarter in China

column525: that Mac unit sales were up 31%. And like the rest of the world
column526: or most of the rest of the world
column527:
IDC is projecting that PC sales in China contracted by 5% last quarter. And so once again bucking the tide.

column528:
"

Also

column532: the Mac

column535: not in Greater China

column538: higher than all the others

column540:
"

And so really and truly
column541: it\u2019s sort of everything you look at in China was extremely good. We have been working significantly on expanding our ecosystem there
column542: and so we added Union Pay as a payment option for customers. We increased the iPhone point of sales to over 40
column543: 000 during the quarter. That\u2019s up about 9% year on year. And more importantly than the total number
column544:
we are in many more cities than we were before.

column545:
"

We worked significantly on our online store. Our online store revenue was up over three times year over year. As you probably heard us say before
column546:
we\u2019ve opened several stores in China recently. We\u2019re now at 21 in Greater China and we\u2019re on track still to achieve 40 stores by the middle of next year. The online store will also be expanding from around 319 cities to where they can hit two day delivery to 365 cities. So adding about 50 new cities by the end of this quarter.

column547:
"

And so the net is we\u2019re investing a lot across the board in our infrastructure
column548: in our products
column549:
on partnering with different companies. The Chinese developers are coming on in significant numbers. We\u2019ve now made payments to developers in Greater China of almost $5 billion over half of which was in the last 12 months.

column550:
"

column553:
I\u2019ve never seen as many people coming into the middle class as they are in China. And that\u2019s where the bulk of our sales are going. And so we\u2019re really proud of the results there and continue to invest in the country.

"

Shannon Cross

column555:
"

but are we seeing cannibalization from the iPhone 6 plus and how are you sort of thinking about the IBM partnership as it relates to iPad?

"
column558:
"

Number one
column559: we have to stop having the situations where we sell through more than we sell in
column560: where we don\u2019t have to have an inventory correction. That was over a million units. Two
column561: have we had cannibalization? The answer is yes. We\u2019re clearly seeing cannibalization from iPhone and on the other side
column562: from the Mac. And of course
column563: as I\u2019ve said before
column564: we\u2019ve never worried about that. It is what it is. That will play out
column565: and at some point
column566: it will stabilize. I\u2019m not sure precisely when
column567:

column568:

column571:
but everything I see I like on it. I\u2019m a big believer in the ability for iPad to play in a major way in enterprise. And so I\u2019m looking forward to seeing that play out as we move forward.

column572:
"

column573: it makes you feel a lot better than the sales do. And so things like first time buyer rates
column574: the latest numbers from the U.S. are somewhere around 40%. And if you look at China
column575: they\u2019re almost 70%. And so these numbers are not numbers that you would get if the market were saturated. And so I continue to believe
column576: even though I\u2019ve seen people write that
column577: that I think that theory is not correct
column578:
and do not see that.

"
column579:
"

We also see usage numbers that are off the charts
column580: so far above competition it\u2019s not even in the same planet. And we see customer satisfaction at or near 100%. And so these kind of numbers
column581: along with intent to buy numbers
column583:
the ecommerce numbers.

"
column584:
"

And so my belief is that as the inventory plays out
column585: as we make some continued investments in our product pipeline
column586: which we\u2019re doing
column587: that we already have planned and have had planned for some time
column588: between that
column589: the inventory playing out
column590: the enterprise starting to take over
column591: I think still I believe the iPad is an extremely good business over the long term. When precisely it begins to grow again I wouldn\u2019t want to predict
column592:

Luca

column603:
"

Luca Maestri

column604:
"

The logic has not changed over the years. We look at our business plans
column605:
we look at what we want to accomplish from product perspective. We look at the capital needs that we have to run the business and to grow the business. And then we see that we\u2019re in this great position that we can return cash to shareholders.

"
column606:
"

We know Apple very well. We are very excited by the level of customer response that we\u2019ve got for our current portfolio. We\u2019re super confident about the pipeline of products and services that we have
column607: and therefore
column608:
we believe that there is great value in our stock.

"
column609:
"

And that is the reason why
column610: again this year
column611: we\u2019re allocating the majority of the increase
column612: which is the largest increase that we\u2019ve ever done
column613: we\u2019re increasing the program by $70 billion. And the vast majority of that we\u2019re allocating to the share repurchase
column614: because again
column615:
we believe there\u2019s great value in the stock.

"
column616:
"

We also know
column617: and understand
column618: that we have several investors that value income. And so that\u2019s important for us to increase the dividend. And as we\u2019ve said in the past
column619: we plan to continue to increase the dividend every year. And as we\u2019ve said in the past
column620: we will come back at about this time next year and give you another update to the program
column621: because we will have better information

column624: of course we have a very strong balance sheet. We do have some cash in the U.S. We will continue to generate cash in the U.S.
column625:
but definitely a good portion of the program will be funded through debt. We will raise debt both in the U.S. and outside of the United States.

column627: of course we\u2019ve got a very
column628: very strong balance sheet. We\u2019ve got a very open dialog with the rating agencies. And so we feel we have a lot of room for us to fund the program. So from a balance sheet standpoint
column630:
very comfortable with the program that we\u2019ve announced today.

column680: this is for you. You mentioned something in your past comment that you thought a lot of the iPhone sales were going into the middle class in China. And I\u2019m just wondering if you could elaborate on that and open it up more broadly speaking

{"Apple (AAPL) Timothy D. Cook on Q3 2015 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Apple

Timothy D. Cook - Chief Executive Officer & Director
