column22: and welcome to the Apple Incorporated Third Quarter Fiscal Year 2015 Earnings Release Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded. At this time for opening remarks and introductions
column23: I would like to turn the call over to Nancy Paxton
column24: Senior Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead
column28:
"

Thank you. Good afternoon
column29: and thanks to everyone for joining us. Speaking first today is Apple CEO Tim Cook
column30: and he'll be followed by CFO Luca Maestri
column31:
and after that we'll open the call to questions from analysts.

"
column32:
"

Please note that some of the information you'll hear during our discussion today will consist of forward-looking statements
column33: including without limitation those regarding revenue
column37: taxes and future business outlook. Actual results or trends could differ materially from our forecast. For more information
column38: please refer to the risk factors discussed in Apple's Form 10-K for 2014
column39:
the Form 10-Q for the first two quarters of fiscal 2015 and the form 8-K filed with the SEC today along with the associated press release. Apple assumes no obligation to update any forward-looking statements or information which speak as of their respective dates.

"
column40:
"

I'd now like to turn the call over to Tim for introductory remarks.

"
column41:
"

Timothy D. Cook - Chief Executive Officer & Director

"
column44: and thanks for joining us. It's been a busy and exciting quarter and I'm delighted to talk to you about the highlights. Today
column45: we're proud to report record June quarter results with revenues of $49.6 billion and earnings of $10.7 billion. Our year-over-year growth rate in the fiscal third quarter accelerated over the first half of fiscal 2015. Revenues were up 33%
column46: our fastest growth rate in over three years
column47:
and earnings per share were up 45%. We achieved these incredibly strong results despite reducing channel inventories across our product lines by over 1 million units and despite the challenging FX environment.

"
column48:
"

Revenue exceeded the high end of our guidance by $1.6 billion as we topped our internal expectations for sales of iPhone
column49: iPad
column50: Mac and Apple Watch. We had another stellar quarter for iPhone
column51: establishing a new June quarter record. iPhone unit sales grew 35%
column52: which is almost three times the rate of growth of the smartphone market overall and we gained share in all of our geographic segments. iPhone revenue grew even more strongly
column53:
up 59%. The strong iPhone results were broad-based in both developed and emerging markets and we experienced the highest switcher rate from Android that we've ever measured.

"
column54:
"

Most importantly
column55: iPhone customer metrics are tremendous. ChangeWave's most recent survey of US customers found that iPhone has the highest customer satisfaction rate of any smartphone brand by a wide margin
column56: and that among iPhone owners planning to purchase a new phone
column57:
86% plan to purchase another iPhone. That compares to 50% repurchase intent for the next highest brand measured.

"
column58:
"

We also had a tremendous record quarter for Mac
column59:
continuing to defy the industry trend with unit growth of 9% in a market that IDC estimates contracted by 12%. Growth was fueled by great response to our new MacBook and we're working hard to catch up with customer demand.

"
column60:
"

We generated over $5 billion in services revenue
column61: setting a new all-time record. Within services
column62:
the App Store produced its best quarter ever with revenue growing 24%.

"
column63:
"

Our results from Greater China were outstanding with revenue growth of 112% and iPhone unit growth of 87%. This is particularly impressive given IDC's estimate of only 5% growth for the Greater China smartphone market. We also achieved our highest ever PC market share in the segment with Mac sales growing 33% over last year. And our ecosystem in China continues to grow at a very fast pace
column64:
with App Store revenue more than doubling in the quarter. Luca will go into more detail on our product and financial results in a moment.

"
column65:
"

A major highlight of the past quarter for all of us here at Apple was the launch of Apple Watch in April. As you know
column66: we've been very excited to get this revolutionary product to customers. We started taking preorders in nine countries on April 10
column67: and demand immediately exceeded supply by a wide margin. To prioritize those first orders and to deliver the best experience for our customers
column68: we delayed the availability of Apple Watch in our own retail stores until mid June. We made huge progress with the production ramp across the quarter and near the end of the quarter expanded into six additional countries. And in just the past few days
column69: we've been able to catch up with demand
column70:
enabling us to expand Apple Watch availability to a total of 19 countries currently with three more countries to be added at the end of this month.

"
column71:
"

The feedback from Apple Watch customers is incredibly positive and we've been very happy with customer satisfaction and usage statistics. Market research from Wristly measured a 97% customer satisfaction rate for Apple Watch and we hear from people every day about the impact it's having on their health
column72: their daily routines
column73: and how they communicate. Our own market research shows that 94% of Apple Watch owners wear and use it regularly
column74:
if not every day.

"
column75:
"

Messaging and activity features are among the most popular and social networking apps including Twitter
column76:
WeChat and LINE are seeing the most usage among third party apps. We believe that the possibilities for Apple Watch are enormous and that's been reinforced in just the first few weeks since it became available to customers.

"
column77:
"

For example
column78: doctors and researchers at leading hospitals in the US and Europe are already putting Apple Watch to work in improving patients' lives. Nebraska Medicine
column79: the latest hospital to adopt Apple Watch
column80:
has rolled out new apps that facilitate communication between patients and doctors and provide quick access to important chart and dosage information.

"
column81:
"

Ochsner Health System of Louisiana is using Apple Watch with hypertension patients to gather important information like daily activity and blood pressure level
column82:
and leading cancer centers like London King's College Hospital are incorporating Apple Watch into trials for ongoing care and monitoring of cancer patients.

"
column83:
"

Great Apple Watch solutions go well beyond healthcare. Users are tracking their fitness
column84: getting breaking news alerts
column85: following their investments
column86: connecting with friends
column87: and living a healthier day. The user experience for Apple Pay and Siri is nothing short of incredible and customers are enjoying countless other features through the over 8
column88:
500 third-party apps available for Apple Watch.

"
column89:
"

This is just the beginning of what this new platform can deliver. With Apple watchOS 2
column90: developers now have the ability to build richer and more powerful native apps for Apple Watch
column91: taking advantage of the heart rate sensor
column92: the Digital Crown
column93: accelerometer and more
column94:
ushering in a whole new class of apps designed specifically for the wrist.

"
column95:
"

It's a rare and special privilege to launch a new platform with such promise and potential
column96:
and I know I speak for everyone at Apple when I say that we can't wait to see what our developers and customers do with it.

"
column97:
"

We hosted a fantastic developers' conference in June with thousands of attendees from 70 countries coming together with Apple engineers to share in the excitement of our three operating systems
column98: OS X
column99: iOS
column100: and watchOS. We've been working hard to make our products even more intelligent
column101: more powerful and more meaningful in all aspects of our customers' lives
column102:
while adding new continuity features to make the experience across our devices more seamless than ever and preserving the security and privacy that our customers deserve. Public betas of OS X El Capitan and iOS 9 are available now and customer versions of all three updated OSs are on schedule and will be delivered in the fall.

"
column103:
"

We're very excited about our news app coming to iPhone and iPad with iOS 9. We believe it will be the best news reading experience on any mobile device
column104: combining a beautiful magazine layout with real-time customized digital media content. News will follow over a million topics and pull relevant stories based on the user's specific interests without compromising their privacy. We've already signed 25 leading publishers
column105: representing more than 75 of the world's most influential news
column106: sports
column107: business and magazine titles
column108: including CNN
column109: the New York Times
column110: the Financial Times
column111: ESPN
column112: Bloomberg Business
column113: Cond\u00e9 Nast
column114: Hearst
column115: Reuters
column116: Time
column117:
Inc. and The Daily Telegraph.

"
column118:
"

The September quarter is off to an exciting start. We're thrilled by the response to Apple Music
column119: which launched in over 100 countries on June 30. Apple Music is a single immersive app that combines the best ways to enjoy music all in one place. It's an incredible streaming music service
column120: a pioneering worldwide live radio station broadcasting 24 hours a day
column121:
and a great place for music fans to connect with their favorite artist. Customers and reviewers love the human curation features of Apple Music and the way it's helping people discover new music.

"
column122:
"

Millions and millions of customers are already experiencing the new service using the three-month trial period
column123: and the numbers are growing substantially every day. Over 15
column124: 000 artists have signed up to post on Connect
column125: where we are already seeing great original content
column126: including a world premiere video by Drake. Millions of listeners around the world are tuning in to Beats 1
column127: the first of its kind worldwide radio station featuring some of the most talented and passionate music lovers on the planet. This all adds up to a renewed sense of excitement around music
column128:
which we love and expect to continue as Apple Music gets traction with customers.

"
column129:
"

Last week we launched Apple Pay in the UK
column130: bringing customers our easy
column131: secure and private way to pay. On day one
column132: we had an incredible roster of over 250
column133:
000 locations and major credit and debit cards from many of the UK's most established banks supporting Apple Pay. Customers are using Apple Pay to ride the London Underground as well as the over ground systems of Transport for London and we hope this will be a model for other public transportation systems around the world.

"
column134:
"

In the US
column135: we've seen fantastic support from merchants of all sizes. We are excited to see this momentum continue with the new Square reader coming this fall. It will bring Apple Pay to even more neighborhood businesses where you pay every day
column136: from your corner coffee shop to your local farmer's market
column137: bolstering the 80
column138: 000 small- and medium-size businesses we're already adding every month. American Express will add Apple Pay support for its robust portfolio of corporate cards next month
column139: offering businesses and their employees a new way to make easy and secure payments. And as we head into the school year
column140: 700 universities and colleges across the US will accept Apple Pay such as Auburn University
column141: the University of California Irvine
column142: Colorado State University
column143: the University of Kentucky and the University of Oklahoma
column144:
among many others. We're on track for Apple Pay acceptance at over 1.5 million US locations by the end of 2015.

"
column145:
"

I'd like to thank our customers
column146: developers
column147: business partners and employees for another record breaking quarter. We're very hard at work on our exciting pipeline of new hardware
column148: software and services
column149:
and we're continuing to expand our global reach into new markets. And we're passionately committed to leaving the world better than we found it.

"
column150:
"

With that
column151:
I'll turn the call over to Luca.

"
column152:
"

Luca Maestri - Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer

"
column153:
"

Thank you
column154: Tim. Good afternoon
column155: everyone. As we have done for the first half of our fiscal 2015
column156: we are reporting another record quarter today. Revenue for the June quarter was $49.6 billion
column157: an increase of $12.2 billion or 33% year over year. Our growth was driven by the tremendous performance of iPhone
column158: the introduction of Apple Watch and the continued strength of Mac and App Store sales. We achieved these great results in the context of a very challenging foreign exchange environment around the world and a reduction in channel inventory of over 1 million units across our product lines
column159:
which makes our growth performance even more remarkable.

"
column160:
"

As Tim mentioned
column161: our results were especially impressive in Greater China
column162: where revenue more than doubled year over year to over $13 billion. Emerging markets overall grew 79% to almost $18 billion and represented 35% of our total company revenue. Company gross margin was 39.7%
column163: better than our expectations
column164: mainly due to strong iPhone sales. Operating margin was 28.4% of revenue and net income was $10.7 billion
column165: a new June quarter record. Diluted earnings per share were $1.85
column166: a 45% year-over-year increase and cash flow from operations was $15 billion
column167:
also a new third quarter record.

"
column168:
"

For details by product I'll start with iPhone. We sold 47.5 million iPhones in the quarter
column169: representing 35% year over year growth and demand for iPhone 6 and 6 Plus has continued to be terrific all around the world. iPhone sales more than doubled in Germany
column170: Korea
column171: Malaysia
column172: and Vietnam. We're up over 85% in Greater China and in India
column173: and increased more than 45% in several countries including Italy
column174: Spain
column175:
the Netherlands and Turkey.

"
column176:
"

The strong mix of iPhone 6 and 6 Plus led to an iPhone ASP of $660
column177: an increase of $99 year over year
column178: despite the significant negative foreign exchange impact I referred to earlier. We reduced iPhone channel inventory by about 600
column179: 000 units during the quarter
column180:
which left us at the low end of our target range of 5 to 7 weeks of channel inventory.

"
column181:
"

Next I'd like to talk about the Mac. We sold 4.8 million Macs
column182: representing 9% year-over-year growth. As we have done for several years in a row
column183:
we continued to gain significant market share based on IDC's latest estimate of a 12% global PC market contraction. Mac growth was driven by portables and we are delighted with the very strong customer reception of our new MacBook. We ended the quarter slightly below our 4 to 5 week target range for Mac channel inventory.

"
column184:
"

Turning to iPad. We sold 10.9 million compared to 13.3 million in the year-ago quarter. iPad sell-through was 11.2 million as we reduced channel inventory by about 300
column185: 000 units. This left us within our 5 to 7 week target range of iPad channel inventory. iPad customer metrics continue to be extremely positive. ChangeWave recently measured a 97% customer satisfaction rate for iPad Air 2 and among consumers planning to purchase a tablet within 90 days
column186: over half plan to purchase an iPad. For corporate buyers
column187:
the purchase intent was even stronger at over 70%.

"
column188:
"

We do not participate in the low end of the tablet market
column189: but we are extremely successful where we do compete. NPD recently indicated that iPad has 76% share of the US market for tablets priced above $200. We're very excited about the advances in the iPad experience coming in iOS 9 in the fall
column190: including the slide over and split view features for retail multitasking
column192:
and enhanced QuickType for composing text even faster.

"
column193:
"

We're also seeing great momentum in the enterprise market. For instance
column194: riding on the success of iPad use by its pilots
column195: United Airlines has not only renewed its iPad program with more than 10
column196: 000 iPad Air 2s
column197: but has also made a strategic decision to provide iPhones to over 20
column198: 000 flight attendants. In the near future
column199:
United plans to introduce new apps to transform the customer experience and improve integration with flight operations.

"
column200:
"

We're also very happy with the progress of our IBM partnership. IBM released 13 new MobileFirst for iOS apps in the June quarter
column201: including new apps in retail banking and healthcare
column202:
as well as new horizontal apps for HR and sales. There are now 35 apps in IBM's MobileFirst for iOS catalog that connect users to big data and analytics right on their iPads or iPhones. And we expect a total of 100 apps to be available by the end of 2015.

"
column203:
"

Active customer engagements have also grown to over 500 and recent notable customer wins include Air Canada
column204: National Grid in the UK and Banorte in Mexico. In April
column205: Apple
column206: IBM and Japan Post announced a joint initiative to deliver iPads with IBM developed apps and analytics to connect Japanese senior citizens with services
column207: healthcare
column208: community and family. Japan Post hopes to reach 4 million to 5 million Japanese customers with these solutions by 2020. Since announcing this initiative less than three months ago
column209:
we've already seen strong interest from other countries looking for innovative ways to support an aging population.

"
column210:
"

Importantly
column211: we also continue to work closely with leading business software and solution providers to help businesses of all sizes transform work with iPad and iPhone. The number of these mobility partners has expanded rapidly to over 40. They're developing new and differentiated solutions on iOS across many industries
column212:
and attracting very significant customer interest.

"
column213:
"

Turning to services. We generated over $5 billion in revenue
column214: a new all-time record
column215: and an increase of 12% over last year thanks primarily to strong growth from apps. The revenue from the App Store increased 24% and the number of transacting customers grew 19%
column216: also setting an all-time record. Services growth was particularly strong in China
column217: where the App Store revenue more than doubled year over year. China based developers have created 250
column218:
000 apps for our China App Store and the response from our customers has been tremendous.

"
column219:
"

The revenue from other products grew sharply
column220: up 49% over last year. The contribution from Apple Watch accounted for well over 100% of the growth of the category
column221: and more than offset the decline of iPod and accessory sales. As we've said in the past
column222:
we do not plan to disclose Apple Watch metrics because we don't intend to provide insight that could help our competitors.

"
column223:
"

Our retail and online stores had a very busy quarter
column224: with customer visits up 49% year-over-year
column225: driven especially by the very strong interest in Apple Watch. Thanks to our very popular Apple Store app
column226: mobile traffic to our online stores during the quarter equaled desktop traffic for the first time ever. We opened three new stores
column227: our second store in Brazil
column228: our sixth store in Manhattan
column229: and our twenty-second store in Greater China. That brought us to a global store count of 456
column230: of which 190 are outside the United States
column231:
and we are on track to have 40 stores open in Greater China by the middle of next year.

"
column232:
"

Let me now turn to our cash position. We ended the quarter with $202.8 billion in cash plus marketable securities
column233: a sequential increase of $9.3 billion. $181 billion of this cash
column234: or 89% of the total
column235: was offshore. In the June quarter
column236: we issued a total of $10 billion of term debt
column237:
consisting of $8 billion US dollar denominated notes and \u00a5250 billion denominated notes as we continue to diversify our global debt investor base. This left us with $50 billion of term debt outstanding at the end of the quarter.

"
column239:
we turned over $13 billion to our investors. We paid $3.1 billion in dividends and equivalents and we spent $4 billion to repurchase 31.2 million Apple shares to open market transactions. We also launched a $6 billion accelerated share repurchase program in May and received an initial delivery of 38.3 million shares. The purchase period for the new ASR will end in or before November of 2015.

"
column240:
"

We have continued to execute our capital return program at a fast pace and we now take an action on over $126 billion of our $200 billion program
column241:
including $90 billion in share repurchases. The weighted average price for all open market purchases and completed ASR programs to date is $86.

"
column242:
"

Now as we move ahead into the September quarter
column243: I'd like to review our outlook
column244:
which includes the types of forward-looking information that Nancy referred to at the beginning of the call. We expect revenue to be between $49 billion and $51 billion compared to $42.1 billion in the year-ago quarter. We expect gross margin to be between 38.5% and 39.5%. We expect OpEx to be between $5.850 billion and $5.950 billion. We expect OI&E to be about $400 million and we expect the tax rate to be about 26.3%.

"
column245:
"

Also today our Board of Directors has declared a cash dividend of $0.52 per share of common stock payable on August 15
column246: 2015 to shareholders of record as of August 10
column248:
"

With that
column249:
let's open the call to questions.

"
column250:
"

Nancy Paxton - Senior Director
column252:
"

We ask that you limit yourself to one
column253: one-part question and one follow-up. Operator
column254: may we have the first question
column255:
please?

"
column256:
"

Question-and-Answer Session

"
column257:
"

Operator

"
column258:
"

[Operation Instructions] First we will hear from Katy Huberty with Morgan Stanley.

"
column259:
"

Kathryn L. Huberty - Morgan Stanley & Co. LLC

"
column260:
"

Yes
column261: thanks. Good afternoon. While the year on year iPhone growth was very attractive
column262: the sequential unit decline in the June quarter was worse than the past two years. Why do you think that was
column263: and in particular
column264:
why drain channel inventory when iPhone 6 is selling so well? And then I have a follow-up.

"
column265:
"

Timothy D. Cook - Chief Executive Officer & Director

"
column266:
"

Katy
column267: it's Tim. As Luca mentioned
column268: the channel inventory did go down by 600
column269: 000. We sold more units than we thought we would and so that was a part of that. The other part of it is that we always run with just the amount of inventory that we think we need. And so to the degree that sales are distributed in the countries with disproportionally with shorter supply chains
column270: or the standard deviation demand is less
column271:
we would always choose to have less.

"
column272:
"

And so in this particular quarter
column273: we were able to end basically right at the bottom end of our range and we view that as a good thing
column274: not a bad thing. Obviously the revenues could have been much higher if we would have expanded the channel
column275: but if you don't need to do that
column276: that's not how we think about the business. We run the business for the long term
column277:
not the 90-day clock.

"
column278:
"

In terms of what's going on with iPhone
column279: the 35% growth is almost three times the market. And if you look at it at a little narrower regional level
column280: Western Europe grew 30% versus a market of 7%
column281:
so four times market. Japan grew over five times market. We doubled in Korea versus a market that was shrinking. And India we grew at 93% and this is on top of the Greater China numbers that we've already covered that grew 87% during the quarter against a market of 5%. And so we did exceptionally well I think in any way that you look at it.

"
column282:
"

In terms of the percentage of customers that have upgraded to a 6 and 6 Plus versus that have not upgraded
column284: or meaning that 27% of the installed base of customers prior to the launch of 6 and 6 Plus have now upgraded. And so we view that as a very bullish sign on the future
column285: that there's a lot of headroom left for upgraders. We also are incredibly happy to see the highest Android switcher rate that we've observed. And so from our point of view
column286:
the iPhone is doing outstanding.

"
column287:
"

Kathryn L. Huberty - Morgan Stanley & Co. LLC

"
column288:
"

So Tim
column289: just to extend that conversation to the longer term
column290: as I'm sure you're aware
column291:
you're lapping some pretty significant comps as it relates to the upgrades that you're talking about as well as significant growth in China. What is the framework that you use to convince yourselves that iPhone units can continue to grow over the longer term?

"
column292:
"

Timothy D. Cook - Chief Executive Officer & Director

"
column293:
"

Well you know
column294: Katy
column295: we purposely just give guidance for the current quarter and we've done that. And obviously the kind of numbers that we have indicated growth in the revenue means that iPhone would have another stellar quarter. And so we're very confident that this quarter is going to be great. How the future looks
column296: we'll take it one quarter at a time. But as I back up from it and look at it more from a macro point of view
column297: the things that makes me very bullish is the 27% number I just quoted
column298: the fact that we are seeing the highest Android switcher rate
column299: the customer satisfaction that we have on the iPhone versus the competition. It's a huge margin. The loyalty rate that we have versus competition
column300:
an enormous gap there.

"
column301:
"

I also look at the first time iPhone buyers and we're still seeing very
column302: very large numbers in the countries that you would want to see those in
column303: like China and Russia and Brazil and so forth. I also see a market that over a five-year horizon
column304: if you look at the IDC numbers
column305: is projected to grow from 1.3 million in 2014 to over 1.9 billion \u2013 this is billion
column307: billion in 2019. And so it's an incredible market. I think everybody's going to own a smartphone
column308: and I think we've proven that we can compete for a fair number of those
column309:
as you can see from our results.

"
column310:
"

Kathryn L. Huberty - Morgan Stanley & Co. LLC

"
column311:
"

Great. Thank you very much.

"
column312:
"

Nancy Paxton - Senior Director
column313:
Investor Relations and Treasury

"
column315: Katy. Could we have the next question
column316:
please?

"
column317:
"

Operator

"
column318:
"

That will come from Bill Shope with Goldman Sachs.

"
column319:
"

William C. Shope - Goldman Sachs & Co.

"
column320:
"

Okay
column321:
great. Thank you. Could you walk us through the key factors behind your gross margin range for the September quarter and in particular how we should think about the sequential ForEx impact this quarter and the impact of a potential product transition cost?

"
column322:
"

Luca Maestri - Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer

"
column323:
"

Definitely. This is Luca. So we got into 38.5% to 39.5%
column324: and so just keep in mind last year in Q4
column325: our gross margin declined by 140 basis points sequentially. So this year we're expecting a sequential decline of 220 basis points. I would point to three main factors for the decline. First of all
column326: to your point around foreign exchange
column327: it continues to be a challenging environment given the strengthening of the US dollar. In our case
column328: the impact on margin after the hedges is going to be about 30 basis points for Q4. Also
column329: I want to point to a different mix
column330: which is typical of our seasonality as we enter the back-to-school season during Q4. And thirdly
column331: the transition cost that you've mentioned as we prepare for a busy fall. And so those are the three factors that will have an impact on gross margin sequentially. I would point that in general costs continue to be
column332:
particularly commodity costs continue to be favorable and so there would be a partial offset to the factors that I mentioned.

"
column333:
"

William C. Shope - Goldman Sachs & Co.

"
column334:
"

Okay
column335: thanks. And then could you give us a bit more color on the mix dynamics for the iPhone in the June quarter and how this compares to prior generations and your expectations? Obviously there continues to be an upward bias helping the ASPs as you mentioned
column336:
but could you give us a bit more detail on what exactly you're seeing here? Particularly I think it's interesting in the context of a continued tilt towards the emerging regions obviously.

"
column337:
"

Luca Maestri - Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer

"
column338:
"

Yeah
column339: so as we mentioned
column340: the ASP for iPhone was up $99
column341: 18% increase year-over-year and this is really driven by the mix
column342: by the fact that we've added iPhone 6 Plus to a new price point and in general
column343: iPhone 6 and 6 Plus are doing extremely well as a percentage of the portfolio. And keep in mind that this $99 was partially offset by $24 of unfavorable foreign exchange. So the number would have been even better. So yes
column344: clearly 6 and 6 Plus. And I think we talked about it in prior calls
column345: the 6 Plus is doing particularly well in the markets that you would expect
column346: Greater China
column347: other Asian markets. Those are markets where our growth rates are particularly strong and the 6 Plus
column348: because of the screen size
column349:
is doing extremely well.

"
column350:
"

William C. Shope - Goldman Sachs & Co.

"
column351:
"

All right. Thank you.

"
column352:
"

Nancy Paxton - Senior Director
column353:
Investor Relations and Treasury

"
column354:
"

Thanks
column355: Bill. Could we have the next question
column356:
please?

"
column357:
"

Operator

"
column358:
"

That will come from Gene Munster with Piper Jaffray.

"
column359:
"

Eugene C. Munster - Piper Jaffray & Co (Broker)

"
column360:
"

Hi
column361: good afternoon. Luca
column362: you talked a little bit about gross margins in the previous question. But could you talk about how we should think about the trends in the gross margin? In other words is
column363: should the margin trends that we've seen in other cycles continue into next year? And then a follow-up or another question for Tim here
column364:
is that the Watch has been under a lot of interest from investors and some may have wanted a little bit more. You outlined some of the opportunities and some of the progress you've had. But any thoughts that you have for investors who may say that the category is just not taking off as fast as they would have hoped?

"
column365:
"

Luca Maestri - Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer

"
column366:
"

Okay Gene
column367: let me start with gross margin. As Tim said before
column368: obviously we guide to the current quarter. You know
column369: as we look at it at a macro level. I think there are
column370: you know every cycle is different for a variety of reasons. There are also things that are not necessarily within our control. So for example
column371:
currency markets can be very different one year to the next. We know that the next year is going to represent an additional challenge given where the dollar has moved. Commodity markets may be very different from one year to the other.

"
column372:
"

There are things that remain relatively similar as we launch new products. For example
column373: we innovate the products. We want to make them better all the time
column374: and that typically requires additional cost and so the cost structures of our products
column375: new products
column376: tend to be higher than the products that they replace. Having said that
column377: as you know we've got a very
column378: very good track record to reduce those cost factors over the lifecycle of the products. I think this should give you a bit of color. Of course maybe the one thing that I want to point out again as we get into the following year
column379:
is that of course currency will be an issue.

"
column380:
"

Eugene C. Munster - Piper Jaffray & Co (Broker)

"
column381:
"

Okay. Thank you.

"
column382:
"

Timothy D. Cook - Chief Executive Officer & Director

"
column383:
"

Yeah Gene
column384: this is Tim. Let me talk about the Watch some. As you know
column385: we made a decision back in September
column386: quite several months ago not to disclose the shipments on the Watch and that was not a matter of not being transparent
column387: it was a matter of not giving our competition insight that's a product that we've worked really hard on. However
column388: let me give you some color so to avoid reaching sort of a wrong conclusion. If you look at the other products category and look at the revenue in this category
column389: it would not be an accurate thing to just look at the sequential change or the year over year change and assume that were the total Watch revenue because the aggregate balance of that category
column390: both sequentially and year over year
column391: is shrinking. Obviously iPod is a part of that
column392: but there are other things in there
column393: accessories and so forth
column394:
that are shrinking.

"
column395:
"

Secondly to provide a bit more color
column396: sales of the Watch did exceed our expectations and they did so despite supply still trailing demand at the end of the quarter. And to give you a little additional insight
column397: through the end of the quarter
column398: in fact the Apple Watch sell-through was higher than the comparable launch periods of the original iPhone or the original iPad. And we were able to do that with having only 680 points of sale. And as you probably know
column399: as I had reviewed earlier
column400: the online sales were so great at the beginning
column401: we were not able to feed inventory to our stores until mid-June. And so those points of sale pretty much
column402:
the overwhelming majority of the low numbers of sales were not there until the last two weeks of the quarter.

"
column403:
"

And so as I look at all of these things
column404: we feel really great about how we did. Now our objective for the quarter wasn't primarily sales. Beyond the very good news on sales
column405: we're more excited about how the product is positioned for the long term because we're starting a new category. And as I back up and look at this
column407: 500 apps. We've already announced the next operating system
column408: watchOS 2. It will bring native apps which are going to be killer to the Watch. Even though the store layout was delayed
column409: we've learned a lot about the buying experience. Based on that experience
column410:
we're now planning to expand our channel before the holiday because we're convinced that the Watch is going to be one of the top gifts of the holiday season.

"
column411:
"

Now most importantly of all of this is that customer sat is off the charts because we've constantly seen if you can get the customer sat off the charts you can wind up doing fairly well over time. We've also learned a lot about managing quite an assortment and so forth. And so I sort of back up and look at this and I feel fantastic about what the team has done and delivered and I know I never go anywhere without the Watch and it's not because I'm the CEO of Apple. I'm that attached to it and I get lots of notes from a lot of people that feel the same way. And so that's how I look at the Watch.

"
column412:
"

Nancy Paxton - Senior Director
column413:
Investor Relations and Treasury

"
column414:
"

Thanks
column415: Gene. Could we have the next question
column416:
please?

"
column418:
"

From Bernstein we'll hear from Toni Sacconaghi.

"
column419:
"

Antonio M. Sacconaghi - Sanford C. Bernstein & Co. LLC

"
column420:
"

Yes
column421: thank you. Luca
column422: I think in your prepared remarks you talked a little bit about your market share of iPad in the US above $200 being 78%. And I'm wondering if you think about the iPhone and your market share in the premium category
column423: how do you think about it? So I've seen market data that says 60% market share for phones above $300 or you have actually 90% market share for phones above $600. And I'm wondering if
column425: you could maybe talk about how you think about your market share
column426: where you play given that your ASP is comfortably above $600? What do you think your market share is above $500 or $600 in smartphones? And how do we think about that
column427:
that market share going forward?

"
column428:
"

Timothy D. Cook - Chief Executive Officer & Director

"
column429:
"

Toni
column430: it's Tim. We look at it a bit differently than you do. We look at it as our job is to grow our products regardless of the price
column431: which means that we need to convince in some cases people to move from one price band to the other. And that we think if we do a great job with the product that people will be willing to spend more because they get so much more out of it. And I think you can look at the results on the iPhone and see that in action. I mean
column432: we grew 87% in China. We grew 90%-plus in India. Emerging markets are growing 65%. These numbers are unbelievable and they're done in an environment where it's not the best of conditions. So that's how we look at. We don't do the MBA analysis of there's only X people buying in a price band and therefore we can only get X minus Y percent. That's not the way we've ever looked at it. If we did
column433:
we wouldn't be shipping any products.

"
column434:
"

Antonio M. Sacconaghi - Sanford C. Bernstein & Co. LLC

"
column435:
"

Tim
column436:
I'm asking in part because you talked about the highest ever Android switcher. So I'm wondering if indeed your goal of expanding the category is happening or whether you are taking share and how do you measure the relative contribution of each of those in your success. So is the strength and the dramatically above market growth because you're taking share in that high-end category and how far along are you there? Or can you point to proof points that you've actually expanded the size of the market for products of your price point?

"
column437:
"

Timothy D. Cook - Chief Executive Officer & Director

"
column439: I think there's no doubt if you look at it we are expanding the market size in those areas. It's also true that there's some people that are switching from comparable price points to the iPhone
column440: and that's great too. But I think the answer is that both of those things are happening and it's key that we do both
column441:
not just one.

"
column442:
"

Antonio M. Sacconaghi - Sanford C. Bernstein & Co. LLC

"
column443:
"

Okay. And then if I could just ask you to comment on how you think about replacement cycles with the current iPhone 6 cycle. So when you look at replacement cycles over the last three quarters
column444: are they similar to what you saw one and two years ago when you think about replacement? And one of the things that also sort of struck me was I think you cited market research having repurchase intention of 86% versus your competitors at 50%. Quite frankly
column445: the 86% sounds low to me. Is that actually consistent with what you see in the marketplace
column446:
about 86% of iPhone buyers ultimately buy another iPhone? So perhaps we can think about replacement cycle.

"
column447:
"

Timothy D. Cook - Chief Executive Officer & Director

"
column448:
"

Yes.

"
column449:
"

Antonio M. Sacconaghi - Sanford C. Bernstein & Co. LLC

"
column450:
"

And how that's changed and the percentage number and how that jives with reality?

"
column451:
"

Timothy D. Cook - Chief Executive Officer & Director

"
column452:
"

The 86% also seems low to me but I was quoting a third-party source and not our own data. Our own data would look better than that. But the numbers are only comparable if I quote the third-party source for both and so that's what I'm doing.

"
column453:
"

On the upgrade cycle and what we're seeing
column454: it's not remarkably different. However
column455: there's a number of plans that people began signing up for in the last year that could change it. These are upgrade any time kind of plans. They may be one year leases that could actually help the upgrade rate. And I think it'll be interesting to see how that plays out over the next horizon. But generally speaking
column456: I see positive vectors there
column457: not negative
column458:
in the aggregate.

"
column459:
"

Nancy Paxton - Senior Director
column460:
Investor Relations and Treasury

"
column462: Toni. Can we have the next question
column463:
please?

"
column464:
"

Operator

"
column465:
"

We'll go to Jim Suva with Citi.

"
column466:
"

James D. Suva - Citigroup Global Markets
column467:
Inc. (Broker)

"
column468:
"

Thank you very much. As you look at many of your products have been absolutely fantastic and at different phases in their life
column470: whether it's iPad
column471: iPhone
column472: iPod
column473:
and iPhone looks like it's facing some very challenging comps here in the next few quarters. Does this make you shift even more strategic focus into broadening the reliance on a couple products such as you mentioned Apple Radio. There's a lot more content on the Apple Watch and apps and then also Apple Pay. Are you increasingly focusing on hiring and kind of non hardware things (45:32)? Or are these kind of more peripheral activities and still the focus is kind of right now on the phone?

"
column474:
"

Timothy D. Cook - Chief Executive Officer & Director

"
column475:
"

Jim
column476: it's Tim. We think the phone has a lot of legs to it. I mean
column477: many
column478: many
column479: many years. There's tons of innovation left at the phone. I think we're in the early innings of it
column480: not in the late innings
column481:
and I think the market rate of growth over the long haul will also be impressive. And so there will be multiple winners here. And so that's how I see it.

"
column482:
"

In terms of the other things that we're doing
column483: we have some great capability and great teams in Apple. And so we can do more than one thing
column484: and so we have other things that we're working on as well. But at the aggregate level
column485: we still remain very focused because if you look at our size versus the number of projects we have going
column486:
it's much smaller compared to most. But that's how we do things and that's how we get the level of quality that we want out of each one of those.

"
column487:
"

And so the other things that you named
column488: whether it be Apple Music or Apple Pay
column489: both of these are very important to us. And things that you didn't mention
column490: the Mac continues to perform very well. I am still bullish on iPad. We've gotten with iOS 9
column491: there's some incredible productivity enhancements coming in with split view and slide over and picture-in-picture. These things are incredible features. The enterprise business is clearly picking up and more and more companies are either contracting for or writing apps themselves. I think and I believe that the iPad consumer upgrade cycle will eventually occur because as we look at the usage statistics on iPad
column492: it remains unbelievably great. I mean
column493: the next closest usage of the next competitor
column495:
"

And so these are extraordinary numbers. It's not like people have forgotten iPad or anything. It's a fantastic product. So I see a lot of runway. And as I look geographically
column496: where we've been doing really good in the emerging markets
column497: our share is still not high in any of them
column498: and so there's a lot of headroom there as well
column499: as there is in most developed markets as well. And so I look around
column500:
I see opportunity left and right. And that's what we're focused on.

"
column501:
"

James D. Suva - Citigroup Global Markets
column502:
Inc. (Broker)

"
column503:
"

Great. Thank you so much.

"
column504:
"

Nancy Paxton - Senior Director
column505:
Investor Relations and Treasury

"
column506:
"

Thanks
column507:
Jim. Could we have the next question please?

column508:
"

Operator

column509:

We'll hear from Steve Milunovich with UBS.

column510:
"

Steven M. Milunovich - UBS Securities LLC

column511:
"

Thank you. Tim
column512: there's some concern about what's going on in China with the stock market and economically. How do you think that plays out for Apple? On one hand you've got more stores
column513: broader distribution
column514: the 4G infrastructure is playing out. On the other hand
column515:
the economy might be weakening. Is a phone a discretionary purchase or not? How do you think about going forward in China?

"
column516:
"

Timothy D. Cook - Chief Executive Officer & Director

"
column517:
"

Yeah
column518: it's a very good question
column519: and we remain extremely bullish on China and we're continuing to invest. Nothing that's happened has changed our fundamental view that China will be Apple's largest market at some point in the future. It's true
column520: as you point out
column521: that the equity markets have recently been volatile. This could create some speed bumps in the near term. But to put it in context
column523: despite that volatility in the Chinese market
column524: they're still up 90% over the last year
column525: and they're up 20% year-to-date
column526:
and so these kind of numbers are numbers I think all of us would love.

"
column527:
"

Also
column528: the stock market participation among Chinese household is fairly narrow. And the stock ownership is very concentrated in a few people who put what appears to be a smaller portion of their wealth in the market than we might. And so I think generally this has been
column529: at least as we see it
column530: maybe it's not true for other businesses
column531: that this worry is probably overstated. And so we're not changing anything. We have the pedal to the metal on getting to 40 stores mid next year. As we had talked about before
column532:
we're continuing to expand the indirect channel as well.

"
column533:
"

As you point out
column534: and I think this is a major point that many people miss
column535: the LTE penetration in China is only at 12%. And China doesn't possess the level of fiber that some other countries do
column536: and so in order to get the great video performance
column538:
raising that penetration is really great. I think that really plays to an incredible smartphone future there.

"
column540: and I can't underestimate \u2013 I can't overstate this. The rise of the middle class there is continuing
column541: and it is transforming China. McKinsey
column542: I saw a recent study from McKinsey that's projecting the upper middle class to grow from 14% to 54% of households over the ten-year period from 2012 to 2022. So we're within that period at this moment
column543: and you can see for all of us that travel there so much
column544:
with every trip you can see this occurring. And so I think we would be foolish to change our plans. I think China is a fantastic geography with an incredible unprecedented level of opportunity there. And we're going to be there.

"
column545:
"

Steven M. Milunovich - UBS Securities LLC

"
column546:
"

I also wanted to ask
column547: can you give us any more detail on the switching rate
column548: how much is it up? And I noticed in your advertising there's the shift to the
column549: if it's not an iPhone
column550: it's not an iPhone. And I assume that while you're not as involved as Jobs was
column551:
you're approving these ads. So it seems like you're really focused on market share gain right now.

"
column552:
"

Timothy D. Cook - Chief Executive Officer & Director

"
column554: I'm very familiar with the ads. In certain geographies
column555: the way that we win is to get switchers. In other geographies
column556: the way that we win is to get people to buy their first smartphone. In other geographies
column557: the way that we win is to get people to upgrade from their current iPhone. And all of those are very important for us. In many geographies
column558: it's two of those or in some geographies it's all three of those. And so all of those are important. We are very focused on growing iPhone around the world
column559:
not just in one geography and getting our message out there through ads is one way to do that.

"
column560:
"

Steven M. Milunovich - UBS Securities LLC

"
column561:
"

Thank you.

"
column562:
"

Nancy Paxton - Senior Director
column563:
Investor Relations and Treasury

"
column564:
"

Thank you
column565: Steve. Could we have the next question
column566:
please?

"
column567:
"

Operator

"
column568:
"

And that'll come from Shannon Cross with Cross Research.

"
column569:
"

Shannon S. Cross - Cross Research LLC

"
column570:
"

Thank you very much. I wanted to talk about FX but not necessarily from a direct impact. But what are you seeing in terms of demand as you've raised prices in various geographies and how are you thinking about it as you go into sort of the next iPhone cycle in terms of having to sort of normalize the pricing for what some of the currencies have done over the past year?

"
column571:
"

Luca Maestri - Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer

"
column572:
"

Yes
column573: Shannon. So obviously FX has been a significant hit in many ways
column574: of course. I mean it reduces our growth rate. We would be 800 basis points higher this quarter from the 33% that we've reported if it wasn't for the movement in currencies around the world. And really when you look around the world
column575: it's really if you exclude China
column576:
essentially every single currency has weakened against the dollar. We are pretty careful and thoughtful about where we increase prices and when and by how much during mid-cycle because it's not something that we particularly like to do. We've had circumstances around the world this year where frankly we didn't have many options because the currency movement was so large and so we've had to reprice.

"
column577:
"

I have to say that it's been remarkable. Look
column578: in the long run a strong US dollar is not a positive for our international business. It's normal to see a drop in demand when prices go up. That goes without saying. It has been remarkable so far to see that we did take prices in a few markets. But really remarkable to see how resilient iPhone sales have been
column579: because we have increased
column580: in spite of these price increases
column581: we've increased sales and we've increased market share in all our geographies around the world
column583:
"

Shannon S. Cross - Cross Research LLC

"
column584:
"

Great. And then can you talk a bit about linearity during the quarter on a geographic basis? Somewhat going back to the China question
column585:
I mean did you see it slow down toward the end of the quarter? Or was it solid through it? And just any other color you can give geographically with Europe and some of the other macro events that are going on.

"
column586:
"

Timothy D. Cook - Chief Executive Officer & Director

"
column587:
"

Yeah
column588: Shannon
column589: it's Tim. Maybe the best way to talk about this is sort of at the product level. On the Watch
column590: our June sales were higher than April or May. I realize that's very different than what some of the
column591: is being written
column592: but the June sales were the highest. And so the Watch had a more of a back-ended kind of a skewing. The phone itself followed what I would call a normal seasonal kind of pattern. And if you look at the \u2013 it sounds like you're honing in on the Greater China results themselves. There is no obvious impact from the last quarter in the Greater China numbers. And obviously with the aggregate or the consolidated number being 112%
column593:
it's hard to find a lot of bad things in the numbers.

"
column594:
"

Nancy Paxton - Senior Director
column595:
Investor Relations and Treasury

"
column596:
"

Thank you
column597:
Shannon.

"
column598:
"

Nancy Paxton - Senior Director
column599:
Investor Relations and Treasury

column1:
{"Apple's (AAPL) CEO Tim Cook on Q4 2015 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Apple
column9:
"

Tim Cook - Chief Executive Officer

"
column10:
"

Luca Maestri \u2013 SVP and Chief Financial Officer

"
column18:
"

Amit Daryanani - RBC Capital Markets

"
column21:
"

Good day ladies and gentlemen
column22: and welcome to the Apple Incorporated Fourth Quarter Fiscal Year 2015 Earnings Release Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded. At this time for opening remarks and introductions
column23: I would like to turn the call over to Nancy Paxton
column24: Senior Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead
column28: and thanks to everyone for joining us. Speaking first is Apple CEO Tim Cook
column29: and he'll be followed by CFO Luca Maestri
column30:
after that we'll open the call to questions from analysts.

"
column31:
"

Please note that some of the information you'll hear during our discussion today will consist of forward-looking statements
column32: including without limitation those regarding revenue
column33: gross margin
column36: taxes and future business outlook. Actual results or trends could differ materially from our forecast. For more information
column37: please refer to the risk factors discussed in Apple's Form 10-K for 2014
column38:
the Form 10-Q for the first three quarters of fiscal 2015 and the form 8-K filed with the SEC today along with the associated press release.

"
column39:
"

Apple assumes no obligation to update any forward-looking statements or information which speaks as of their respective dates.

"
column40:
"

I'd now like to turn the call over to Tim for introductory remarks.

"
column41:
"

Tim Cook

"
column44: and thanks for joining us. Today
column45:
we are reporting a very strong finish to a record breaking year and I\u2019d like to reflect on some of the highlights.

"
column46:
"

We completed our fiscal year in September
column47: and we are proud to report revenue of $234 billion
column48: an increase of 28% and $51 billion over 2014. This is our largest absolute revenue growth ever. To put that into some context
column49:
our growth in one year was greater than the full year revenue of almost 90% of the companies in the Fortune 500. We made huge inroads into emerging markets generating over $79 billion in revenue and growing 63% despite very strong headwinds from foreign exchange rates.

"
column50:
"

These results are made possible by Apple\u2019s commitment to innovation and creating the best products on earth. In the past 12 months around the world we\u2019ve sold over 300 million devices including 231 million iPhones
column51:
55 million iPads and 21 million Macs setting new unit records and increasing our global market share for both iPhone and Mac.

"
column52:
"

We crossed 100 billion cumulative downloads from the App Store and we added powerful new services to our ecosystem
column53: including Apple Pay in the United States
column54: in the United Kingdom
column55: Apple Music in over a 100 countries
column56:
and Apple News in the U.S.

"
column57:
"

We also entered an entirely new category with Apple Watch and we are in the very early innings of this promising new part of our business. We generated over $53 billion dollars in net income and grew earnings per share by 43%. We returned almost $50 billion to shareholders through dividends and share repurchases while continuing to invest confidently in research and development
column58: marketing and distribution
column59: our retail and online stores
column60:
our supply chain and our infrastructure.

"
column61:
"

We also completed 15 acquisitions to enhance and accelerate our roadmap for products and services. We accomplished all of these things while intensifying our efforts to protect the environment to promote equality and human rights and to ensure the security and privacy we know our customers deserve.

"
column62:
"

We are ending the year on a high note with a record breaking September quarter including sales of 48 million iPhones beating our expectations and up 22% year-over-year. Momentum for iPhone 6 and iPhone 6 Plus remained very strong across the quarter and we established a new launch record for iPhone 6s and iPhone 6s Plus near the end of the quarter.

"
column63:
"

We are seeing strong interest around the world and we\u2019ve been getting great feedback from customers who love the iPhone\u2019s new features including 3D touch
column64: live photos
column65: the new iSight camera
column66:
and the powerful new A-9 processor in the iPhone 6s and 6s Plus.

"
column67:
"

We exited the quarter with demand for our new iPhones exceeding supply but we\u2019ve made good progress with our manufacturing ramp in the initial weeks of October. We sold an all time record 5.7 million Macs continuing to defy the negative trend in the global personal computer market which IDC estimates contracted by 11%.

"
column68:
"

The App Store set new all-time quarterly records for both the number of transacting customers and overall revenue. The strong performance of the App Store helped fuel $5.1 billion in services revenue also an all-time record.

"
column69:
"

Sales of Apple Watch were also up sequentially and were ahead of our expectations. This quarter we introduced beautiful new Apple Watch cases and bands including new Gold and Rose Gold aluminum Apple Watch Sport models. We released Watch OS 2 in September paving the way for a whole new class of native apps that are faster and can take advantage of the hardware capabilities of Apple Watch such as the microphone
column70:
speaker and the heart rate sensor.

"
column71:
"

Today
column72: there are over 13
column73: 000 apps in the Watch App Store including over 1300 native apps such as Facebook messenger
column74:
MLB At Bat and Runkeeper and the number is growing rapidly.

"
column75:
"

Apple Watch has already had a tremendous effect on customers\u2019 health and fitness and the stories we\u2019re hearing about its impact are truly inspirational. I personally heard from people who credit Apple Watch with saving their lives and customers are finding new applications all the time in their day to day activities.

"
column76:
"

Revenue in Greater China nearly doubled year-over-year and we continue to focus and invest heavily there. I just returned from a four day visit to Hangzhou and Beijing where we announced major new initiatives to provide renewable energy for our supply chain. I also visited our retail stores in China which are among the busiest in the world.

"
column77:
"

On Saturday we opened a new store
column78: our 25th in Greater China to a very enthusiastic crowd and we are on track to achieve our goal of 40 stores by the middle of next year. Yesterday
column79:
we started taking orders for the all new Apple TV and it was a huge first day for this exciting new product. We want to provide the same innovation in the living room that we delivered in our iOS devices. People are already watching more TV through apps today and we think apps represent the future of TV. We\u2019ve built a new foundation around this vision with a new operating system called tvOS innovative ways to connect with your screen and a smart use of Siri to search for what to watch.

"
column80:
"

Next month

column82: the most powerful iPad we\u2019ve ever made. iPad Pro will enable a new generation of apps for entertainment and productivity
column83: design and illustration
column84: engineering and medical and much more

column86:
to business professionals.

"
column87:
"

iOS 9 has hit the ground running on track to be downloaded by more users than any software release in Apple\u2019s history with 61% of active iOS devices already running at less than six weeks after its September the 16th release.

"
column88:
"

In late September
column89: we also launched OS X El Capitan which has made the world most advanced desktop operating system more refined and powerful than ever before. Apple Music has set a completely new standard
column90: redefining and combining the best ways to enjoy music in a single immersive app. Over 15 million individual and family accounts are experiencing Apple music including over 6.5 million paying customers. We are thrilled to bring Apple Music to China beginning this quarter along with iTunes
column91:
movies and iBooks and we are especially happy to offer such great new and diverse content to our large highly engaged and rapidly growing customer base in China.

"
column92:
"

We are also looking forward to bringing Apple Music to the new Apple TV beginning this week. Apple Pay is seeing double digit growth in transaction month after month and we continue to add major businesses including Starbucks which will roll out Apple Pay support to all its U.S. stores in 2016.

"
column93:
"

Apple Pay now supports merchant rewards programs as well and popular retailers that will be coming online in the next few weeks. We are thrilled to announce today that we are partnering with American Express to bring Apple Pay to eligible customers in key global markets so even more people can experience the easy
column94:
secure and private way to pay.

"
column95:
"

Apple Pay will be available to eligible American Express customers in Australia
column96: in Canada this year and is expected to expand to Spain
column97: Singapore and Hong Kong in 2016. The reach of our ecosystem continues to grow and iOS is changing more and more aspects of our customer\u2019s lives in very meaningful ways from their health
column98: to their homes
column99:
to their cars.

"
column100:
"

In Health
column101: there are now more than 1
column102: 600 health kit enabled solutions that are helping us live a healthier day. In the home there are over 50 brands working on home kit enabled accessories that can be privately and securely controlled from your iPad and iPhone
column103: and in the car more than 50 automobile models have been announced with CarPlay support which provides a smarter
column104:
safer and more fun way to use iPhone in the car. And we will continue to work to make the iOS experience even more meaningful across more touch points of our daily lives.

"
column105:
"

The impact of research kit also continues to build. We recently announced new studies on autism
column106:
epilepsy and melanoma adding to the important studies already underway on conditions from asthma to diabetes to Parkinson\u2019s disease.

"
column107:
"

Our iOS news app is off to a great start. Nearly 40 million people are reading Apple news and we\u2019ve been getting very positive feedback from the publishers. We have now signed more than 70 publishers representing hundreds of titles and we\u2019re happy to announce that news just launched in the United Kingdom and Australia with partners such as the BBC
column108: NewsCorp
column109: The Telegraph
column110: The Guardian
column111: Financial Times
column112:
Daily Mail and the Australian Broadcasting Service.

column115: announcing a new strategic partnership with Cisco in September while furthering our progress with IBM in building our mobility partners program. We estimate that enterprise markets accounted for about $25 billion in annual Apple revenue in the last 12 months
column116:
up 40% over the prior year and they represent a major growth vector for the future.

"
column117:

I\u2019d like to thank our talented and incredibly hardworking employees
column118:
our developers and our business partners around the world and of course our very loyal customers for making 2015 Apples\u2019 most successful year yet.

With that

Luca Maestri

Thank you
column123: Tim. Good afternoon
column124: everyone. It\u2019s great to conclude our record fiscal 2015 with our strongest September quarter ever. Revenue for the quarter was $51.5 billion
column125: an increase of $9.4 billion or 22% year over year. Our growth was driven by the tremendous performance of iPhone
column126:
the expanded availability of Apple Watch and all time high services revenue and Mac sales.

column127:

column128:
"

In constant currency

our growth during the fourth quarter would have been 800 basis points higher. We once again reported very strong numbers in Greater China with revenue growing 99% year-over-year to $12.5 billion. Emerging markets performance was strong overall up 65% year-over-year and representing 31% of total company revenue for the quarter.

"
column130:
"

column133: a new September quarter record. Diluted earnings per share were $1.96

column135:
also a new fourth quarter record.

"

For details by product I'll start with iPhone. We sold 48 million iPhones in the quarter
column137:
up 22% year over year with strong performance around the world throughout the quarter. Total iPhone sales were up 120% in Mainland China and grew over 35% in South Asia and increased by over 20% in several markets around the world including Germany and Italy.

"
column138:
"

iPhone ASP was $670
column139: an increase of $67 year-over-year
column140:
thanks to more favorable mix and in spite of the very significant negative impact from foreign exchange that I referred to earlier.

"
column141:
"

We increased iPhone channel inventory by less than 2 million units in order to support our new product launch at the very end of September quarter. We exited the quarter with demand exceeding supply and channel inventory below our target range of 5 to 7 weeks.

"
column142:
"

Next I'd like to talk about the Mac. We sold 5.7 million Macs
column143:
which is an all time quarterly record and represents 3% year-over-year growth. We extended our very long running trend of PC market share gains based on IDC's latest estimate of a 11% global market contraction. Mac growth was driven primarily by the great customer response to our new MacBook and sales of MacBook Pro also remained strong. We ended the quarter below our 4 to 5 week target range for Mac channel inventory.

"
column144:
"

Turning to iPad. We sold 9.9 million compared to 12.3 million in the year-ago quarter. iPad sell-through was 10.4 million as we reduced channel inventory by about 500
column145:
000 units. We exited the quarter below our 5 to 7 week target range of iPad channel inventory.

"
column146:
"

iPad customer metrics remain extremely positive. In August
column147: ChangeWave measured a 97% consumer satisfaction rate for iPad Air 2 and among consumers planning to purchase a tablet within 90 days
column148:
70% planned to purchase an iPad. Corporate buyers reported a 95% satisfaction rate for iPad and a 90 day purchase intent of 73%.

"
column149:
"

In the segments of the tablet market where we compete

we continue to be very successful. Recent data from NPD indicates that iPad has 73% share of the U.S. market for tablets priced above $200. And the latest data published by IDC indicates that iPad has 74% share of the U.S. Commercial Tablet market.

"
column151:
"

As Tim mentioned our enterprise initiatives continue to expand. In September we announced a new strategic partnership with Cisco to optimize their networks for iOS devices with a goal of providing iOS mobile users with great performance advantage over other mobile platforms.

column156: travel and transportation and industrial sectors

column160: 000 Macs deployed within the company with 1

column162:
thanks to the much reduced support cost and better residual value. This is a terrific example of the kind of opportunity our devices offer to improve user experience and create value in the enterprise world.

"
column163:
"

Our mobility partner program also continues to grow with more than 25 new partners added in the September quarter bringing the total to over 65 and we are already seeing some great success stories with this program. We are also very excited about the potential of iPad Pro and the enterprise. For example
column164: with the Bloomberg professional app
column165: more than 325
column166: 000 financial professionals will be able to use iPad Pro to gain instant global access to finance and business news
column167:
market data and portfolio tracking and trading tools.

Turning to services. We generated $5.1 billion in revenue
column169: a new all-time record
column170: and an increase of 10% over last year mainly due to strong growth from apps. The revenue from the App Store increased 25% and the number of transacting customers grew 18%
column171: also setting an all-time record. Services growth was particularly impressive in China
column172:
where Apple App Store revenue grew by 127% year-over-year. The momentum behind the App Store in China has been tremendous with huge interest from developers and customers alike. Our developer program in China has grown dramatically in the last year with over 1 million members in our program today.

"
column173:
"

Revenue from other products grew strongly up 61% over last year
column174:
thanks to the growing contribution from Apple Watch. We expanded Apple Watch distribution significantly over the course of the quarter and it was available at almost 5000 locations in 32 countries at quarter end.

"
column175:
"

Our retail and online stores had a very busy quarter. We opened 7 new stores
column176:
including our first store in Belgium. That brought us to a global store count of 463 of which 195 are in 15 countries outside the United States.

"
column177:
"

In fiscal 2016
column178:
we expect to open or replace between 40 and 50 stores and we continue to place particular emphasis on Greater China where we plan to have 40 stores opened by the middle of next year.

column179:
"

Customers have been very interested in the iPhone upgrade program offered in our U.S. retail stores. The iPhone upgrade program gives customer purchasing a connected device an easy convenient way to get a new phone every year with low monthly payments to a third party lender along with the security and protection of AppleCare Plus.

"
column180:
"

After making 12 or more installment payments
column181: customers can upgrade to a new iPhone. Let me also quickly discuss three accounting matters. First
column182: relative to the iPhone upgrade program that I just mentioned
column183:
we will be reducing revenue at the time of sale for the cost associated with the program and deferring the portion of revenue related to AppleCare software upgrade rights and non software services for each iPhone sold.

"
column184:
"

Second
column185: in September based on an analysis of market offerings we reduced the estimated selling price of future software upgrade rights and non software services that we defer for each iOS device and Mac sold
column186:
the reduction is between $5 and $10 per unit.

"
column187:
"

Third
column188:
also in September we lengthened the time period over which the deferred revenue associated to iPads will be recognized from two years to three years.

"
column189:
"

Let me now turn to our cash position. We ended the quarter with $205.7 billion in cash plus marketable securities
column190: a sequential increase of $2.8 billion. $187 billion of this cash
column192: was outside of the United States. In the September quarter
column193: we issued a total of $5.8 billion of term debt
column194: consisting of 1.25 billion British pound denominated notes
column195:
2.25 billion Australian dollar denominated notes and 2 billion euro denominated notes.

"
column196:
"

This left us with $56 billion of term debt outstanding at the end of the quarter.

column197:

We were very active in the market during the quarter and returned over $17 billion to our investors. We paid $3 billion in dividends and equivalents and we spent $14 billion to repurchase almost 122 million Apple shares through open market transactions. We also completed our fifth accelerated share repurchase program in July and retired an additional 10 million shares at settlement.

"
column198:

We have now completed over $143 billion of our $200 billion program including $104 billion in share repurchases of which $36 billion was repurchased in fiscal 2015 alone. Now
column199: as we move ahead into December quarter
column200:
I like to review our outlook which includes the types of forward looking information that Nancy referred to at the beginning of the call. We expect revenue to be between $75.5 and $77.5 billion compared to $74.6 billion in the year ago quarter. We expect gross margin to be between 39% and 40%. We expect OpEx to be between $6.3 billion and $6.4 billion. We expect OI&E to be about $400 million and we expect the tax rate to be about 26.2%.

column349: but that protection diminishes as we go through the year and so we should expect that in over time during the course of fiscal 2016 that protection will come off assuming that the dollar stays at current levels. Keep in mind

there are some currencies around the world that where we cannot economically hedge and so those currencies are bit excluded from what we're talking about right now.

column379: in many cases the reasonable seize sales force. And in addition to a direct sales force there is a huge worldwide indirect channel that many customers buy from and count on buying some services from. And so I do not envision Apple's having a large enterprise sales force will certainly make \u2013 we continue adding some people more on the engineering side
column380:
but I don't envision having a large direct sales force.

"
column381:
"

Shannon Cross

"
column383: great. Thank you. And can you give us some more color on China
column384: 120% year-over-year growth in iPhones

but can you talk in general about what you're seeing in the marketplace and perhaps where you think you in terms of penetration from a smartphone standpoint especially with a China Mobile which has a substantial opportunity to grow given the LTE penetration?

column386:

Tim Cook

column387:
"

Yes. If you look at China

column392: we've been able to grow without the market growing. iPhone 6 was the number one selling smartphone in Mainland
column393: China last quarter and iPhone 6 Plus was number three. And so
column394: we did fairly well. The sort of the economic question which I know there's a bit lot of attention on
column395: frankly
column396: if I were to shut off my web and shut off the TV and just look how many customers are coming in our stores regardless to whether they're buying
column397: how many people are coming online
column398: and in addition looking at our sales trend
column400:
"

I wouldn't know if there was any economic issue at all in China. And so I don't know how unusual we are with that. I think that there's a misunderstanding probably particularly in the Western world about China's economy
column401: which contributes to the confusion. That said
column402: I don't think it\u2019s growing as fast as it was
column403: but I also don't think that Apple's results are largely dependent on minor changes than growth. I think it\u2019s much more of contributing \u2013 I think other things contribute to that much more. That does say
column404: you'll never had problem there
column405: because the economy
column407: I'm dumb enough to think that. But I just think that the area that it's currently operating within
column408: it's hard to tell the difference of the consumer level for us. I mean
column409: you really can't tell the difference
column410:
if you look at sort of our daily and weekly numbers.

column411:
"

So
column412: we're very bullish on it

column414: or the quarter after
column415: we're investing for the decades ahead and as we look at it our own views is that China will be Apple's top market in the world. And that's not just for sales
column416: that's also developer community is growing faster than any other country in the world. And so
column418: very strong. I was very impressed with the number the developers I met last week and of course

the customers in stores are enthusiastically contagious.

column420:
"

Nancy Paxton

column421:

column425:

column429: 33% not that a bigger number

column431:
"

Does this suggest that there is maybe more of a consistency to upgrading than the street perceives. And then on the other side in terms of new customers

column435:
"
