column436: but obviously android is the largest one by far. And so that's what that means
column437:
and that number is the largest that we've ever recorded since we began measuring it three or so years ago.

"
column439: it\u2019s a huge number
column441: very proud of that number. In terms of 2016 versus 2015 new customers
column442: it's hard to predict. I'm very happy with how we're doing. We're doing better than we've ever been doing. People -- I know there's a fixation on the upgrade rate. When I look at the upgrade rate
column444:
what I see is I feel good that it\u2019s a low number because that's low number means that there is 69% of the people that are out there prior to the iPhone 6 and 6 plus that haven't bother to upgrade this year. That's a large number.

"
column445:
"

And so
column446: I'd see that is opportunity. Do I think it has anything
column447: does to length to consistency? I think part of it is and I believe that the iPhone upgrade plans that are out there as I've mentioned before it seems to me on the future. We'll tell it\u2019s true or not
column448: but it seems to me it\u2019s going to act as a catalyst to accelerate some of this upgrades. And I think that's not something that we're going to see this quarter or next quarter
column449:
but it seems like it\u2019s going to happen beginning a year for now or so.

"
column450:
"

It have begins to be \u2013 you've seen the plan. They look more and active like a subscription than they do like a purchase. And that's great for the customer because many of them want to upgrade on a frequent basis and they can do this very
column451: very simply. In terms of new
column452: I don't know
column453: whether we'll more new or not. I can tell you that that's always our objective. We want to add a lot more people to the ecosystem and certainly if you look in the emerging markets
column454: even like

column456: in China

68% of the people that purchased an iPad it was the first tablet they've owned and 40% of those have never owned any Apple product.

column458:
"

Just to go through one product with one set of number. I don't want to get through a bunch of numbers because it does contain the data than I don't want to share. But these are things that we're very focused on. And the first time buyer number is surprisingly strong. And keep in mind that we have a good history of bunch of people buy one Apple product
column459:
they have a great experience. They begin to look at other Apple products. And of course we makes they all work well together.

Steve Milunovich

Nancy Paxton

Tim Cook

"

Let me go back to your question. And this is an exactly what you're asking that what your view

column496:
"

As you move down the line

column498:
that gives a feel for very important market and we cannot where the numbers are.

column499:
"

Simona Jankowski

"
column500:
"

Great. Thank you very much.

column501:
"

Nancy Paxton

"

"

Thank you

please?

Amit Daryanani

column508:

Thanks a lot. Good afternoon guys. Two questions from me as well. I guess
column509: first could you talk about the gross margin dynamic as you go from September to December
column510:
the midpoint implies on 20 basis points. I think the last five years that's only happen once the gross margin is going down in fiscal Q1. Can you just talk about what the FX dynamic or what area the other headwinds that you think that implies gross margins being done in December?

"
column511:
"

Tim Cook

"
column512:
"

Yes. Let me give you puts and takes for margins for the December quarter. On the positive side
column513:
of course as you mentioned that we would have positive leverage from the higher seasonal volumes. Also what we've seen over the last several quarters is a commodity environment that has been quite favorable and we expect it to remain favorable during the December quarter.

"
column514:
"

On the other hand
column515: of course we are launching a lot of new products. We\u2019ve launched some during September. We are launching some now and everything we launch new products
column516: we make them better. We had features and new technology and these products when we launch and tend to have higher cost structures than the products what they replaced. We have a very good track record overtime to reduce those cost structures
column517:
but every time we introduce a new product that is a headwind at the beginning of the cycle for gross margin.

"
column518:
"

While it\u2019s different from a year ago very significantly with the foreign exchange impact that we have mentioned before it remains a very significant headwind as I mentioned earlier to Tony I believe we are dealing with that to a combination of hedging
column519: price realignments [ph] cost initiatives
column520:
but on a net basis foreign exchange we will clearly by a sequential headwind.

"
column521:
"

Amit Daryanani

"
column522:
"

Got it. And then Tim when you talk about seeing iPhone growth in fiscal Q1
column523:
I\u2019m curious is that statement more reflective of iPhone units or iPhone revenues so that the ASPs could hardly get growth even if units are not there. And then would you expect to exit within the 5 to 7 week optimal inventory range in fiscal Q1?

column524:
"

Tim Cook

"
column525:
"

I don\u2019t know that we will exit. We make that call late in the quarter as we see what the demand is because we are actually trying to position the inventory for the following quarter instead of the current quarter. And it\u2019s very difficult to predict. What was your other question?

"
column526:
"

Amit Daryanani

"
column527:
"

I was just curious to your statement on iPhone growth in fiscal Q1
column528:
is that a reflection of\u2026.

"
column529:
"

Tim Cook

"
column530:
"

Is it revenue? I was making a revenue statement but units are also
column531:
yes we expect units to be up as well.

"
column532:
"

Amit Daryanani

"
column533:
"

Thank you.

"
column534:
"

Tim Cook

"
column535:
"

Yes.

"
column536:
"

Nancy Paxton

"
column538:
Amit. Can we have the next question please?

"
column540:
"

From JPMorgan we\u2019ll go to Rod Hall.

"
column541:
"

Rod Hall

"
column542:
"

Yes thanks for taking my question. I just wanted to ask Tim maybe if you could comment on the mix between iPhone 6 and iPhone 6s. And whether the mix of demand is any different than what you say for instance that the iPhone 5
column543: 5s point whether there is more say iPhone 6
column544:
I know you highlighted that the iPhone 6 is a number one phone in China for example and then I have a follow up?

"
column546:
"

The statement I made in China was about Q4 and the 6s was only available in China for two days last quarter. The iPhone 6s is the most popular iPhone that we currently sell. In terms of has there been a change. If you look at iPhone 6 today
column547: and add iPhone 6 Plus and compare that to last year\u2019s 5s we are doing better
column548:
at that price point than we were previously.

"
column549:
"

Rod Hall

"

Okay
column551: thank you. And then there\u2019s follow up for what you were doing on the upgrade program. I am wondering if can you envision a time ever made in the U.S. or elsewhere where you would not have to come into an Apple store to activate it or to take advantage of the upgrade you might be able to do that somewhere else
column552:
do you start now what your\u2026.

"
column554:
"

That\u2019s a really good question. We actually solved that problem back in 2007. But then quickly had to change it in order to scale in a major way. And so that is something that we would always -- sort of always in our mind that one day from a customer experience point of view we would like to make things as easy as possible for the customer.

"
column555:
"

And to some degree you can already do that with buying online. But there are many different plans and search what the people buy
column556: that they have to come in for several times we would love to have that automated and working with our partners
column558:
"

Rod Hall

"
column559:
"

Great. Thank you very much.

column560:

Tim Cook

column561:

Yes.

A - Nancy Paxton

column1:
{"Apple's (AAPL) CEO Tim Cook On Q1 2016 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Apple Inc. (NASDAQ:AAPL)

"
column2:
"

Q1 2016 Results Earnings Conference Call

"
column10:
"

Luca Maestri - CFO

"
column15:
"

Toni Sacconaghi - Sanford C. Bernstein

"
column23: ladies and gentlemen
column24:
and welcome to this Apple Incorporated First Quarter Fiscal Year 2016 Earnings Release Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded.

"
column27: I would like to turn the call over to Nancy Paxton
column28: Senior Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead
column30:
"

Nancy Paxton

"
column31:
"

Thank you. Good afternoon and thanks for joining us. Before we begin
column32: we want you to know that in addition to our press release and summary data schedule
column33: we've published some supplemental material that we'll be referring to in our remarks today and you can find a link to this supplemental material on our Investor Relations' website
column34:
at apple.com/investor. And it's also included as an exhibit in the Form 8-K we filed with the SEC earlier today.

"
column35:
"

Speaking first today is Apple CEO
column37: and he will be followed by CFO
column38: Luca Maestri and after that
column39:
we'll open the call to questions from analysts.

"
column40:
"

Please note that some of the information you'll hear during our discussion today will consist of forward-looking statements
column41: including
column46: other income and expense
column47:
taxes and future business outlook.

"
column48:
"

Actual results or trends could differ materially from our forecasts. For more information
column49: please refer to the risk factors discussed in Apple's Form 10-K for 2015 and the Form 8-K filed with the SEC today that I mentioned earlier
column50:
along with today's press release. Apple assumes no obligation to update any forward-looking statements or information which speaks as of their respective dates.

"
column51:
"

I'd now like to turn the call over to Tim for introductory remarks.

"
column52:
"

Tim Cook

"
column53:
"

Thanks
column54: Nancy
column55: and good afternoon
column56: everyone
column57: and thank you very much for joining us. Today
column58: we're reporting Apple's strongest financial results ever. We generated all-time record quarterly revenue of $75.9 billion in the December quarter
column59:
in line with our expectations and up 2% over last year's blockbuster results.

"
column60:
"

This is a huge accomplishment for our company
column61: especially given the turbulent world around us. In constant currency
column62:
our growth rate would have been 8%. Our record revenue and continued strong operating performance also led to an all-time record quarterly net income of $18.4 billion.

"
column63:
"

We sold 74.8 million iPhones in the December quarter
column64: an all-time high. To put that volume into perspective
column65: it's an average of over 34
column66: 000 iPhones an hour
column67: 24 hours a day
column68:
seven days a week for 13 straight weeks. It's almost 50% more than our Q1 volume just two years ago and more than four times our volume five years ago.

"
column69:
"

74.8 million iPhones is an incredible number and it speaks to both the immense popularity of iPhone and the phenomenal execution of our teams to deliver a massive number of devices in such a short period of time.

"
column70:
"

Our results are particularly impressive
column71:
given the challenging global macroeconomic environment. We're seeing extreme conditions unlike anything we've experienced before just about everywhere we look.

"
column72:
"

Major markets
column73: including Brazil
column74: Russia
column75: Japan
column76: Canada
column77: Southeast Asia
column78: Australia
column79: Turkey and the eurozone
column80: have been impacted by slowing economic growth
column81:
falling commodity prices and weakening currencies.

"
column82:
"

Since the end of fiscal 2014
column83: for instance
column84: the euro and British pound are down double-digits
column85: and major currencies such as the Canadian dollar
column86: Australian dollar
column87: Mexican peso
column88:
and Turkish lira have declined 20% or more. The Brazilian real is down more than 40% and the Russian ruble has declined more than 50%.

"
column89:
"

66% of Apple's revenue is now generated outside the United States
column90:
so foreign currency fluctuations have a very meaningful impact on our results. Page one of our supplemental material illustrates this point.

"
column91:
"

$100 of Apple's non-U.S. dollar revenue in Q4 of 2014 translated to only $85 last quarter due to the weakening currencies in our international markets. As you can see
column92: the movement has been dramatic. Last quarter alone
column93:
the currency impact has been very large.

"
column94:
"

Page two of our supplemental material illustrates our Q1 revenue and growth rates expressed in constant currency. The 8% growth rate I spoke about earlier translates to $80.8 billion in constant currency revenue
column95: which is $5 billion more than our reported revenue. For perspective
column96:
that difference is about the size of the annual revenue of a Fortune 500 company.

"
column97:
"

We know the conditions in China have been a source of concern for many investors. Last summer
column98: while many companies were experiencing weakness in their China-based results
column99: we were seeing just the opposite
column100: with incredible momentum for iPhone
column101: Mac and the App Store
column102:
in particular.

"
column103:
"

In the December quarter
column104: despite the turbulent environment
column105: we produced our best results ever in Greater China
column106: with revenue growing 14% over last year
column107: 47% sequentially
column108:
and 17% year-over-year in constant currency. These great results were fueled by our highest ever quarterly iPhone sales and record App Store performance.

"
column109:
"

Notwithstanding these record results
column110: we began to see some signs of economic softness in Greater China earlier this month
column111: most notably in Hong Kong. Beyond the short-term volatility
column112:
we remain very confident about the long-term potential of the China market and the large opportunities ahead of us and we are maintaining our investment plans.

"
column113:
"

Despite the economic challenges all over the world
column114: Apple remains incredibly strong. We have a very satisfied and loyal customer base. We saw a greater number of switchers from Android to iPhone than ever in Q1
column115:
and we are very optimistic about our business over the long-term.

"
column116:
"

Innovation has always been the reason behind our success and we remain committed to making the best products in the world and expanding the Apple experience to change our customer's lives in better and more meaningful ways.

"
column117:
"

We've invested through economic uncertainty in the past and we've always come out stronger on the other side. In fact
column118: some of the most important breakthrough products in Apple's history were born as a result of investing through the downturn. We've also seen these times as opportunities to invest in new markets
column119:
just as we're doing now in areas such as India and other emerging markets.

"
column120:
"

Getting back to our record Q1 performance
column121: let me give you some highlights of what we've accomplished since our last quarterly call together. We shipped the amazing new iPad Pro
column122:
which has been extremely well received by customers along with a new smart keyboard and revolutionary Apple Pencil.

"
column123:
"

We launched the all-new Apple TV with its own App Store
column124: laying the foundation for the future of television. We had our best quarter by far for Apple TV sales and the number of apps developed for Apple TV is growing rapidly. Today there are over 3
column125:
600 apps delivering everything from games to entertainment to educational programming.

"
column126:
"

We expanded distribution of Apple Watch to almost 12
column127: 000 locations in 48 countries during the quarter. As we expected
column128: we set a new quarterly record for Apple Watch sales
column129:
with especially strong sales in the month of December.

"
column130:
"

We released OS X El Capitan
column131:
refining the experience and improving performance for our Mac customers. We also updated the entire iMac family with stunning new retina displays and introduced a new line up of wireless accessories.

"
column132:
"

We launched Apple Pay in Canada and Australia with American Express and announced plans to bring this amazingly convenient
column133: private
column134: and secure mobile payment experience to China
column135: Hong Kong
column136:
Spain and Singapore in the coming year.

"
column137:
"

Consumers have spent billions of dollars with Apple Pay. In the second half of 2015
column138: we saw a significant acceleration in usage
column139:
with a growth rate 10 times higher than in the first half of the year.

"
column140:
"

There are now over 5 million contactless payment ready locations in the countries where Apple Pay is live today and it's soon to be accepted at thousands of Exxon and Mobil branded stations across the U.S. via their Speedpass+ app.

"
column141:
"

Finally
column142: we also shared the incredible Apple Music experience with even more listeners
column143:
with over 10 million paying subscribers less than four months since customers began paying for the service.

"
column144:
"

Our financial position has never been stronger. We had the mother of all balance sheets
column145: with almost $216 billion in cash
column146:
which translates to nearly $39 per diluted share of Apple stock. We continue to invest confidently in our future and we also continue to return capital to our shareholders at a rapid pace.

"
column147:
"

Our investors have been asking for a while about the recurring nature of our business. Especially during a period of economic uncertainty
column148:
we believe it is important to appreciate that a significant portion of Apple's revenue recurs over time.

"
column149:
"

First and foremost
column150: our customer satisfaction and retention rates are second to none and provide us with a long lasting foundation. For example
column151: recent consumer surveys by 451 Research
column152: formerly known as ChangeWave
column153:
measured an incredible 99% customer satisfaction rate for iPhone 6S and 6S Plus and an equally impressive 97% rate for the iPad Air 2. They also indicate that our iPhone loyalty rate is almost twice as strong as the next highest brand.

"
column154:
"

In addition
column155: a growing portion of our revenue is directly driven by our existing install base. Because our customers are very satisfied and engaged
column156: they spend a lot of time on their devices and purchase apps
column157: content
column158:
and other services.

"
column159:
"

They also are very likely to buy other Apple products or replace the one that they own. And because of the enduring value of the device
column160:
their replacing is likely higher to be given or sold to someone who will also love and use it often.

"
column161:
"

So
column162: as a result
column163: our install base has been growing very fast and has recently reached a major milestone
column164: crossing 1 billion active devices for the first time. This is an unbelievable asset for us. Because our install base has grown quickly
column165: we have also seen an acceleration in the growth of our services business
column166:
another large and important source of recurring revenues.

"
column167:
"

Now that we have reached this milestone of 1 billion active devices
column168:
we felt this would be a great opportunity to share more information on what has become one of the largest service businesses in the world.

"
column169:
"

So now
column170: I'd like to turn the call to Luca
column171: who will provide more insight into how our platform has grown
column172:
followed by details on our record quarterly results.

"
column173:
"

Luca Maestri

"
column174:
"

Thank you
column175: Tim
column176: and good afternoon
column177: everyone. Each quarter
column178: we report results for our Services category
column179: which includes revenue from iTunes
column180: the App Store
column181: AppleCare
column182: iCloud
column183: Apple Pay
column184: licensing
column185: and some other items. Today
column186: we would like to highlight the major drivers of growth in this category
column187:
which we have summarized on page three of our supplemental material.

"
column188:
"

The vast majority of the services we provide to our customers
column189: for instance
column190: apps
column192: are tied to our installed base of devices
column193:
rather than to current quarter sales.

"
column194:
"

For some of these services
column195: such as content
column196: we recognize revenue based on transaction value. For some of the services
column197: such as the App Store
column198:
we share a portion of the value of each transaction with the app developer and only recognize revenue on the portion that we keep.

"
column199:
"

To fully comprehend the scale of the services that we are delivering to our installed base and how fast this business is growing
column200: we look at purchases in addition to revenue. When we aggregate the purchase value of services tied to our installed base during fiscal 2015
column201:
it adds up to more than $31 billion. That's an increase of 23% over fiscal 2014.

"
column202:
"

In the recent December quarter
column203: purchases of installed base services reached $8.9 billion
column204:
which is a growth rate of 24% year-over-year.

"
column205:
"

The size and growth of these services tied to our installed base compare favorably to other services companies you're familiar with. Our installed base services are also quite profitable
column206: with gross margins that
column207: on a purchase value basis
column208:
are similar to our company average.

"
column209:
"

Also
column210: we're very excited by the scale and growth of our active installed base
column211:
as we indicate on page four. We define an active device as one that has been engaged with our services within the past 90 days. Our active installed base has recently past 1 billion devices with year-over-year growth of more than 25%.

"
column212:
"

Apple is in a unique position of strength. We have world class scales in hardware
column213: software and services all under one roof
column214:
which lets us innovate in ways that other companies can't.

"
column215:
"

We have built a huge installed base around four platforms
column216: iOS
column217: Mac OS
column218:
watchOS and tvOS. We have tremendously satisfied and loyal customers who are engaged with our services at a fast growing rate. All of this provides us with an unparalleled foundation for the future of Apple business.

"
column219:
"

Let me now turn to the details of our record breaking December quarter. As Tim said
column220: revenue was $75.9 billion
column221: an increase of $1.3 billion or 2% year-over-year. Our growth was driven by all-time record iPhone sales
column222: all-time record revenue from services
column223: the expanded availability of Apple Watch
column224:
and the successful launch of the new Apple TV.

"
column225:
"

We achieved this record revenue performance despite a very large negative impact from the weakness of foreign currency and in constant currency; our revenue growth rate was 8%.

"
column226:
"

We once again achieved very impressive results in Greater China
column227: with revenue growing 14% year-over-year and 47% sequentially to an all-time record of $18.4 billion. Emerging markets performance was strong overall
column228:
up 11% year-over-year and representing 34% of total company revenue for the quarter.

"
column229:
"

Company gross margin was 40.1%
column230: up sequentially and better than our expectations
column231:
mainly due to favorable commodity costs and product mix.

"
column232:
"

Operating margin was 31.9% of revenue and net income was $18.4 billion
column233: a new all-time record. Diluted earnings per share was $3.28
column234: a 7% year-over-year increase over our previous all-time record and cash flow from operations was very strong
column235:
at $27.5 billion.

"
column236:
"

For details by product
column237: I will start with iPhone. We sold 74.8 million iPhones in the quarter
column239: 000 compared to last December quarter's sensational results. Total iPhone sales grew 76% in India and more than 45% in Korea
column240:
Middle East and Africa.

"
column241:
"

Sales were also up 20% or more in many western European countries and grew 18% in Mainland China. iPhone ASP was $691 compared to $687 in the year ago quarter
column242:
in spite of a very unfavorable foreign exchange impact.

"
column243:
"

We continue to see very strong interest in iPhone not only with consumers but also with business users. Among corporate buyers planning to purchase smartphones in the March quarter
column244:
451 Research found that 79% planned to purchase iPhones. That is the highest iPhone purchase intent in the eight-year history of the survey.

"
column245:
"

We started the quarter below our channel inventory target range and thanks to an extremely successful manufacturing ramp; we were able to exit the quarter slightly above the low end of our target range of five to seven weeks of iPhone channel inventory.

"
column246:
"

Next
column247: I'd like to talk about the Mac. We sold 5.3 million Macs compared to 5.5 million last year
column248: a decline of 4%. We continued our long running trend of PC market share gains
column249: based on IDC's latest estimate of an 11% global market contraction
column250:
and we were especially happy with 27% year-over-year Mac sales growth in Mainland China. We ended the quarter within our four to five-week target range for Mac channel inventory.

"
column252: we sold 16.1 million
column253: compared to 21.4 million in the year ago quarter
column254:
and we exited the quarter within our five to seven-week target range of iPad channel inventory.

"
column255:
"

In the segments of the tablet market where we compete
column256: we continue to be highly successful. Recent data from NPD indicates that iPad has 85% share of the U.S. market for tablets priced above $200. And the latest data published by IDC indicates that iPad accounts for 67% of the U.S. commercial tablet market comprising enterprise
column257: government
column258:
and education.

"
column259:
"

iPad customer metrics are also extremely positive. In November
column260: 451 Research measured a 97% consumer satisfaction rate for iPad Air 2 and among consumers planning to purchase a tablet within the next six months
column261:
65% plan to purchase an iPad. Corporate buyers reported a 95% satisfaction rate for iPad and a March quarter purchase intent of 73%.

"
column262:
"

Our enterprise initiatives continue to expand. IBM released 48 new IBM MobileFirst for iOS apps in the December quarter and there are now over 100 apps in the IBM MobileFirst for iOS catalog for iPhone
column263:
iPad and Apple Watch.

"
column264:
"

Our partnership with Cisco has gained significant momentum since we announced it at the end of August. Our engineering teams are on track to deliver exciting new capabilities that create a fast lane for iOS business users by optimizing Cisco networks for iOS devices and apps
column265:
integrate iPhone with Cisco enterprise environments and provide unique collaboration opportunities on iPhone and iPad.

"
column266:
"

We are also continuing to grow our mobility partner program. We added more than 25 partners in the December quarter
column267: bringing the total to over 90. One great example of our progress in the enterprise is Eli Lilly
column268: who boosted sales productivity by equipping 15
column269: 000 field based personnel across the world with iPad. A leader in mobile technology
column270:
Lilly has eliminated laptops in the field and is upgrading its U.S. field sales teams to iPad Pro.

"
column271:
"

Turning to services
column272: we generated almost $6.1 billion in revenue
column273: including $548 million we received from a patent infringement dispute. Excluding that amount
column274: our services revenue was $5.5 billion
column275: a new all-time record and an increase of 15% over last year
column276:
thanks in large part to strong growth from apps.

"
column277:
"

Revenue from the App Store increased 27% and the number of transacting customers grew 18%
column278: also setting an all-time record. Among our customers who purchased apps and content from our iTunes stores
column279:
the average amount spent per customer reached an all-time high in the December quarter.

"
column280:
"

Revenue from other products grew strongly
column281: up 62% over last year
column282: thanks to the growing contribution from Apple Watch
column283: as well as the successful launch of the new Apple TV
column284:
both of which established new all-time quarterly records. We expanded Apple Watch distribution significantly over the course of the quarter and we experienced especially strong results during the holiday buying season.

"
column285:
"

Let me now turn to our cash position. We ended the quarter with $215.7 billion in cash plus marketable securities
column286:
a sequential increase of $10.1 billion. $200 billion of this cash or 93% of the total was outside the United States.

"
column287:
"

We returned over $9 billion to investors during the quarter. We paid $3 billion in dividends and equivalents and we spent $3 billion to repurchase 26 million Apple shares through open market transactions. We also launched our sixth accelerated share repurchase program
column288:
spending $3 billion and receiving an initial delivery of 20.4 million shares.

"
column289:
"

We have now completed over $153 billion of our $200 billion program
column290: including $110 billion in share repurchases. As we have done in the past
column291:
we plan to provide an update on our capital return program when we report our second quarter results in April.

"
column292:
"

We also plan to be very active in the U.S. and international debt markets in 2016
column293: in order to fund our capital return activities. Also today
column294: our Board of Directors has declared a cash dividend of $0.52 per share of common stock payable on February 11
column296: to shareholders of record as of February 8
column298:
"

As we move ahead into the March quarter
column299: I'd like to review our outlook
column300:
which includes the types of forward-looking information that Nancy referred to at the beginning of the call.

"
column301:
"

We expect revenue to be between $50 billion and $53 billion. We are providing a wider range for revenue than usual for the second quarter because of the volatility we are seeing in the economy and in the financial and currency markets.

"
column302:
"

We expect gross margin to be between 39% and 39.5%. We believe these are extremely strong margins in light of the headwinds we face from foreign exchange and the sequential loss of leverage. We expect OpEx to be between $6 billion and $6.1 billion
column303: we expect OI&E to be about $325 million
column304:
and we expect the tax rate to be about 25.5%.

"
column305:
"

As you know
column306: we don't provide guidance beyond the current quarter and it's difficult for us to forecast economic and foreign exchange factors; however
column307: at this point
column308:
we believe the March quarter faces the most difficult year-over-year compare relative to the rest of the year.

column576:
"

We do believe that this
column577: too
column578:
shall pass and that these countries will be great places and we want to serve customers in there and so we're not retrenching. That's not -- we don't believe in that. We fortunately are strong enough to continue investing and we think it's in Apple's best long-term interest to do so.

"
column579:
"

Obviously
column580: from a cost point of view
column581: the downside of economic stress is that some asset prices get cheaper
column583:
and that sort of thing. And so I think this is exactly the period that you want to invest and do so confidently.

"
column584:
"

Shannon Cross

"
column585:
"

Thank you.

"
column586:
"

Nancy Paxton

"
column587:
"

Thank you
column588:
Shannon. Could we have the next question please?

"
column589:
"

Operator

"
column590:
"

We'll hear from Steve Milunovich with UBS.

"
column591:
"

Nancy Paxton

"
column592:
"

Steve
column593:
are you there?

column595:
"

Steve?

"
column596:
"

Nancy Paxton

"
column597:
"

Let's go on to the next question please.

column598:
"

Operator

And we'll hear from Brian White with Drexel.

column600:
"

Brian White

"
column602: could you talk a little bit about the next leg of growth in China? Obviously
column603: Apple has done a phenomenal job there
column604: but where do we see the next leg coming from? And also
column605: you mentioned investing in India. Where do you see that over the next two to three years? I think there's 1 billion mobile subscribers there
column606:
almost the size of China. Thank you.

"
column607:
"

Tim Cook

"
column608:
"

Yeah. Brian
column609: good question. In terms of China
column610: the LTE penetration as of the end of last October
column611: which is the last data I've got
column612:
was in the mid-20s. And so there's an enormous upgrade cycle there for people that are still running on 3G handsets.

"
column613:
"

Also
column614: I've talked about this before
column615: but I think it's worth mentioning again
column616: because it's easy to lose perspective with some of the things you read every day
column617: is that the middle-class in China was less than 50 million people in 2010
column619:
it's projected to be about half a billion.

"
column620:
"

And so there's just an enormous number of people moving into the middle-class. And we think this provides us a great opportunity to win over some of those customers into the Apple ecosystem.

"
column621:
"

And so I think the demographics are great. We're continuing to invest in retail stores. Angela and her team have been on this very aggressive rollout plan. We now have 28 stores in Greater China and we're on target to have 40 in the summertime of this year.

"
column622:
"

And so we're continuing on distribution. Obviously
column623:
we've got product things in mind and are crafting our products and services with China heavily in mind. We remain very bullish on China and don't subscribe to the doom and gloom kind of predictions frankly.

"
column625: India is also incredibly exciting. India's growth
column627: is very good. It's quickly becoming the fastest growing BRIC country. It's the third largest smartphone market in the world
column628:
behind China and the United States.

"
column629:
"

The population of India is incredibly young. The median age there is 27. I think of the China age being young
column631:
37 and so 27 is unbelievable. Almost half the people in India are below 25. And so I see the demographics there also being incredibly great for a consumer brand and for people that really want the best products.

"
column633: we've been putting increasingly more energy in India. India revenue for us in Q1 was up 38%. We also had currency issues in India
column634:
as everybody else did. Constant currency growth was 48%.

"
column635:
"

And so it's a very rapidly expanding country. And I think the government there is very interested economic reforms and so forth that I think all speak to a really good business environment for the future.

"
column643:
Brian. Could we have the next question please?

"
column645:
"

We'll hear from Kulbinder Garcha with Credit Suisse.

"
column647:
"

Thank you. My question's for Tim on the iPhone business. You talk a lot about the macroeconomic weakness weighing on units
column648: but is some of the issue just that last year replacement got accelerated and this year it's kind of normalizing
column649: and that's kind of a one-time headwind in terms of the unit growth that you see in that business. Is any of that going on
column652:
"

And the other follow-up I had was that you've mentioned in recent calls
column655: prior to when the 6 came out
column656:
that were now on the larger screen phones. Can you give us an update on what that number is? I think the last time it was in the low 30s. Thanks.

"
column659: last question first. The number of people who had an iPhone prior to the iPhone 6 and 6 Plus announcements -- and so this was in September of 2014 that have not yet upgraded to a 6
column660: 6 Plus or 6s or 6s Plus is now 60%. So
column661: another way to think about that is 40% have
column663:
"

In terms of your initial question about is there some of the compare issue that are people that ran out quickly to buy a 6 and 6 Plus and sort of accelerated? There is no doubt that we had a unbelievable year last year and the Q2 was particularly really
column664:
really strong because of the pent-up demand that left from Q1 in addition to Q2. And so there's no doubt about that.

"
column666: I think you can tell from the numbers that Luca is talking about just on the currency side and that's before thinking through the affect that price increases can sometimes have on the business over a period of time
column667:
it's clear that the economic piece is large.

"
column672:
Kulbinder. Could we have the next question please?

"
column674:
"

And next we'll hear from Steve Milunovich with UBS. Mr. Milunovich
column675:
you may want to check your mute button.

column680:
"

column682:
"

column684:
"

Yes. Thank you. Good afternoon. A question and a follow-up. As far as the question
column686: I wanted to get a better sense from you in terms of what is the overarching message of introducing a little more details here around services. Is this really to just reinforce the power of the franchise or the platform at Apple in terms of to really navigate tougher macro times in terms of the higher level recurring revenue
column687: or is it a stepping stone to much more in terms of Apple service
column688: i.e. I think of all the stuff you do on the data center side. Could we eventually have seen
column689:
with the help of IBM and Cisco that you eventually move more into the cloud services for the enterprise?

"
column692: good question. We started breaking out services
column694: in the beginning of fiscal year 2015. And as that business has grown and as it became clear to us that the investors wanted -- investors and analysts wanted more visibility into that business
column695: we've now elected to break it out and show the full size
column698:
and make comments on the profitability of it from a transparency point of view.

"
column699:
"

I do think that the assets that we have in this area are huge and I do think that it's probably something that the investment community would want to and should focus more on.

"
column700:
"

In terms of our future plans
column701: I wouldn't want to comment about any particular thing
column704:
we wouldn't be breaking it out if it wasn't an area that was very important to us in the future.

"
column710:
"

And I wanted to follow-up on the upgrade advance program dynamics. Can you talk a little more about what you're seeing in terms of in-store at the Apple Stores? Are you seeing any sort of dislocation in terms of folks who are moving to the upgrade or finance program
column711:
are they moving more toward Apple versus maybe the in-store percentage that used to be related to the carriers?

"
column713: are folks just going with Apple now
column716:
as part of these upgrade programs?

"
column720: this has nothing to do with wanting to move customers from one person to another. This has to do with wanting to provide customers a very simple way to upgrade. Because we serve a significant number of customers in the Apple Store who want the iPhone when it's new and when it comes out
column721: and so we've designed a program that made it simple and easy to do that. I have no idea over time how the percentage of the sales will vary between carriers and the Apple retail store
column722:
but that's not our overriding objective.

"
column724:
"

Okay. Thank you. Good afternoon.

"
column727:
Mark. We have time for one more question.

"
column729:
"

And your final question will come from Jim Suva with Citi.

"
column731:
"

Thank you very much. A question for Tim and then a detail follow-up for Luca. Tim
column733: a lot of CEOs view that and their strategy is very different go-to-market strategy
column734: some change the way they go to market
column737: Apple's been very known in always having a premium product. With the slowdown in the macro FX and also GDP revision
column738: is Apple's strategy go-to-market still always at premium product
column739: or is there a need to go to more also a middle market or lower price point to attract more customers? Just because it seems like growing that installed base and services
column741:
really economically could really help out Apple in the long-term.

"
column742:
"

And then the financial question for Luca is on that patent litigation
column744: when you gave guidance three months ago
column745: did you have a view that that was coming in? And if so
column746: was that included in the guidance or not
column747:
or was that post the quarter guidance?

"
column748:
"

And I assume it's all one-time this quarter you recorded it
column750:
and then we don't cause that to reoccur again going forward. Thank you very much.

"
column752:
"

Our strategy is always to make the best products. And that -- for the smartphone market
column753:
that we are able to provide though several different price points for our customers. We have the premium part of our line is the 6s and the 6s Plus.

"
column754:
"

We also have a mid-price point
column755:
with the iPhone 6 and the iPhone 6 Plus. And we continue to offer the iPhone 5s in the market and it continues to do quite well. And so we offer all of those and I don't see us deviating from that approach.

"
column756:
"

We always want to offer somebody the -- not -- we don't design to a certain price point. We design a great product and we make it priced at a great value. And today
column757:
we're able to offer all three of those different iPhone options.

"
column762: obviously this is a one-off item that affected the December quarter. As I said earlier
column765:
our gross margin would have been 39.7%. It will not repeat going forward.

"
column766:
"

To your question around was it included in the guidance
column768: the probability of receiving the amount was incorporated in the development of the guidance range. If you remember
column770:
and that number was included within the range.

"
column772:
"

Thank you very much gentlemen.

"

column1:
{"Apple (AAPL) Timothy Donald Cook on Q2 2016 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Apple
column9:
"

Timothy Donald Cook - Chief Executive Officer & Director

"
column10:
"

Luca Maestri - Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President

"
column12:
"

Simona K. Jankowski - Goldman Sachs & Co.

"
column13:
"

Eugene Charles Munster - Piper Jaffray & Co (Broker)

"
column14:
"

Kathryn Lynn Huberty - Morgan Stanley & Co. LLC

"
column16:
Jr. - Sanford C. Bernstein & Co. LLC

"
column17:
"

Shannon S. Cross - Cross Research LLC

"
column18:
"

Steven M. Milunovich - UBS Securities LLC

"
column19:
"

Rod B. Hall - JPMorgan Securities LLC

"
column23:
and welcome to the Apple Incorporated second quarter fiscal year 2016 earnings release conference call. Today's call is being recorded.

"
column24:
"

At this time for opening remarks and introductions
column25: I would like to turn the call over to Nancy Paxton
column26: Senior Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead
column28:
"

Nancy Paxton - Senior Director
column30:
"

Thank you. Good afternoon and thanks to everyone for joining us today. Speaking first is Apple CEO Tim Cook
column31: and he'll be followed by CFO Luca Maestri. After that
column32:
we'll open the call to questions from analysts.

"
column33:
"

Please note that some of the information you'll hear during our discussion today will consist of forward-looking statements
column34: including without limitation those regarding revenue
column38: taxes
column40: and plans for capital return and debt issuance. Actual results or trends could differ materially from our forecast. For more information
column41: please refer to the risk factors discussed in Apple's Form 10-K for 2015
column42: the Form 10-Q for the first quarter of fiscal 2016
column43: and the Form 8-K filed with the SEC today along with the associated press release. Apple assumes no obligation to update any forward-looking statements or information
column44:
which speak as of their respective dates.

"
column46: today's comments will refer to a metric we describe as the purchase value of services tied to our installed base. This is a non-GAAP measure
column47:
and a reconciliation to the corresponding GAAP measure can be found on our Investor Relations website at Apple.com/investor.

"
column48:
"

I'd now like to turn the call over to Tim for introductory remarks.

"
column49:
"

Timothy Donald Cook - Chief Executive Officer & Director

"
column50:
"

Thanks
column51: Nancy. Good afternoon
column52: everyone
column53: and thank you for joining us. Today we're reporting the results of a very busy and challenging quarter
column54:
and we're also announcing an update to our capital return program.

"
column55:
"

Revenue for the quarter was $50.6 billion
column56: which was within our guidance range. Despite the pause in our growth
column57: our results reflect excellent execution by our team in the face of ongoing macroeconomic headwinds in much of the world and difficult year-over-year comparisons. We saw continued currency weakness in the vast majority of our international markets. In constant currency
column58: our revenue declined by 9% from last year
column59: 400 basis points less than the reported decline of 13%. For the first half of the fiscal year
column60:
our revenue in constant currency was up 1% year on year.

"
column61:
"

Despite challenges
column62: there were a number of encouraging signs during the quarter. Our installed base of over 1 billion active devices continued to grow strongly. We added a huge number of Android switchers and new-to-Mac customers
column63: and we generated very strong growth from Services. We sold 51.2 million iPhones in the quarter
column64:
consistent with the range of our own expectations but lower than the exceptional year-ago quarter when we saw an acceleration in iPhone upgrades and 40% iPhone sales growth over the previous year.

"
column65:
"

To provide some additional color
column66:
iPhone sales come from three sources: customers who upgrade from previous iPhone models; customers who switch from Android and other operating systems; and customers who purchase a smartphone for the first time.

"
column67:
"

As we look at each of these three sources of iPhone sales
column68: we see a business that is healthy and strong. First
column69: from an upgrade perspective
column70: during the first half of this year the upgrade rate for the iPhone 6s cycle has been slightly higher than what we experienced in the iPhone 5s cycle two years ago
column71: but it is lower than the accelerated upgrade rate that we saw with iPhone 6
column72: which as you know was a big contributor to our phenomenal revenue growth a year ago. Most importantly
column73: our customers are incredibly loyal. A recent Kantar survey of U.S. smartphone purchasers indicated a 95% iPhone loyalty rate
column74:
the highest ever measured for any smartphone.

"
column75:
"

Second
column76: we continue to see a very high level of customers switching to iPhone from Android and other operating systems. In fact
column77:
we added more switchers from Android and other platforms in the first half of this year than any other six-month period ever.

"
column78:
"

And third
column79: with only 42% smartphone penetration of the global handset market today
column80: iPhone is still attracting millions of first-time smartphone buyers each quarter
column81: especially from emerging markets. For example
column82:
in India our iPhone sales were up 56% from a year ago.

"
column83:
"

Next I'd like to talk about Services
column84: which was our second largest revenue-generating category during the quarter. Setting aside the amount we received from a patent settlement in the December quarter
column85: the March quarter Services revenue was our highest ever. Services revenue jumped 20% to $6 billion. App Store revenue was up 35% to beat last quarter's all-time record. And Apple Music continues to grow in popularity
column86: with over 13 million paying subscribers today. We feel really great about the early success of Apple's first subscription business
column87:
and our Music revenue has now hit an inflection point after many quarters of decline.

"
column88:
"

The Services business is powered by our huge installed base of active devices
column89: which crossed 1 billion units earlier this year. As we discussed on this call in January
column90: those 1 billion-plus active devices are a source of recurring revenue that is growing independent of the unit shipments we report every three months. In fact
column91: the purchase value of services tied to our installed base was a record $9.9 billion in the March quarter
column92: up 27% over last year
column93:
accelerating from the 24% growth rate we reported in the December quarter.

"
column94:
"

The reach of Apple Pay also continues to expand following a very successful launch in China in the March quarter and last week's rollout in Singapore. Apple Pay is growing at a tremendous rate
column95: with more than five times the transaction volume of a year ago and 1 million new users per week. There are more than 10 million contactless-ready locations in the countries where Apple Pay has launched to date
column96: including over 2.5 million locations now accepting Apple Pay in the United States
column97:
and more expansion of Apple Pay is coming soon.

"
column98:
"

Turning to the Mac
column99: we met our sell-in expectations in addition to reducing channel inventory by about 100
column100: 000 units. Overall
column101: the Mac continues to attract a large percentage of new customers. In our latest survey of major markets
column102: over half of buyers were new to the Mac. And in some countries
column103: the percentage is extremely high
column104: like in China
column105:
where over 80% of customers were purchasing a Mac for the first time. We're confident in our Mac business and our ability to continue to innovate and gain share in that area.

"
column106:
"

Turning to the Apple Watch
column107: unit sales met our expectations in the quarter. For some color on how we think about Apple Watch sales
column108: we expect its seasonality to be similar to the historical seasonality of iPod
column109: which typically generated 40% or more of its annual unit sell-through in the December quarter. We started shipping Apple Watch just one year ago
column110: and it has quickly become the best-selling and most loved smartwatch in the world. In fact
column111:
unit sales of Apple Watch during its first year exceeded sales of iPhone in its first year.

"
column112:
"

Last month
column113: we refreshed the lineup for the spring with new bands and a new starting price point
column114: and the response from customers has been great. Apple Watch is an increasingly essential part of users' lives
column115: from responding to messages
column116: managing calendars and navigating with maps
column117: to helping them be more fit. And in some cases
column118: the heart rate sensor has even helped save lives. We're really excited about the first year with Apple Watch. We have learned a lot
column119:
and we believe it has an exciting future head.

"
column120:
"

We announced some fantastic new products during the March quarter. IPhone SE became available on March 31
column121: so none of its sales were reflected in our second quarter results. But so far this quarter we're seeing terrific customer response. IPhone SE is the most powerful four-inch phone ever
column122: and it's a great option for customers all over the world who want a compact phone with advanced features and a great price without compromising performance. Demand has been very strong and exceeds supply at this point
column123:
but we're working hard to get the iPhone SE into the hands of every customer who wants one as quickly as possible. The addition of the iPhone SE in the iPhone lineup places us in a better strategic position to attract even more customers into our ecosystem.

"
column124:
"

We also unveiled the stunning 9.7-inch iPad Pro with cutting-edge performance and our most advanced display yet. The reviews of our new iPad Pros have been great
column125: and we're hearing from customers that the features and capabilities in the new Pros make them both the ultimate upgrade for iPad owners and a great PC replacement. In the June quarter
column126: we expect to see our best iPad revenue compare in over two years. IPad is the best selling
column127: best reviewed
column128: and most used tablet on the market. Customers tell us that they love iPad for its unique mix of portability
column129: capability
column130: and versatility
column131: with over 1 million iPad apps in the App Store to help them work
column132: play
column133: learn
column134:
and create.

"
column135:
"

We also announced CareKit
column136: a new software framework that developers can use to help people take a more active role in their health by keeping track of their care plans
column137: monitoring their symptoms and medication
column138: and delivering the insights they need to make smart decisions about their health. We're very excited about the ways iPhone and Apple Watch are helping people lead healthier lives. We believe there's great promise here for the future
column139:
and we are very interested in where this can take us.

"
column140:
"

As always
column141: we're contributing to society beyond our products
column142: promoting the use of renewable energy across our facilities and inside our supply chain and developing cutting-edge technologies to revolutionize recycling of the materials we use. We are unwavering in our commitment to protect the security and privacy of our customers and their data
column143:
and we're actively promoting inclusion and equality across our business.

"
column144:
"

As we continue through the June quarter
column145: I'd like to remind you that we measure the health of customer demand based on sell-through. Despite ending Q2 within our channel inventory targets
column146: in light of the macroeconomic environment
column147:
we plan to lower our channel inventories in the June quarter. This will impact our reported revenue in Q3. Luca will provide more details on this in his commentary.

"
column148:
"

But before I turn over the call to him
column149: I'll summarize by saying that the future of Apple is very bright. Our product pipeline has amazing innovations in store. We're very excited about bringing together developers for our four major platforms at our Worldwide Developers Conference in June. We are forging ahead with important investments in research and development
column150: in our infrastructure
column151: and in our supply chain. We've made 15 acquisitions in the last four quarters to accelerate our product and Services roadmaps
column152: and we're always on the lookout for companies with great technology
column153: talent
column154:
and strategic fit.

"
column155:
"

Creating value for shareholders by developing great products and services that enrich people's lives will always be our top priority and the key factor driving our investment and capital allocation decisions. As our business continues to generate high levels of free cash flow
column156: we are in the fortunate position to expand our capital return program again this year
column157: as we have done each year since we started the program four years ago. Today we're announcing an extension of the timeframe of the program by four quarters through March of 2018
column158:
and we are expanding the total program size from $200 billion to $250 billion.

"
column159:
"

Luca has more details on this announcement and our results for the March quarter. Luca?

"
column160:
"

Luca Maestri - Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President

"
column161:
"

Thank you
column162: Tim
column163: and good afternoon
column164:
everyone. Let me start with the March quarter results.

"
column165:
"

Revenue for the quarter landed within our guidance range of $50.6 billion compared to $58 billion in the year-ago quarter
column166: a decline of 13%. As we had expected
column167: our comparisons to last year were influenced by the continued strength of the U.S. dollar against foreign currencies. As Tim said
column168: in constant currency
column169:
our revenue declined by 9%.

"
column170:
"

On a geographic basis
column171: in Asia
column172: our revenue grew strongly in Japan
column173: but it declined in greater China and the rest of Asia-Pacific. However
column174: our business in these two regions is faring better than the numbers might suggest. We had significant channel inventory reductions and currency weakness
column175:
which affected our reported revenue for both these segments.

"
column176:
"

In Mainland China
column177: revenue was down 11%
column178: and the decline was 7% in constant currency terms. Keep in mind that we were up against an extremely difficult year-ago compare when our Mainland China revenue grew 81%. We remain very optimistic about the China market over the long term
column179:
and we are committed to investing there for the long run.

"
column180:
"

Gross margin was 39.4%
column181: near the high end of our guidance range
column182: thanks to strong cost performance. Operating margin was 27.7% of revenue
column183: and net income was $10.5 billion. Diluted earnings per share were $1.90
column184:
and cash flow from operations was strong at $11.6 billion.

"
column185:
"

For details by product
column186: I'll start with iPhone. We sold 51.2 million iPhones in the quarter compared to 61.2 million in the year-ago quarter
column187: a decline of 16%. It was a particularly challenging comparison to the record quarter a year ago
column188: when iPhone sales grew 40%
column189: as we entered last March quarter in supply/demand imbalance
column190: which was recovered during the quarter. Also
column191: this year we reduced channel inventory by 450
column192:
000 units while we increased inventory by 1 million units a year ago. We have exited the quarter within our five-week to seven-week target range for channel inventory.

"
column193:
"

iPhone ASP was $642 compared to $659 in the year-ago quarter
column194:
with weak international currencies and very popular mid-tier and entry offerings contributing to the difference year over year.

"
column195:
"

iPhone's momentum in business markets continues to be very impressive. A recent survey by 451 Research
column196: formerly known as ChangeWave
column197: found that among U.S. corporate buyers planning to purchase smartphones in the June quarter
column198:
78% plan to purchase iPhones. That's the highest June quarter iPhone purchase intent ever measured by the survey and five points higher than a year ago.

"
column199:
"

Turning to Services
column200: we generated $6 billion in revenue
column201: an increase of 20% over the March quarter last year
column202: thanks primarily to the continued strong performance of the App Store
column203: with revenue growing 35% to a new all-time high. According to App Annie
column204: the App Store generated 90% more global revenue than Google Play in the March quarter
column205: up from a 75% lead in 2015. Among our customers who purchased apps and content from our iTunes Store's
column206:
the average amount spent per customer reached a new all-time record in the March quarter.

"
column207:
"

Next
column208: I'd like to talk about the Mac. We sold 4 million Macs compared to 4.6 million last year
column209: a decline of 12%. It was a challenging quarter for personal computer sales across the industry
column210: but we believe we gained market share. Despite the overall market slowdown
column211: we generated double-digit Mac growth in a number of markets
column212: including Russia
column213: Korea
column214: Singapore
column215: Taiwan
column216:
and the UAE.

"
column217:
"

And just last week we updated the MacBook
column218: our thinnest and lightest Mac
column219: with the latest processors
column220: faster graphics
column221: faster flash storage
column222:
and longer battery life. We think our customers are going to love this update. We ended the quarter within our four-week to five-week target range for Mac channel inventory.

"
column223:
"

Turning to iPad
column224: we sold 10.3 million units compared to 12.6 million units in the year-ago quarter. We also reduced channel inventory by about 200
column225: 000 units
column226:
and we exited the quarter within our five-week to seven-week target range.

"
column227:
"

In the segments of the tablet market where we compete
column228: we continue to be highly successful. Recent data from NPD indicates that iPad has 78% share of the U.S. market for tablets priced above $200. And the latest data published by IDC indicates that iPad accounts for 72% of the U.S. commercial tablet market
column229: comprising business
column230: government
column231:
and education.

"
column232:
"

iPad customer metrics are also extremely positive. In February
column233: 451 Research measured a 97% consumer satisfaction rate for iPad Air 2. And among consumers planning to purchase a tablet within the next six months
column234: 59% plan to purchase an iPad
column235: more than three times the purchase intention rate of the next highest brand measured. Corporate buyers reported a 94% satisfaction rate for iPad
column236:
and the June quarter purchase intent of 71%.

"
column237:
"

Revenue from other products grew 30% over last year thanks to Apple Watch. We have expanded distribution to 60 countries and introduced bands in beautiful new colors for spring
column238: so customers can personalize their watches in more ways with a range of colors
column239: styles
column240: and materials. Our customers are very happy with Apple Watch
column241:
with 451 Research measuring 94% customer satisfaction.

"
column242:
"

We're also making great progress with our enterprise initiatives. IBM now has engagements for more than 200 deployments of native iOS apps for large enterprise customers to accelerate mobile transformation. Our Mobility Partner program also continues to grow
column243:
with 108 partners across 20 countries.

"
column244:
"

We see continued broad industry adoption of native iOS apps to transform how professionals do their work and serve their customers. For example
column245: retail bankers are using iOS apps on iPads to greet and onboard customers
column246: reduce queue times
column247: and improve the customer experience. And in hospitals
column248:
doctors and nurses are using iOS apps on iPhone and iPad to share and communicate more effectively so that they can spend more time with patients and less time on administrative tasks.

"
column249:
"

Let me now turn to our cash position. We ended the quarter with $232.9 billion in cash plus marketable securities
column250: a sequential increase of $17.2 billion. $208.9 billion of this cash
column252: was outside the United States. We issued $15.5 billion in U.S. dollar denominated notes during the quarter
column253:
including our first green bond tranche to fund initiatives such as renewable energy and environmental design projects. We exited the March quarter with $72 billion in term debt.

"
column254:
"

We returned $10 billion to investors during the quarter
column255: including $2.9 billion in dividends and equivalents and $7 billion on repurchases of 71.8 million Apple shares through open market transactions. We have now completed over $163 billion of the current $200 billion capital return program
column256:
including $117 billion in share repurchases.

"
column257:
"

As Tim mentioned
column258: today we are announcing the latest update to our program
column259: which we are increasing to a total of $250 billion. Once again
column260: we're allocating the majority of the expansion of the program to share repurchases. Given our strong confidence in Apple's future and the value we see in our stock
column261: the board has increased the share repurchase authorization by $35 billion
column262:
raising it from the current $140 billion level to $175 billion. We will also continue to net share settle vesting employee restricted stock units.

"
column263:
"

We also know that the dividend is very important to many of our investors who value income
column264: and we are raising it for the fourth time in less than four years. The quarterly dividend will grow from $0.52 per share to $0.57 per share
column265: an increase of about 10%. This is effective with our next dividend
column266: which the board has declared today and is payable on May 12
column267: 2016 to shareholders of record as of May 9
column268: 2016. We continue to plan for annual dividend increases going forward. With $12 billion in annual dividend payments
column269: we are proud to be one of the largest dividend payers in the world. In total
column270: with this updated program
column271: during the next eight quarters we expect to return $87 billion to our investors
column272:
which represents about 15% of our market cap at the current stock price.

"
column273:
"

As in the past
column274: we expect to fund our capital return program with U.S. cash
column275: future U.S. cash flow generation
column276: and borrowing from both domestic and international debt markets. We will continue to review capital allocation regularly and solicit input on our program from a broad base of shareholders. This allows us to be thoughtful about the size
column277: the mix
column278:
and the pace of the program.

"
column279:
"

As we move ahead into the June quarter
column280: I'd like to review our outlook
column281: which includes the types of forward-looking information that Nancy referred to at the beginning of the call. We expect revenue to be between $41 billion and $43 billion. The revenue guidance implies a year-over-year decline as we lap an incredibly strong June quarter last year where revenue grew 33%
column282: due in part to accelerated iPhone upgrade purchases. This tough compare is compounded by the continued weak macro environment this year and the strong U.S. dollar
column283:
which affects our revenue growth in international markets.

"
column284:
"

Embedded in this guidance is a planned channel inventory reduction worth over $2 billion
column285: as we have elected to be prudent about our channel inventory position given the current macro environment. The guidance also reflects a range of possible scenarios related to how quickly we can get into supply/demand balance for iPhone SE. Due to these factors
column286:
our expected demand is greater than the revenue range implies.

"
column287:
"

Sequentially
column288: our guidance implies a revenue decline of 15% to 19%
column289: which is comparable to the 17% sequential decline that we've averaged from the March to June quarter for the last three years
column290:
despite the anticipated channel inventory adjustments I just described. We expect seasonal sequential declines in iPhone and iPad sales and a sequential increase in Mac sales. We also expect iPhone ASPs to decline sequentially as we get farther from the launch of iPhone 6s and iPhone 6s Plus and as iPhone SE enters the mix.

"
column291:
"

We know that our revenue guidance falls short of market estimates for the third quarter. We believe the difference comes primarily from three areas: first
column292: the $2 billion-plus channel inventory reduction I just mentioned; second
column293: the effect of the channel inventory reduction and the launch of iPhone SE on iPhone ASPs
column294: as well as the current constrained supply of iPhone SE; and third
column295: different estimates for Mac
column296:
which we expect to grow sequentially at a rate similar to what we have experienced in the past June quarters.

"
column297:
"

We expect gross margins to be between 37.5% and 38%. We expect continued cost improvements to be more than offset by the sequential loss of leverage from lower revenue and a different mix of products. We expect OpEx to be between $6 billion and $6.1 billion. We expect OI&E to be about $300 million
column298:
and we expect the tax rate to be about 25.5%.

"

"

With that

I'd like to open the call to questions.

column355:
our test is not on the size. We would definitely buy something larger than we've bought thus far. It's more about the strategic fit and whether it's a great technology and great people. And so we continue to look and we stay very active in the M&A market.

column451: it's increased by 80%. And so when you think about upgrade cycles

column454: really good business in the developed markets

column456: and also to continue to attract over Android switchers. With our worldwide share

column462: and so we'll begin to see some really good networks coming on in India. That will unleash the power and capability of the iPhone in a way that an older network
column463: a 2.5G or even some 3G networks
column464: would not do. And so the infrastructure is one key. The second one is building the channel out. Unlike the U.S.
column465: as an example
column466: where the carriers in the U.S. sell the vast majority of phones that are sold in the United States
column467: in India the carriers in general sell virtually no phones. And so it's out in retail

column470:

And so we've been in the process \u2013 it's not something that we just started in the last few weeks. We've been working in India now for a couple of years or more

and I think there's a really great opportunity there.
