column554: thanks for the question. If you take Greater China
column555: we include Taiwan
column556: Hong Kong
column557: and Mainland China in the Greater China segment that you see reported on your data sheet. The vast majority of the weakness in the Greater China region sits in Hong Kong. And our perspective on that is it's a combination of the Hong Kong dollar being pegged to the U.S. dollar
column558: and therefore it carries the burden of the strength of the U.S. dollar. And that has driven tourism
column559: international shopping
column560:
and trading down significantly compared to what it was in the year ago.

"
column561:
"

If you look at Mainland China
column562: which is one that I am personally very focused on
column563: we are down 11% in Mainland China on a reported basis. On a constant currency basis
column564: we're only down 7%. And the way that we really look at the health or underlying demand is look at sell-through. And if you look at it there
column565:
we were down 5%. And keep in mind that that's down 5% on a comp a year ago that was up 81%.

"
column566:
"

And so as I back up from this and look at the larger picture
column567: I think China is not weak as has been talked about. I see China as may not have the wind at our backs that we once did
column568: but it's a lot more stable than what I think is the common view of it. And so we remain really optimistic on China. We opened seven stores there during the quarter. We now are at 35. We'll open five more this quarter to achieve 40
column569: which we had talked about before. And the LTE adoption continues to rise there
column570:
but it's got a long way ahead of it. And so we continue to be really optimistic about it and just would ask folks to look underneath the numbers at the details of them before concluding anything. Thanks for the question.

"
column571:
"

Shannon S. Cross - Cross Research LLC

"
column572:
"

Okay
column573: thanks. And then my second question is with regard to OpEx leverage or thinking about when I look at the revenue
column574: your revenue is below our expectations
column575: but OpEx is pretty much in line. So how are you thinking about potential for leverage
column576: I don't know
column577:
cost containment maybe when macro is bad and revenue is under pressure? And how are you juggling that versus the required investment you need to go forward?

"
column578:
"

Luca Maestri - Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President

"
column579:
"

Shannon
column580: it's Luca. Of course we think about it. We think about it a lot. And so when you look at our results
column581: for example
column583: for the March quarter was up 10%
column584: which is the lowest rate that you've seen in years. And when you look within OpEx
column585: you actually see two different dynamics. You see continued significant investments in research and development because we really believe that's the future of the company. We continue to invest in initiatives and projects ahead of revenue. We have a much broader portfolio than we used to have. We do much more in-house technology development than we used to do a few years ago
column586:
which we think is a great investment for us to make. And so that part we really need to protect and we want to continue to invest in the business.

"
column587:
"

And then when you look at our SG&A portion of OpEx for the March quarter
column588: it was actually down slightly. So obviously
column589: we think about it
column590: and of course we look at our revenue trend and we take measures accordingly. And when you look at the guidance that we provided for the June quarter
column591: that 10% year-over-year increase that I mentioned to you for the March quarter goes down to a range of 7% to 9% up. And again
column592: the focus is on making investments in R&D and continuing to run SG&A extremely tightly and in a very disciplined way. As you know
column593: our E-to-R
column595: is around 10%. It's something that we're very proud of. It's a number that is incredibly competitive in our industry
column596: and we want to continue to keep it that way. At the same time
column597:
we don't want to underinvest in the business.

"
column598:
"

Shannon S. Cross - Cross Research LLC

"
column599:
"

Thank you.

"
column600:
"

Nancy Paxton - Senior Director
column602:
"

Than you
column603: Shannon. Could we have the next question
column604:
please?

"
column605:
"

Operator

"
column606:
"

From UBS
column607:
we'll hear from Steve Milunovich.

"
column608:
"

Steven M. Milunovich - UBS Securities LLC

"
column609:
"

Thank you. Tim
column610: I first wanted to ask you about Services
column611: and how do you view Services? You've obviously highlighted it the last two quarters. Do you view it going forward as a primary driver of earnings
column612: or do you view it \u2013 you mentioned platforms in terms of your operating systems
column613: which I would agree with. And in that scenario
column614: I would argue it's more a supporter of the ecosystem and a supporter of the hardware margins over time and therefore somewhat subservient to hardware. So it's great that it's growing
column615: but longer term
column616:
I would view its role as more creating ecosystem that supports the high margins on hardware as opposed to independently driving earnings. How do you think about it?

"
column617:
"

Timothy Donald Cook - Chief Executive Officer & Director

"
column618:
"

The most important thing for us
column620: is that we want to have a great customer experience. So overwhelmingly
column621: the thing that drives us are to embark on services that help that and become a part of the ecosystem. The reality is that in doing so
column622: we have developed a very large and profitable business in the Services area. And so we felt last quarter and working up to that that we should pull back the curtain so that people could \u2013 our investors could see the Services business both in terms of the scale of it and the growth of it. As we said earlier
column623: the purchase value of the installed base services grew by 27% during the quarter
column624: which was an acceleration over the previous quarter. And the value of it hit just \u2013 or was just shy of $10 billion. And so it's huge
column625:
and we felt it was important to spell that out.

"
column626:
"

Steven M. Milunovich - UBS Securities LLC

"
column627:
"

Okay. And then going back to the upgrades of the installed base
column628: you clearly mentioned that you've pulled forward some demand
column629: which makes sense. But there does seem to be a lengthening of the upgrade cycle
column630: particularly in the U.S. AT&T and Verizon have talked about that. Investors I think perceive that maybe the marginal improvements on the phone might be less currently and could be less going forward. At the same time
column631: I think you just announced that you can get the upgrade program online
column632:
which I guess potentially could shorten it. Do you believe that upgrade cycles are currently lengthening and can continue to do so?

"
column633:
"

Timothy Donald Cook - Chief Executive Officer & Director

"
column634:
"

What we've seen is that it depends on what you compare it to. If you compare to the iPhone 5s
column635: what we're seeing is the upgrade rate today is slightly higher or that there are more people upgrading
column637: in a similar time period in terms of rate than the iPhone 5s. But if you compare to iPhone 6
column638: you would clearly arrive at the opposite conclusion. And so I think it depends on people's reference points. And we thought it very important in this call to be very clear and transparent about what we are seeing. And so I think in retrospect
column639: you can look at it and say
column640: well maybe the appropriate measure is more to the iPhone 5s
column641: and I think everybody intuitively thought that the upgrades were accelerated with the iPhone 6. In retrospect
column642: when you look at the periods
column644:
"

Steven M. Milunovich - UBS Securities LLC

"
column646:
"

Nancy Paxton - Senior Director
column649: Steve. Can we have the next question
column652:
"

We'll go to Rod Hall with JPMorgan.

"
column653:
"

Rod B. Hall - JPMorgan Securities LLC

"
column656: for fitting me in. I wanted to start with a more general question. I guess. Tim
column657: this one is aimed at you. As you think about where you thought things were going to head last quarter when you reported to us and how it's changed this quarter
column658: obviously this kind of a disappointing demand environment. Can you just help us understand what maybe the top two or three things are that have changed
column659:
so as we walk away from this we understand what the differences are and what the direction of change is? And I've got a follow up.

"
column660:
"

Timothy Donald Cook - Chief Executive Officer & Director

"
column663: you're probably indirectly asking about our trough comment
column665: from last quarter. And when we made that
column666: we did not contemplate or comprehend that we were going to make a $2 billion-plus reduction in channel inventory during this quarter. And so if you factor that in and look at true customer demand
column667: which is the way that we look at it internally
column668:
I think you'll find a much more reasonable comparison.

"
column669:
"

Rod B. Hall - JPMorgan Securities LLC

"
column671: great. Thank you. And then for my follow-up
column672: I wanted to ask you about the tax situation a little bit. Treasury obviously has made some rule changes
column675: you could comment on what the impact to Apple from those is
column679:
how you guys see the tax situation for Apple looking forward? Thanks.

"
column680:
"

Luca Maestri - Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President

"
column682: these are new regulations. We are in the process of assessing them. Frankly
column684: we don't anticipate that they're going to have any material impact on our tax situation. Some of them relate to inversion transactions
column685: so obviously that's not an issue for us. Some of them are around internal debt financing
column686: which is not something that we use
column687: so we don't expect any issue there. As you know
column688: we are the largest U.S. taxpayer by a wide margin
column689:
and we already pay full U.S. tax on all the profits from the sales that we make in the United States. So we don't expect them to have any impact on us.

"
column692: and I'll let Tim provide more color
column693: but we've been strong advocates for comprehensive corporate tax reform in this country. We continue to do that. We think a reform of the tax code would have significant benefits for the entire U.S. economy
column694: and we remain optimistic that we're going to get to a point where we can see that tax reform enacted. At that point in time
column696:
we would have much more flexibility around optimizing our capital structure and around providing more return of capital to our investors.

"
column697:
"

Timothy Donald Cook - Chief Executive Officer & Director

"
column698:
"

The only thing I would add
column700: is I think there are a growing number of people in both parties that would like to see comprehensive reform
column701: and so I'm optimistic that it will occur. It's just a matter of when. And that's difficult to say
column702:
but I think most people do recognize that it's in the U.S.'s interest to do this.

"
column703:
"

Rod B. Hall - JPMorgan Securities LLC

"
column709: Rod. A replay of today's call will be available for two weeks as a podcast on the iTunes Store and webcast on Apple.com/investor and via telephone. The numbers for the telephone replay are 888-203-1112 or 719-457-0820
column710: and please enter confirmation code 7495552. And these replays will be available by approximately 5:00 PM Pacific time today. Members of the press with additional questions can contact Kristen Huguet at 408-974-2414
column711: and financial analysts can contact Joan Hoover or me with additional questions. Joan is at 408-974-4570
column712:
and I'm at 408-974-5420. Thanks again for joining us.

"
column715:
that does conclude today's presentation. We do thank everyone for your participation.

column1:
{"Apple (AAPL) Timothy Donald Cook on Q3 2016 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Apple
column9:
"

Timothy Donald Cook - Chief Executive Officer & Director

"
column10:
"

Luca Maestri - Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President

"
column12:
"

Shannon S. Cross - Cross Research LLC

"
column13:
"

Steven M. Milunovich - UBS Securities LLC

"
column14:
"

Kathryn Lynn Huberty - Morgan Stanley & Co. LLC

"
column16:
"

Simona K. Jankowski - Goldman Sachs & Co.

"
column17:

Gene Munster - Piper Jaffray & Co.

"
column20:
"

Kulbinder S. Garcha - Credit Suisse Securities (NYSE:USA) LLC (Broker)

"
column23: everyone
column24: and welcome to this Apple
column25:
Incorporated third quarter fiscal year 2016 earnings release conference call. Today's call is being recorded.

"
column26:
"

At this time for opening remarks and introductions
column27: I would like to turn the call over to Nancy Paxton
column28: Senior Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead
column30:
"

Nancy Paxton - Senior Director
column31:
Investor Relations and Treasury

"
column33: good afternoon and thanks to everyone for joining us. Speaking first today is Apple CEO Tim Cook
column34: and he'll be followed by CFO
column36:
we'll open the call to questions from analysts.

"
column37:
"

Please note that some of the information you'll hear during our discussion today will consist of forward-looking statements
column38: including without limitation those regarding revenues
column40: operating expenses
column41: other income and expense
column43: and future business outlook. Actual results or trends could differ materially from our forecast. For more information
column44: please refer to the risk factors discussed in Apple's Form 10-K for 2015
column45: the Forms 10-Q for the first two quarters of fiscal 2016
column46: and the Form 8-K filed with the SEC today along with the associated press release. Apple assumes no obligation to update any forward-looking statements or information
column47:
which speak as of their respective dates.

"
column48:
"

In addition
column49: today's comments will refer to a metric we describe as installed base related purchases. This is a non-GAAP measure
column50:
and a reconciliation to the corresponding GAAP measure can be found on our Investor Relations website at Apple.com/investor.

"
column51:
"

I'd now like to turn the call over to Tim for introductory remarks.

"
column52:
"

Timothy Donald Cook - Chief Executive Officer & Director

"
column53:
"

Thanks
column54:
Nancy. Good afternoon and thank you for joining us. Today we're pleased to report third quarter results that reflect stronger customer demand and business performance than we anticipated just 90 days ago and include several encouraging signs.

"
column55:
"

Revenue of $42.4 billion was near the high end of our guidance range and gross margin of 38% was at the top of our guidance range. We achieved these results while reducing channel inventory by about $3.6 billion
column56:
significantly more than the $2 billion inventory reduction we had expected. So our sell-through was markedly greater than our sell-in.

"
column57:
"

iPhone accounted for the vast majority of the channel inventory reduction. iPhone unit sell-through was down just 8% year on year
column58: an even greater improvement over the March quarter than we predicted
column59:
and we expect the September quarter sell-through comparison to improve further. We feel good about our channel inventory levels and believe they position us well for the months ahead.

"
column60:
"

We had a very successful global launch of iPhone SE
column61: and demand outstripped supply throughout the quarter. We brought on additional capacity and were able to achieve supply/demand balance as we entered the September quarter. At its launch
column62:
we said that the addition of the iPhone SE to the iPhone lineup placed us in a better position to meet the needs of customers who love a four-inch phone and to attract even more customers into our ecosystem.

"
column63:
"

In both cases
column64: that strategy is working. Our initial sales data tells us that the iPhone SE is popular in both developed and emerging markets
column65:
and the percentage of iPhone SE sales going to customers who are new to iPhone is greater than we've seen in the first weeks of availability for other iPhones launched in the last several years.

"
column66:
"

Overall
column67: we added millions of first-time smartphone buyers in the June quarter
column68: and switchers accounted for the highest percentage of quarterly iPhone sales we've ever measured. In absolute terms
column69: our year-to-date iPhone sales to switchers are the greatest we've seen in any nine-month period
column70:
and our active installed base of iPhones is up strong double-digits year over year.

"
column71:
"

We saw tremendous performance from our Services businesses
column72: which grew 19% to a June quarter record of $6 billion. The growth was broad-based
column73: with App Store revenue up 37% to a new all-time high
column74: in addition to strong increases in Music
column75: iCloud
column76: and AppleCare. In the last 12 months
column77: our Services revenue is up almost $4 billion year on year to $23.1 billion
column78: and we expect it to be the size of a Fortune 100 company next year. Most of our terrific Services performance during the quarter was fueled by our active installed base of devices
column79:
with installed base-related purchases of $10.3 billion accelerating to 29% growth year on year.

"
column80:
"

We had our best iPad compare in 10 quarters
column81:
with revenue growing 7% thanks to the rollout of the 9.7-inch iPad Pro. We're proud to have the most exciting lineup of tablets and accessories in the world and exceptionally high customer satisfaction and engagement. Our surveys also show that about half of iPad Pro purchases are buying them for work. iPad Pro is the ultimate upgrade for existing iPad users and the ultimate replacement device for customers switching from PC notebooks.

"
column82:
"

Apple Watch continues to be the best-selling smartwatch in the world. And just this month
column83: J.D. Power ranked it highest in customer satisfaction among all smartwatches. With watchOS 3 coming this fall
column84: customers will be able to update their Apple Watches with an enhanced user interface
column85: significantly improved performance and all-new fitness and health capabilities
column86: including activity sharing. We're just getting started with the Apple Watch
column87:
and we look forward to even more exciting announcements in this space.

"
column88:
"

On a personal note
column89: during the past quarter I visited China and India
column90: and I am very encouraged about our growth prospects in those countries. We remain very optimistic about the long-term opportunities in Greater China and we continue to invest there. We opened our 41st Greater China retail store during the quarter
column91:
and we also made a $1 billion investment in Didi Chuxing.

"
column92:
"

Switchers and first-time smartphone buyers represented the lion's share of our iPhone sales in the quarter
column93: and our installed base of iPhones in China has grown by 34% over the last year alone. According to China Mobile
column94: there are more iPhones on their network than any other brand
column95: with iPhone users ranking first in terms of customer loyalty
column96: data usage and ARPU. By far
column97: the largest portion of our global channel inventory reduction was in Greater China
column98:
so our underlying business there is stronger than our results imply.

"
column99:
"

We face some challenges in Greater China
column100: as the economic environment has slowed down since the beginning of the year. This is reflected in consumer confidence and retail spending
column101:
and the Chinese yuan has depreciated by 7% relative to the U.S. dollar since August of last year. Hong Kong's tourism and retail businesses also continue to be significantly impacted by the stronger Hong Kong dollar relative to other Asian currencies.

"
column102:
"

Combining this backdrop with the tough comparison to last year
column103: when revenue grew 112%
column104: and the channel inventory reduction this year
column105: we're reporting a decline in revenue in the June quarter. But to keep things in perspective
column106: when we look back on our accomplishments in this segment over the last couple of years
column107: they are truly remarkable. In the first three quarters of this fiscal year
column108: our total revenue from Greater China was almost $40 billion
column109: up 55% from the same timeframe just two years ago
column110:
while iPhone units were up 47%.

"
column111:
"

India is now one of our fastest growing markets. In the first three quarters of this fiscal year
column112: our iPhone sales in India were up 51% year on year. We just announced a first of its kind design and development accelerator to support Indian developers creating innovative applications for iOS
column113: and we opened a new office in Hyderabad to accelerate maps development. We're looking forward to opening retail stores in India down the road
column114:
and we see huge potential for that vibrant country.

"
column115:
"

As we look forward to the fall
column116: we are thrilled by customers' response to the software and services we previewed at our Worldwide Developers Conference last month. This was our biggest WWDC ever. And for the first time
column117: we have four innovative Apple platforms for our developers' apps
column118: iOS
column119: macOS
column120: watchOS
column121: and tvOS. In fact
column122:
iOS 10 will be the biggest release ever for iOS.

"
column123:
"

The momentum of all four platforms shows the strong relationship Apple enjoys with customers throughout their day and wherever they go
column124: whether it's at home
column125: in their car
column126: at work
column127: or everywhere in between. The Apple ecosystem is thriving and growing
column128:
and our new OS releases this fall will take these great experiences to a new level.

"
column129:
"

Customers can look forward to more expressive ways to communicate with messages now with its own App Store
column130: allowing users to create and share content
column131: make payments
column132: add stickers and more
column133: all without leaving messages
column134: which is now one of the largest messaging services in the world. Customers can also look forward to a broader and more intelligent role for Siri
column135: which will work with your favorite apps from the App Store
column136:
so you can ask Siri to book a ride with your favorite ride sharing app or send money to someone with Square.

"
column137:
"

There are also beautifully redesigned apps for music
column138: maps and news
column139: significant enhancements to HomeKit
column140: CarPlay
column141: and the Health app
column142: building on our strategy to give users a seamless experience in all aspects of their lives. There's also a major update with macOS Sierra
column143: with new features like Siri and Apple Pay that make the Mac smarter and more helpful than ever
column144:
and even stronger continuity features across all the Apple devices.

"
column145:
"

These experiences become more powerful and intuitive as we continue our long history of enriching our products through advanced artificial intelligence. We have focused our AI efforts on the features that best enhance the customer experience. For example
column146: machine learning enables Siri to understand words as well as the intent behind them. That means Siri does a better job understanding and even predicting what you want
column147: then delivering the right responses to requests. To make Siri an even smarter assistant
column148: we're opening the service to developers
column149:
and this fall Siri will be available across our entire product line.

"
column150:
"

We're also using machine learning in many other ways across our products and services
column151: including recommending songs
column152: apps
column153: and news. Machine learning is improving facial and image recognition in photos
column154: predicting word choice while typing in messages and mail
column155: and providing context awareness in maps for better directions. Deep learning within our products even enables them to recognize usage patterns and improve their own battery life. And most importantly
column156: we deliver these intelligent services while protecting users' privacy. Most of the AI processing takes place on the device rather than being sent to the cloud. And starting this fall
column157: we'll be using sophisticated technology called differential privacy
column158:
enhancing our ability to deliver the kinds of services we dream of and customers love without compromising on the individual privacy our customers have come to expect from us.

"
column159:
"

This fall we'll also bring Apple Pay to Safari so users can easily make secure and private purchases when shopping on participating websites. Tens of millions of users around the world are enjoying Apple Pay today at stores and in app
column160:
with estimated monthly active users up more than 450% year on year last month.

"
column161:
"

Leading financial partners tell us that three out of four contactless payments in the U.S. are made with Apple Pay. This is amazing. There are more than 11 million contactless-ready locations in the countries where Apple Pay is available today
column162: including 3 million locations now accepting Apple Pay in the United States. With the launch of France
column163: Switzerland
column164: and Hong Kong this month
column165: Apple Pay is now live in nine markets
column166: including six of our top 10. Adoption outside the U.S. has been explosive
column167:
with over half of transaction volume now coming from non-U.S. markets.

"
column168:
"

With our latest OS releases
column169: the unparalleled continuity across Apple devices will become even more powerful. For example
column170: macOS Sierra will sense other devices and use secure protocols to communicate. With an authenticated Apple Watch
column171: I can auto-unlock my Mac when I open it without typing a password. With Universal Clipboard
column172: I can copy and paste text
column173: images
column174: and even video between my iOS devices and my Mac. And I can automatically access the files on my Mac desktop and documents folder from another Mac
column175: iOS device
column176:
or even a PC.

"
column177:
"

Innovations like these are the kinds of things that only Apple can do. We have an incredible lineup of products in our pipeline
column178:
and I'm very bullish about our long-term opportunity.

"
column179:
"

Now I'd like to hand it over to Luca to share more details with you on the June quarter.

"
column180:
"

Luca Maestri - Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President

"
column181:
"

Thank you
column182: Tim. Good afternoon
column183: everyone. Revenue for the June quarter was $42.4 billion
column184: near the high end of our guidance range
column185: compared to $49.6 billion in the year-ago quarter. Customer demand for our products and services was stronger than we had anticipated at the beginning of the quarter. As Tim mentioned
column186:
we reduced overall channel inventories by roughly $3.6 billion.

"
column187:
"

On a geographic basis
column188: our revenue grew strongly in Japan to a new June quarter record
column189: and we experienced healthy growth in a number of other important markets
column190: including Russia
column192: Turkey
column193: India
column194:
and Canada.

"
column195:
"

Gross margin was 38%
column196: at the top of our guidance range. Operating margin was 23.9% of revenue
column197: and net income was $7.8 billion. Diluted earnings per share were $1.42
column198:
and cash flow from operations was strong at $10.6 billion.

"
column199:
"

For details by product
column200: I will start with the iPhone. We sold 40.4 million iPhones in the quarter. We also reduced channel inventory by over 4 million units compared to about 0.5 million units a year ago
column201: so sell-through was down by 8%. We exited the quarter near the low end of our five-week to seven-week target range for channel inventory. The rollout of our new entry-level iPhone SE concurrent with the channel reduction of more than 4 million higher-end iPhones resulted in a lower than usual iPhone ASP of $595. Therefore
column202:
we expect ASPs to improve this quarter.

"
column203:
"

We experienced strong iPhone growth in many markets
column204: with sales in Russia more than doubling year over year
column205: and double-digit growth in many other key countries
column206: including Japan
column207: Turkey
column208: Brazil
column209: India
column210: Canada
column211:
and Sweden.

"
column212:
"

iPhone continues to show great momentum in business markets. A recent survey by 451 Research found that among U.S. corporate buyers planning to purchase smartphones in the September quarter
column213:
75% plan to purchase iPhones. This is the highest corporate purchase intent ever measured by the survey for the September quarter.

"
column214:
"

Turning to Services
column215: we generated $6 billion in revenue
column216: an increase of 19% over the June quarter last year. We set a new record for customers transacting on our iTunes Stores. And among our customers who purchase apps and content
column217: the average amount spent per customer was the highest that we've ever measured. The App Store's growth rate has now accelerated for four consecutive quarters
column218: reaching 37% in Q3. The App Store is overwhelmingly the preferred destination for both customers and developers. According to App Annie
column219: we generated 100% more global revenue than Google Play in the June quarter
column220:
widening our lead from the March

"
column221:
"

quarter.

"
column222:
"

Because of this continued growth
column223: for the first nine months of our fiscal year
column224: Services increased from 8% of our total revenue a year ago to 11% this year
column225:
and it represents an even higher percentage of our profitability.

"
column226:
"

Next I'd like to talk about the Mac. We sold 4.3 million Macs compared to 4.8 million last year. It was a challenging quarter for personal computer sales across the industry
column227: with IDC estimating a 4% global contraction. In addition to the overall market slowdown
column228: we faced a very difficult compare to the year-ago quarter
column229: when we introduced a new MacBook Pro and a new iMac. Despite these challenges
column230: Mac continues to gain a high percentage of new customers
column231:
and our Mac installed base has grown to a new all-time high at the end of the June quarter. We ended the quarter below our four-week to five-week target range for Mac channel inventory.

"
column232:
"

Now turning to iPad
column233: revenue grew 7%. iPad ASP was $490 compared to $415 in the year-ago quarter
column234: with the increase driven by iPad Pro
column235: and we sold 10 million iPads compared to 10.9 million in the year-ago quarter. We also reduced channel inventory by about 500
column236:
000 units and exited the quarter within our five-week to seven-week target range.

"
column237:
"

In the segments of the tablet market where we compete
column238: we continue to be highly successful both in terms of market share and customer metrics. Recent data from NPD indicates that iPad gained share in the overall U.S. tablet market in the June quarter and has 84% share of tablets priced above $200. And in May
column239: 451 Research measured a 96% consumer satisfaction rate for iPad mini and a 95% rate for iPad Air. Among U.S. consumers planning to purchase a tablet within the next six months
column240: 63% plan to purchase an iPad
column241: almost four times the purchase intention rate of the next highest brand measured
column242:
with iPad Pro the top choice for planned purchases. Corporate buyers report a 94% satisfaction rate for iPad and a purchase intent of 71% for the September quarter.

"
column243:
"

One recent example of iPad business adoption is Sberbank
column244: Russia's largest bank
column245: which is adding 22
column246: 000 iPads to more than 10
column247:
000 purchased last year to deploy corporate mobility solutions across the organization and enable its consultants to serve customers in a more engaging and more efficient way.

"
column248:
"

More broadly
column249: we're making great progress with our enterprise initiatives and we see strong growth opportunities ahead of us. In May
column250: we announced a global strategic partnership with SAP to reimagine business processes with native iOS apps. SAP is the world's largest enterprise software provider
column251: with more than 130 million potential users among its 300
column252: 000 global customers. In fact
column253: it's estimated that 76% of global business transactions touch an SAP system. Our partnership will deliver an SDK to fast-track iOS projects for SAP environments
column254: an iOS academy to enable the 2.5 million SAP developers around the world to build great native iOS apps
column255:
and a portfolio of industry-specific apps to accelerate mobile transformation in the enterprise.

"
column256:
"

Last month
column257: we announced the first three solutions from our Cisco partnership
column258: two that will dramatically improve the network performance of iOS traffic running on Cisco networks
column259:
and one that will bring the desk phone to the 21st century by integrating iPhone Wi-Fi calling into Cisco Spark.

"
column260:
"

Let me now turn to our cash position. We ended the quarter with $231.5 billion in cash plus marketable securities
column261: a sequential decrease of $1.4 billion. $214.8 billion of this cash
column262: or 93% of the total
column263:
was outside the United States.

"
column264:
"

We issued a total $2.4 billion of debt in Taiwan and in Australia
column265: while retiring $2.5 billion in U.S. debt
column266: leaving us with $72 billion in term debt at the end of the quarter
column267:
essentially unchanged from last quarter.

"
column268:
"

We returned a total of over $13 billion to investors during the June quarter as follows. We paid $3.2 billion in dividends and equivalent. We spent $4 billion on repurchases of 41.2 million Apple shares through open-market transactions. And we launched a new $6 billion ASR
column269:
resulting in initial delivery and retirement of 48.2 million shares.

"
column270:
"

We also completed our sixth accelerated share repurchase program
column271: retiring an additional 8.7 million shares. We've now completed almost $177 billion of our current $250 billion capital return program
column272: including $127 billion in share repurchases. During the quarter
column273: we also spent $1 billion on a minority investment in Didi Chuxing in China
column274:
completed three acquisitions and incurred $4.2 billion in capital expenditures.

"
column275:
"

As we move ahead into the September quarter
column276: I'd like to review our outlook
column277: which includes the types of forward-looking information that Nancy referred to at the beginning of the call. We expect revenue to be between $45.5 billion and $47.5 billion. We expect gross margin to be between 37.5% and 38%. We expect OpEx to be between $6.050 billion and $6.150 billion. We expect OI&E to be about $350 million
column278:
and we expect the tax rate to be about 25.5%.

"
column279:
"

Also today
column280: our Board of Directors has declared a cash dividend of $0.57 per share of common stock
column281: payable on August 11
column282: 2016 to shareholders of record as of August 8
column284:
"

With that

I'd like to open the call to questions.

column405:

column413: when I look at foreign exchange

column588: that AR can be really great. And we have been and continue to invest a lot in this. We are high on AR for the long run. We think there are great things for customers and a great commercial opportunity. And so we're investing
column589:
and the number one thing is to make sure our products work well with other developers' products like Pok\u00e9mon. And so that's the reason why you see so many iPhones out in the wild right now chasing Pok\u00e9mons.

"
column590:
"

Gene Munster - Piper Jaffray & Co.

"
column591:
"

Would you say there's going to be a computing shift to AR longer term?

"
column592:
"

Timothy Donald Cook - Chief Executive Officer & Director

"
column593:
"

I notice there are people that want to call it a new computer platform
column594: and we'll see. I think there's a tendency in this industry to call everything new the next computer platform. However
column595: that said
column596: I think AR can be huge. So we'll see whether it's the next platform. But regardless
column597:
it will be huge.

"
column598:
"

Gene Munster - Piper Jaffray & Co.

"
column599:
"

Thank you.

column600:
"

Nancy Paxton - Senior Director
column602:
"

Thanks
column603: Gene. Can we have the next question
column604:
please?

column605:
"

Operator

column606:

We'll go to Mark Moskowitz with Barclays.

column607:
"

Mark Moskowitz - Barclays Capital
column608:
Inc.

"
column609:
"

Yes
column610: thank you. Good afternoon. I just want to follow up
column611: Tim
column612: if I could
column613: related to the R&D pace of growth
column614: clearly a lot of momentum there over the last couple years. But we're just trying to figure out how much of that is dedicated to existing products and services versus what's next? Can you give us a sense in terms of when investors should think about the ROI coming back to them from the R&D perspective? And a corollary to that
column615: is it really restricted just to products and services currently
column616:
or can we see more of a cloud services apparatus evolve over time where you do more and more in the enterprise just given the core trips with SAP and Cisco and IBM?

"
column617:
"

And then my follow-up for Luca is around ASPs for the iPhone. We keep getting a lot of questions around iPhone SE in terms of how cannibalistic could it be to the core iPhone franchise. Are you seeing any moderation in terms of the ASP pressures here?

"
column618:
"

Timothy Donald Cook - Chief Executive Officer & Director

"
column620: we do continue to invest significantly in R&D. The growth rates are still large on a year-over-year basis
column621: and Luca can share the exact ones. But I think the recent quarter was in the mid-20% for R&D. The balance of the company we're managing more flattish from a year-over-year point of view. The products that are in R&D
column622:
there is quite a bit of investment in there for products and services that are not currently shipping or derivations of what is currently shipping. And so I don't want to talk about the exact split of it. But you can look at the growth rate and conclude that there's a lot of stuff that we're doing beyond the current products.

"
column623:
"

Luca Maestri - Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President

"
column626: I talked about the $595 in Q3. It's down $65 on a year-over-year basis. Keep in mind
column627: about $20 of that $65 is foreign exchange. So during the quarter
column628: we had this combination of starting with no iPhone SE units in channel inventory
column629: so we had to do an at least a partial channel fill that obviously had an impact on ASPs. And then the other element was the fact that we've reduced more than 4 million units of channel inventory on the high end. So the combination of these two things obviously had an impact on ASPs. But I think as I said or Tim said during the prepared remarks
column630:
we do expect iPhone ASP to improve sequentially as we move into the September quarter because these two factors that I just mentioned are not going to repeat.

"
column632: of course we've got limited experience because the phone has been in the market just for a few weeks. But when we look at our survey data on iPhone SE
column634: we believe that the iPhone SE is doing exactly what it was intended
column635: which is we are seeing a higher rate of new to iPhone customers
column636: which is obviously very important to us because we bring new people into the iOS ecosystem. And we see a higher rate of previous iPhone owners that really prefer the four-inch form factor. We have not seen clear evidence of cannibalization from iPhone 6S or iPhone 6S Plus. Of course
column637:
there's always going to be some level of cannibalization. But really to us what is much more relevant is the much bigger opportunity to bring more people into the iOS ecosystem.

"
column638:
"

Nancy Paxton - Senior Director
column641: Mark. Could we have the next question
column646:
"

Kulbinder S. Garcha - Credit Suisse Securities (USA) LLC (Broker)

"
column648: just a couple questions for me. Luca
column649: I just want to clarify that last point on ASPs on iPhone because last quarter it seemed that you were quite clear that that was a negative driver to the gross margin of the company. So I understand there are other drivers going into the September quarter. But just to be clear
column650: the phone units you didn't sell through that were depleted in channel inventory
column651:
those are relatively high gross margin as well. That's the clarification.

"
column654: as Apple has spoken more and more loudly I guess in the last three or four quarters
column655: I just think about some of the comments you've made about the TV market and how it's been stuck I think in the 1960s and the 1970s and the experience hasn't changed. I understand you've got the Apple TV box out. But in terms of driving actual video-on-demand services
column656: is that something that Apple wants to do themselves? Do you want a partner? Could you even build content? How do you think about that as an actual business opportunity as opposed to here's an Apple box and we sell some units
column657:
but it's not that meaningful to the overall company in terms of size? I'm just curious given the installed base and users you have. Thanks.

"
column658:
"

Luca Maestri - Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President

"
column660: on your question on iPhone ASP
column661: I'm not sure if I understood it correctly. But clearly the iPhone SE has a downward impact on iPhone ASP
column663: because it comes at the low end of the range. From a gross margin perspective
column664: it is slightly dilutive to company margins
column665:
but the impact is not particularly large.

"
column666:
"

Kulbinder S. Garcha - Credit Suisse Securities (USA) LLC (Broker)

"
column669:
"

Timothy Donald Cook - Chief Executive Officer & Director

"
column670:
"

On the Apple TV question
column671: the introduction of Apple TV and tvOS last October and the subsequent OS releases and what's coming out this fall
column672:
think of that as building the foundation for what we believe can be a broader business over time. And so I don't want to be more precise than that. But you shouldn't look at what's there today and think we've done what we want to do. We've built a foundation that we can do something bigger off of.

"
column673:
"

Kulbinder S. Garcha - Credit Suisse Securities (USA) LLC (Broker)

"
column676:
"

Timothy Donald Cook - Chief Executive Officer & Director

"
column677:
"

Thank you for the question.

Good day everyone and welcome to this Apple
column26: Incorporated Fourth Quarter Fiscal Year 2016 Earnings Release Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded. At this time

column30:
ma'am.

"
column31:

Nancy Paxton - Apple
column33:
"

Thank you. Good afternoon and thanks to everyone for joining us. Speaking first today is Apple CEO Tim Cook
column34: and he will be followed by CFO Luca Maestri. And after that
column35:
we'll open the call to questions from analysts.

"
column36:
"

Please note that some of the information you'll hear during our discussion today will consist of forward-looking statements

and the Form 8-K filed with the SEC today along with the associated press release. Apple assumes no obligation to update any forward-looking statements or information which speak as of their respective dates.

column46:
"

I'd now like to turn the call over to Tim for introductory remarks.

"
column47:

Timothy Donald Cook - Apple
column48:
Inc.

"
column49:
"

Thanks
column50: Nancy. Good afternoon
column51: and thank you for joining us. We're in the middle of a very busy season for Apple
column52: and on Thursday of this week
column53:
we're holding another event here on the Apple campus. All of us are excited and we think our customers are going to love these latest innovations.

"
column54:
"

Our results for the September quarter were very strong. We generated $46.9 billion in revenue in the quarter
column55: toward the high end of our guidance range. Gross margin was 38%
column56: at the very top of our range. We sold 45.5 million iPhones
column57: reflecting continued improvement in year-over-year performance compared to the last two quarters
column58:
as we forecasted in January. iPhone sales were up year-over-year in 33 of our top 40 markets.

"
column59:
"

As you know
column60: iPhone customers are the most satisfied and loyal customers in the world
column61: and fiscal 2016 saw more customers switch from Android to iPhone than ever before. This is due to the superior customer experience we deliver with our products
column62:
and it's something no other company can match.

"
column63:
"

We had a record-setting quarter for Services
column64: with revenue growth accelerating to 24%
column65: reaching $6.3 billion. App Store revenue continued to skyrocket
column66: while Music revenue grew by 22% thanks to the growing popularity of Apple Music. In fact
column67:
J.D. Power recently announced that Apple Music enjoys the highest customer satisfaction rating in the streaming music market.

"
column68:
"

Earlier this month I visited Japan
column69: where Apple Pay went live yesterday. Japanese customers are already in the habit of making contactless payments where they commute
column70: dine and shop
column71: so we expect a strong response and rapid adoption of Apple Pay. Around the world
column72: we're seeing very strong growth in transaction volume through Apple Pay
column73:
which also launched in Russia and New Zealand this month and is coming to Spain in the next few months.

"
column74:
"

Apple Pay transactions were up nearly 500% year-on-year for the September quarter. In fact
column75: we completed more transactions in the month of September than we did across all of fiscal 2015. And with Apple Pay support now built into Safari
column76:
hundreds of thousands of websites are bringing Apple Pay to their customers. Our major partners tell us that Apple Pay shows the highest conversion rate of any digital wallet.

"
column77:
"

We remain very confident about the future of our Services business given the unmatched level of engagement
column78: satisfaction and loyalty of our growing installed base. We have almost doubled the size of our Services revenue in the last four years
column79: and as we've said before
column80:
we expect it to be the size of a Fortune 100 company in fiscal 2017.

"
column81:
"

As for our newest products
column82: we're thrilled with the customer response to iPhone 7 and iPhone 7 Plus. These are the best iPhones we've ever made
column83: with breakthrough camera systems
column84: immersive stereo speakers
column85: and the best iPhone performance in battery life ever
column86: thanks to the custom-designed Apple A10 Fusion chip. They feature the brightest
column87: most colorful iPhone displays to date and come in gorgeous new finishes. Demand continues to outstrip supply
column88:
but we're working very hard to get them into customers' hands as quickly as possible.

"
column89:
"

We're also off to a great start with Apple Watch Series 2
column90: the next generation of the world's most popular smartwatch
column91: packed with new features including built-in GPS
column92: water resistance
column93: a dramatically brighter display and a powerful dual-core processor. Individuals and businesses alike are recognizing the potential of Apple Watch to help people stay healthy
column94: motivated and connected. One recent example is Aetna
column95: which has announced a new initiative to revolutionize its members' health experience by subsidizing Apple Watch for individual customers and select large employers. In addition
column96: Aetna is also providing Apple Watch to nearly 50
column97:
000 of its own employees to encourage them to live a healthier day.

"
column98:
"

We've just rolled out new versions of iOS
column99: macOS and watchOS and customers are loving the many great new features including Siri on the Mac
column100: enhanced health and fitness capabilities for Apple Watch and a delightful new way to experience your photos on iOS with a feature we call memories. We've made massive advances in messages
column101: making them more expressive and fun than ever with powerful animations
column102: invisible ink and handwritten notes. We're seeing great offerings from developers in the all new App Store for Messages
column103:
and there has been a marked increase in our monthly active users.

"
column104:
"

One of the great new features of iOS 10 is the Home app
column105: which is making home automation easy to set up and intuitive to use. Customers can easily set up and securely control all their HomeKit accessories
column106: from lights and cameras to the garage doors and air conditioners
column107: all from their favorite iOS devices. We expect over 100 HomeKit-compatible products to be on the market by the end of this year
column108:
all reviewed and approved by Apple to help ensure customer security when using them. Our Apple stores are wonderful places to discover and learn about these great products for the connected home.

"
column109:
"

With our latest operating systems
column110: machine learning is making our products and services smarter
column111: more intuitive and even more personal. We've been using these technologies for years to create better user experiences
column112: and we've also been investing heavily both through R&D and acquisitions. Today
column113: machine learning drives improvements in countless features across our products. It enables the proactive features in iOS 10
column114:
which offers suggestions on which app you might want to use or which context you might want to include in an email. Our camera and photo software uses advanced face recognition to help you take better pictures and object and scene recognition to make them easier to sort and find. Machine learning makes the fitness features of Apple Watch more accurate and even helps extend battery life across our products.

"
column115:
"

Machine learning continually helps Siri get even smarter in areas such as understanding natural language. We've extended Siri to work in many new ways by opening it to developers and most recently by making Siri available to Mac users in Mac OS Sierra. We're already seeing great momentum in just the first few weeks from developers leveraging the Siri and speech APIs and we're very happy with the engagement it's driving with Siri.

"
column116:
"

Looking ahead
column117: we're seeing some very exciting developments in India. Reliance Jio is rolling out a a first of its kind all-IP network in India with 4G coverage in 18
column118: 000 cities and 200
column119: 000 villages across the country. They're offering a free year of service to purchasers of new iPhones and we're partnering with them to ensure great iPhone performance on their network. Our iPhone sales in India were up over 50% in fiscal 2016 compared to the prior year
column120:
and we believe we're just beginning to scratch the surface of this large and growing market opportunity.

"
column121:
"

We're also very happy with the progress of our enterprise market initiatives
column122: which continue to expand. Just last month
column123: we announced a partnership with Deloitte to help companies quickly and easily transform the way they work by maximizing the power
column124: ease of use
column125: and security of the iOS platform. Deloitte is creating a unique Apple practice with over 5
column126: 000 strategic advisors focused on helping businesses transform work in functions across the enterprise. We're also collaborating on the development of Enterprise Next
column127:
a new Deloitte consulting service designed to help clients across more than 20 industries take full advantage of the iOS ecosystem and quickly develop custom solutions through rapid prototyping.

"
column128:
"

As we close the books on another incredible year
column129: I'd like to thank our talented employees for their hard work and passion for making the best products in the world
column130: our amazing developer community for their relentless creativity and our wonderful customers
column131:
business partners and shareholders for their loyalty and support.

"
column132:
"

Now I'll hand it over to Luca to share more details on the September quarter.

"
column133:
"

Luca Maestri - Apple
column134:
Inc.

"
column135:
"

Thank you
column136: Tim. Good afternoon
column137: everyone. Revenue for the September quarter was $46.9 billion
column138: towards the high end of our guidance range. Our revenue grew very strongly in many emerging markets
column139: including Russia
column140: Turkey
column141: the Middle East
column142: Thailand and Vietnam
column143:
and we continue to see solid growth in Japan and in Latin America.

"
column144:
"

Gross margin was 38%
column145: at the top of our guidance range
column146: thanks to favorable cost performance. Operating margin was 25.1% of revenue and net income was $9 billion. Diluted earnings per share were $1.67 and cash flow from operations was $16.1 billion
column147: which is a new record for the September quarter. For details by product
column148: I will start with iPhone. We sold 45.5 million iPhones in the quarter
column149: thanks to the very successful launch of iPhone 7 and iPhone 7 Plus and continued strong demand for other iPhones. Including 2.7 million iPhones that were in transit at the end of the quarter
column150: we increased iPhone channel inventory by 2.5 million units
column151:
and we exited the quarter well below our five to seven week target range of channel inventory.

"
column152:
"

We experienced strong iPhone growth in many markets around the world
column153: including Canada
column154: Latin America
column155: Western Europe
column156: Central and Eastern Europe
column157: the Middle East
column158: India and South Asia. iPhone sales in Greater China declined during the quarter
column159: but the initial customer response to iPhone 7 and 7 Plus gives us confidence that our December quarter performance in China will be significantly better on a year-over-year basis than our September quarter results
column160:
even as we lap the all-time record period from a year ago.

"
column161:
"

Worldwide demand for iPhone 7 and 7 Plus has significantly outpaced supply
column162: particularly on iPhone 7 Plus
column163:
and we're working very hard to get the new iPhones into the hands of our customers as quickly as possible.

"
column164:
"

iPhone ASP increased to $619 in the September quarter
column165:
which was above our expectations. That's up from $595 in the June quarter when we launched iPhone SE and we had a significant channel inventory reduction. We expect iPhone ASP to increase markedly on a sequential basis to a level similar to our ASP in the December quarter last year.

"
column166:
"

Customer interest and satisfaction with iPhone remains extremely strong. In the U.S. for instance
column167: the latest survey fielded by 451 Research found that among consumers planning to purchase a smartphone within 90 days
column168: 65% plan to purchase iPhone
column169: with the current iPhone owners reporting a 97% customer satisfaction rating. Among corporate smartphone buyers
column170: the latest survey measured a 95% iPhone customer satisfaction rating and found that of those planning to purchase smartphones in the December quarter
column171:
79% planned to purchase iPhone.

"
column172:
"

Turning to Services
column173: we generated an all-time record $6.3 billion in revenue with an increase of 24% over a year ago. The App Store growth rate has now accelerated for five consecutive quarters
column174: reaching 43% in the September quarter. The App Store remains the preferred destination for both customers and developers. According to App Annie
column175: it generated 100% more global revenue than Google Play in the September quarter. In addition to the great performance from apps
column176: we saw strong double-digit revenue growth in several other service categories and Apple Pay transaction volume has grown dramatically
column177:
as Tim mentioned.

"
column178:
"

Next I'd like to talk about the Mac. We sold 4.9 million Macs
column179: facing a difficult year-over-year compare
column180: given the launch of new Macs in the spring of 2015. Despite this
column181:
our Mac installed base reached a new all-time high at the end of the September quarter and we'll have some exciting news to share with current and future Mac owners very soon. We ended the quarter below our four to five week target range for Mac channel inventory.

"
column182:
"

Turning to iPad
column183: revenue was flat compared to last year. iPad ASP was $459
column184: $26 higher than a year ago
column185: with increase driven by the new iPad Pro line. We sold 9.3 million iPads
column186: and we reduced channel inventory by about 80
column187: 000 units
column188:
exiting the quarter below our five to seven-week target range.

"
column189:
"

We continue to be highly successful both in terms of market share and customer metrics in the segments of the tablet market where we compete. Recent data from NPD indicates that iPad gained share in the U.S. tablet market in the September quarter and had 82% share of tablets priced above $200. And in August
column190: 451 Research measured a 96% consumer satisfaction rate for iPad mini
column192: and a 93% rate for iPad Pro. Among U.S. consumers planning to purchase a tablet within the next six months
column193: 73% plan to purchase an iPad
column194: more than eight times the purchase intention rate of the next highest brand measured
column195:
with iPad Pro once again the top choice for planned purchases. Corporate buyers reported a 94% satisfaction rate for iPad and a purchase intent of 68% for the December quarter.

"
column196:
"

In the enterprise market
column197: we are seeing some great examples of iPad and Mac deployment. Our Mobility Partner Program continues to grow stronger
column198: with over 120 partners around the world offering tailored solutions to businesses of all sizes. Revel Systems
column199: a leading iPad point-of-sale solution partner
column200: recently announced a global agreement with Shell retail to implement Revel's iPad based POS system services at 34
column201: 000 Shell locations worldwide
column202:
including support for Apple Pay in countries where Apple Pay is available.

"
column203:
"

IBM has just released new data on the great results of its Mac rollout. With more employees choosing Mac than ever before
column204: there are now more than 90
column205: 000 Macs across the organization in addition to 48
column206: 000 iPads and 81
column207: 000 iPhones. IBM reports that PCs have three times the cost to manage
column208: drive twice the number of support calls and are 5 times more likely to require a follow-up appointment to resolve an issue than Macs. Thanks to much lower support cost and significantly higher residual value
column209:
the company is saving as much as $535 per computer when comparing the total cost of Mac ownership to a PC over a full-year lifecycle.

"
column210:
"

Let me now turn to our cash position. We ended the quarter with $237.6 billion in cash plus marketable securities
column211: a sequential increase of $6.1 billion. $216 billion of this cash or 91% of the total was outside the United States. We issued $7 billion of debt in July
column212:
leaving us with $79 billion in term debt at the end of the quarter.

"
column213:
"

We returned over $9 billion to investors during the September quarter as follows. We paid $3.1 billion in dividends and equivalents. We spent $3 billion on repurchases of 28.6 million Apple shares through open market transactions
column214: and we launched a new $3 billion ASR
column215: resulting in initial delivery and retirement of 22.5 million shares. We also completed our seventh accelerated share repurchase program
column216: with adding an additional 12.3 million shares. So total buyback activity during the quarter reduced our share count by 1.5%. We have now completed $186 billion of our current $250 billion capital return program
column217:
including $133 billion in share repurchases.

"
column218:
"

During the September quarter
column219: we also completed four acquisitions and incurred $3.6 billion in capital expenditures. Our total CapEx for the year was $12.8 billion. Our effective tax rate for the quarter was 26%
column220:
slightly higher than the 25.5% we guided to because of a differential graphic mix of earnings relative to our regional expectations. Our tax rate for the full fiscal year was 25.6%

"
column221:
"

As we move ahead into the December quarter
column222: I would like to review our outlook
column223: which includes the types of forward-looking information that Nancy referred to at the beginning of the call. We expect revenue to be between $76 billion and $78 billion. This represents a return to growth over the all-time revenue record set in the December quarter a year ago. We expect gross margin to be between 38% and 38.5%. We expect OpEx to be between $6.9 billion and $7 billion. We expect OI&E to be about $400 million
column224:
and we expect the tax rate to be about 26%.

"
column225:
"

Also today
column226: our Board of Directors has declared a cash dividend of $0.57 per share of common stock
column227: payable on November 10
column229: to shareholders of record as of November 7
column231:
"

With that
column232:
I would like to open the call to questions.

"
column233:
"

Nancy Paxton - Apple
column234:
Inc.

"
column235:
"

And we ask that you limit yourself to one one-part question and one follow up. May we have the first question
column236:
please?

"
column237:
"

Question-and-Answer Session

"
column239:
"

First we'll hear from Gene Munster with Piper Jaffray.

"
column240:
"

Eugene Charles Munster - Piper Jaffray & Co.

"
column241:
"

Hey
column242: good afternoon and congratulations. And Tim
column243: now that we're a month in the iPhone 7
column244: are you seeing anything measurable in terms of the growing trend of annual upgrades? And second is
column245: historically in terms of new product categories
column246: you guys have always looked for unique advantage before getting into a segment. And I'm curious about the car. There are a lot of rumors out there
column247:
and would like your perspective on how you think about an advantage that Apple could add in the auto space?

"
column248:
"

Timothy Donald Cook - Apple
column249:
Inc.

"
column250:
"

In terms of iPhone 7
column252: the carriers that had upgrade plans
column253: the information that we have from them is that demand is very robust. But from a worldwide point of view

column342: we had a surge of upgraders that came into the market for the iPhone 6 or iPhone 6 Plus
column343: and the upgrade rate increased relatively more in Greater China than elsewhere around the world. And so when that upgrade rate in fiscal year 2016 returned to a more normal upgrade rate
column344: which would be akin to what we saw with the iPhone 5S as a point
column345:
it had further to fall. And so that's the main reason in our view that you see a difference.

column349: which really the main one is really the first one and the second one was a symptom of it

We continue to invest in marketing and advertising. At the same time
column616:
we want to continue to be efficient and lean. It's something that we've done very well over the years and want to continue to do that.

"
column617:
"

So what you've seen
column619: you've seen investments in R&D growing at 25% and then our SG&A expenses to be about flat. And this is kind of the approach that we want to take and continue to take going forward. If you step back for a second and you look at our implied guidance for the December quarter
column620: we got an expense to revenue ratio of 9%. This is extremely competitive in our industry and I would say in general. And so we want to continue to have this balance
column621:
make the right investments and remain efficient.

"
column622:
"

James D. Suva - Citigroup Global Markets
column625: and congratulations and thanks for the details
column630: Jim. Can we have the next question
column633:
"

We'll go to Rod Hall with JPMorgan.

"
column634:
"

Rod B. Hall - JPMorgan Securities LLC

"
column637: guys. Thanks for the question. I had one for Luca and then a follow-up for Tim. So
column639: I wanted to ask about the gross margin guidance. I think that the Street and we were expecting something a little bit higher. And again
column640: that's about 50 basis points lower and the Street it was I think 70 basis points lower. And I'm just curious
column641:
do you think that people are mis-modeling that or is there something going on with pricing or mix there that you could provide us more color on? So that's my first question.

"
column646: let me give you some detail both on a sequential basis and I'll give you also something on a year-over-year basis because maybe that's where the disconnect comes from
column647: looking at the last year's gross margins in the December quarter. On a sequential basis
column648: we are essentially guiding to some improvement in gross margins. We had 38% both in the June quarter and in the September quarter. We're guiding slightly higher for the December quarter because on the positive
column649:
we're going to have of course better leverage and the mix in the December quarter tends to be better. But we need to keep into account the fact that these positives are going to be partially offset by the cost structures of the new products that we are launching now and we've launched already a few during the September quarter and that will have an impact on our December quarter results.

"
column651: keep in mind that last year we did
column657: but there's a couple of things that I think need to be considered before doing a year-over-year compare. And it's the fact that last year we had this award for a patent infringement of $548 million. That is
column659: is 40 bps. And then we've got the FX situation
column662: 70 bps. And so you're left with less than 100 basis points deterioration on a year-over-year basis where again
column663:
we have the reality of new cost structures into our products.

"
column665: very important I think for investors to understand that what's happened during the last two years. During the last two years
column666: the U.S. dollar has appreciated by 15% over the basket of currencies where we do business. And we're a company that generates two thirds of our revenues outside the United States
column667: 15% appreciation of the U.S. dollar. So on a year-over-year basis
column668: just 2016 over 2015 was 340 bps impact from foreign exchange. This is something that we have offset almost entirely through a number of initiatives going from pricing actions to cost initiatives to our hedging program
column670: the strong dollar becomes the new normal and we need to work with that. And I think over the years
column671:
we made very good trade-offs and our gross margins have been quite stable over time.

"
column672:
"

Rod B. Hall - JPMorgan Securities LLC

"
column676: I wanted you to ask you
column677: this question comes up once in a while
column678: but I just wanted to ask you if you could talk to us a little bit about the arguments on both sides of the dividend question. I mean
column679: Apple seems to be perpetually undervalued. It's a very large company. It's getting harder and harder to grow. Your payout ratio is significantly below the S&P 500. I know you can't tell us what your intentions are here
column680: but if you could help us understand how that thinking around the dividend works
column682:
"

Timothy Donald Cook - Apple
column684:
"

We review the capital return annually
column685: and we've established a cadence now to announce our thinking on that every April. And so we have a robust discussion around the dividend and the buyback. We very much believe that Apple is very undervalued
column686: and so we're investing with confidence in the company that we know really well. And so that thinking has I think proven out over time and I think been very good for our shareholders. And in addition to that
column687: we know that some shareholders really like a dividend and some ongoing income
column688:
and so we've provided a amount that we think is a good amount and have a good track record of raising it annually. And so we'll be able to say more on that I'm sure in April of next year.

"
column693:
"

Rod B. Hall - JPMorgan Securities LLC
