column23: everyone
column24: and welcome to this Apple Incorporated first quarter fiscal year 2017 earnings release conference call. Today's call is being recorded. At this time for opening remarks and introductions
column25: I would like to turn the call over to Nancy Paxton
column26: Senior Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead
column28:
"

Nancy Paxton - Apple
column30:
"

Thank you. Good afternoon and thanks to everyone for joining us today. Speaking first is Apple CEO Tim Cook
column31: and he'll be followed by CFO Luca Maestri. And after that
column32:
we will open the call to questions from analysts.

"
column33:
"

Please note that some of the information you'll hear during our discussion today will consist of forward-looking statements
column34: including without limitation those regarding revenue
column38: taxes
column39: and future business outlook. Actual results or trends could differ materially from our forecast. For more information
column40: please refer to the risk factors discussed in Apple's Form 10-K for 2016 and the Form 8-K filed with the SEC today along with the associated press release. Apple assumes no obligation to update any forward-looking statements or information
column41:
which speak as of their respective dates.

"
column42:
"

I'd now like to turn the call over to Tim for introductory remarks.

"
column46: Nancy
column47: and good afternoon everyone
column48: and thanks very much for joining us. I'm very happy to share with you the outstanding results of Apple's December quarter. We generated the highest quarterly revenue in Apple's history along with all-time unit and revenue records for iPhone and Apple Watch
column49: all-time revenue records for Services and Mac
column50:
and all-time revenue records for four out of our five geographic segments. The strong performance of our business also produced all-time record earnings per share.

"
column51:
"

Revenue in the quarter was $78.4 billion
column52: which was above the top of our guidance range. iPhone had a tremendous quarter thanks to exceptional demand that beat our own internal expectations. While iPhone 7 is our most popular model
column53: we saw especially strong demand for iPhone 7 Plus
column54: which was a higher portion of the new product mix than we've ever seen with Plus models in the past. Demand for iPhone 7 Plus exceeded supply throughout the quarter
column55:
and we came into supply/demand balance in January.

"
column56:
"

iPhone 7 Plus has earned rave reviews for its advanced new features
column57: especially the dual camera system
column58: which produces stunning portraits and high-quality zoom. This is a uniquely Apple feature that is surprising and delighting our users. Both iPhone 7 and iPhone 7 Plus are empowering our customers to be more productive
column59: more engaged
column60: and more expressive than ever by integrating hardware
column61: software
column62:
and services to create experiences that only Apple can deliver.

"
column63:
"

It was our best quarter ever for Services
column64: with almost $7.2 billion in revenue. App Store customers broke all-time records during the holiday quarter
column65: including $3 billion in purchases in December alone
column66:
making it the App Store's single best month ever.

"
column67:
"

Our innovative and vibrant developer community has created over 2.2 million apps for doing almost anything that you can imagine. Apple's developer community has now earned over $60 billion
column68:
including over $20 billion in 2016 alone.

"
column69:
"

Revenue from our music business grew for the third quarter in a row
column70:
and our AppleCare and iPlus storage services had all-time record results.

"
column71:
"

Apple Pay continued its strong momentum
column72: with the number of users more than tripling over the past year and hundreds of millions of transactions and billions of dollars in purchases in the December quarter alone. Transaction volume was up over 500% year over year as we expanded to four new countries
column73: including Japan
column74: Russia
column75: New Zealand
column76: and Spain
column77: bringing us into a total of 13 markets. Apple Pay on the Web is delivering our partners great results. Nearly 2 million small businesses are accepting invoice payments with Apply Pay through Intuit QuickBooks Online
column78: FreshBooks
column79: and other billing partners. And beginning this quarter
column80:
Comcast customers can pay their monthly bill in a single touch with Apple Pay.

"
column81:
"

Services are becoming a larger part of our business
column82: and we expect the revenues to be the size of a Fortune 100 company this year. Our Services offerings are now driving over 150 million paid customer subscriptions. This includes our own services and third-party content that we offer on our stores. We feel great about this momentum
column83:
and our goal is to double the size of our Services business in the next four years.

"
column84:
"

The Mac not only returned to growth but generated its highest quarterly revenue ever. Our latest data shows that most Mac customers are buying their first Mac
column85:
with the vast majority of them coming from a Windows PC.

"
column86:
"

The new MacBook Touch with Touch Bar is an outstanding example of the innovation made possible by integrating world-class hardware and software. We were supply constrained for the new MacBook Pro throughout the December quarter and are just now coming into supply/demand balance.

"
column87:
"

It was also our best quarter ever for Apple Watch
column88: both units and revenues
column89: with holiday demand so strong that we couldn't make enough. Apple Watch is the best-selling smartwatch in the world and also the most loved
column90: with the highest customer satisfaction in its category by a wide margin. Apple Watch is the ultimate device for a healthy life
column91:
and it is the gold standard for smartwatches. We couldn't be more excited about Apple Watch.

"
column92:
"

We're also thrilled with the response to AirPods. Customers love the magical experience AirPods are delivering. And if you haven't tried them yet
column93: you'll be delighted when you do. They're far ahead of anything else on the market today
column94:
and we're working hard to catch up with the incredible demand.

"
column95:
"

With AirPods off to a fantastic start
column96: a strong full first year for Apple Watch
column97: and Beats headphones offering a great wireless experience using the Apple-designed W1 chip
column98: we now have a rich lineup of wearable products. Their design
column99: elegance
column100:
and ease of use make us very excited about the huge growth potential for wearables going forward.

"
column101:
"

Our ecosystem is broadening to more and more of the areas where people spend their time
column102: at the gym
column103: on the go
column104: in the home
column105: and on the job. For example
column106: every major automaker is committed to supporting CarPlay with over 200 different models announced
column107: including five of the top 10 selling models in the United States. There are well over 1 million people using CarPlay now
column108:
and this continues to grow rapidly.

"
column109:
"

And we are leading the industry by being the first to integrate home automation into a major platform with iOS 10. With Siri and a new Home app in iOS 10
column110: everywhere you go
column111: you can easily and securely control all of your home accessories with your iPhone
column112: iPad
column113:
or your Apple Watch.

"
column114:
"

The number of HomeKit-compatible accessories continues to grow rapidly
column115: with many exciting solutions announced just this month
column116: including video cameras
column117: motion detectors
column118: and sensors for doors
column119: windows
column120: and even water leaks. Perhaps even more importantly
column121: we are unmatched when it comes to securing your home with HomeKit-enabled door locks
column122: garage doors
column123:
and alarm systems.

"
column124:
"

I'm personally using HomeKit accessories and the Home app to integrate iOS into my home routine. Now when I say good morning to Siri
column125: my house lights come on and my coffee starts brewing. When I go to the living room to relax in the evening
column126: I use Siri to adjust the lighting and turn on the fireplace. And when I leave the house
column127: a simple tap on my iPhone turns the lights off
column128: adjusts the thermostat down
column129: and locks the doors. When I return to my house in the evening
column130: as I near my home
column131: the house prepares itself for my arrival automatically by using a simple geofence. This level of home automation was unimaginable just a few years ago
column132:
and it's here today with iOS and HomeKit.

"
column133:
"

We're making great progress in the enterprise market alongside our major partners. The combination of iOS and Cisco technology is giving companies everywhere the opportunity to vastly improve the user experience for their mobile employees. With enhanced networking performance
column134: up to eight times faster roaming
column135: better reliability for apps
column136: and native voice experience
column137: we're excited about how much more productive the workforce will be with these great capabilities. In fact
column138:
the total number of joint customer opportunities has grown over 70% since last quarter.

"
column139:
"

Enterprises are using IBM's new Mobile at Scale design and development model to deploy multiple iOS apps with speed and efficiency. For example
column140: Finnair is transforming aircraft maintenance
column141: and CEMEX is revamping activities from attracting new clients to invoicing to after-sales support. And later this spring
column142: SAP will be rolling out its SDK for iOS
column143:
providing its community of more than 2.5 million developers the tools to build powerful native iOS apps that leverage the SAP HANA cloud platform. We're delighted with how these partnerships are making it even easier for enterprise customers to transform how work gets done with iOS.

"
column144:
"

As we reflect on a record-breaking December quarter
column145: I'd like to thank our developers
column146: our business partners
column147: and our employees for their incredible contributions and commitment. And I'd like to thank all of our customers around the world for their excitement and loyalty
column148:
which ultimately drive these results.

"
column149:
"

Now I'd like to turn it over to Luca to talk about the quarter in more detail.

"
column150:
"

Luca Maestri - Apple
column151:
Inc.

"
column152:
"

Thank you
column153: Tim. Good afternoon everyone. Revenue for the December quarter was $78.4 billion
column154: the highest quarterly revenue in the history of Apple and above our guidance range. As Tim mentioned
column155: the strength of our results was very broad-based
column156: as we set new revenue records for iPhone
column157: for Services
column158: for Mac
column159: and for Apple Watch. We also established new all-time revenue records in most developed and emerging markets
column160: with strong growth rates in many countries
column161: including the U.S.
column162: Japan
column163: Canada
column164: France
column165: Australia
column166: Brazil
column167: India
column168: Turkey
column169:
and Russia.

"
column170:
"

We accomplished all this despite a very challenging foreign exchange environment due to the continued strength of the U.S. dollar. As we had expected
column171: our year-over-year performance in Greater China improved significantly relative to the September quarter. Total Greater China segment revenue was down 12%
column172: but revenue from Mainland China was even with the all-time record results from a year ago and grew in constant currency terms. In all other geographic segments
column173:
we generated all-time quarterly record results.

"
column174:
"

We had the benefit of a 14th week during the quarter this year
column175: but this was offset by four factors. First
column176: this year we grew China inventory significantly less than a year ago. Second
column177: iPhone 7 launched earlier in the September quarter compared to the iPhone 6s launch the previous year
column178: creating a more difficult comparison for the December quarter this year. Third
column179: the stronger U.S. dollar affected total revenue growth this year by 100 basis points. And fourth
column180: our year-ago revenue included the benefit of a one-off $548 million patent infringement payment. Also
column181:
strong customer interest left us in supply/demand imbalance for several of our products throughout the quarter this year.

"
column182:
"

Gross margin was 38.5%
column183: at the high end of our guidance range. Operating margin was 29.8% of revenue
column184: and net income was $17.9 billion. Diluted earnings per share were $3.36
column185: a new all-time record
column186:
and cash flow from operations was $27.1 billion.

"
column187:
"

We had a terrific quarter for iPhone as we sold 78.3 million units
column188: a new all-time record and an increase of 5% over last year. Customer demand was even higher than our reported results
column189:
as iPhone unit sell-through was up 8%.

"
column190:
"

We saw double-digit iPhone growth in the U.S.
column192: Western Europe
column193: Japan
column194: and Australia
column195: and even stronger growth in many emerging markets
column196: including Brazil
column197: Turkey
column198: Russia
column199: Central and Eastern Europe
column200: and Vietnam. iPhone ASP increased to $695 in the December quarter from $619 in the September quarter
column201:
driven by the very strong product mix and the amazing success of iPhone 7 Plus.

"
column202:
"

Despite stronger demand than last year
column203: we added only 1.2 million units of iPhone channel inventory across the quarter
column204:
significantly less than the increase of 3.3 million units a year ago. And we exited the quarter near the low end of our 5 to 7-week target channel inventory range.

"
column205:
"

Customer interest and satisfaction with iPhone are exceptional
column206: not only with consumers
column207: but also with business users. In the U.S.
column208: for instance
column209: the latest data from 451 Research on consumers indicates a 97% customer satisfaction rating among all iPhone owners and a 99% satisfaction rating for owners of iPhone 7 Plus. Among corporate smartphone buyers
column210: the iPhone customer satisfaction rating was 94%. And of those planning to purchase smartphones in the March quarter
column211:
78% plan to purchase an iPhone.

"
column212:
"

Turning to Services
column213: we generated an all-time record $7.2 billion in revenue
column214: an increase of 18% year over year. Our run rate growth was actually higher when taking into account two discrete items. On one hand
column215: the 14th week added to Services revenue this December quarter. On the other hand
column216:
that benefit was more than offset by the comparison to the one-off $548 million patent infringement payment included in Services revenue a year ago.

"
column217:
"

The App Store continued its impressive run
column218: breaking all previous revenue records. Year-over-year App Store revenue growth was 43% through the first 13 weeks of the quarter. It's great to see that both average revenue per paying account and the number of paying accounts grew strongly during the quarter. And according to App Annie's latest report
column219: App Store revenue continues to outpace the industry overall
column220:
with more than double the revenue of Google Play in calendar 2016.

"
column221:
"

Next I would like to talk about the Mac. We sold 5.4 million Macs and generated our highest-ever quarterly Mac revenue. We were very happy to report double-digit unit growth in several countries
column222: including Japan
column223: Mainland China
column224: India
column225: the Netherlands
column226: and Sweden
column227:
as well as in the U.S. education market. We ended the quarter at the low end of our 4 to 5-week target range for Mac channel inventory.

"
column228:
"

Turning to iPad
column229: we sold 13.1 million units
column230: which was ahead of our expectations. And we posted double-digit growth in both Mainland China and India
column231: as we've expanded distribution channels in those countries and we continue to attract a very high percentage of first-time tablet buyers. We also reduced channel inventory by about 700
column232: 000 units as opposed to an increase of 900
column233: 000 units last year
column234:
and we exited the quarter near the low end of our five to seven-week target range.

"
column235:
"

iPad is incredibly successful in the segments of the tablet market where we compete
column236: both in terms of market share and customer metrics. Recent data from NPD indicates that iPad had 85% share of the U.S. market for tablets priced above $200. And in November
column237: 451 Research measured a 94% consumer satisfaction rate for iPad Mini
column239:
and 96% for iPad Pro.

"
column240:
"

Among U.S. consumers planning to purchase a tablet within the next six months
column241: purchase intention for iPad is more than four times higher than any other brand measured
column242: with iPad Pro once again the top choice for planned purchases. Corporate buyers reported a 96% satisfaction rate and a purchase intent of 66% for the March quarter. In fact
column243: businesses of all sizes are choosing iPad and iPhone to have them reimagine their everyday activities. We're seeing strong momentum in sectors such as retail
column244: where iOS solutions are being deployed for everything from product development to logistics to mobile point-of-sale. Companies like Toys \"R\" Us
column245: Coach
column246:
and Kate Spade are using iOS and our mobility partner solutions to dramatically transform their customer and employee experiences.

"
column247:
"

Our retail stores experienced strong double-digit growth in visitors and revenue in the December quarter. And we continued to expand our global presence
column248: with plans to open our first store in Singapore and our second store in Dubai soon. We are continually updating our stores and adding new and exciting outreach programs to educate kids on our products
column249: entertain the community with fresh live music
column250: teach future Swift developers to code
column252: grow
column253:
and evolve their businesses.

"
column254:
"

Let me now turn to our cash position. We ended the quarter with $246.1 billion in cash plus marketable securities
column255:
a sequential increase of $8.5 billion. $230.2 billion of this cash or 94% of the total was outside the United States. We also had $77.1 billion in term debt and $10.5 billion in commercial paper outstanding at quarter end.

"
column256:
"

We returned almost $15 billion to investors during a very busy December quarter for our capital return activities. We paid $3.1 billion in dividends and equivalents. We spent $5 billion on repurchases of 44.3 million Apple shares through open market transactions. And we launched a new $6 billion ASR
column257: resulting in an initial delivery and retirement of 44.8 million shares. We also completed our eighth accelerated share repurchase program
column258:
retiring an additional 4.4 million shares. This led to a net diluted share count reduction of 65.3 million shares during the quarter.

"
column259:
"

We've now completed $201 billion of our current $250 billion capital return program
column260:
including $144 billion in share repurchases. And we plan to provide investors with our annual update on the capital return program in the spring.

"
column261:
"

Our effective tax rate for the quarter was 26%
column262:
as expected.

"
column263:
"

And as we move ahead into the March quarter
column264: I'd like to review our outlook
column265: which includes the types of forward-looking information that Nancy referred to at the beginning of the call. We expect revenue to be between $51.5 billion and $53.5 billion. This guidance range includes a $1.2 billion year-over-year headwind from foreign exchange. We expect gross margin to be between 38% and 39%. This guidance range includes an 80 basis points sequential headwind from foreign exchange. We expect OpEx to be between $6.5 billion and $6.6 billion. We expect OI&E to be about $400 million
column266:
and we expect the tax rate to be about 26%.

"
column267:
"

Also today
column268: our Board of Directors has declared a cash dividend up $0.57 per share of common stock
column269: payable on February 16
column270: 2017 to shareholders of record as of February 13
column272:
"

With that
column273:
I'd like to open the call to questions.

"
column274:
"

Nancy Paxton - Apple
column275:
Inc.

"
column276:
"

And we ask that you limit yourself to one one-part question and one follow-up. Operator
column277: may we have the first question
column278:
please?

"
column279:
"

Question-and-Answer Session

"
column280:
"

Operator

"
column281:
"

Your first question will come from Katy Huberty with Morgan Stanley.

"
column282:
"

Kathryn Lynn Huberty - Morgan Stanley & Co. LLC

"
column284: thank you. First
column285: Luca
column286: what are the factors that caused you to widen the gross margin guidance for the March quarter? And what are the one or two factors that put you at the low end versus the tailwinds that might put you at the high end of that range? And then I have a follow-up
column287:
thank you.

"
column288:
"

Luca Maestri - Apple
column289:
Inc.

"
column290:
"

Sure
column291: Katy. If you look back at our history
column292: 100 basis points range for gross margin is not unusual. Clearly during a period when foreign exchange is very volatile
column293: we think it's more prudent to broaden the range a bit. I've mentioned that we expect \u2013 assuming that rates don't move too much
column294: we expect foreign exchange to be a major negative as we move from the December to the March quarter. You know that the dollar has appreciated significantly toward the end of the December quarter
column295: and so we've got 80 basis points of sequential headwind from foreign exchange. We also have the sequential loss of leverage
column296: which is typical of our seasonality
column297: but we expect to offset these two impacts with cost efficiencies and also with our mix of products and services. So obviously if the dollar is a little less strong than it is today
column298: we could do a bit better on gross margins. Obviously
column299: we continue to work very hard on our cost efficiency
column300:
so we'll see where we land.

"
column301:
"

Kathryn Lynn Huberty - Morgan Stanley & Co. LLC

"
column302:
"

Thank you. And
column303: Tim
column304:
there's a reasonable probability that you may get access to the $200 billion-plus of cash that's been locked overseas. So I think it would be helpful to just get an update on your views around potentially larger M&A and some of the areas of interest that you've noted in the past like owning more original content to penetrate more of the TV opportunity that the company has long talked about addressing. Thank you.

"
column305:
"

Timothy Donald Cook - Apple
column307:
"

Katy
column308: I am optimistic given what I'm hearing that there would likely be some sort of tax reform this year
column309: and it does seem like there are people in both parties that would favor repatriation as a part of that. So I think that's very good for the country and good for Apple. What we would do with it
column310: let's wait and see exactly what it is. But as I said before
column311: we are always looking at acquisitions. We acquired 15 to 20 companies per year for the last four years. And we look for companies of all sizes
column312:
and there's not a size that we would not do based on just the size of it. It's more about the strategic value of it.

column602: I have a question for you. Back in April 2012
column603: you said on one of these earnings calls that I've always hated litigation and I continue to hate it
column604: and I highly prefer to settle versus battle. Yet you recently decided to initiate a lawsuit against Qualcomm. I'm wondering if you can comment on the ostensible change or departure from this viewpoint
column605: and what would be a successful end result of this litigation
column606:
and whether you can confirm whether there's any potential gross margin risk in the future as a result of this litigation.

"
column607:
"

Timothy Donald Cook - Apple
column608:
Inc.

"
column609:
"

I feel the same way I did in April of 2012. I don't like litigation and view it as a last resort. And so you should take from our filing that we viewed it as we didn't see another way forward. They were insisting on charging royalties for technologies that they had nothing to do with. And so we were in a situation where the more we innovated with unique features like Touch ID or advanced displays or cameras
column610: just to name a few
column611:
the more money Qualcomm would collect for no reason and the more expensive it would be therefore for us to innovate.

"
column612:
"

And so it's somewhat like buying a sofa
column613: and you charge somebody a different price depending upon the price of the house that it goes into. Just from our point of view
column614: this doesn't make sense
column615: and we don't believe it will pass muster in the courts. In addition to that
column616: as a part of their increasingly radical steps they were taking to try to hold up that model
column617:
they withheld $1 billion in payments that they owed us. And so we felt like we had no choice was the net of it.

"
column618:
"

In terms of where it goes
column619: we'll see. I don't like litigation. And so if there's another way
column621: but at this point I don't see it. I fully expect at this point in time that it will take some time
column622:
but in the end I think common sense will prevail and the courts will see it for what it is. And so that's the way I see it. Thanks for your question.
